If you want to see the best things Stockholm can offer you, you must visit the Vadstena Abbey (a Catholic Monastery of the XIV century), the Stockholm City Museum, the Royal Palace, the Nobel Museum, the largest art gallery in Sweden, the National Museum and the Bergian Garden.

Gothenburg

Gothenburg is Sweden's second-largest city and the largest industrial center. The name of the town translates, literally, as "the fortress of the Goths". It dates back to the early XVII century and was simultaneously built as a port and a defensive outpost against the Danish invasion. Gothenburg is known as the "Mecca" of the canoe and kayak lovers. It is home to the largest amusement park on the Scandinavian peninsula. The cruises on the 240-kilometer canal, which connects the lake network with the bay and boat trips to the coastal islands, are very popular among travelers. 

Malmö

Malmö is the third-largest city in Sweden, located in the south of the country, and connected to Denmark by the Øresund Bridge. Until 1658, Malmö was owned by Denmark. The Malmö Castle testifies to the Danish period in its history. Once, it served as a defensive structure and a prison at the same time. Nowadays, there are several fascinating museums in the castle. Malmö is remarkable for its Gothic architecture, numerous squares, boulevards, and parks. The Royal Park is probably the most attractive of the latter. And Malmö is also a very musical city. Musicians perform in squares and on improvised platforms. Here you can even the displays of the artists. 

Swedish Lapland

Swedish Lapland deserves special attention among tourists in Sweden. It is a part of the country inhabited by the indigenous Sami people of the North. Lapland is a region of untouched and primordial nature. Here you can admire the northern lights and the sun at night. If you visit north Sweden, you should definitely visit Abisko National Park, which will amaze you with its virgin northern nature and stunning arctic scenery. There are many waterfalls and majestic fjords. The unspoiled natural environment is home to moose, deer, wolves, and white foxes. You can go dog sledding and fishing in the park. In settlement of Abisko, the royal trail begins with a total length of 425 km. It is the longest hiking trail in Sweden. The route attracts skiers, cyclists, and hikers. 

Ski infrastructure in Sweden includes 113 slopes and 84 ski lifts. 

Swedish Sälen

Swedish Sälen is considered to be the largest ski region in Scandinavia. It stretches for 30 km and consists of four resorts: Stöten, Tandådalen/Hundfjället, Lindvallen/Högfjället, Kläppen. The skiing season in Sweden starts in the middle of November and lasts until the end of April, while the resort of Riksgränsen is open from February to June.

Gotland

Sweden is surrounded by a large number of islands — flat and rocky, populated, and uninhabited. The island of Gotland is the largest of them. Hisingen occupies the leading position by the number of inhabitants, where over 147 thousand people live.

Many islands are used as "country villages," and Swedes go there on weekends by boats. There are also popular resorts on Sweden's islands. For example, the island of Sandön is suitable for recreation with children: there are beautiful windless beaches with clean sandy shores. When you go to the windy coasts of Skåne, Tylösand, or Halland islands, you can enjoy windsurfing.

description.en: Abkhazia is a partially recognized state in the Transcaucasus, bordering Russia and Georgia. Sokhumi is the capital of Abkhazia. The country attracts even the most sophisticated travelers with its nature — giant mountains covered with centuries-old trees, impetuous waterfalls and rivers, clear lakes, and, of course, the Black Sea. Tens of thousands of tourists annually enjoy the clean sea and bright sun at sea resorts (Gagra, Pitsunda, Gadaut, New Athos). You can see the smallest river in the world and the deepest caves on Earth in Abkhazia. Ancient Caucasian customs are still honored here. Local residents will never let a guest go hungry and without drinking domestic wine. Abkhazian dolmens (burial structures) are even older than the Egyptian pyramids. The country can also boast of its Great Wall, 160 km long.

Albania is a country of indigenous culture spread over the Mediterranean coast. Here you can admire mountain castles, incredible beauties of nature, laze on the beaches and learn a lot about the history and traditions of the "country of eagles". The eagle is the national symbol of Albania. Ancient fortresses, majestic mosques, and churches, bunkers from the time of Enver Hoxha stand next to modern buildings, hotels, and restaurants. A trip to Albania is suitable for travelers with different income levels; the country is actively developing tourism.

geography.en: Albania is located in Southeast Europe, has access to the Adriatic and Ionian Seas, and borders on Greece, Northern Macedonia, Montenegro, Serbia, and Kosovo. The relief of the country is mountainous with many lakes and rivers. Albania shares with Northern Macedonia Lake Ohrid, the oldest and deepest lake in the Balkan Peninsula. The highest point of the country is Mount Korab (2764 m). Albania is a parliamentary republic, formally headed by the president. Administratively, the country is divided into twelve regions. There are 61 municipalities in these regions, each of which consists of communes.

long_description.en:
Tirana

Tirana is the capital and the largest city in Albania. There are not many sights in it, but they are compactly located — in the center of the town, around Skanderbeg Square, named after the national hero of Albania (he is also called Gjergj Kastrioti). Nearby there is a statue of the famous Mother Teresa. Around the square, there are buildings in different architectural styles. We recommend you visiting Efem Bey Mosque, the Orthodox Resurrection Cathedral, the clock tower, the Historical and Archaeological Museum. They offer excellent collections of exhibits. The Mausoleum of Enver Hoxha and his own bunker, from which the museum was made today, is one of the symbols of a bygone era. You can also look at the Congress building, walk through the Grand Park of Tirana, and the city streets, admire the famous colorful houses of the locals. By the way, in the south of the city, there is a large artificial lake, near which you can have a picnic or sit in a cafe. The key attraction is the national park on Mount Dajti (Dajtit). You can get here by cable car, which is 4.5 km long. The panoramic views will pleasantly surprise you!

Durrës

The second-largest city in the country, Durrës, is located on the Adriatic coast, just 38 km west of Tirana. It was founded by the Greeks, during the colonization of the Mediterranean coast. The main sights are the Archaeological Museum, the Venetian Tower, the huge Roman Amphitheatre, the Mosaic Museum, the Fatih Mosque, the Palace of the First President and King Ahmet I. Durrës is also a major port and resort — it has excellent beaches, and hotels and restaurants on the coast meet European standards! By the way, if your trip is not limited only to Albania, there is a ferry connection with the Italian cities of Trieste and Ancona, as well as the Slovenian town of Koper. 

Shkodër

Shkodër is the oldest Albanian city, located in the north of the country, near the junction of the Drin and Buna rivers. The best place to admire the scenery is from the main attraction — Rozafa Castle. Walk through stone ruins and look out from its observation towers. From here, you can see the picturesque scenery, the city itself, and the famous lead mosque on the palm of your hand. The entrance is paid, and there is also a Museum of the Castle, which you can visit for an extra fee. Lake Skadar or Lake Shkodër is the second renowned attraction. It is the largest fresh lake on the Balkan Peninsula. Make sure you check out the views from the coast, walk in the forests and take a boat tour of its water surface! Shkodër is distinguished by the fact that it is a Catholic city (the majority of the population is Muslim); at the same time, many other religious buildings are belonging to different confessions.

Vlorë

The first capital of independent Albania also deserves your attention. We are talking about the large port city of Vlorë. It is located in the southwest, 147 kilometers from Tirana. Its main attractions are the Muradiye Mosque, the Historical and Ethnographic Museum, and the Museum of Independence. Lovers of antiquities should visit the Porto Palermo Castle and the ancient amphitheater Orikum (I century B.C.). Here you can have a great rest on the beach, and also take a cruise to the island of Sazan (located across from Vlora).

Sarandë

Another port city in Albania, Sarandë, is located in the south of the country, close to the Greek island resort of Corfu, where the ferry goes. It is also called the "Southern Gate" of Albania. Sandy beaches and favorable climate (about 300 sunny days per year) attract resort recreation lovers. And those wishing to explore the antiquities can visit the Butrint National Park, not far from Saranda (has the UNESCO World Heritage status), look at the ruins of the ancient city of Phoenike, with a huge Acropolis and Jewish synagogues. Be sure to take a picture at Blue Eye, a natural spring, 16 kilometers northeast of Sarandë.

Gjirokastër

The famous Albanian museum city of Gjirokastër, located in the south of the country, is on the road between Tirana and Sarandë in the Drin Valley. The town is known as an example of perfectly preserved medieval architecture of the Ottoman Empire. In 2005, it was included in the UNESCO World Heritage list. The city itself is small, with narrow streets, so it is better to explore it on foot. The main sights are the fortress of the XII century and the Museum of Arms. The city has a lot of cafes and souvenir shops. We recommend you buying something as a souvenir, and also have a look at the bazaar in the Old Town. By the way, vegetables and fruits in Albania are quite cheap.

description.en: The small country of Andorra is famous for its ski resorts, sunny weather, thermal springs, picturesque nature, and a tax-free zone throughout the country. There is a place for both a noisy holiday with friends and a quiet family vacation. And lovers of culture and tradition will definitely find something to explore in Andorra's historical sites and museums.

geography.en: Andorra is a European microstate. However, it is the largest among the smallest. And the full name sounds majestic — the Principality of the Valleys of Andorra. The country is located in the south of the Eastern Pyrenees, and its main part is located at an altitude of over 1000 meters above sea level. It borders France to the north and Spain to the south. In fact, Andorra is a basin surrounded by mountain peaks. The highest point is the peak of Coma Pedrosa (2943 m). The proximity of the Mediterranean slightly softens the harshness of the mountain climate, so Andorra is considered to be one of the sunniest countries.Administratively, it is divided into seven parishes (Parroc), and those, in turn, consist of quarters (quarts).

long_description.en:
Andorra la Vella

If you come to Andorra, you should definitely visit its capital, Andorra la Vella. This most alpine European capital stands on the Gran Valira River. The city is small and, in fact, is a big shopping center. So, go shopping. The city's malls and boutiques offer a wide range of international brands, which can be purchased here at a much lower price. In the capital, it is also worth seeing the church called Església de Sant Esteve (XI-XII century), visit the medieval fortress Casa de la Vall with its chapel, and the museum of philatelists. In the evening, you can relax in a cozy cafe or restaurant. One of the famous architectural sights of Andorra that you should definitely see is the Pont de la Margineda of the XII century. It has a great view, and engineers are still wondering about the mystery of its amazing stability. You need to go to the village of Santa Coloma, which is located in the vicinity of the capital, to see this miracle.

Encamp

The town of Encamp is located 7 km from the capital, in the ski area of Grandvalira. It is very easy to get to the popular slopes Pas de la Casa and Grau Roig on the Funicamp cable car. During high season, there is a free bus to the ski lift, and a special small train runs from the city to the ski area. By the way, with the help of this lift, you can also get to the slopes from Escaldes. Encamp has many sports complexes, saunas, cafes, and shops for the most sophisticated tourists. Historical attractions include the Church Of Sant Roma De Les Bons and ancient houses. Take the cable car up to Lake Engolasters (1616 meters), which offers stunning views of the Encamp Valley.

Ordino

For those who love cultural recreation, we recommend going to the northern town of Ordino. There are no ski slopes here, and the nearest ones are in the Vallnord zone (Arcalís – Ordino Slopes). But Ordino is known as the historical and cultural center of Andorra. Here, in addition to historical buildings in the Romanesque style, there is a unique Museum of Miniature with works of the famous Nikolai Syadristy, Casa d'Areny-Plandolit house-museum (XVII-XIX centuries), the Museum of the Post Office and an unusual for Catholic Europe Museum of Orthodox iconography of St. George. Not far from Ordino, there is the village of La Cortinada, which has a Museum of Nature of Andorra, as well as a mill and sawmill with working mechanisms of the XVII-XVIII centuries. We recommend to visit the trails of the Sorteny Valley reserves, to admire the picturesque nature, to get acquainted with flora and fauna of Andorra.

Escaldes

The town of Escaldes is famous for its thermal springs of Caldea, which are rich in sodium and other useful minerals. Their water is used both for medicinal purposes and in various water attractions. Be sure to visit the Perfume Museum and learn everything about the world of scents. You can also visit a cultural center for contemporary art with a collection of handicraft items.

description.en: The Republic of Belarus is a blue-eyed state in the very center of Europe. There are so many parks and reserves that the country has been deservedly nicknamed the "lungs of Europe. The post-Soviet traditions and European values are mixed up here. They love to cook potatoes and "party" in underground pubs. Here, they admire modern art and develop World of Tanks, Viber, and Flo.

geography.en: The Republic of Belarus is located in the central part of Eastern Europe. The territory of the state borders with Lithuania, Latvia, Russia, Ukraine, and Poland. The country has no access to the sea, but there are many rivers (over 20 thousand), lakes (about 11 thousand), and forests (about 2/5 of the territory). About 8% of the national territory of Belarus is protected by the state — four national parks and two reserves, as well as a large number of reserves of national and local importance. Belarus is divided into six regions: Minsk, Mogilev, Grodno, Brest, Vitebsk, and Gomel. Each of them bears the name of the main city of the region. The capital of the republic, Minsk, has the status of a city of republican subordination.

long_description.en:
Minsk

Minsk is the capital of Belarus. Tourists usually do not expect anything promising from this city, and it's better for them, to tell the truth. Because Minsk is really able to surprise: Stalin's Empire of the City of the Sun and the Cathedral of Saint Virgin Mary in the Wileński Baroque style, neo-Gothic lines of the Church of Saints Simon and Helena, and classical plays, creative art hubs and old quarters, impressive new buildings and, like a cherry on a cake, a huge glass rhombicuboctahedron of the National Library of Belarus. You will feel the unique atmosphere of the city as soon as you take a couple of steps through the Gates of Minsk, and you won't even notice how the charm of the capital captures you.

Gomel

Minsk is beautiful, but like any other capital city, it is fast, thundering, and fussy. How much better is Gomel, the town above the Sozh! Unhurried walks through the green squares, the old Sovetskaya Street, sometimes taking you to secret courtyards with authentic establishments, colorful sunsets, which lovers see off from the middle of the longest pedestrian bridge in the country — this is about Gomel. Make sure you visit the main attraction of the city — the Rumyantsev-Paskevich Residence, known for its chic architectural and park complex. 

Brest

Behind Białowieża Forest, on the very border of Belarus and Poland, there is Brest, a city with a rich history. The walls of the famous Brest Fortress have become the venue of many important historical events. Today, you can hear the bells of cathedrals, the songs of street musicians, the noise from the open areas of trendy bars, and the hum of passers-by, who wander aimlessly through the ancient cobbled streets behind the high fortification. Brest is charming in detail, even as a cute torchbearer lights city lights on Sovetsky Avenue every evening. It is a perfect place for a quiet, measured weekend. 

Mogilev

Mogilev, a modest city with metropolitan ambitions, is situated on the wide rapids of the Dnieper. Here, every street remembers the epochs of the greats — Alexander Pushkin was watering passers-by with champagne from the windows of the College of Culture at the present Komsomolskaya Street; Feodor Chaliapin was performing opera on the stage of the Drama Theatre; the great Vera Komissarzhevskaya was resting in the park after the performances; and who knows, maybe Nicholas II once sat on that very bench? Mogilev is charming, but you won't have time to get bored: take a ride on catamarans along the Dubrovenka or on a bicycle through the thick pine groves of the Pechersk Lake Park, walk along the ancient streets, and make sure you go to the festival of soap bubbles and potato pancakes.

Grodno

Grodno is the cultural capital of Belarus, the second capital of the Belarusian People's Republic, and the third capital of Rzeczpospolita. This city is a completely different Belarus, where Poles and Lithuanians feel like home, while locals are more often in Europe than in Minsk. Cobblestone paved Sovetskaya Street, Museum of Iron, eclectic interiors of the Old and New Castles, St. Francis Xavier Cathedral, Lutheran Church, Castle Hill — there's plenty to see in Grodno. And we have not yet listed theatres, private and public museums, and creative spaces, where the cultural elite of the city organize meetings. 

Vitebsk

But if you don't have enough culture in Grodno, go to Vitebsk, the small capital of the Renaissance. Chagall and Zadkine were born here, Malevich gave lectures, and Repin sipped tea from a plate on the summer veranda of the estate. People come here for a quiet bohemian rest, leisurely stroll along its well-groomed streets, and admire the picturesque views of the Western Dvina and Vićba rivers. We recommend visiting the Holy Assumption Cathedral, Vitebsk Town Hall, the Marc Chagall Museum, walk along the pedestrian Suvorov Street and, of course, buy a ticket to the famous festival of culture Slavic Bazaar, which is held every year in July.

description.en: Belgium is the unspoken capital of Europe. That's the place where the European Parliament and European Commission sits, and the General Headquarters of NATO is located. It's a kingdom of bustling market squares, a diversity of canals, mysterious Medieval castles, bell towers and sharp-spired houses, enigmatical stalactitic caves, comfortable Spa resorts, picturesque beaches on the North Sea, marvelous chocolate, mind-blowing Belgian waffles, and renowned beer. The brewing culture of Belgium was included in the UNESCO Lists of Intangible Cultural Heritage. Everything here is filled with the spirit of history and nobility. It's a wonderful place for cycling, walking, and recreational holidays by the seaside.

geography.en: The Kingdom of Belgium is a country in Western Europe. It neighbors on France, Germany, the Netherlands, and Luxembourg. It is washed by the North Sea in the North-West. There are plenty of full-flowing and overland rivers. The Meuse and Scheldt rivers are the two largest among them. Belgium is divided into three geographical regions: the coastal plain, the central plateau, and the Ardennes uplands. On the administrative level, the country is divided into the Flemish, Walloon, Brussels-Capital regions.

long_description.en:
Belgium is one of the countries in the Low Countries which incredible cities attract millions of tourists every year. Every city of the Kingdom has its peculiar character, image, and temper. The interesting history, renowned architectural monuments, a wonderful cuisine shall be your loyal fellow travelers on the tour around Belgium.

Brussels

This city creates a feeling of magic and unreality at first sight. This is a wonderful capital of Belgium, Brussels. It is located on the banks of the River Senne and manages to combine modern buildings and monuments in the Gothic style, castles, cathedrals, and bell towers. The city was mentioned for the first time in 966. The Dukes of Burgundy, Philip the Good, and Charles V. The production of articles of luxury and jewelry was flourishing in Brussels. After the Willebroek Canal between the city and the port of Antwerp had been built, Brussels became one of the most attractive and richest cities in the Flemish Region. Today, it has a large port, two international airports, and three railway stations. Brussels is a beautiful and atmospheric city with a diversity of cafes and restaurants. They offer delicious coffee with renowned waffles with chocolate, escargots and one of the best sorts of beer in the world. It would be interesting for many people to attend a meeting of the European Parliament and see how they pass the laws of the European Union. Brussels is filled with architectural masterpieces: the Grand Place or Grote Markt (a central city square), the City Hall, the King’s House or the Bread Hall, the Palace of Justice, and Brussels Stock Exchange. The Atomium is a monument created for the World’s Fair in 1958. Tourists love this place! 

Antwerp

Antwerp is the second in size and the largest seaside city in Belgium. It stands on the banks of the river Schelde and the North Sea. It’s one of the largest seaports in the world and the second one in size in Europe. A convenient location had been providing Antwerp with the status of the richest town in Northern Europe for a long time. The best diamond’s faceting masters work here. Numerous attractions, museums, and exhibitions tell about the centuries-old fascinating history of Belgium and Antwerp. We recommend you to start your tour with the Antwerp Central Station which is recognized as one of the most beautiful railway stations in the world. Then, head to the Queen Astrid Square renowned for the gallery of jewelry stores. The Het Steen, City Hall, the Cathedral of Our Lady, Museum aan de Stroom which roof is an observation deck - that’s only one ounce of the fascinating places in the city. The oldest zoo in Europe is also situated in Antwerp. It is over 170 years old! Around 770 species of rare animals live here. Some well-preserved pavilions were built in the previous century. The Chocolate Line of Dominique Persoone is the place every person with a sweet tooth must attend! Peter Paul Rubens and Anthony van Dyck — the renowned artists of their time — used to live and create their masterpieces in Antwerp. This city proudly occupies the place of the important educational and cultural center of Europe. 

Bruges

Bruges is a charming city in West Flanders. After the Hollywood movie, everyone dreams to come here for at least one day. The city has plenty of picturesque narrow canals running between the colorful facades of the houses decorated with plants. Bruges is often called the Northern Venice due to its beautiful canals which often let in sea-going vessels. There are 54 bridges in Bruges; 12 of them are moveable. Architectural monuments, Medieval towers or tower bells, cathedrals or figures of saints can be seen at every corner of this city. The Church of Our Lady deserves special attention. Inside, you can see the worldwide known marble statue of “Madonna and Child” by Michelangelo. You have to see the city from the water and from the height to have a full picture. So, don’t hesitate to enjoy a ship tour along its numerous canals. The Belfort Tower which was erected back in 1240 and is 83 meters in height will offer a wonderful view.

Ghent

A cozy town of Ghent is located 50 km away from Brussels. The capital of East Flanders is situated at the confluence of the Leie and Scheldt rivers. It had been the second in size city in Europe after Paris from 1000 to 1550. A wide range of historical attractions, palaces, parks, and cathedrals managed to survive till nowadays. The most popular and frequently visited places in the city include the Medieval Gravensteen Castle, City Hall, Het Belfort van Gent and its observation deck, Masons' Guild Hall, Saint Bavo Cathedral, St. Michael's Bridge. We highly recommend you to visit Patershol quarter, Graslei and Korenlei Streets, located on the embankment of the Leie river famous for its Flemish architectural style. 

Leuven

Another charming town of Belgium is located on the picturesque banks of the river Dyle. Wonderful Leuven is famous for the oldest Catholic university in Belgium and beer of the tradename Stella Artois. It has been produced here from the XV century. The production of beer is promoted to the rank of science in Belgium. There is even a department at the university called “The Academy of Brewing”. The city offers a wide range of fascinating architectural monuments such as the square of Grote Markt, Sint-Geertruikerk and Sint-Kwintenskerk Churches. The Leuven Town Hall is built in the late Brabantine Gothic style with three tiers of sculptures of famous people. It’s one of the most impressive buildings in the city and country in general. When you enter the Spanish quarter with well-preserved Medieval buildings made of red bricks, you dive into the atmosphere of the XVII century. In the evening, you should definitely visit the longest bar square in Europe called the Ode Markt.

description.en: Bulgaria is an amazing country that combines everything that a modern tourist loves: the cleanest beaches of the Black Sea, marked with the "Blue Flag", ski slopes of varying complexity, and a huge number of mineral springs. And there are so many objects protected by UNESCO that Bulgaria is on the 3rd place in Europe after Greece and Italy.

geography.en: Bulgaria is located in the north-east of the Balkan Peninsula. It borders with Romania, Turkey, Greece, Macedonia, and Serbia. The Black Sea washes a part of its territory. The relief of Bulgaria is very diverse and colorful. Plains and lowlands prevail, there is the Rila-Rhodope massif in the west. The highest point, Musala mountain, reaches 2925 meters. The country is also rich in lakes and sandy beaches. Bulgaria ranks second in the world by the number of mineral springs.

long_description.en:
The cities of Bulgaria are unique. Their main feature is that they are similar to the majority of other European places at the same time, but have their own special Balkan character.

Sofia

Sofia is the capital of Bulgaria and one of the oldest cities in Europe. It survived the reign of Greeks, Romans, and Ottomans, which influenced the architectural appearance of the streets and an incredible number of religious buildings. There is the oldest temple in Bulgaria, the Amphitheatre of Serdica (III-IV centuries AD), and the Square of the Roman Arena, which is slightly smaller than the Colosseum. The amazing contrast between antiquity and modernity makes this place interesting to explore. There are the XIII century frescoes, the IV century Roman rotunda, and the X century Turkish décor. The popular ski resort Vitosha Ski AD neighbors with historical and ancient buildings. You can get to its closest lift by public transport.

Plovdiv

Plovdiv, Bulgaria's second-largest city, is located in the south of the country. Even ancient Greek writers praised the picturesque nature of this region. Its coat of arms is decorated with the inscription "Ancient and Eternal". There are preserved monuments of architecture of ancient times and the era of Turkish rule. In 2019, the city was recognized as the cultural capital of Europe. One of the most amazing sights of Plovdiv is the ruins of the Roman theatre (the II century BC) and the ancient stadium (the II century AD). Today, the ruins have been restored, and exhibitions and concerts are held on the stage of the theatre. There are many churches, temples, and mosques in the town: the Dervish Monastery of Mevlevi Hane, as well as the Monastery of St. Peter and St. Paul, is the highest situated monasteries in Bulgaria. Its height is 1650 m. The monastery is the highest in Bulgaria. Not far from Plovdiv, there is the town of Banya and the famous resort of Karlovo Mineral Baths. Apart from relaxing in the pools with mineral water, tourists can enjoy the picturesque nature of the area. 

Varna

Varna is the sea capital of Bulgaria, situated on the coast of the Black Sea. Despite hundreds of thousands of tourists, the city has not lost its historical charm. It is here that the cleanest sea resorts are located: Golden Sands and Saints Constantine and Helena, marked with the "Blue Flag". In addition, there are amazing sights. A striking example of antiquity is the Roman Thermae of 7000 square meters, which were built back in the II century. Behind the city, there are no less interesting places: the Kamchia Biosphere Reserve, where rare species of birds and fish live, and the Stone Forest valley, where 3-meter columns of stone still amaze even scientists. Varna awaits adventurers as well as fans of family beach holidays. 

Burgas

Burgas is located in the center of the southern part of the Black Sea coast. A couple of years ago, the city was awarded the status of "the most comfortable city for life". It has been successfully keeping it to this day. It is a large industrial center with its own oil derricks and interesting tourist destinations. The sea surrounds Burgas, so many sights are connected with water: the ruins of the fortress Rusokastro, Roman ruins of ancient Deultum, as well as the Sea Park and Lake Atanasovsko. St. Anastasia Island deserves special attention. It fully belongs to the Orthodox Church and attracts pilgrims and tourists from all over the world. 

Sozopol

Sozopol, which was once the oldest Greek settlement and fishing village, today has become one of the most famous Bulgarian resorts. In 610 BC, the colony of Apollonia Pontica was located here, which greatly influenced the local architecture. The Old Town, a historical reserve with rocky cliffs and fantastic sea views, offers a closer look at history. Here, in the open air, there are the XVIII-XIX centuries Bulgarian Renaissance-style buildings: House of Marietta Stefanova, Thracian Tavern, Church of St. George, a wooden well of the VI-III centuries BC, and a water supply system of the V century BC. The culture of all nations that have ever lived on the territory of modern Bulgaria is concentrated in Sozopol.

Nessebar

The city of 40 churches, the oldest of all towns in the Balkans — that's what one can say about Nessebar. It is located on a cape washed by the Black Sea. The Greeks founded Nessebar in the V century BC on the site of an old Thracian settlement. The genuine charm of the past has been preserved here: medieval churches of Slavic and Greek culture, wooden buildings of the XIX century, and cobbled streets. Most of the city's churches are under UNESCO's protection. The interesting ensembles include the churches of Saint Paraskevi (the XIII-XIV centuries), Saint Sofia (Old Metropolis, the V century), Saint John the Baptist, the Holy Archangels Michael and Gabriel, and the Church of Christ Pantocrator. All these amazing buildings will be interesting to connoisseurs of the authentic architecture of the past. Modern entertainment includes Aqua Paradise water park with 40 unique locations for children and adults, bars, and nightclubs. 

Bansko

Bansko is one of the winter resorts located in the Pirin National Park. It gained wide popularity not so long ago, so there are no crowds willing to conquer the slopes even during the high season. Such ski resorts as Borovets — the oldest and most prestigious one with a lot of red slopes —, as well as Pamporovo — an ideal place for beginners skiers — are no less interesting.

description.en: Bosnia and Herzegovina is an amazing country that has managed to survive the civil war and preserve its historical and natural values. It is a genuine crossroads of cultures, with mosques peacefully neighboring Orthodox churches and Catholic cathedrals. In the winding medieval streets of ancient cities, life seems to have been frozen many centuries ago, and close by, modern quarters are pulsating with energy. The no less splendid snowy peaks rise above the beautiful green valleys, and incredible blue lakes hide between them. The unique Perućica rainforest surrounds the highest peaks, and the beautiful Skakavac Waterfall hides here as well. Locals are in no hurry, do not plan anything in advance, and love tourists. They are happy in the here and now and are always ready to teach this wisdom to fussy travelers.

Hungary is a very beautiful and contrastive country. It is known primarily for its thermal springs and popular balneological resorts. The Hungarians themselves say that if you just stick a stick deep into the ground, you will get another healing spring from the hole. It is believed that this is the country where matches, a Rubik's Cube, and a ballpoint pen were invented. Hungary has an incredibly complex language with 25 cases, but the Hungarians are very proud of it. The number of tourists is increasing from year to year. Wonderful nature, architecture, SPA resorts, wineries — there are all conditions to spend time with interest.

geography.en: Hungary is located in Central Europe. It is neighboring Slovakia to the north, Ukraine to the northeast, Romania to the east, Serbia to the south, and Austria to the west. The majority of the territory is flatland. Hungary, from north to south, is crossed by the Danube River, which is 410 km long. Besides, Hungary is famous for its Lake Balaton (592 square meters), which the Hungarians themselves call "our sea", although its median depth is only 3 meters. The whole country is divided into 20 administrative-territorial units, 19 of which are megye (counties) and the city of republican submission (Budapest), which is equivalent to megye.

long_description.en:
Budapest

Most tourists, when going to new countries, start their acquaintance with the capital. And that's the right way! After all, the main city of any country is its cultural center. Budapest is no exception. The first thing you need to see is the parliament building, located on the bank of the Danube and built in the Neo-Gothic style. Its height is 96 meters, and it is one of the highest historical buildings in the capital. One should also take a walk along Andrássy Avenue, which is included in the UNESCO World Heritage List. There are many ancient buildings, the Opera House and museums. A landmark from the category of "the most significant ones" is the Liberty Bridge or Chain Bridge. Built in the XIX century, it connected two parts of the city — Buda and Pest. You should definitely take a walk along the Danube embankment and visit the Buda Castle, the residence of the Hungarian kings. It is a whole city within the city. It can take half a day to get to know it, but it is worth visiting. Many people go to Budapest to visit the largest bathing complex in Europe, the Széchenyi Thermal Bath. There are fifteen indoor and three outdoor pools with healing thermal waters, so you can not only enjoy the culture and art but also heal.

Debrecen

The second most populated city in the country is Debrecen. You can start your walk from the central square and see the Reformed Great Church. This building was constructed in the style of neoclassicism at the beginning of the XIX century, has two towers with clocks, which notify the time several times a day. For those interested in ethnography, you can visit the Deri Museum, while lovers of modern art should visit the Modem Centre. Hortobágy National Park, a UNESCO World Heritage Site, is 40 km from Debrecen. It is home to more than 300 species of birds, and every June, it hosts the Horse Festival, which attracts not only horse lovers and fans of horseback riding, but also many tourists. With children, you can go to the Nagyerdei Park, where you can enjoy rides and visit the zoo.

Eger

Eger is a small ancient town, famous for its thermal springs. It is located 140 km from Budapest. Besides the balneological resort, the town attracts with its unique architecture of different centuries and styles and the ability to make unique sorts of wines. The most famous is the Egri Bikaver, a blended red wine, which is aged for two years and stored only in bottles. After your SPA vacation, you should head to Egervár, a fortress erected in the XIII century. Here you will find the Dobo Istvan Museum, the most popular one in Hungary.

Pécs

Those who prefer a quiet holiday should go to Pécs, a quiet city that managed to avoid the devastating effects of war. The symbol of the town is the XVI century Mosque of Pasha Qasim. At different times, both Muslim and Christian religious services were held in the building. Today it houses the parish church for Catholics of Belváros. You can also visit Sts. Peter and Paul's Cathedral Basilica. The famous Hungarian composer Franz Liszt played the organ in this cathedral.

Hévíz

Hévíz is a small town with the largest thermal lake in Europe. The life in the baths is boiling almost all year round — the temperature of the water does not drop below +23 C. Not far from Hévíz, there is a small town of Keszthely where you can find the Festetics Palace, a bright example of Baroque architecture.

Győr

You can continue your acquaintance with Hungary by going to Győr, a city that is often called a "water town" because it is located on the banks of the Raba River. It's nice just to go fishing or to be alone with nature. The Gothic Hédervári Chapel, a beautiful building with a priceless golden bust of Ladislaus I, occupies a special place among the sights. There is also an icon of the crying Virgin Mary. While walking around the historic city center, visit the Golden Eagle Pharmacy Museum. Jesuit monks created it in the 50s of the XVII century.

Szeged

A popular destination for tourists is Szeged, a sunny city located in southern Hungary. If you want to learn about modern art and features of Hungarian folklore, you should visit the Móra Ferenc Museum. On your way, you'll see the Szeged Synagogue, which will amaze you with its Art Nouveau style and majestic stained-glass windows. One of the city's most interesting attractions is the Pick Salami and Szeged Paprika Museum. Here you can learn about the secrets of growing paprika, which came to Hungary during the Turkish invasion. The seasoning was so delicious to the Hungarians that they learned how to grow the best varieties of paprika.

description.en: Gibraltar is a British Overseas Territory that is disputed by Spain. It is an unusual place, which you could have only visited with a British visa until recently. A Schengen entry permit is now enough for that. Gibraltar is a huge rock, around which all life is concentrated. It is both a nature reserve and a large port and a giant observation deck. Although the area is not vast, there's plenty to see, do, and wonder about.

Thousand-year-old glaciers cover Greenland. They hold back the whole island, but slowly, year after year, they melt. As a result, huge ice edges slide into the ocean and break down with a rumble — this is how a new iceberg is born. On the island, they are the height of a fifteen-story house and up to 40 km in length. Northern harsh beauty is charming, has its own charm, especially when you are not used to it. There are no trees in Greenland at all. The deserted, cold landscape is diluted with colorful wooden houses. Funny, birdhouse-like, they are raised on piles above the ground, thus escaping winter snow drifts. The island's miniature towns are like toys. The magical transformation of the ice kingdom takes place in summer when Greenland turns into a blooming and fragrant island — floral bright with a piercing blue sky.

long_description.en:
• The tourist needs to have enough of the local currency. You should take care of that even on the Big Land - exchange the money for Danish krone. In Greenland, the currency exchange rate is very low, and the exchange is only possible in the bank offices of major cities. There are enough ATMs in all towns and cities, as most locals get paid with a bank card.
  • Souvenirs from whale mustache, walrus bone, and walrus tusks can only be taken off the island with a special permit from tourist offices or specialized shops. Otherwise, you can't avoid problems at customs.
  • When planning a visit to Greenland, you should bring sunscreen and glasses as the sun reflects off the snow and blinds your eyes and burns your skin.
  • In summer, clouds of mosquitoes annoy tourists and locals on the icy island. To protect yourself from insects, you must stock up on repellents.
  • Tourists and locals love to have picnics in the sun within the city limits. Keep in mind that Greenland has strict nature protection legislation - you must not leave garbage and food waste. Burying them in the ground is prohibited, as they can lie in the ground without decomposing for several years in a harsh climate. Breaking the ban is punishable by very high fines.
  • Fishing is one of the attractions for tourists, but a fishing license must be obtained in advance from the tourist office.
  • The land of eternal ice is quite expensive for living. Prices for food are very high, especially for fresh fruit and vegetables, as everything is exported from the mainland. But seafood and fish are quite affordable, as are all kinds of delicacies from whale and seal meat.
  • It's strict with alcohol here. Because of its destructive influence, especially on the indigenous peoples of the north, the strong drinks are almost prohibited. Alcoholic beverages are very expensive and are sold on weekdays until 18-00, and on Saturdays until 13-00.
  • There are no railways or highways between cities. The settlement ends, and the road rests on a rock. You can get to another settlement only by air or by sea.
  • Sled dogs are still used in northern Greenland, and it is common to see dog sleds on the road. By the way, they have a preferential right of way on the roads.
  • The land of eternal ice has its own hot springs. The most famous of them is located on the island of Uunarthok. It is believed to have been discovered by the Vikings 1000 years ago. The water temperature in it is +38C°.
  • Local residents are not like Europeans; they consider themselves descendants of the Inuits. And Eskimo (an offensive word for locals) stands for a "man eating raw meat." Calling them Eskimos is like calling an African Negro.
  • Far north of Greenland, Inuit, like thousands of years ago, build snow needles, hunt polar bears, and eat raw fish.
  • This is one of the few countries where whale hunting is allowed, and its meat is sold in local shops.
  • Greenlanders are a free nation in terms of sexual relations. There are very few people on the island; many meet each other without even knowing they are related. That is why locals love foreigners and engage in sexual relations with them, primarily for the sake of mixing blood. If a blue-eyed child is born after the departure of a European tourist, it is well attended.
  • Due to the harsh climate, nothing is being produced in Greenland. All products are shipped from the mainland. As for animal rearing, it is possible to breed only deer, sheep, and sheep bulls.
  • The island has the cleanest drinking water in the world.
  • It is possible to take pictures of local people only after their permission, and it is prohibited to take photographs of church services.

description.en: Greece is a country of rich ancient history and extraordinary beauty. In terms of archaeological, cultural, and historical heritage, Ancient Greece is ahead of many other countries and delights tourists with its fortresses and ancient temples, amphitheaters, and museums, and of course, the magnificent Mediterranean beaches. Everyone who has ever been here had vivid impressions from visiting this incredible country.

geography.en: Greece is located in the southern part of the Balkan Peninsula. It also includes a large number of islands, which make up 20 percent of the country's total territory. Ancient Greece is washed by the Mediterranean, Ionian, Aegean, Cretan, and Libyan Seas of the Mediterranean basin. It borders on Albania in the north-west, Northern Macedonia and Bulgaria in the north, and Turkey in the north-east. The Peloponnese (2200 square kilometers) is the largest peninsula and cradle of the ancient Greek civilization. It has a population of about one million people. Crete (8259 square kilometers) is considered to be the largest among the islands, followed by Euboea (3654 square kilometers), Lesbos (1630 square kilometers), and Rhodes (1401 square kilometers). The territory of Greece consists mainly of medium-high mountain ranges. The highest peaks are Mount Olympus (2917 m) and Parnassus (2457 m). Mountain rivers, breathtaking beauty of their waterfalls, many lakes of different origin, canyons, and caves, the incredible beauty of the bay and lagoon are other "zests" of nature in Greece. The country's administrative system was reformed in 2011 under the Kallikratis Programme. Greece now has seven decentralized administrations, 13 regions, and 325 municipalities, as well as an Autonomous Monastic State of the Holy Mountain with a special status and its own visa regime.

long_description.en:
Athens

Athens is the capital of the country and bears the name of the ancient Greek goddess of war and wisdom. The names of the ancient philosophers Plato, Socrates, and Aristotle, and such masters of drama as Sophocles, Aeschylus, and Euripides, are closely associated with the name of this city. One or two days will not be enough to visit all the sights of Athens. There are over two hundred museums alone. In addition to them, a tourist has to find time to see a large number of ancient monuments, including the Acropolis, the temples of Zeus and Hephaestus, the Tower of the Winds, and Panathinaikos Stadium, which hosted the first Olympic Games in modern history. The best panoramic view of Athens can be seen from Philopappos and Lykavitos Hills. The first one offers a magnificent view of the Acropolis and the architectural ensemble consisting of the Theatre of Dionysus Eleuthereus, Parthenon and Erechtheion. And when the weather is good, you can see the Saronic Gulf, the Port of Piraeus, and even the nearby island of Aegina from Lykavitos.

Thessaloniki

Thessaloniki is Greece's second-largest city, its northern capital, and the cultural center. Many of the monuments of Thessaloniki are listed as UNESCO World Heritage Sites. Tourists who come to this ancient city have places to explore. Its architecture has not been exposed to modern changes. There are no skyscrapers, and all the buildings are not too high. The White Tower of Thessaloniki is a so-called symbol and the main attraction of the city. Visitors can see the exposition of the Museum of Byzantine Culture and climb to the observation deck, which offers stunning views of the city and the central waterfront. Archaeological lovers will be interested in visiting the ancient city of Dion (dedicated to the god Zeus), which is 90 km from Thessaloniki.

Halkidiki

The peninsula of Halkidiki is located in north-eastern Greece, on the northern coast of the Aegean Sea. It is a real paradise for tourists. Halkidiki consists of three separate peninsulas: Kassandra, Sithonia, and Athos. Kassandra is considered to be the most popular part of the resort, where the most comfortable hotels and beaches are located. Sithonia is associated with measured relaxation with small cozy coves and well-maintained beaches. Athos is a convent republic that consists of 20 orthodox monasteries. An interesting fact is that since ancient times there has been a ban on visiting the Holy Mountain by any female creatures. It concerns not only women but also animals. For violation of the law, criminal liability with a term of imprisonment from 8 to 12 months is provided. Men must obtain a special permit (diamonitirion) to visit Athos. Athos offers fascinating sightseeing tours in the monasteries of Meteora.

Crete

Crete is the largest island in Greece and the fifth-largest in the Mediterranean Sea. Several seas wash it at once - Libyan, Cretan, Ionian Seas. In the lagoon of Balos, you can watch all three seas merge. It is stunningly beautiful, with the water shimmering in all shades of blue. Heraklion is considered to be the capital of Crete, while other major cities include Rethymno, Lasithi, and Chania. There are many historical attractions here, but the Palace of Knossos, the Arkadi Monastery, and the old Venetian port of Chania deserve special attention.

Corfu

Corfu (Kérkyra) is the second-largest island in the Ionian Islands. It is covered with cypress forests, olive groves, and orange plantations. It is, without exaggeration, a green paradise. The old town is surrounded by fortress walls built to protect it during the Venetian protectorate. It is a perfect island for a beach vacation. You should keep in mind that the water is warmer in the east of the country, so take this fact into account while choosing resorts. On the island, you should visit the resort village of Paleokastritsa with its caves and monastery, the Achilleion Palace and Saint Spiridon Orthodox Cathedral, dating back to the XV century.

Rhodes

Rhodes is another beautiful Greek resort island. It is located in the Aegean Sea near Turkey. The coastline of Rhodes is an endless chain of sandy beaches. The capital of the island is the town of Rhodes, built by the Knights Hospitaller. Fortifications of Rhodes are the main attraction of the city, built during the blossom of the Byzantine Empire. The historical part of the town is a significant cultural heritage of world importance.

Kos

The island of Kos, located 4 km from the southwest coast of Turkey, will also be a great place to relax. According to one version, the name "Kos" is derived from the word "crab". In ancient times, the crab was the emblem of the island and minted on local coins. The father of world medicine, Hippocrates, was born on Kos. Lovers of antiquity are attracted here by the ruins of 22 early Christian basilicas, the most famous of which is the Basilica of Saint Stephen in Kefalos. It will also be interesting to visit the castles of Knights Hospitaller of the XV-XVI centuries in Andimachia and Kefalos, as well as the Byzantine castle in Pelion.

description.en: Georgia is the most ancient country, which has seen a lot during its centuries-old history. Each conqueror left his mark on the tortured body of the country, but no one broke the real Georgian character. It has been preserved to this day. Beautiful mountain landscapes, cities, and resorts with mineral springs, a culture that combines the spirit of Europe and Asia, incredibly delicious food, and excellent wine — that's how you can describe modern Georgia. Speaking of wine, it is an integral part of the Georgian people. There is still a tradition in Georgia, which is passed down from generation to generation: when a child is born in a family, they lay down kvevri (clay vessels for wine), and they drink wine from it on the day of his maturity. As a rule, everyone who comes to this beautiful country takes a bottle of real Georgian wine with them. It has been considered here since ancient times: "a guest is a person who has come from God", that is why you will be greeted with respect and friendliness everywhere and will undoubtedly be generously treated. Believe us, this country will not leave indifferent anybody who has visited it at least once.

geography.en: Georgia is located in the Middle East, at the junction of Europe and Asia, in the western part of Transcaucasia. It neighbors with Russia in the north, Azerbaijan in the east, Armenia and Turkey in the south. The waters of the Black Sea washes its coast. Georgia's territory has everything: towering mountains, mountain rivers, thick forests, alpine meadows, semi-deserts, glaciers, and gorges. The highest mountain settlement in Europe — Ushguli — is located n the region of Svaneti, at 2200 meters above sea level. It's home to about 200 people. In the eastern part of the Khokh Range, on the border between Russia and Georgia, rises the mighty Mount Kazbek (5034 m). Many mountain-climbers dream of conquering this peak. The Kura River is the largest in the country. It has its origin in Turkey and flows through Georgia and Azerbaijan, flowing into the Caspian Sea.

long_description.en:
An exquisite combination of identity of ancient places and modernity.

From one year to another, Georgia attracts travelers from all over the world with its character, authenticity, color, hospitality, and beautiful nature. It has numerous ancient churches and fortresses, caves, waterfalls, healing springs, and mountain ranges. Each city and village in Georgia has its own unique character and atmosphere. 

Tbilisi

Tbilisi (old name Tiflis) is the principal city and capital of Georgia, located on the banks of the Kura River (Mtkvari). You should start your acquaintance with the town from the main street — Shota Rustaveli Avenue. Here you can find the Parliament, the Vorontsov's Palace, Griboyedov Russian Drama Theatre and Rustaveli National Theatre, the National Museum, the Zurab Tsereteli Art Gallery. Each square meter of this ancient city is fascinating. A marvelous building or another sight hides just around a corner. The streets of the Old Town have preserved their historical identity, and the buildings have the features of medieval build-up. There are many historical attractions and monuments in Tbilisi — Metekhi Temple and Anchiskhati Church, the Narikala Fortress, the Sioni Cathedral of the Dormition, and many others. To enjoy the breathtaking views of the city, it is worth climbing the several observation decks the town offers. The best view of the city is from the Ferris wheel in the park on Mount Mtatsminda. You can reach it in a cable car. After a busy cultural program, you can go to any of the numerous cafes or restaurants where you can enjoy unique local cuisine and have a glass of excellent Georgian wine.

Kutaisi

The parliamentary patrimony of Georgia is the city of Kutaisi, located on the banks of the Rioni River. Historically, it is the second capital of Georgia. Ancient Kutaisi (Eeta) used to be the capital of the Kingdom of Colchis. According to the mythology, it was to its ruler that Argonauts went to get the Golden Fleece. Ancient Bagrati Cathedral towering on a hill is the most important place. It had stood in ruins for over three centuries and was restored only in 2012. Climbing by cable car to the Gabashvili Culture and Recreation Park, located on one of the highest hills of the city, you can see Kutaisi in all its beauty. From the second capital, you can go on tour to the Gelati Monastery and Motsameta Monastery, Sataplia Nature Reserve, and Prometheus Cave (Kumistavi), which is one of the largest in Europe.

Batumi

The Black Sea coast of the Caucasus has its own paradise - the famous resort city of Batumi. It is the capital of the Autonomous Republic of Adjara. It was mentioned for the first time by Aristotle even before our era. Since ancient times, this place has been famous as a major commercial city and port. Batumi is renowned for its multi-faceted architecture, numerous fountains, one of the oldest and richest botanical gardens in the former Soviet Union, a collection of the Archaeological Museum of Adjara, magnificent hotels with hammams and SPAs. The beaches have a developed infrastructure and are decorated with themed sculptures. The moving statue of Ali and Nino constructed in 2010 is one of the most famous of these. Here you can rent bicycles, play tennis and visit numerous cafes and restaurants. 

Borjomi

At the height of more than 800 meters above sea level, among the mountains and forests, hides the balneological and climatic resort of Borjomi. It has over 200 sunny days a year, the cleanest mountain air, and the world-famous water of the same name from the healing mineral spring. It is most widely used for medical treatment: people drink it, take baths and inhale vapors. The Grand Duke Mikhail Romanov started to improve Borjomi. The royal family loved this place as a holiday destination and recreation center for treatment. Nowadays, there are over 200 historical monuments in the Borjomi gorge. Among them, you will find the Palace of the Romanov family, built in the 18th century. Only in Borjomi, you can buy local delicacy — jam made from the cones. It is not only delicious but also beneficial. It cures bronchopulmonary diseases and enhances an immune system. 

Bakuriani

A small mountain village of Bakuriani is situated on the slopes of the Trialeti Range. It is close to Borjomi, and both resorts are connected by a narrow-gauge railway. It is a modern ski resort with developed infrastructure, as well as a health resort for people with bronchopulmonary diseases. It offers about 210 sunny days a year, but it's quite snowy in winter. The village is located at the crossroads of geographical zones, so nature here is amazingly beautiful, diverse and attracts tourists. While exploring the area, you can climb Kokhta Mountain, breathe some fresh forest air, go to Lake Tabatskuri and visit the ancient Timotesubani monastery. The village also offers the Bakuriani Alpine Botanical Garden of the Institute of Botany under the Georgian Academy of Sciences. 

Gudauri

Gudauri is another popular ski resort in Georgia, located on the slopes of the South Caucasus near the Cross Pass. It offers excellent ski slopes for beginners and certified slopes for experienced downhill skiers. Besides, the area is perfect for freeriding. There are also other places for active tourism in Gudauri: tennis courts, indoor swimming pools, and everything one might need for hang gliding.

Kobuleti

Kobuleti resort city is an ideal place for a vacation and recreation therapy on the Black Sea coast. It has a long history that goes back to the fifth millennium AD. It does not have an exhausting summer heat: a cool breeze blows from the sea, the air is saturated with essential oils of eucalyptus, pine and citrus trees, which together with the sea has a beneficial effect on health. If you are planning a trip with your family and children, you will not be bored here — the resort has a large amusement park called "Tsitsinatela".

description.en: Denmark is the smallest country in Scandinavia, which gladly opens its doors to its magical world, and lures tourists for a reason. A land where both adults and children will never be bored. A country that you can visit both in winter and summer. A place where historical sights and the beauty of untouched nature are perfectly combined. Denmark is absolutely deservedly called the pearl of Scandinavia. After all, only here you can live in a real castle, and then enjoy relaxation in a SPA hotel, "hang out" in an amusement park, and then go on a sea cruise, admire the picturesque beaches, and then arrange an incredible gastronomic tour. This country has everything to make you love it and want to come back here over and over again!

geography.en: Denmark is located in Northern Europe and is the southernmost of all Scandinavian countries. Its closest neighbors are Sweden, Norway, and Germany. The territory of Denmark is washed by two seas, the Baltic Sea and the North Sea.Denmark is not only a separate independent state but also the primary member of the Unity of the Realm, which also includes the Faroe Islands and Greenland. They are members of the unity by a special act, but all judicial, legislative, and executive powers are in the hands of Denmark.In terms of administrative division, the country underwent major changes and reorganizations in 2007. Before the changes, Denmark had 14 Amtas (administrative units) and 270 municipalities. The 2007 municipal reform left five main administrative regions and 98 municipalities in the country. The Faroe Islands and Greenland are part of the unity under conditions of autonomy.Regions of DenmarkHovedstaden is a metropolitan area, which is located in the northeastern part of the island. This is where Copenhagen, the capital of Denmark, is located, and where the country's entire scientific and technological potential is concentrated. Tourists come here for the capital's attractions and Rosenborg Castle.Zealand is an area that occupies most of the island of the same name and is additionally divided into North and South Zealand, as well as the adjacent islands. North Zealand is famous for its beautiful beaches and forests, exciting museums and castles. One of the iconic places is Kronborg Castle from "Hamlet". South Zealand is an image of serenity and untouched nature, as well as medieval architecture, castles, manors, and temples. The main city of the area is Sorø, which is surrounded by three lakes and stands almost on an island.The North Jutland Region is the northernmost region of continental Denmark, with Aalborg as its capital. The industry is well-developed here, as many architectural masterpieces have survived. The significant cities of Northern Jutland include Hjørring (city of churches) and Frederikshavn (large port).Central Jutland is the largest region of Denmark, which occupies just over 30% of the country. Its principal cities are Viborg (the regional capital, educational and religious center) and Aarhus (a large port with many museums, temples, educational, and entertainment facilities).Southern Denmark is the warmest and most fertile region in southern Denmark and borders with Germany. The exciting cities include Vejle (the capital of the region), Billund (home of the famous Legoland Park), Nyborg (the town with the castle of the same name), and Kolding (the city of castles, museums, and a gorgeous botanic garden).It is worth noting that each region is further divided into cities and communes. In addition, the cities may have their own districts.

long_description.en:
Copenhagen

Copenhagen is the capital of Denmark and the city where you should start to get acquainted with this beautiful country. Copenhagen is the most visited city in Scandinavia, so you can only dream of a peaceful vacation with a few tourists. However, it remains cozy and very atmospheric. It is worth starting with the monument to the Little Mermaid. Here you can admire the Kastellet fortress, which was built back in the XVII century. The Amalienborg palace ensemble, the official residence of the monarchs, also deserves your attention. If you are looking for some romance, head to Nyhavn. And if you want a beach holiday, come to Copenhagen in summer. Attractions in Tivoli Gardens, a city-bike ride, a water bus, Michelin-starred restaurants, the hippie town, and the Round Tower's observation deck are just some of the attractions you'll love. 

Billund

Billund is the real kingdom of LEGO. It was in this city that the first factory for the production of the famous constructor was opened. The largest Legoland park was also built here. Absolutely all buildings, attractions, and decorations are made of LEGO. In total, this incredible complex consists of over 46,000 parts. The park will be attractive not only for children but also for adults. And it is not the only attraction of Billund. A visit to the safari park and hippodrome, where you can take horseback riding lessons and watch the races, is just as exciting. It's worth noting that you will also enjoy a simple walk through the streets of the city. Cozy paved roads, fabulous houses and an abundance of flowers — the pictures are very atmospheric

Odense

Odense is a city for those who want to immerse themselves in the fairy-tale of Hans Christian Andersen, admire the gingerbread houses, and enjoy the romance. Fairy-tale characters meet here at every turn, and you can also collect a whole collection of photos of different monuments. In addition, St. Canute's Cathedral is considered to be one of the main attractions of the city, which has both a sad and very beautiful story. Funen Village is another interesting place for tourists. This is an open-air museum, where you can not only see the architecture of ancient Odense but also look at real peasant houses.

Aalborg

Aalborg is a fantastic city that attracts tourists with its charm. Renaissance-style buildings, a Gothic cathedral, a castle that dates back to the XVI century, cozy streets — it is a pure pleasure to walk and enjoy the magical atmosphere. Besides the listed sights, the city museums (devoted to art, history, Navy), the Town Hall, and the mansion of the merchant Jens Bang are also worth seeing. Jomfru Ane Gade is a real highlight of Aalborg. It is a pedestrian street and consists entirely of bars and restaurants with small terraces.

Roskilde

Roskilde is one of the most unusual cities in Denmark, and its popularity increases several times in the first half of July. The whole secret is that this is the time when the city is hosting a major rock festival, which is considered to be one of the coolest and most interesting in Europe. World-famous performers, beer rivers, cheerful and loud youth — for the whole week, the city changes its appearance beyond recognition. If you want a calmer and more measured rest, you should come to Roskilde in a different month. At the same time, you won't be bored in the city. The Cathedral, the Viking Ship Museum, City Museum, Royal Palace — all these attractions are just 30 km from Copenhagen. 

Aarhus

Aarhus is the second-largest city in Denmark, which is cozily located on the bay. It is often referred to as the city with the youngest population as it is home to a large number of students. For tourists, Aarhus is appealing with its attractions: Town Hall, the Church of Our Lady, State and City Museums, Viking Museum, Old Town, Botanical Garden. Thrill-seekers should visit the Tivoli amusement park, where they can experience a free fall or a dead loop. Shopaholics will love their stay in Aarhus too, as the city is home to Bruun's Gallery, the largest shopping center.

description.en: Ireland is an island state located in the north part of the Atlantic Ocean. Fluffy lambs on lush green pastures, cozy cities, and ancient castles, the power of the Atlantic region and friendly people — that's about Ireland, which fabulous atmosphere chill to the marrow. From vibrant Irish dances to live music, that makes your legs move; big festivals drag you into the public drive; and in the evenings, it's hard to resist the temptation to find leprechauns and pixies. Although, who knows, maybe it's all because of the stiff Irish scotch that you have drunk the night before in the bar?

geography.en: The Republic of Ireland is a state that occupies the largest part of the territory of the homonymous island. It also includes 35 small inhabited islands and about 20 that are not populated nowadays. The Atlantic Ocean washes the coast of Ireland in the north and west, the Irish Sea, the Straits of St. George and the Northern Sea in the east, and the Celtic Sea in the south. The length of the border with Great Britain is 360 kilometers. Here, the climate is mild, and plants do not lose green outfits all year round, that's why the island is called Emerald. The landscape is mainly flat, but there are low mountains and plateaus on the island's outskirts. The territory of Ireland is divided into four provinces, which include 26 traditional counties.

description.en: Iceland is a northern island country surrounded by the Atlantic Ocean. In this land, a tourist seems to time-travel into the atmosphere until the beginning of time on Earth: the movement of tectonic plates, the craters of volcanoes, glaciers and icebergs, hot springs and moss-covered lava fields. Here, a strong wind trembles the manes of low Icelandic horses; the soil falls off the cliffs from the basalt rocks; in the ocean, pods of whales sing their songs, and all this against a background of mesmerizing northern lights. In small villages, people still roof their houses with moss, always believe in trolls, and treat them friendly. These create the atmosphere of a magical northern fairy tale.

geography.en: The island state of Iceland is located in the west of Northern Europe in the northern part of the Atlantic Ocean between Greenland and Norway. The territory of the country consists of the island of the same name, as well as small islands around it. In the east, Iceland is washed by the Norwegian Sea, in the north — by the Greenland Sea, and in the west, Iceland and Greenland are separated by the Danish straits. The highest point of the island is Hvannadalshnúkur Peak, which is 2109.6 meters high. Iceland is called the country of volcanoes. There are about 200 of them here, and 35 are active. Tectonic structure and relief features have contributed to the appearance of numerous geysers and hot springs in Iceland. Many of them are within national parks.The inland territory of the country consists almost entirely of eternal glaciers. People do not live here, and mountains, volcanoes, and waterfalls are suitable for wild multi-day tracking without a hint of civilization. The rest of Iceland is connected by a large ring road — Ring Road No. 1. It encircles the whole island and closes in a chain so that you can see all the main attractions of the country in 10 days of a leisurely road trip.

long_description.en:
Reykjavik

Reykjavik is Iceland's capital and its largest city, home to the majority of the country's population. When exploring the streets of the world's northernmost capital, make sure you visit a Lutheran church with the complicated name Hallgrímskirkja, the cathedral, and Whale Museum. You'll find another unique temple with unusual architecture, Landakotskirkja, or Cathedral of Christ the King on the hilltop of the city. Perlan is another fascinating attraction. This is the boiler house, and its tanks are filled continuously with thermal water to heat the buildings of the town. At the same time, it is an observation deck for those who want to admire the city from a height through special panoramic telescopes. There is also a so-called restaurant here, the floor of which is constantly rotating, and the Saga Museum, consisting of wax figures that tell about the life and traditions of the locals. From Reykjavik, you can make a day trip to the Golden Ring: watch the Gullfoss Falls break down in the gorge, walk along the geothermal Haukadalur valley, take a photo of the Kerið crater, visit the Þingvellir National Park, which is a UNESCO World Heritage Site, and at the end - to warm up in the hot torrent of the Hveragerði river. The Icelandic Phallological Museum is another "highlight" of Reykjavik. It features over 200 species of animal phalli. The open-air water park with geothermally heated pools is especially popular among the public and tourists. 

Keflavik

Keflavik is a small town where any tourist will inevitably visit. It is the main airport in the country, so your acquaintance with Iceland will start with Keflavik. The most famous attraction of this seaside town is the Blue Lagoon - a geothermal resort, which is distinguished by its delicate blue water color. In summer, whale and dolphin watching are organized for tourists. Sea cruises remain to be the most popular option for family holidays. 

Torn of continents

If you drive counter-clockwise along Ring Road #1 from Reykjavik, at some point, you'll have to jump from North American to Eurasian Lithosphere Plate. This "torn of continents" is located in the south of Iceland, in the picturesque Thingvellir National Park, the first meeting place of the Icelandic Parliament, the oldest one in the world. Behind the basalt rocks of Thing's fields, you will find the capital of the southern region, the city of Selfoss. The town itself is not very remarkable. The Ghost Centre Museum, the Tree and Art Gallery, and the Art Gallery are popular among tourists. But don't worry, you won't be bored for a long time: local travel agencies offer a lot of options for active leisure. Some exciting and extraordinary activities include horse riding in the city outskirts near raging waterfalls and lakes overlooking glaciers; extreme rafting on the Ölfusá River, where you can't tell whether there is more water or salmon; trips to the most famous crater lake in Iceland — Kerið.

Austurland region

The Austurland region takes the traveler into its ice shackles. The largest glacier on the island, Vatnajökull, hides a volcano and ice caves under its cold thickness. Its waters feed the largest ice lagoon in Iceland, Jökulsárlón, which azure blows your mind. Nearby, in Skaftafell National Park, the Svartifoss waterfall is buzzing. Framed in hexagonal basalt columns, it is one of the park's most popular attractions. 

Egilsstadir

The city of Egilsstadir, the capital of Austurland, is situated 300 kilometers from the park. Its colorful houses stand near Lake Lagarfljót. Thanks to the largest forest area in Iceland, the city has a beautiful ecological environment. We recommend going to see the beauty of Hengifoss, Iceland's third-highest waterfall, and move on!

Akureyri

Akureyri hides in the depths of Ayia Fjord. It is the second most important city in the country. The northern capital is protected from the cold winds of the Arctic by high mountains. Here you shall find the largest ski resort in Iceland — Hlíðarfjall. It offers perfect conditions for hockey players and figure skaters, and fans of underwater fishing will find perfect holes in rivers and lakes. The main sights of Akureyri are outside the city limits. These are Godafoss Falls, Sulfur volcano and volcanic Lake Askja. If you have some time, you should visit the most powerful waterfall in Europe, Dettifoss, which is often compared in its magnificence with Niagara.

Sauðárkrókur

Sauðárkrókur lays on the picturesque banks of the Skagafjörður. It is the main city of the Nordurland-Vestra region. It is known as the center of Icelandic horse breeding. Every local citizen has several horses, and once a year, the city gathers the whole country for the horse festival. There is a thermal pool in 15 kilometers from Sauðárkrókur, where you can warm yourself up surrounded by snow-covered mountain slopes. Glaumbær Farm & Museum is a must-visit spot on the map. Its mossy turf houses are fabulous! Also, stop by Reykjafoss Falls and check out the Atlantic Ocean and the weird basalt cliffs on the banks of the Vatnsnes Peninsula. 

Ísafjörður

North-West Iceland is ready to shelter you in the city of Ísafjörður, the capital of the Western Fjords. It stands on the banks of the picturesque Skutuls Fjord, surrounded by absolutely wild nature. Usually, tourists arrive in Ísafjörður on liners, cruising the Icelandic fjords. The ancient streets of the city are designed for a leisurely walk to get acquainted with the town — one day is pretty much enough. From Ísafjörður, you can go to the island of Vigur, where the smallest post office and the only windmill in Iceland are located. Go for a walk through the most beautiful green valleys, visit the Dynjandi waterfall, and also get to the "bird market" at Cape Latrabjarg.

Borgarnes

Borgarnes is the homeland of Icelandic heroes Erik the Red and Leif Erikson, and the administrative center of Westerland. The city specializes in organizing eco-tours: hiking along the trails of the Snæfellsjökull National Park at the foot of the glacier of the same name; descent to the oldest and longest lava caves in Iceland — Surtshellir and Víðgelmir, with their colored stalactites and stalagmites; trips to black volcanic beaches, with surreal lava formations along the coast; tours to hot springs and waterfalls; cruises in the Borgarfjörður Fjord. The Snæfellsnes Peninsula is located within an easy reach from here. It is often called "Iceland in miniature" due to its diverse landscapes. In winter, Snæfellsnes is perfect for taking pictures of northern lights, so don't forget to charge your camera's battery.

description.en: Cyprus is the famous island of Aphrodite and has been attracting travelers for thousands of years. A hospitable country with friendly and open people, excellent climate, gentle sea, architecture of different eras and styles, and excellent cuisine — that's Cyprus. The chic beaches that have been awarded the European Union Blue Flag for their cleanliness and safety deserve special recognition. During a tourist trip to Cyprus, you can not only relax on its flawless sunny beaches, but also climb Mount Olympos, visit the dead city of Famagusta, and ride on donkeys.

geography.en: Cyprus is at the crossroads of three parts of the world — Europe, Asia, and Africa and washed by the Mediterranean Sea. The closest neighbors of the Republic are Syria, Lebanon, Israel, and Egypt. Such an advantageous location has caused intrusions on its territory since ancient times. Nowadays, the island is divided between three states. Until 1960, the island had been under the British Mandate, after which it became an independent state. However, 2% of the territory remained under the British military bases of Akrotiri and Decelia. De jure, the remaining part (98%), is to be owned by the independent Republic of Cyprus. However, de facto, since 1974, it has occupied only 60 percent of the island and a number of smaller islands: Ayios Georgios, Yeronisos, Glykiotissa, Kila, Klides, Kordhylia, and Mazaki. The northern part (36% of the territory) is controlled by the partially-recognized (only by Turkey) Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus. The north and south of the island are divided by the so-called "green line" — a buffer zone passing through the capital of Cyprus — Nicosia. This territory is under the control of a contingent of the United Nations Peacekeeping Force in Cyprus (UNFICYP).The Kyrenia mountain range stretches almost all over the island, and the Troodos mountain system is located in the south-west.

long_description.en:
The Cypriot civilization is over nine millennia old. The first mention of Cyprus is found back in the works of Homer, so once you get to this ancient island, you feel like a hero of Greek mythology. The country amazes with the number of attractions in each, even the smallest, city.

Nicosia

The capital of Cyprus is Nicosia, located in the center of the country between the mountain ranges of Kyrenia and Troodos. There are many interesting cultural attractions here: the Archbishop's Palace, the Gallery of Modern Art, the Cyprus Archaeological Museum, and the Handicraft Center. But the most outstanding and, at the same time, tragic sight is the Green Line inside the Old City.
