It is a conventional strip, which is under the control of UN peacekeeping forces and divides the country into two parts — Greek and Turkish. The strip runs among winding alleys, colonial-era buildings, between churches and mosques, bars and street cafes. Sandbags and people in military uniforms are a reminder that it is worth paying attention while walking and getting to know Nicosia. 

Larnaca

Larnaca is a major resort town and home to the largest international airport in the Republic of Cyprus. The modern area of Larnaca is located on the site of the ancient city-state of Kition. Every year, millions of tourists and pilgrims from different religions visit Larnaca. Here you shall find the famous Orthodox shrine — the Church of Saint Lazarus, built in the IX century on the site of the tomb of Lazarus, who, according to the Gospel of John, was resurrected by Jesus on the fourth day after his death. Here is also a part of his relics. Muslims come to Larnaka to visit their fourth most important shrine in the Islamic world, the Hala Sultan Tekke. The most interesting monument of Roman architecture is the Kamares Aqueduct, which is located near Salt Lake and Mackenzie Beach. The lake attracts a large population of pink flamingos in winter. Like many resort towns, Larnaca has a luxurious Finikoudes Promenade, a yacht marina, chic municipal beaches, many restaurants, and cafes offering a variety of national dishes. 

Ayia Napa

Ayia Napa is the most popular resort town in Cyprus with many high-class hotels, restaurants, bars, cafes, and nightclubs. Here you can scuba dive, windsurf, and water ski, visit the luna park and Europe's largest water theme park, Water World. In addition to active entertainment, you can visit, for example, the Ayia Napa Monastery and the Ethnographic Museum for cultural enrichment. 

Protaras

Not far from Ayia Napa is the village of Protaras, famous for its golden beaches and clean water. This resort is not so full of nightclubs and bars and is more focused on a measured family holiday. The locals also like to spend time here. On the top of a large mountain, in the heart of the city, is the Church of St. Elijah, the Prophet XIV, which offers a beautiful view.

Limassol

Limassol, the main sea gate of Cyprus, is the center of trade of the island, the center of offshore companies, a popular resort, as well as a recognized center of wine-making in the country. Annually, in September, a wine festival is held here. The embankment, or rather its western part, where the sculpture park (Molos) is located, is one of the favorite places of tourists and locals. In the vicinity of the city, you can also see several interesting sights — Kolossi Castle, Ancient Kourion, and the Sanctuary of Apollo Hylates.

Paphos

Paphos is a SPA town for lovers of ancient history and archaeology. Here you will find Villa Dionysus, the mosaics of which amaze with their beauty and splendor, House of Theseus, Tombs of the Kings, dating back to III century BC, the Holy Garden — Geroskipou. But the most popular attraction is the Baths of Aphrodite, which is a cave, with a small lake and a small waterfall.

Pano Lefkara

On the slope of the Troodos mountain range lies the picturesque village of Pano Lefkara, buried in olive plantations and orange gardens. The name is translated from Greek as "White Mountains". The village is named after the white limestone from the mountains. This material was used to build the majority of the houses and even to pave the streets. In Lefkara, there is the ancient Church of the Holy Cross, where the Orthodox shrine, a fragment of the Crucifixion, is kept. But the main thing that attracts art lovers and tourists from all over the world is the famous lace, the secret of weaving of which is passed on from generation to generation. It is said that in 1481, Leonardo da Vinci himself came to Lefkara to get acquainted with this art and took the local handmade lace from here for the altar of the Cathedral of Milan. In 2009, the Lefkaritica lacemaking technique was inscribed on the UNESCO's Masterpieces of the Oral and Intangible Heritage of Humanity. The main male trade in Lefkar is the production of silver filigree products. Both are available at numerous Lefkara shops. 

Troodos mountain range

The southernmost ski resort in Europe is the Troodos mountain range. The season here lasts from December to March. It is not the most active skiing resort, but it has its own charm — mild climate, forest landscapes, and, most importantly - a small number of people. From here, you can go for a walk to nearby villages, each of which is known for something different: Omodos — wine, Lefkara — lace, Agros — a variety of meat dishes. In summer, people come here to climb Mount Olympos and enjoy a breathtaking view, which is a worthy reward for climbing. 

Akamas Peninsula

Akamas Peninsula is the National Park near Paphos, a UNESCO World Heritage Site. There is no agricultural land on its territory, and nature is untouched. The pathway of Aphrodite and Adonis are two of the most popular walking routes for tourists. After the walk, you can swim in the Blue Lagoon with the purest turquoise water.

description.en: When Kosovo is mentioned, many associations and stereotypes are usually far from tourism. First of all, the history of the region and its political position come to mind. But if we forget about all prejudices, the Republic of Kosovo is a region with an incredibly beautiful landscape, where green wooded mountains are adjoining the plains, rivers, and lakes. Ancient architectural structures have been preserved here, and extreme entertainment is available for travelers. This is an interesting option for a budget trip, which will be remembered for life.

geography.en: The Republic of Kosovo is located in the center of the Balkan Peninsula in the south-east of Europe. It borders Serbia to the north and east, Montenegro to the west, Albania, and Northern Macedonia to the south. As a result of the fact that the independence of the state is recognized only by a part of UN member states, Kosovo is considered to be an independent state or an autonomous province of Serbia. The relief of the region is rather mountainous. The highest point is Mount Đeravica (2656 m) on the border with Albania. The Šar Mountains and Kopaonik Mountain Range are passing through Kosovo. There is no access to the sea, but there are four large rivers (the White Drin, Sitnica, South Morava, and Ibar), many lakes, and ponds (Gazivoda, Radonjić, Batlava, Badovac) and picturesque waterfalls (Mirusha and rapids on the White Drin).The Republic is divided into seven districts (Gjakova, Gjilan, Kosovska Mitrovica, Peć, Pristina, Prizren, and Ferizaj), which in turn consist of 30 municipalities. The three northern municipalities (Leposavić, Zvečan, and Zubin Potok) are not under the authority of the republic and are inhabited by Serbs.

long_description.en:
Prishtina

Prishtina is the capital of Kosovo, which used to be the center of a medieval Serbian state. It is now a completely Albanian city, with the main street named after former American President Bill Clinton. He, like all successive United States authorities, is greatly respected by the local population. There is a portrait of him on Bill Clinton Boulevard and a monument to the former President underneath it. Perpendicular to Clinton Boulevard is George Bush Street.

This is not a classical European capital. Prishtina looks more like a small provincial city. In the center, you can easily meet a cow or see clothes drying. The city is not clean at all, and there is a lot of garbage on the streets and buildings look untidy.

The most significant place in Prishtina is the Newborn Monument symbolizing the birth of the new state. It even received the Golden Lion at the 55th International Advertising Festival "Cannes Lions". The inscription is repainted every year. First, it was yellow, and then it was painted with the flags of the states that recognized the independence of Kosovo. In 2017, the letters were painted grey and placed horizontally "N" and "W", which started the inscription "No Walls", painted white on the ground.

Across the street from Newborn Monument, one can see the Heroinat installation dedicated to 20,000 Kosovo women who were victims of violence during the 1998-1999 war. The memorial is composed of medals placed on rods, which together form a three-dimensional portrait of a woman.

Prishtina is also famous for another symbol that is often included in the lists of the world's ugliest buildings, the National Library of Kosovo. It combines Albanian and Serbian architectural styles. The building looks like a cluster of separate rectangles fenced with metal wire mesh, with white domes of different sizes.

Prizren

Prizren is the capital of culture, the second-oldest city in the Republic, where the medieval spirit has been preserved. In order to better understand and see Prizren in all its glory, you need to climb the fortress wall, which offers an incredible panorama — cozy little white houses with terracotta roofs, mosques, temples, and the river. This is also the best location where you can watch the sunset over the mountains. The symbolic place of Prizren is an old stone bridge of the XV century, which is painted in most of the pictures. It was destroyed in the 1970s, but it was restored in 1982. Even though now the city is predominantly Muslim, in addition to mosques, ancient Orthodox churches and Catholic churches have been preserved here.

Pec

Pec is the town where the residence of the Patriarchate of Pec is located, from which the Serbian Orthodox Church began. In addition to cult objects, the city attracts tourists with its active and sometimes extreme pastimes — bungee jumping, zip-lines, hiking, paragliding, excursions to caves, etc. On Saturdays, at the local market, you can taste incredibly delicious homemade cheeses.

Kosovska Mitrovica

Kosovska Mitrovica is the city to which people most often go to see the difference between the country's structures. The river divides Mitrovica into two parts, the southern (Albanian) and northern (Serb). In the south, Albanians from all over the country like to celebrate weddings because of the low prices. Here they usually pay with euro and pray to Allah. On the other bank of the Ibar River, a completely different life flows - with a different culture, currency, language, and alphabet. And instead of mosques, there are Orthodox cathedrals.

description.en: It is impossible to resist the charm of the warm nights of the mellow season in Alupka, the breath of the fresh breeze of Yalta, and the delight of hiking through the spring madness of colors on the flowering slopes of Demerdzhi. Crimea is a combination of comfortable hotels and resorts, children's laughter in water parks and dolphinariums, acquaintance with the history of the peninsula. You can choose between quiet walks through cozy resort streets and unrestrained extreme on the steep cliffs, the salt spray of sea voyages, and tranquil beach serenity. Cities and resorts can offer absolutely everything you need for a great holiday. In Crimea, summer is a stunning nature with lush tropical greenery and majestic mountains, healing air, and cozy pebble and sandy beaches. But you should come here at least once in autumn, spring or even winter to reveal the mystery of the Crimean phenomenon — and it will show itself in all its glory.

People often refer to Latvia as the heart of the Baltic States, because it is this country that has collected the best of the region. There are many health centers here. Moreover, Latvians have invented a recipe of unique therapeutic balm (Rīgas Melnais balzams). It takes 24 species of plants that ingrain in oak casks to prepare it. Tourists go to Latvia to experience the hospitality of Latvians, to taste national dishes, to see unique architectural monuments of Art Nouveau style, and just to admire the beauty of the Baltic Sea.

geography.en: Latvia is a small country on the shores of the Baltic Sea, located in Eastern Europe. It borders Estonia to the north, Lithuania to the south, and Russia and Belarus to the east. The relief is predominantly flat, dotted with thousands of rivers and lakes. The 54% of Latvia's territory is covered by forests, which makes the country one of the greenest in Europe. As for the administrative structure, as a result of the 2008 reform, Latvia was divided into 109 regions (novads) and seven republican cities. In July 2009, two more cities of republican subordination were added — Jekabpils and Valmiera; in 2010, another region — Mērsrags — was added. The regions, in turn, are divided into parishes and regional towns.

long_description.en:
Riga

Riga is the capital of Latvia, which is interesting for its streets and architecture. The historic city center is included in the UNESCO World Heritage List. You should start your walk around the city on Jauniela Street, where houses with colored facades are located. You can taste national cuisine and buy handmade souvenirs at the craft fair, which is held every Saturday in the Kalnciema Quarter. The symbol of the capital and the main attraction of the city is the House of Blackheads. The building, constructed in 1334, amazes with a combination of different styles and luxurious interior items: crystal chandeliers, painted ceilings, and so on. These walls regularly host various events, concerts, and exhibitions.

Daugavpils

Daugavpils is Latvia's second-largest and most important city, located on the bank of the Daugava River. Daugavpils fortress is the symbol of the town and an architectural monument of national importance erected in the XIX century. The city has the oldest and the largest museum in the Latgale region. There are collections devoted to numismatics, archaeology, bonistics, and ethnography. The most popular exhibitions are dedicated to the peculiarities of life of the indigenous population of Daugavpils. The Latgale Zoo is suitable for walking with a child, where you can see macaques, marsupial possums, caimans, pythons, and other representatives of fauna that live here in artificially-created conditions of wild nature.

Jurmala

Coming to Latvia and not visiting Jurmala is like flying to Rome and not seeing the Colosseum. The resort city of Jurmala is known not only for its recreation on the Baltic coast but also for the popular singing contest "New Wave", which had been held here from 2002 to 2014. You can start by walking along Jomas Street, the busiest place in the city. There are cafes, restaurants, and shops on both sides. You should definitely take a walk in Dzintari Park, where centuries-old pine trees grow, and there is also a tall tower with an observation deck. As for the beaches of Jurmala, they are wide and clean here, and the average water temperature in the Baltic Sea in summer is +21 °C.

Liepaja

Liepaja is Latvia's third-largest city, located in the western part of the country. The name translates from Latvian as "the city under the lindens". There are indeed many of these trees here, as well as other green plants. Liepaja is famous for its mineral waters, beautiful beaches, and therapeutic mud. Lovers of cultural recreation will be pleased with the Seaside Park with its narrow streets and the Liepaja Holy Trinity Cathedral of the XVIII century with its magnificent organ. The most significant attraction of the city is the Liepaja Castle, built in the late XIX and early XX centuries by order of Russian Emperor Alexander III. The structure was severely damaged during the Second World War, so tourists can only see its fragments. The Karosta Prison, where the tours are conducted, is also impressive. This is the only military prison in Europe, from which no one has ever escaped. 

Sigulda

Another quiet town to visit in Latvia is Sigulda, located 50 km from Riga, on the left bank of the Gauja River. This place is suitable for weekend walks. The town offers a lot to see and do. You can start by visiting the XIII century Sigulda Castle, or rather what is left of it. Only the south-west building with Gothic-style windows and the main tower at the gate have survived to this day. It is noteworthy that the territory is inhabited by Latvian youth, who try to restore the traditions of their people: they cook food at the campfire, fight with swords in armor. In a few steps from the castle, there is the Sigulda Palace, built in 1878-1881, which was the residence of the Kropotkin Princes. You should continue your walk in Turaida Museum Reserve. There is a castle, a sculpture garden, an estate, and an observation deck from which you can enjoy a beautiful panorama. 

Ventspils

Ventspils is a small port town, which has become a resort not so long ago. In the central part is the Market Square, where you can buy original souvenirs. Within a 10-minute walk from the square, there is the Livonian Order Castle, built in 1290. In the port, anyone can go for a boat ride on the Venta River. One of the modern attractions of Ventspils is the colorful cow sculptures located all over the city. They started to be installed after the "Cow Parade" held in 2002. Both adults and children like to be photographed near the cows.

description.en: Lithuania is the largest Baltic state. Despite the fact that the country is not one step behind the progressive European development (just think of how much it costs to have free Wi-Fi in the whole territory), the local population treats myths and legends with care. People here believe in harmony between nature and man. For example, the neighborhoods of Palanga and Neringa are considered to be the most ecologically-clean places in Europe. There are five national parks and 30 regional parks in Lithuania, almost all beaches have the "Blue Flag", which indicates exemplary cleanliness and safety. It is no wonder that the country is secretly recognized as a Baltic health resort: every year, hundreds of thousands of tourists come here to have a rest and improve their health at the best SPA resorts of the Baltic States.

geography.en: Lithuania is located in the north-east of Europe on the Baltic Sea coast. It borders Belarus in the east, Latvia in the north, Poland and Russia (Kaliningrad Oblast) in the southwest. Officially, Lithuania is divided into ten counties (regions): Kaunas, Vilnius, Tauragė, Alytus, Šiauliai, Klaipeda, Marijampolė, Panevėžys, Telšiai, and Utena. There is also an unofficial division of the country into five ethnographic regions: Suvalkija and Lithuania Minor (known as the Klaipeda Region), Dzūkija, Žemaitija, and Aukštaitija. Lithuania is a predominantly flat country. The highest point here is Juozapinė Hill, which rises only 292 meters above sea level. Fields, meadows, lakes, and mixed forests are typical Lithuanian landscapes.

long_description.en:
The cleanest sea air, moderate climate, lack of large industrial enterprises — all this makes Lithuania an ideal place for recreation with children, and health tourism. Even the cities here are very cozy and peaceful — a real earthly paradise for lovers of leisurely walks. 

Vilnius

Vilnius is the capital and the largest city of Lithuania. The pearl of Vilnius is the Old Town, which is on the UNESCO World Heritage List. Vilnius is rightly called the "City of Museums", as there are about 60 of them: from art history to technology. It is also the greenest capital in Europe due to its abundance of gardens and parks. The most iconic is the Bernardine Garden with its XIX century atmosphere. The peculiarity of Vilnius is that there is no subway or tram, and trolleybuses and buses are considered to be the main public transport. By the way, if you are a fan of biking tourism, you will feel very comfortable here. The abundance of bicycle lanes and all conditions for safe and convenient travel are quite tempting. 

Kaunas

Even though Kaunas is the second-largest city in Lithuania, only about 300 thousand people live here. The city is surrounded by 12 fortresses built during the reign of Catherine II. Small and cozy Kaunas looks like a fairy tale with castles, monasteries, narrow streets lined with paving stones. The locals note that Kaunas is a place of churches, where you can find your soul again. The Gothic architectural masterpiece House of Perkūnas, the Baroque Pažaislis Monastery — this is a city between past and present that continues to resist globalization while carefully preserving its historical heritage.

Klaipeda

Klaipeda is the third-largest city in Lithuania. It is famous for its largest sea, non-freezing regional port, as well as beautiful architecture and mild climate. The old town captivates with its XVIII century atmosphere. There are amazing German houses with wooden frames wrapped in grapes, which take tourists several centuries back. It will be interesting for travelers to visit the Klaipeda Castle, built back in 1252, as well as the main symbol of the city — the sailing ship "Meridian" on the Danube embankment. The longest sand dune in Europe, the Curonian Spit, is located behind the town. Klaipeda is a place for those who prefer calm and quiet rest. Streets soaked in the spirit of antiquity, national parks, botanical gardens — the city impresses with its grandeur, despite its small size. 

Druskininkai

Druskininkai is a resort town in southern Lithuania, which is suitable for fans of different types of recreation. The place is famous for its mineral springs, luxurious water park, ski resort, nature reserves, and historical buildings. The local mineral springs have been visited by aristocrats since the XVIII century. Later, the place was called a princely resort, and today, it is an open-air museum. The peculiarity of the town is that it has a covered snow arena (Snow Arena), which is ready to welcome skiers and snowboarders all year round. 

Palanga

Palanga is the famous sea resort and the "amber capital" of Lithuania. Picturesque streets, buildings in the neo-Renaissance style — apart from beach recreation, there is something to brighten up your leisure time here. While in this city, make sure you walk along Jonas Basanavičius Street. It's a mini Broadway that rests on a picturesque pier, by the way, one of the oldest in the country. The city is filled with cafes, restaurants, bars, SPAs, and sports courts. This is a quiet place for a holiday with children or a romantic vacation.

Šiauliai

Šiauliai is the museum capital of the Baltic states. Even those tourists who don't like this kind of rest will find the museum to their liking. How can you pass by the museum of cats, chocolate, beer, or miss the smallest museum in the world, which is located in the hollow of an oak tree? Of course, the most spectacular location is the Hill of Crosses. A pilgrimage site for Orthodox Christians and Catholics. There are over 100,000 crosses of different sizes on the mountain. Even Pope John Paul II left his crucifixion here. It is safe to say that Šiauliai is a unique city that has managed to preserve its historical charm.

description.en: Liechtenstein is a small country in Western Europe. It is headed by a prince who has almost absolute power. The name of the principality comes from the name of the ruling dynasty. It is the only German-speaking country in the world that has no common borders with Germany. It is an interesting fact that the state has not had its own army since 1868 — it has not participated in any wars or military operations since then. There is also no airport or railroad; the only public transport is buses. But there is a fascinating nature and picturesque views, ancient castles overhanging gorges, and medieval architecture in cozy towns. Tourists come here to dive into the local fairytale, go skiing, sightseeing, cheese and wine tasting, and enjoy life.

The miniature but not less significant Grand Duchy of Luxembourg hides in the heart of Europe. It's one of the oldest states in the world, grown from an ancient castle. The whole territory of Luxembourg is located on the hills, and that is why it is often called the "best balcony" or "observation deck" of Europe. The second variant is more accurate, as the whole country is a single sight, where every meter and corner is imbued with the history of different epochs. Picturesque medieval castles, the rocky gorges of the Mullerthal region, the steep cliffs in the Alzette Valley, wine tastings in the Moselle Valley, endless vineyards, numerous bridges, luxurious panoramic views of the surrounding countryside — all this will fill your stay in Luxembourg with the most incredible emotions and vivid impressions. This country has created first-class conditions for recreation and tourism for every taste.

geography.en: Luxembourg is one of the smallest sovereign states in Europe, located in its western part. It borders on Belgium to the north, France to the west and south, and Germany to the east. The state is divided into three districts with administrative centers in Grevenmacher, Luxembourg, and Diekirch. In turn, they are divided into 12 cantons, subdivided into 116 communes.

long_description.en:
The Grand Duchy of Luxembourg is a small state, but with great dignity, economic stability, and beautiful landscapes. It is considered to be one of the greenest countries in Europe. Every year, thousands of tourists come here to dive into the atmosphere of the Middle Ages, escape from the hustle and bustle of big cities and feel the spirit of old Europe. Each town in Luxembourg is charming in its own way.

Luxembourg

Luxembourg is the capital of the Duchy of the same name. The city is erected at an altitude of 334 m above sea level at the confluence of the rivers Alzette and Pétrusse. It is divided into two parts — the Lower and Upper Towns, connected by beautiful bridges that add a unique romance to the place. The Lower Town houses numerous banks, financial institutions, company boards, and breweries. The Upper Town is an ancient Luxembourg fortress, a mysterious and beautiful place, with many architectural monuments. The VI century Chapel of Saint-Keren partially carved in the wall, the Gothic Saint Michael's Church, the Ducal Palace with its tall towers and spires, the former Town Hall will take you back many centuries. A woodland park with many alleys, paths, among which are hidden sharp rocks and gorges, valleys of the rivers Alzette and Pétrusse please the eye with emerald greenery. All this makes Luxembourg one of the greenest cities in Europe. After a stroll through the wonderful streets of this city, make sure you try a local pastry, especially the apple pie, a recipe of which has been handed down from father to son for many years. The taste is unbelievable! 

Echternach

Echternach, the oldest city in Luxembourg, is located near the border with Germany and grew on the site of an ancient monastery. Its main attractions are the central square, the basilica, and the museum of St. Willibrord Abbey, the Roman Villa, and the artificial lake Echternach. We recommend you to come here in the first half of August. At this time, the city hosts the music festival "E-Lake". Under the open sky, on the shore of the lake, musicians, rock performers, hip-hop, famous DJs from around the world gather together. It is a fascinating and colorful action, filled with soulfulness and universal unity.

Diekirch

Diekirch is the center of sports life in Luxembourg. Football and tennis championships and Eurocross are held here every year, while downhill competitions are held on well-equipped slopes. Bicycles are the most popular leisure and means of transport. There are many interesting cycling routes of varying difficulty in the city: through narrow green streets, in the forest, in the mountains, and along streams. You can buy a map for such a walk at any bookstore, and rent a bicycle. In the center of the town, there is a statue of a donkey, which is a symbol of the city. To fully imbue the atmosphere of this beautiful place, you must go fishing on the River Sur and enjoy the silence and harmony of the town.

Wiltz

Wiltz is the largest city in the north of the Grand Duchy, the capital of the Luxembourg Ardennes. Locals say it's a favorite meeting place for world-class spies and scouts, but so far, not a single case has been made public. The main attractions of the city are Wiltz Castle, which is over 800 years old and its Witches' Tower, a wonderful park with views of the river of the same name with the city and the Ardennes Mountains. Two kilometers away from the city is the country's parachuting center, where extreme lovers can fly and see the performances of parachuting masters. The spectacle is beautiful and impressive. 

Remich

Another town of the Duchy that grew out of a small village and became a center of tourism and winemaking is Remich, the pearl of the Moselle Valley. It is quiet and cozy, with its unique atmosphere. To feel it, admire panoramic views of the city and vineyards, walk along the Moselle embankment in the shadow of centuries-old linden and cherry trees, take a boat ride and, of course, visit the tasting of Moselle wines — a great pride of this region. Remich will stay in your heart forever.

Mondorf-les-Bains

Mondorf-les-Bains is a resort city with the highest level of service, known all over the world. It is located in the south-east of Luxembourg, where it is hidden between the hills from the winds. It is an ideal place for health and active recreation. There are several well-equipped ski slopes and splendid hotels with thermal facilities. Holidays in this city will bring you the warmest memories.

description.en: Macedonia is one of the most unexplored European countries. There are no crowds of tourists on the streets, so the local population gladly welcomes every guest. Macedonia is known as one of the world's cultural centers: on its territory, there are many ancient and medieval monuments. However, people also come here for the sake of natural beauty: lakes, forests, mountains — the country has plenty of them.

geography.en: North Macedonia is located in the south-east of Europe, on the Balkan Peninsula. It borders on Kosovo and Serbia in the north, Albania in the west, Greece in the south, and Bulgaria in the east. Macedonia is located within two large mountain systems: in the extreme west — the high Pindus Mountains, in the center and east — the lower Rhodope Mountains, which are divided by the Vardar River. The administrative division of the country includes 84 communities and the city of Skopje, an independent unit of local self-government.

long_description.en:
Skopje

The capital of the Republic of Macedonia is Skopje, located in the north of the country, a few kilometers from the Serbian border. In 1963, there was an earthquake, which destroyed three-quarters of the city, and almost all historical sights. As part of the "Skopje 2014" project, the government has planned to improve the city, with new monuments, fountains, sculptures, and museums. The "Warrior on a Horse" fountain monument, more than 15 meters high, is the trademark of Skopje. Not far from it, there is the sculpture of Byzantine Emperor Justinian. Then you can see the Stone Bridge, built in the VI century, aiming to connect the old part of the city with the new one. When crossing it, look down to see the "Bathing Girls" — bronze sculptures frozen in motion. The bridge survived the earthquake and has preserved the Mother Teresa Memorial House and the Kale Fortress with its beautiful view.

Bitola

Bitola is the second-largest city in Macedonia. It is located near the border with Greece on a low mountain plateau. The most famous attraction is the ruins of the ancient city of Heraclea Lyncestis. Of course, not much is left of the ancient buildings, but here you can see the Roman amphitheater, baths, and portico. These lands often suffered from the invasion of the Tatars, so there are mosques left on the territory. The Gazi Hajdar Kadi Mosque is the most famous one, built in the middle of the XVI century. In the same period, a clock was installed in the center of the city, which to this day, gathers Muslims for prayer.

Kumanovo

Another picturesque town in Northern Macedonia is Kumanovo, 35 km north of Skopje. The area is famous for its mineral water, which was named after the town — "Kumanovka". The main streets of Kumanovo still bear the history to this day: the majority of the buildings date back to the XIX century. You can learn more about Kumanovo in the national museum. And if you have time, go and see Kokino, an archaeological monument, which is about 3800 years old. 

Ohrid

Ohrid is a town on the shore of the blue lake of the same name, with picturesque houses around it. The lake is one of the most famous sights in Europe and is under UNESCO protection. The city itself is the main resort center of Macedonia. The ancient amphitheater, where magical musical evenings are held, is a real trademark. A beautiful view opens from Samoil's Fortress, which is often depicted on souvenir cards. Ohrid is home to the Robevi House, built in the XIX century. The building is an example of classical architecture, inside which there is a national museum with priceless artifacts. Here you can see gold postmortem masks, minted silver cups, bronze helmets, and collections of coins.

Tetovo

Tetovo is a city in northwest Macedonia, located at the foot of the Šar Mountains. It was founded around the Church of the Holy Virgin in the XIII century as a small Orthodox town. But, already in the XIV century, the Ottoman Empire conquered these lands, after which the rapid construction of mosques, baths, and markets began. The monastery of the Islamic order of Bektashi dervishes — the Arabati Baba Teḱeand and the Decorated Mosque (Šarena Džamija) remained to this day. There are many cozy cafes in Tetovo, the owners of which offer to taste local dishes — do not deny yourself this pleasure.

description.en: Malta is a unique island state in Europe, located at the crossroads of not only European and African trade routes but also various cultures. If Italy's borders resemble a shoe, Malta's borders look like a trail left by this very shoe. Indeed, not only Italy left its mark in the history and culture of Malta. Turkey, France, led by Napoleon, and of course, Great Britain, whose colony the country had been until the 70s of the XX century, have also left their marks. Fans of ancient architecture, as well as divers, yachtsmen, and climbers, will find here entertainment to their liking. Malta is ideal for all types of recreation and is ready to welcome tourists all year round.

geography.en: The country has only maritime borders. The closest neighbors by sea are Italy and Tunisia, as well as numerous islands in Greece. Malta is the largest island of the archipelago. The islands of Gozo and Comino are also considered inhabited. The islands of Saint Paul and Filfla, Cominotto, Filfoletta are so tiny that no one lives there. Malta is considered to be the smallest state in Europe, which is only 27 km long and 15 km wide. Gozo is half as little, and Comino is barely 2 km long. It is the only country in Europe without natural rivers and lakes. The typical landscape of Malta is the numerous steep stone slopes that attract climbers from all over the world. The highest point, Ta' Dmejrek peak, reaches a height of only 253 meters. Malta is divided into six districts, three regions, and 68 municipalities.

long_description.en:
Despite the tiny size of the state, there are still big cities here. The density of historical buildings per square meter here is so high that not only individual sights are under UNESCO protection, but the whole town. 

Valletta

Valletta is the capital of the island state of Malta, which was founded back in the XVI century by the Order of the Knights of St. John making it one of the largest and oldest ports in the Mediterranean. The name of the city is directly linked to the founding knight, Jean Parisot de la Valletta. He also led an army that protected the port from the Turkish invasion. This fortress city is so densely built up with castles and ancient architectural structures, which have been preserved in their original form, that it was fully included in the program of protection of the World Organization UNESCO. Because the streets in Valletta are very narrow, locals and tourists travel here mainly on foot or in horse-drawn carriages. However, the capital is worth visiting not only for fans of ancient architecture but also for all those who want to learn English. Due to the long stay in the status of a British colony, English is the second state language in Malta. Valletta offers a large number of schools, colleges, gymnasiums, and universities, which annually admit hundreds of thousands of students from around the world. 

Mdina

Mdina is the former capital of Malta, with only 306 inhabitants. It has many palaces, cathedrals, a unique city gate, and a variety of museums that tell the story of the past of the Knights of the Order of Malta. You can access the city-fortress through the City and the Greek Gates. It's an interesting fact that locals walked through the City Gate, and only slaves walked through the Greek Gate. Despite its tiny size, Mdina has an impressive number of palaces: Vilhena Palace, Xara Palace, Palazzo Santa Sofia, Palazzo Inguanez. All buildings were erected in 1726-1729. In the past, the constructions were barracks and hospitals, and today some of them have been converted into hotels, while others are home to noble Maltese families. The cathedral in Mdina is wrapped in secrets and legends. This is where Paul the Apostle, who arrived in Malta after his shipwreck, supposedly stayed. A majestic and silent city — this is the name of the first capital of Malta, which is worth visiting for all fans of solitude and thoughtful rest.

Sliema

Sliema used to be a small fishing village in the past. It has now become the main recreation and shopping center in Malta. It is home to dozens of modern hotels for tourists, and the holiday season lasts all year round. The Roman Catholic past greatly influenced the architecture of the city. Typical cathedrals, palaces, and baroque towers are scattered throughout the city. Fort Tigné was erected to protect the city from the French invasion in 1793-1795. It is one of the oldest polygonal defensive structures in the world. It is in excellent condition nowadays and attracts tourists from all over the world. In addition to historical buildings, there is a luxurious waterfront with a monument "White Shadows". The carved human silhouettes cast white shadows only early in the morning or in winter when the sun is very low. Not many people know about this feature of the monument. 

Saint Julian's

Saint Julian's is a resort city located along the Mediterranean coast, close to the capital of Malta, where many tourists strive for recreation. Due to the mild climate, the island state is also popular in winter. St. Julians is famous for its luxurious hotels and bustling parties. The resort has the well-preserved buildings of the past, numerous chapels, and churches, as well as the renowned monument of Love, set on the waterfront. It represents large inverted letters LOVE. To see the inscription correctly, you need to look at the reflection in the water. By the way, not many tourists know about this trick. Palazzo Dragonara, Spinola Palace, and Lapsi Church are the main architectural sights of the city. The Cathedral of Our Lady of Mount Carmel is another iconic place. The majestic building in Neo-Gothic style is located on the shore of a picturesque bay on the promenade. St. Julians is an ideal resort for young people and gamblers, as here you shall find the largest casinos in the country. 

Mellieha

Mellieha is a popular tourist destination where historical ensembles of sanctuaries and palaces meet together with luxurious hotels and resorts. One of the main attractions of Mellieja is the Grotto of Madonna. Pilgrims from all over the world come here to see the shrine. There is a statue of the Virgin Mary inside the natural cave, illuminated by hundreds of candles. Moreover, there is also a brook in the grotto, which, according to legends, is considered to be miraculous. It can be accessed at any time of day, unlike other churches that only open their doors during divine services. In addition to the traditional Roman Catholic churches, there is the Għadira Nature Reserve, where migratory birds live. Tourists can also visit the numerous towers scattered throughout the city, Fort Campbell and Armier Bay, where pirates used to rest.

description.en: Moldova is a cozy country where majestic churches have settled down in a shadow of dense maples and acacia, the country where medieval fortresses and ancient noble manors have remained till now. In Moldova, you will find a huge selection of excellent local wines, each of them with its own unique bouquet. But few people know that Moldova is famous not only for its grapevines. It provides essential oils for many producers of cosmetics in Europe and the USA. Have you never seen a plantation of lavender, rose, or sage? Then you should go to Moldova.

geography.en: The Republic of Moldova is a landlocked state in Eastern Europe, bordering Romania and Ukraine. The landscape in Moldova is hilly-like; there are no high mountains here. There are few forests, as most of the area is used for agriculture. There are many rivers in the country, the largest of which are the Dniester and Prut, which is the border with Romania. The Moldovan authorities do not control part of Moldova's territory (12%) in the east of the country. There is the Pridnestrovian Moldavian Republic (PMR), which is not recognized by the international community. Administratively, Moldova is divided into 32 districts, 13 municipalities, and an autonomous unit of Gagauzia.

long_description.en:
Chisinau

Chisinau is the capital of Moldova and its largest city, which is home to about 23% of the total population of the country. It is the main hub of the political, financial, and commercial life of the country, its cultural and educational center. It has the main museums and theatres of Moldavia, and there is also an organ hall. There are many restaurants and cafes, supermarkets and small shops in the city. Architecturally, the city is quite diverse. Here you can find fascinating buildings of pre-revolutionary and Soviet period, and in the upper part of the town, you will come across very extraordinary modern skyscrapers. The ancient Orthodox temples should be specially noted among the historical monuments. There are 23 lakes within the city borders, and not far from its outskirts, there is the Ghidighici Reservoir. In addition, Chisinau is one of the greenest cities in Europe, and its magnificent Botanical Garden has more than 10 thousand species of plants. Wide streets dressed in green velvet, numerous parks and squares, bright flower beds, and romantic lakes turned Chisinau into a wonderful place for a quiet family holiday.

Bender

If you are interested in history and come to Moldova, you should definitely visit Bender. It is an ancient city, first mentioned in 1408. It is located on the left bank of the Dniester River and is now part of the PMR. Bender is the main port on the Dniester River, a major railway junction, and a city of manufacturing. There are not many sights there, except for several memorials to the victims of various wars — from the Russian-Turkish wars to the civil war of 1991-1992. But there is the Bendery Fortress within the city's borders, which attracts tourists here. It was built back in the XVI century by the Turks to control Bessarabia, and until the second half of the XVIII century, it had been invincible. Then, during several wars with the Turks, it was taken three times by the Russian troops. The fortress has a large area, it is well-preserved to this day, and since 2008, it has been reconstructed in the PMR. 

Balti

Balti is a large industrial center, the second-largest city in the country by population, which is called the "northern capital" of Moldova. Balti is crossed by the Raut River and its inlets Rautel, Copăceanca, and Flemynde. The city's central square is one of the largest in Europe. There are several ancient and modern temples in Balti. They include the delightful Saint Constantine and Elena Cathedral, as well as the very beautiful and unusual modern Archangels Michael and Gabriel Church. The town has enough good restaurants and cafes with national, European, and Japanese cuisines. In general, Balti is a very cozy city. 

Tiraspol

Tiraspol is the capital of the unrecognized PMR. Despite the difficulties caused by the economic isolation of the republic, the city continues to develop. In recent years, new modern buildings have been erected here. In general, Tiraspol does not overwhelm with architectural beauty, most of the buildings date back to the Soviet period, but the city is clean and tidy. There are several impressive monuments in the town, particularly to the Russian commander Suvorov. In any case, it's curious to see how the unrecognized republic lives. 

Soroca

Soroca is a small ancient town, located on the right bank of the Dniester River, may compete with Chisinau for the title of the greenest city in the country and Europe, and it is still unknown who will win. The city is literally drowning in greenery. Despite its modest size, the city will please tourists with a number of interesting buildings, though modern. And its pearl is the Soroca Fort, built by the ruler of the Moldavian Principality Stephen the Great, at the end of the XV century.

description.en: The Principality of Monaco is a microstate that selected the picturesque shores of the Ligurian Sea. This country is a luxury resort in the south of France. Here, day and night, people place bets in one of the most famous casinos in the world, the motors of Formula 1 cars roar, the purest sea sparkles (by the way, there are no jellyfishes in it!), expensive yachts are moored, and wealthy people throw mind-blowing parties. Not everyone can afford a holiday in Monaco, but travelers are drawn here to stroll through the picturesque streets under the majestic slopes of the Alps!

geography.en: Monaco is second in size and first in the density of population per square meter. The country is surrounded by France on all sides. Many people do not even single it out as a separate state. The borders of Monaco and its city coincide. The city-state is divided into ten administrative districts, which are closely intertwined. There is currently a project in progress of the 11th district. To make it happen, the country reclaiming its territory by the sea.

long_description.en:
Monaco City

Monaco City is the capital of the Principality and one of the most populated cities in the world. The main attractions are collected in the Old Town, at the top of Saint-Antoine: the luxurious white-stone Prince's Palace of Monaco, where the royal family lives, the Oceanographic Museum, which had been headed by Jacques-Yves Cousteau himself for some time, one of the oldest buildings of the city — Chapel of Mercy and Monaco Cathedral of Saint Nicholas. It's a pleasure to walk along the winding streets of Monaco-Ville. Every building here is an architectural and historical monument. Chic mountain landscapes and salty sea breeze will add some extra euphoria.

Monte Carlo

Monte Carlo is a city celebrated in cinematography, a luxurious town of betting of the black. In the XIX century, Prince Charles III Grimaldi built a casino on a hill, among the sheep pastures. Since then, it is a favorite place for the power players, who arrive at the palace not in coaches, but in the gorgeous cars. Monte Carlo has the best restaurants and the most expensive hotels in the Principality, high-fashion houses and glamorous clubs. In addition to being the center of the gambling industry, Monte Carlo has established itself as an elite resort on the Côte d'Azur. There is a belief that only in Monaco, you can get an even tan without painful burns. So hurry up to the accessible municipal beach of Larvotto and start soaking in some vitamin D. 

La Condamine

While residents and visitors spend their fortunes in Monte Carlo and show off their intelligence at festivals in Monaco, the La Condamine area is responsible for the economy of the whole country. Respectable and balanced, it is an incredible contrast to other districts. Here you can find the headquarters of banks and large companies, key businesses, and shopping malls. La Condamine is a real business-machine. And it looks like it's not going to stop. Every year, the area grows due to artificial mounds. La Condamine will please you with its prices: compared to the luxury resorts of Monaco, restaurants, and hotels are much more budget-friendly. And there's plenty to see here too: the oldest Port Hercule in the Principality's districts; the Pedestrian Street Rue Princess Caroline with orange trees; St. Nicholas Cathedral, known as the tomb of the princes of Monaco. 

Fontvieille

The phenomenon of Fontvieille is that the locals conquered its land from the sea. The contrast between Fontvieille and other parts of Monaco is evident to you. It looks more like a country village than an advanced industrial center, as it is generally considered. The Italians and the French love this quiet harbor. Partying here is less noisy than sporting events. Football matches at the Stade Louis II, international athletics starts, and mountaineering competitions gather thousands of fans. Amateurs and professionals have fun conquering the steep cliffs of Grimaldi. Top attractions in Fontvieille also include hang-gliding. And for those who prefer an educational and lazy holiday, the doors of museums and city parks are always open.

description.en: The Kingdom of Norway is a European country that stretches from head to tail on the "back" of the Scandinavian peninsula. This country gave skiing to the world, has equal labor rights for women and men, awards the Nobel Peace Prize, and deposits the income from the oil industry for the Global State Pension Fund.

geography.en: Norway occupies the western part of the Scandinavian peninsula. The Kingdom also owns a large number of nearby islands, the Svalbard archipelago, the islands of Jan Mayen and Bear in the Arctic Ocean, and Bouvet Island in the south of the Atlantic. Under the 1961 Convention, Norway lays claim to Peter I Island and Queen Maud Land in Antarctica. Unofficially, Norway is divided into five tourist regions: Northern Norway, Trøndelag, Western Norway, Østlandet, and Sørlandet. They stretch along a narrow strip along the Norwegian Sea, evenly sharing the most exciting sights among themselves.

long_description.en:
Oslo

Start your adventure in Oslo, the capital of Norway. The city, like all Scandinavia, is quite restrained and simple, although this doesn't detract from its northern charm. In Oslo, you won't find the fancy bohemian architectural forms that other European capitals are rich in. With a rather modest baseline, the Norwegians were able to create a city with a zest. You'll probably be interested to see the futuristic Opera House, partially sunken into the water, the classic building of the Norwegian Parliament, the elegant halls of the City Hall, and the graffiti-painted Grünerløkka quarter. You should also definitely visit Ekebergparken Sculpture Park, Munch Museum, the Kon-Tiki, and Fram Museums, dedicated to Viking ships.

Bergen

The North Sea coast is home to Bergen, the former capital of Norway and the current "capital of rains", with 270 days of rainfall a year. It is at least worth stopping by for a stroll along the UNESCO World Heritage Quay of Bryggen. It is a merchant's quarter with facades facing the sea that dates back to the Hanseatic League era. At the very least, you can eat the freshest seafood bought at the Fish Market and feed the gulls at Lake Lille Lungegårdsvannet in the city park. It makes sense to take the funicular to Mount Fløyen, which offers fabulous views of the furry hills and bright houses of the city. If you're lucky enough to get to a concert by the famous Bergen Symphony Orchestra, you'll have a real treat!

But there's more to it than that. Bergen is a living "gateway to the kingdom of fjords." This is where all sorts of sea tours along the coast of Norway begin. Whether it's a tour of the nearby fjords for a couple of hours or a full trip to Hardanger and Sognefjord for a few days - the captain of the ship is waiting for you in Bergen.

Røros

Back in 1644, the mining town, which managed to preserve its unique atmosphere to this day, was founded in the mountains of Norway. We are talking about Røros — a living museum, a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Tourists are attracted here by the serenity floating over the smooth surface of picturesque lakes and rivers, the majesty of the mountains hanging over their heads, and a thick, slender forest, drowned in the mist. The town with a dozen authentic wooden houses does not have much entertainment. In winter, locals offer dog sledding trips, and in summer, cycling along the mountain trails. And we recommend taking the legendary M/S Fæmund ferry on Lake Femund, Norway's third-largest.

Tromsø

Tromsø is the main city of Northern Norway. In summer, the sun shines here around the clock, and in winter, the sky is bursting with the magical waves of northern lights. There are many bars, night clubs, restaurants, and discos in the city, where the local brewery has been supplying an excellent drink for 100 years. The Arctic Cathedral is the irreplaceable symbol of Tromsø, a work of architectural art that looks like an iceberg. The International Film Festival and Northern Lights Festival should be included in the cultural program of the city, and families with children are recommended to visit the polar zoo.

Just outside the city limits, the wild polar nature begins. Climbers come here to conquer the majestic Mount Støren; extreme climbers are attracted by hiking along the arctic ridge of the Lyngen Alps. For those who are not addicted to adrenaline rush, Tromsø organizes walks on foothill trails and cruises on the Lyngenfjord.

Stavanger

Stavanger is the largest city in Western Norway and the oil capital of the country. The town itself is better known for its surroundings. Here you can find one of the most famous Norwegian fjords — Lysefjord, with Preikestolen steep cliff hanging over it, which is also known as Pulpit Rock. From Stavanger, you can take trips to Rogaland County, where a huge Kjeragbolten stone is stuck between the Kjerag cliffs, at an altitude of 984 meters. 

Trondheim

In Trondheim, the city of students and the cultural capital of Norway, life hits the spotlight on the weekends. It is rich in sightseeing. Nidaros Cathedral, Scandinavia's oldest shrine, has been decorating Trondheim with its Gothic facades for over ten centuries. The green labyrinths of the northernmost Botanical Garden in the world are located nearby. The Music Museum is ready to share its knowledge about ancient musical instruments with everyone. Trondheim is the ideal city for leisurely walks and silent contemplation of the charming architecture that has grown against the background of unbridled Norwegian nature. So don't hesitate to visit! 

Ålesund

According to Norwegians, Ålesund is the most beautiful city. It was destroyed by a fire a hundred years ago and then rebuilt in the Art Nouveau style. One of the city trams can help you explore the fairy-like streets of Ålesund. It will rush you along the main attractions — Queen Sonja Square, Museum, City Park, and the only building that survived the fire. Make sure you climb the observation deck on Mount Aksla and visit the Atlantic Oceanarium, where you can take out the maritime inhabitants from the bottom of the sea, stroke the head of the stingrays, look at the two-meter-high Anarhichas and feel the sea cucumbers.

One of the most visited fjords in Norway, Geiranger Fjord, is 100 km from Ålesund. Here, the waterfalls of Seven Sisters, the Suitor, and the Bridal Veil cry with lush streams, the Flydalsjuvet Rock floating above the fjord's surface, and the unique mountain landscapes are strictly protected by UNESCO. 

Lillehammer

Lillehammer is cozily settled deep in the country, among the mountains. A Viking on skis, depicted on the emblem of the city, hints that Lillehammer is the center of skiing in Norway. In 1994, Lillehammer hosted the Winter Olympic Games, and today the resort of Sjusjøen is open to every lover of downhill skiing.

Lofoten Islands

The red houses of authentic villages, whale safaris (the ones where you go out for photo hunting), fishing, and the crystal purity of nature — all this is waiting for you in the Lofoten Islands. Here you can smell cod drying in the frosty arctic air, and the sky is decorated with satin ribbons of northern lights throughout winter. Rent a car and visit the cozy villages of Reine and Henningsvær, drive to the beaches of Uckland and Ramberg, and complete your journey with a pint of beer at the bar in the village with the short name of Å.

description.en: Portugal is the westernmost country in continental Europe. Like any ocean-front state, it breathes freedom, shines with the sun, and enjoys life every day. People here love football and good wine, always stop to admire the sunset and spend five minutes talking about nothing. Many people used to call Portugal "the Sleeping Beauty of Europe", but to tell the truth, it has already washed its face and drinks coffee, ready to take one of the first places in the contest of the most popular countries of the continent.

geography.en: The Portuguese Republic occupies the south-western part of the Iberian Peninsula. Spain is its only neighbor, and the Atlantic Ocean washes its shores. The country's territory is divided into northern, central, metropolitan, and southern regions, as well as the island of Madeira and the Azores. Despite its modest size, recreation conditions here are very diverse. The architecture, landscapes, atmosphere, and even the weather are radically different.

long_description.en:
Lisbon

Lisbon is the capital of Portugal. It is a city of inspiration, warm sun, white and blue facades, and red roofs. There's no need to worry about getting lost. Whichever alley you turn in, you're in the right place: on the terrace of the ancient Pastéis de Belém or by the Rua Augusta Arch on the Praça do Comercio, under the broken vaults of the Carmo Convent or by the white walls of the majestic Basilica da Estrela. So, get lost and remember that Lisbon is a city of aesthetic walks, where life is at the moment. Here's a grey Portuguese man who sells hand-made ceramics in an old shop near the Feira da Ladra, further up the hill, like a crown, tower the high walls of the Moorish castle of São Jorge. In the evening, the stone streets of Alfama, which until recently had been ringing the horns of traditional yellow trams, are filled with melancholy Fado tunes. 

Sintra

Lisbon is hard to get tired of, but for a change, we recommend a day trip to Sintra, the favorite holiday destination of the Portuguese kings. The panorama of this city seems to have come down from the pages of the fairytale of princesses and dragons. On the green hills, in the foggy forests, you can see the towers of family estates, the walls of fortresses, and ancient castles. At the very top stands the pearl of Sintra, the Pena Palace. Its bright facades witnessed the fall of the monarchy a hundred years ago and today provide a popular background for Instagram's pictures. Absolutely opposite in its atmosphere, the mystical Quinta da Regaleira hides in the dense park, famous for its secret underground passages, inverted towers, and Masonic stories. There is a lighthouse 20 minutes away from Sintra. There is a stele underneath it, which declares: "You are on the edge of Europe." This is Cape Roca, where the wind throws the dust of the ocean in your face, the height of the rocks make you dizzy, and the borderless Atlantic gives you hope for a promising future.

Porto

Porto lives in the north of Portugal, the region where the independence of this sunny country was born. The portrait of this city is intoxicating: the ancient, half-ruined estates laid down by the founders adjoin the restored glossy villas, the azulejo paintings on the facades look spectacular against the backdrop of massive iron bridges, and the labyrinths of the streets lead to the wine shops, where port wine flows over the edge. Once upon a time, it was this city that inspired J. Rowling to write Harry Potter. Perhaps, the view of fog-shrouded Porto from the window of an old wooden tram running to the ocean will inspire you to magic too?

Coimbra

Coimbra is the former capital of Portugal and the current university city. Here, one architectural monument stands on the other one, and the landscapes of the streets are so beautiful that you unintentionally start to regret that you do not know how to photograph with your eyes. Coimbra is the cradle of the Portuguese mentality when they sing the most soulful Fado and know everything about Saudade. Such regalia obliges the city to keep its face, but only until sunset: at night, it explodes with students' parties and festivals.

Algarve

If you are looking for a family holiday destination, do not hesitate to choose the Algarve. It is the southernmost region in Portugal. It smells of freedom, oranges, and almond plantations. The largest city in the Algarve is Faro. This resort can boast of gorgeous sandy beaches and lagoons, luxury hotels and golf courses, cozy fish restaurants, and authentic architecture. Make sure your cultural program includes the Estoi Palace in Rococo style, and Igreja do Carmo — a temple made of gold leaf and a luxurious example of Baroque architecture. The water park and Zoomarine Park are worth visiting with children. If you are looking for a party to crash, you should take a trip to neighboring Albufeira or Portimão.

Azores

Portugal has its own treasure chest. It is the Azores, an archipelago of nine islands in the rebellious waters of the Atlantic Ocean. There's almost no civilization here, and to tell you the truth, you won't need it at all. After all, the Azores are designed to breathe to the fullest extent, to look at the underwater world with a tank behind your back, climbing caves, in the depths of which the underground geysers beat, roam on the edge of the crater of the volcano and scuba dive with cachalots and whales in the waters of the archipelago.

Madeira

Eco-tourism, surfing, gastro-tourism, diving, a cultural program, and lazy beach relaxation — this is a short list of opportunities Madeira offers you. A lush green island towers over the ocean a thousand kilometers off the coast of Europe. The capital of Madeira is the city of Funchal. It will captivate you from your first stroll through its ancient streets: the fantastic garden of the Colonial Quinta do Palheiro and Orchid Garden, the Fort of São Tiago, and the Cathedral from Funchal (Sé), the picturesque Cape Cabo Girao and the Valley of the Nuns. The only drawback of the resort is that there are no equipped beaches at all. If you want to sunbathe, you'll have to go to the neighboring island of Porto Santo.

description.en: Romania is one of the most mysterious countries in the world, as the legends say that this is where the famous vampire — Count Dracula used to live. Mystical stories are not the only highlight of this European country. Tourists are happy to come here to admire the picturesque nature, walk around ancient castles, enjoy fascinating excursions, visit healing resorts, or relax on the coast of the Black Sea. Low prices are another reason to come to Romania. This country is called one of the cheapest in Europe.

geography.en: The Republic of Romania is located in the south-eastern part of Europe. The Carpathian Mountains go through the whole country, and there is access to the Black Sea. The closest neighbors are Ukraine, Moldova, Hungary, Serbia, and Bulgaria.According to the administrative division, Romania consists of 8 development regions, which, in turn, are divided into 41 județes and one municipality (Bucharest).If we talk about historical regions, we can distinguish the following ones in Romania: Wallachia (or Muntenia). This is where the country's capital is located, as well as the main ski resorts are concentrated. This area is also famous for the Transfăgărășan highway, Lake Vidraru, the towns of Targoviste and Curtea de Argeș.Transylvania. The most popular region in terms of tourism, because this is where the famous Dracula Castle is located. In addition, this part of the country is renowned for its untouched nature, ancient towns, and ancient churches, which are under UNESCO protection.Dobruja. This region is well known to tourists who come to Romania for beach holidays. There is also the famous Danube Delta, an incredibly picturesque National Park.Banat. It is located in the western part of the country and is considered to be the most developed region. The main features of these areas are steep rocks, beautiful cities, and ancient German settlements.Maramureș. This region is the northernmost in Romania. Tourists love it for its beautiful spirit of antiquity. There are small towns with wooden churches, and the locals still keep and honor the ancient traditions.

long_description.en:
Bucharest

Bucharest is a small Paris with its own Arch de Triumph. A city that sits on seven hills. The town where ancient buildings, the houses of the times of socialism, and modern constructions which amaze imagination are intertwined together. Bucharest is "the city of joy", as its name is translated from Romanian. It is worth starting your acquaintance with the capital from the Old Town, where all the most exciting things are concentrated — the Arch de Triumph, the Palace of Parliament (the biggest in the world), and Revolution Square. For relaxation and unity with nature, the capital has numerous gardens and parks — Botanical Garden, Cișmigiu Park, Carol Park, and others. When you come to Bucharest, you cannot ignore the city museums. The most interesting expositions will be offered by the National Museum of the Romanian Peasant and the Museum of History, Village, Art, and Technology. For travelers with children, Bucharest has a Science Museum, an extreme park, a circus, and a small zoo.

Brasov

Brasov is the heart of Transylvania and just a beautiful city, which is cozily located in a narrow valley surrounded by mountains. You should start your acquaintance with a simple walk, as this is the only way to feel the atmosphere of the Middle Ages, which reigns here. Narrow streets, tiled-roof houses, ancient churches — every square meter of the city is imbued with history. The most famous attraction here is Bran Castle or Dracula Castle. It is the former residence of Queen Maria of Romania, but the legend says that this is where the famous vampire lived. The guides will tell you the details of whether he lived here one night or several months. Besides the castle, in Brasov, you can admire the St. Bartholomew Evangelical church(1223), visit the Saint Nicholas Church, and even sit at the desk of the first Romanian school. Another highlight of the city is an amazingly beautiful nature. The mountain peaks offer incredible views of the surrounding countryside.

Sighișoara

Sighișoara is one of the most beautiful cities in Romania, which has been on the UNESCO World Heritage List since 1999. You should go to the Citadel, which dates back to the XII century, to see all the most exciting places. Here you should definitely visit the Clock Tower, where the Historical Museum is located, as well as the observation deck, which offers stunning views of the city. A tourist should also check out the Gothic-style Lutheran Church, the black and white Orthodox Church across the river from the Citadel, the Museum of Medieval Arms and the Vlad Dracul House. July is an ideal time to visit Sighișoara when the city hosts a colorful medieval festival with concerts and performances. 

Constanța

Constanța is the largest port on the Black Sea, a beautiful and surprisingly green resort town. Tourists come here for quiet beach rest. However, the cultural program here, too, can be very diverse. The port of Constanta, where ancient Greek and Ottoman ships stand, is an excellent place to start. Religious monuments, museums of the history of nature, archeology, navigation, ethnography, astronomy also deserve attention. Another highlight of the resort is the casinos, which were built in the early XX century. Travelers with children will not be bored in Constanta. They can always attend a dolphinarium, aquarium, or planetarium to diversify their leisure time.

Sibiu

Sibiu is the most important cultural and religious center of Romania, located in Transylvania. The magic of the city begins in the historic center, where the streets are lined with paving stones, and the architecture is striking with its splendor. The territory of Sibiu can be divided into five parts: Large Square, Small Square, Upper Town, Lower Town, Suburbs. Each, in its own way, is beautiful and can boast of unique sights. The Council Tower, with an observation platform, the Catholic Cathedral, Blue House, Bridge of Liars, the Orthodox Cathedral of the Holy Trinity, and about a dozen other museums and a zoo. You should devote at least two days to a visit to Sibiu.

description.en: The Republic of San Marino is a microstate with an area of only 61 km². It is located on the border of the Italian provinces of Emilia-Romagna and Marche. San Marino is the first republic in Europe. According to a legend, an independent settlement was established here in the IV century, founded by the stonecutter Marin. The capital of the state, having the same name, nestled on the slope of Monte Titano. The mountain is topped with three towers — they are the symbol of the state. The center of the capital is Freedom Square, where the government building is located. The main temple of the country is considered to be the Basilica of San Marino, constructed in 1838 on the site of the church, which was once built by the legendary Marin. And the oldest is the Chiesa di San Francesco, founded in the XIV century. In general, there are many ancient buildings, museums, and monuments, and they are scattered throughout the tiny country. Monte Titano and the center of San Marino are UNESCO World Heritage sites.

The territory of the country contains the treasures of several civilizations: the ancient Celts and Romans lived here, then the Ottomans and the Austro-Hungarians. Thanks to such a rich national composition residing on its territory, this country allows you to feel the spirit of global history, as well as relax with your soul. Serbia is an excellent option for tourists who cannot decide what is more important for them in their new journey. The beaches, mountains, attractions, services, and reasonable prices — this country has everything and does not require any choice. In addition, the ski resort is available at any time of year, due to the subalpine microclimate. Numerous natural complexes with lakes and healing springs with mineral water facilitate the recovery of the organism and the accumulation of internal energy.

geography.en: The Republic of Serbia is located in South-Eastern Europe and is landlocked. It borders Hungary in the north, Romania in the north-east, Bulgaria in the east, Northern Macedonia in the south, Albania, and Montenegro in the south-west, Croatia in the west and Bosnia and Herzegovina in the west. The Danube is the main river, 588 km long, carrying the waters of the Tisa, Sava, Morava, and Drina. Approximately 80% of the territory is a part of the Balkan Peninsula; the other 20% is the Pannonian Basin. There are four mountain systems in Serbia, most of them are in the west — the Dinaric Alps, in the east — the Balkan mountain range and the Serbian Carpathians, and the Morava River in between. In the south, you can see the ancient mountains — part of the Rila–Rhodope Massif. Gjeravica is the highest mountain in Serbia (2656 meters).Serbia is divided into 29 districts, which in turn are divided into cities and communities. According to the Constitution, the country includes two autonomous regions, Kosovo and Metohija, as well as Vojvodina.

long_description.en:
Belgrade

Belgrade is a "phoenix city" that has been repeatedly burned and reconstructed. The tourist Belgrade starts with Belgrade Fortress, located on the banks of the Danube and the Sava. There used to be numerous barracks here, but now it has a picturesque park and a unique historical museum complex, with various weapons, a powder depository, and a symbol of the city — a monument to the Victory over the Turks. The history and heritage of the Balkan Peninsula can be found in the National Museum of Belgrade, built in 1844. There are guides on the territory, who will tell about the history, art, and outstanding personalities. In 1952, a museum was opened in Belgrade, dedicated to the life and work of Nikola Tesla, who was born in Serbia. Within the walls of this building, there are many personal belongings of the scientist, original documents that he himself bequeathed to the city after his death. Among the architectural structures, the Church of Saint Sava is absolutely striking. The prototype of this church is Hagia Sophia in Istanbul.

Novi Sad

Novi Sad is a peaceful city, which creates a bright contrast to the capital. It is the second-largest city in Serbia, located on the right bank of the Danube. In the XVIII and XIX centuries, it was an important trading and manufacturing center, for which it was nicknamed "Serbian Athens". The old part of the city is the center of churches and temples: Orthodox, Roman Catholic, Protestant, Uniate, synagogues, and mosques. Petrovaradin Fortress is the symbol of the city. It is a large fortification erected in 1692 by the Austrians during the war with the Turks. For a measured and peaceful rest, you can walk in the Fruška Gora National Park, which has acquired its status thanks to the presence of rare trees and shrubs.

Niš

Niš is the oldest city in the Balkans, which has been considered to be the gateway between East and West since ancient times. The main attraction is the Nis fortress, which the city inherited from the Romans' conquest of its territory. In ancient times, the fortress was an important strategic object during the war. Today, it is an excellent venue for the Nišville summer jazz festival. Since the invasion of the Turks, Ćele kula, Skulls Tower, has been located here. To terrify their enemies, the Turks built a kind of tower out of Serbian skulls and stones. Now this place is accessible to any visitor. Of course, the object is not for the faint-hearted, but very important for the Serbs — a symbol of fearlessness and patriotism of their people.

Kragujevac

Kragujevac is a bustling university city, scientific and industrial center of the country. When you visit, you should visit the cultural-historical complex Milosev Venac, where buildings erected between 1818-1841 have been preserved. The Amici Palace, the only palace that has survived since the reign of Prince Milos, deserves special attention among the buildings. If you want to take a walk in the fresh air, head to the Grand Park, which covers more than 10 hectares. Here you can walk along the shore of Bubanj Lake, a beautiful area with numerous benches and cozy cafes.

Kruševac

Kruševac is a small town with charming sights: medieval ruins of the times when the city was founded and the church in which the heart of Nikolay Raevsky rests. You can start your walk from the Old Town of King Lazar to see the Church of the Holy First Martyr Stephen, built in the XIV century in Moravian style. Not far away, there is a shady city park. Here, in July, the Serbian festival of Guslars is held, where you can listen to ethnic music and get acquainted with the traditions and customs of the people.

Subotica

Subotica is a very clean and green city, with a huge number of cafes, restaurants and pedestrian streets, located literally on the border with Hungary. For a cultural experience, you should visit the Gallery of Modern Art, located in the Reichle Palace, one of the most beautiful buildings in Subotica. The Hungarian-style City Hall is most impressive in the evening, illuminated by city lights. On the ground floor, there is a city museum and a souvenir shop. You can climb the Town Hall Tower and see the city from a height of 45 meters. Another attraction is the synagogue, built in the Art Nouveau style. For a more relaxing outdoor experience, we would recommend the beautiful Palić lake surrounded by the park.

description.en: Slovakia is the geographical center of Europe and a country with no megalopolises, but with the most preserved castles from the XIII-XVII centuries protected by UNESCO. It is the birthplace of the parachute. Moreover, Slovakia is the homeland of the father and mother of the famous American artist Andy Warhol. The nature of Slovakia impresses with its diversity and offers a varied recreation for fans of ski resorts, rafting enthusiasts, and lovers of measured wellness activities. Slovakia welcomes tourists not only with its enchanting scenery but also with cultural traditions, interesting cuisine, and even weather.

geography.en: The Slovak Republic is located in the eastern part of Central Europe. Its neighbors are the Czech Republic, Poland, Ukraine, Hungary, and Austria. The country is landlocked but also has a developed river connection. The largest rivers in Slovakia are the Tisza, Danube, Morava, and Vah. The territory of the country is mainly hilly. The Western Carpathians surround it in the north and north-east. The highest and most popular mountains are the High Tatras, where the highest point reaches 2655 m (Gerlachovský štít). The country consists of 8 kraje, each one bearing the same name as its main center. In turn, the kraje are divided into districts (79 in Slovakia), and those districts are divided into communities.

long_description.en:
Despite the fact that there are no cities with a population of 1 million or more in Slovakia, their atmosphere and spirit only benefit from it. Cozy streets, ancient castles, and a lot of amazing discoveries await you in any city in Slovakia.

Bratislava

Bratislava, the "secret pearl of the Danube", is located so close to Vienna that, until 1945, a regular tram had run between the two cities. It is a classic European capital with the Old Town, cozy restaurants with home-style cuisine, and an abundance of cycling paths. The capital of Slovakia is a small pedestrian city. It will take no more than 20 minutes to see the beauty and get around the whole center. Picturesque streets are stretching from the center of the city, and a couple of kilometers away, you can already see green meadows, farms, and vineyards. The city is located in the heart of Europe, which allows you to build many combined routes, visiting other famous capitals. There are mineral springs, ski resorts, and interesting leisure activities for tourists of all ages.

Košice

Košice is situated in the east of Slovakia, surrounded by medieval castles, the XIII-century fortress walls, and churches. Its location close to the borders of Hungary, Poland, Ukraine, and the Czech Republic makes it possible to build a convenient route for visiting European cultural centers.
