The transport system is well-developed, and there are many road routes in different directions. Košice has an unofficial title of the capital of youth. Students live here, and the average age of the local population does not exceed 35 years. Despite its status, the city has preserved an incredible amount of antiquity. The whole central street is a protected monument of the past, with the Gothic Cathedral of St. Elisabeth and Freedom Square. Košice has the only cold artesian water source in Europe — the Herl'any geyser. It erupts once every two days.

Trenčín

Trenčín extends to the west of Slovakia, along the river Vah. It was founded in the II century, on the site of the Roman legion Laugaricio. In 1790, the city experienced a devastating fire, during which many historical monuments were lost forever, but some architectural masterpieces managed to survive. Even today, tourists can admire the Piarist Church of St. Francis Xavier, see the Župný dom and the Katov dom, visit the Museum of Trenčín where archaeological finds and art objects from different centuries have been preserved. The heart of the city is the Trenčín Castle, built during the Moravian era. For a long time, it had been in a state of decay and had not been restored. Only 3 of its buildings have survived to nowadays, as. Not far from the town, there is the thermal Spa Nimnica, which has been in active use since 1959. The place is decorated with lakes and thick vegetation.

Banská Bystrica

Banská Bystrica is located in central Slovakia, in the valley of two rivers Hron and Nitra. The unique natural landscape attracts tourists more than historic buildings. The history of the town begins with a small village where several families of German colonists lived. After King Bela IV came to power, the place gained new rights and became the industrial center of the Hungarian kingdom. There are many ancient palaces, churches, the City Fortress, the St. Catherine's Church with five golden altars, the Kremnica Castle telling the story of the Slovak Uprising and other historical monuments. The convenient location allows you to get to Banská Bistrica from Bratislava and Košice.

Prešov

Prešov, just like many other cities in Slovakia, is located in a picturesque place where the two rivers Torysa and Sekčov merge. Since ancient times, Prešov has been a center of education and culture. You will have to gain strength while getting ready for sightseeing — about 300 types of historical and technical heritage have been preserved here. For example, there is a unique technical monument Solivar, where for the first time, salt was extracted from rapeseed by evaporation. When visiting the city, take a moment to explore the facades of the mansions of the XVIII century, one of the highest iconostases of the Greek Orthodox Cathedral, made in the style of Rococo and Lutheran Church of the XVII century. The early medieval castles of Saris and Kapušany and the famous slopes of the High Tatras are 15 km away.

High Tatras

It is impossible not to mention the High Tatras when talking about Slovakia. It is a place for those who love mountains and downhill skiing on the most picturesque slopes. Apart from skiing, there is also biking tourism, rafting down the Dunajec River, and wellness tours. The highest point is Gerlachovský štít (2655 m), waiting for the brave, and nature lovers will be able to appreciate the beauty of the Tatra National Park, where the Botanical Garden is located in the open air, as well as caves, museums and other masterpieces created by Mother Nature.

description.en: It looks like a country that has come off a postcard. This is what those who are lucky enough to be here often say about Slovenia. Mountain peaks covered with snow, alpine meadows, clear river waters, virgin forests, waterfalls, karst caves, and the gentle waves of the Adriatic Sea — nature has given all this wealth to this small country. There are also picturesque castles, medieval streets with neat houses under tiled roofs, ancient paving stones of city streets, and proud spires of cathedrals. Active recreation lovers will appreciate this country. Here they can enjoy both hiking tours and high-speed ski slopes.

geography.en: The Republic of Slovenia is situated in the pre-Alps part of the Balkan Peninsula. It borders Austria, Italy, Hungary, and Croatia. The Adriatic Sea washes its coastline that stretches for almost 50 kilometers. Geographically, Slovenia is divided into four regions. The first is the Alps mountains, which cover 42% of the country's territory. The highest point of the country and the national symbol depicted on the coat of arms and flag, Mount Triglav, is located here. The second is the Pannonian (or Middle Danube) Basin, a plain in the Danube basin that accounts for 28% of the territory. The third one is the Dinaric Highlands, which includes the Karst Plateau with its unique caves. And the fourth one is the Primorska Plateau, which includes Slovene Istria, several areas adjacent to the Adriatic coast, and the valleys of the Vipava and Soča rivers. Administratively, Slovenia is divided into 12 statistical regions and 210 communities, 11 of which have urban status.

long_description.en:
Ljubljana

Ljubljana is the capital of Slovenia. It is located almost in the heart of the country and is a convenient starting point for further trips. Locals call Ljubljana "the dragon city". The legend has it that Jason, the hero of the ancient Greek myths, performed his next heroic feat by killing a dragon in Ljubljana. Numerous sculptures and images scattered all over the city remind us of this. And the Dragon Bridge is guarded by four such creatures at once. The Ljubljana Castle, located on a hill, is worth exploring. As a reward for crossing 150 steps, you will enjoy a magnificent view of the city from the observation deck. Right at the foot of the hill lies the old town with its medieval streets and unique architecture. The Triple Bridge is another iconic place in the Slovenian capital. Coming out from one point on one bank, turning in a fan on the other, it goes to three different places. 

Maribor

Maribor is the second-largest city in the country. Just like in the capital, the castle of the XV century that now houses a museum attracts the attention of travelers here in the first place. Besides, the XVI century Town Hall, the XII century Gothic Saint John Baptist Cathedral, and Vodnik Square, where the market is open in the mornings, are waiting for tourists. Here, as a souvenir, you can buy a bottle of excellent local wine, for the production of which Maribor is famous. The local wine cellars are considered to be the largest in Central Europe, and there are vineyards by the river, which are 400 years old. Thanks to the vineyards, Maribor is listed in the Guinness Book of Records as the oldest city in the world, which produces wine uninterruptedly. Maribor will also be interesting for ski lovers, as there is one of the most popular ski centers in its surroundings — "Maribor Pohorje". And lovers of less active leisure will be offered unique healing therapies.

Celje

Celje is the third-largest city in Slovenia. The small and cozy town of Celje lies at the foot of a hill on which Celje Castle, one of the largest castles in the country, stands. In addition to it, Celje has interesting museums, ancient churches, and cozy parks. Three rivers merge right within the city limits, reinforcing the beauty of the human-made and the beauty of nature. In the vicinity of Celje, there is another tourist attraction, the 90-meter Rinka Falls. 

Koper

Koper is the largest seaside resort town and the main port in Slovenia. It is very close to Italy, so Italian speech can be heard here almost as often as Slovene. In the XIII century, Koper was part of Venice, and the Italian style appeared in local architecture from here. Some buildings, such as the Praetorian Palace and the Loggia Palace, have survived to this day. The oldest structure of the city, the Carmine Rotunda church, was built in the XII century, and another magnificent example of ancient architecture, the Cathedral of the Assumption of the Blessed Virgin Mary, was built in the XV century. By the way, previously the city was located on an island called Goat Island and only in 1825, was filled with a dam that connected it to the mainland and turned it into a peninsula. Although, up to now, the locals still divide the city into the mainland and island. 

Bled

"The Alpine Pearl" is what the people of Slovenia call the town of Bled. Situated on the slopes of the Alps, on the banks of an emerald lake, surrounded by dense forests, it fascinates with its splendor. The aristocracy loved to come here for holidays even back in the Middle Ages. In the XX century, it was the residence of Josip Broz Tito, the head of Yugoslavia. Today, Bled is a popular balneological resort with healing thermal spring water and unique microclimate. In winter, it is a ski resort. This town is also trendy among newlyweds. They come here to spend their honeymoon. A small island in the middle of the lake with a picturesque XVII century church attracts them. According to a legend, if a husband carries his wife in his arms up the 99 steps from the pier to the church, he will be very happy in his marriage. And the "bell of desire" of the church will make any dream come true for the couple. It is worth devoting some time to a tour of Bled Castle, one of the most beautiful and oldest castles in Slovenia. Its observation deck offers a fascinating view. 

Portorož

Portorož is the most fashionable resort in Slovenia. In Italian, the name of the city sounds like the "Port of Roses". They really do grow everywhere here. Recreational infrastructure is represented by SPA centers, beauty salons, unique springs with therapeutic mud, and thermal waters. People come here to relax and have fun on the beaches, in clubs, and water parks. Portorož is also famous for its casinos. Gambling lovers come here from all over the world, but the regulars here are still hot Italians. By the way, Portorož is a real paradise for the lovers of Mediterranean cuisine. 

Piran

Piran is a tiny town, which is located half an hour's walk from Portorož. And it's a must-visit place. It also once belonged to the Republic of Venice, which left its mark on its image. The city fascinates by the color of the Middle Ages and by the almost total absence of vehicles, as the streets of Piran are very narrow. It is worth visiting Tartini Square, St. George's Parish Church, with the hourly bells ringing, and the Maritime Museum.

description.en: Turkey is a welcoming and friendly country with an ancient history, fascinating sea and mountain landscapes. It offers attractions and leisure activities which can fit every taste: from beach holidays to visiting the oldest mosques and ruins of Roman amphitheaters. Turkey has everything for active tourism: diving, windsurfing, rafting, kayaking, canyons in the mountain gorges of Alanya, ski resorts of Uludağ and Kartalkaya, and the opportunity to fly with a paraglider or balloon over Cappadocia. If you are looking for more traditional and relaxing holiday options, Turkey will offer you sea cruises, walks in the pine forests of Kemer, hiking in the mountains, visiting the travertine of Pamukkale, and Cleopatra pools. It may sound trivial, but Turkey is a real paradise for tourists.

geography.en: The Republic of Turkey is territorially located in Southern Europe and Asia. The country has a diverse landscape — rocky mountains, forests, sandy beaches, and prairies. It is neighboring with Georgia, Armenia, Azerbaijan, Iran, Iraq, Syria, Greece, and Bulgaria. Four seas wash the coasts of Turkey: the Black, Mediterranean, Aegean, and Marble Seas, as well as the Bosporus and Dardanelles straits. The biblical River Euphrates flows in the west of the country. The highest mountain, Ararat, is located in the east. The mount is a symbol for Armenians and a subject of dispute between the two states. The administrative and territorial structure of Turkey has both official and unofficial divisions. As for the formal structure, it is divided into 81 provinces (il), which are administered by governors appointed by the state government. Provinces are divided into districts (ilçe), and there are 957 of them. The so-called statistical (unofficial) provinces consist of 7 regions: Marmara, Black Sea, Aegean, Mediterranean, Central Anatolia, Eastern Anatolia, and South-Eastern Anatolia.

long_description.en:
Turkey lives in its rhythm and traditions. Each city has its own flavor. Whichever destination you choose, make sure you plan a trip to an authentic Turkish bazaar, where you can feel the spirit of the country, and even literally taste it. 

Ankara

Ankara is the capital of Turkey. It is a resort city with an excellent infrastructure, entertainment centers, and outstanding architectural monuments of ancient times. The Temple of Augustus and Roman baths remind us about the period of the Roman Empire. Ankara Castle is an excellent example of architecture dating to the Byzantine period. Other significant sanctuaries of the city include the Alâeddin Mosque and the Hacı Bayram Veli Mosque. A tourist should not forget about the Ataturk Mausoleum Complex, which style belongs to modern architecture. And the atmospheric Mahmut Pasha Bazaar will show you real Turkey outside any time limits. 

Istanbul

Istanbul is the largest and most incredibly beautiful city in Turkey. It is located in the southern part of the Bosporus and the Golden Horn Bay in the Sea of Marmara. One part (the smaller one) lays in Asia, and the other one (main) is in Europe. Therefore, Istanbul is called a city with two civilizations and cultures. Istanbul combines the splendor of modern architecture with the grandeur of antiquity. The most famous symbols of the town are the Blue Mosque (Sultanahmet), Hagia Sophia (Ayasofya), where you can feel the atmosphere of the Golden Age, as well as a chic palace on the shore of the Bosporus known as Dolmabahçe. When you come to Ortakoy Marina, you can see the departure of the ships for a boat trip. If you join it, you can admire the city and its bridges, and see the famous Maiden Tower. Travelers with children will have a fun day at the Rahmi Koc Science and Transport Museum. Here you can get inside a submarine, an old tram, or a fire engine. Istanbul offers a wide range of incredibly delicious street food. Make sure you try the freshly caught and grilled fish at the Galata Bridge.

Izmir

Izmir is the third-largest city in Turkey, a resort on the bank of the Aegean Sea, a port and an industrial center. It has many ancient architectural monuments, the age of which is more than three thousand years. The agora of Smyrna is considered to be the main attraction. These are the ruins of an ancient market square. Kemeralti Market is believed to be the soul of Izmir. The traders have been selling their goods here for centuries. Hisar Mosque is the largest mosque in the city, made in the Ottoman style. It is located within a five-minute walk from the bazaar. Mount Pagos and the Kadifekale fortress offer the best views of the city to its guests.

Antalya

Antalya can be deservedly called the capital of resort recreation in Turkey. The city is located on the Mediterranean coast and is the center of the province of the same name. Holidaymakers love Antalya for its magnificent beaches, excellent infrastructure, and affordable hotels. History and antique lovers will not be bored here either. The city will offer them the Yivli Minare Mosque, Iskele, and Tekeli Mehmet Paşa Mosques, Hadrian's Gate (imagine, that it was constructed back in 130!), Atatürk's House Museum, the Archaeological Museum, the clock tower of Saat Kulesi. You can visit Kurshunlu and Duden waterfalls not far from Antalya. The resort is perfect for a vacation with children as it has two water parks and a dolphinarium.

Fethiye

Fethiye is another beautiful resort town. Due to the favorable climatic conditions and lack of wind, paragliding became one of the most popular attractions here. A slow paragliding descent from Mount Babadağ will give the most vivid sensations. Many people come to Fethiye for beach holidays. Moreover, photography, parasailing, kiting, rafting, diving, yachting, or jeep rallying can become a fascinating addition to it.

Bodrum

Bodrum is one of the gorgeous resort towns. It is located in the province of Mugla, in the Aegean Sea, in the north of the Gulf of Gökova. Bodrum is considered to be a youth resort as it has a record number of restaurants, nightclubs, and bars. Due to the frequent winds, this place is popular among surfers. Scandinavians, British, French, bohemians love spending their holidays in Bodrum.

Kemer

Kemer is a charming, quiet town. It is located near Antalya, on the turquoise sea coast, surrounded by pine forests and mountains. Clean air and sea landscapes will leave you with the most positive emotions from your journey. There are several amusement parks and simulators in Kemer. Moreover, there are diving centers for children and adults, which conduct dives to the shipwrecks.

Marmaris

Marmaris is another beautiful and the most European resort town. It is located in a closed bay at the junction of the Mediterranean and Aegean Seas. It offers a wide range of places to explore and things to do: an aquapark, a harbor for yachts, a fortress with a beautiful panorama of the bay and the city, nightclubs, bars, and restaurants. Marmaris is perfect for sailing, windsurfing, and water skiing.

description.en: The Faroe Islands is a secluded northern archipelago. It attracts travelers with its fantastic views of emerald fields with sheep pasturing on them, steel rocks, and the dark blue sea. Small villages with dollhouses astonish with their fairy-tale beauty. You can often come across houses around which there is nothing within a few tens of kilometers. The Faroe Islands is an ideal place for an introverted rest, during which communication with people is kept to a minimum, and unity with nature is at its maximum.

geography.en: The Faroe Islands is an archipelago in the Atlantic Ocean between Iceland and Scotland, consisting of 18 islands. They are of volcanic origin and have a plateau form with pointed ridges. The coastline of the Faroes is steep, with many fjords and cliffs.  There are no large rivers on the archipelago, only small ones that look more like mountain streams. The largest lake is Sorvagsvatn on Vágar Island, which is also called "floating". By the number of waterfalls, the Faroe Islands can easily compete with Iceland. The Faroe Islands is divided into six regions (Sisla) — Eysturoy, Norðoyar, Sandoy, Streymoy, Suðuroy, and Vágar. All of them, in turn, consists of 34 communes.

long_description.en:
Streymoy Island

Here you will find the capital and the only major city in the Faroe Islands — Tórshavn. It was founded in the X century and was named after the god of thunder and lightning Thor. The literal translation means "Thor's harbor". In the center of Torshavn, there is a medieval monastery Munkastovan and the royal warehouse, which survived during a great fire in 1673. Another iconic place in the capital is the Nordic House cultural center, where concerts, exhibitions, and conferences are held. It is a glass building that merges with nature through a roof covered with grass.

Streymoy also has the Westman's Cliffs with numerous colonies of birds and seals living here. The Sornfelli mountain plateau, which overlooks the northwestern part of the Faroe Islands, is 12 kilometers from the capital. In the south of the island, in the village of Kirkjubøur, you can walk near the ruins of the medieval Magnus Cathedral. Houses with traditional grassy roofs surround it. Such an unusual roof is the result of the lack of wood in the Faroe Islands. And in ancient times, shipwrecks near local shores were used as roofs. 

Eysturoy

The second-largest and most populated island in the archipelago. Here is the highest mountain in the Faroe Islands — Slættaratindur (882 m). On a clear day, its peak offers a breathtaking view of the surrounding area and neighboring islands. You can also admire the largest waterfall in the Faroe Islands, Fossa. It is best visited after heavy rains. On the bank of the gorge, surrounded by mountains, is the picturesque village of Gjogv. 

Vagar

The main gem of this island is Sørvágsvatn Lake, which is located on a steep cliff above the ocean. For this reason, it is called "floating". Water from the lake flows into the ocean in the form of Bøsdalafossur waterfall (32 meters). Vágar Airport is the only international airport in the Faroe Islands and is also located in Vagar. A five-kilometer-long traffic tunnel has been built from Vagar to the neighboring island of Streymoy, under the strait. 

Sandoy

This is the only island that has sand dunes. Here, on an area of 111 square kilometers, about seven thousand sheep live. Also, on Sandoy, there are numerous colonies of birds — northern fulmars, small petrels, European storm petrels, European shags, great skuas, Atlantic puffins, etc.

Mykines

It is the westernmost island in the archipelago. Tourists come to see the funny birds — puffins. In their appearance (especially in color), they look like penguins. On the edge of Mykines, there is a snow-white lighthouse with a panoramic view.

description.en: Finland is a country that combines the beauty of wildlife, fabulous landscapes, and the modern design of cities and resorts. Suomi (as locals call Finland) seems to be painted on canvas, and the bright, saturated colors of local landscapes are fascinating. Dense green forests, picturesque lakes, numerous national parks are wonderful places for walks, kayaking, rafting, and canoeing.

geography.en: Finland is located in the north of Europe. The majority of its territory is beyond the Arctic Circle. It borders on Sweden, Norway, and Russia. There are about 190000 lakes and over 30 national parks. Finland's coasts are washed by the Baltic Sea, the Gulf of Bothnia, and the Gulf of Finland. The Republic of Finland consists of six provinces: Lapland, Oulu, Western, Eastern, and Southern Finland, as well as the Åland Islands (the autonomous region within the country). Geographically, the country is divided into Northern, Southern, Western, and Eastern parts.

long_description.en:
Finland attracts travelers from all over the world. Each city in the country has its own character, reflecting the nature and traits of the locals — strong, hardworking, motivated, and infinitely-loving their land.

Helsinki

In the south of Suomi, on the Gulf of Finland, Helsinki stands. It the capital, largest port, the intellectual, the financial, and the cultural center of the country. It includes 315 islands, and parks occupy one-third of its territory. The city center — the Senate Square — is framed by a majestic Empire-style architectural ensemble. There you will find the hallmark of Helsinki — St. Nicholas' Church (Helsinki Cathedral). The soul of the city, its most atmospheric and colorful place is the Market Square (Kauppatori), located on the Baltic coast. Climbing up to the observation deck of the Uspenski Cathedral, you can see the panorama of the city from a height. Esplanade Street, Helsinki's busiest place, is home to many modern shops, boutiques, restaurants, and stylish and trendy bars. 

Turku

Turku is the oldest city in Finland, founded at the beginning of the XIII century, its first capital and an important port on the Baltic Sea and the Aura River. It suffered significant losses during the Second World War, was restored over time, and today appears to us as a beautiful, modern, industrial city. The Cathedral (the oldest building in Turku) and the Medieval Castle, functioning as a museum, have been preserved here. But the most outstanding attraction of Turku is the largest archipelago in the Baltic Sea, located near the city. It is a cluster of twenty thousand small islands. Here you can truly relax away from civilization: fishing, swimming on ferries, yachts, and boats, cycling, and in winter — enjoy skating and skiing. 

Tampere

Tampere is the third-largest city in Finland, founded at the end of the XVIII century, but has managed to keep the coziness and charm of a small town. Its central part is located on a narrow isthmus between lakes, which will be interesting to ride on an old wheeled ship. In addition to the delightful nature, Tampere has many attractions and museums: the Lutheran Cathedral, the temple in the modern style in the Kaleva area, the Orthodox Church of Saint Alexander Nevsky and Saint Nicholas, the Sara Hilden Art Museum, the Spy Museum, the Museum of Dolls and the Moomin Museum. The Tampere Jazz Happening International Music Festival is held here annually in autumn, and the Tampere Biennale is held every two years in spring, bringing together contemporary musicians and performers from around the world.

Mariehamn

The Åland Islands are an autonomous region of Finland, with its capital in Mariehamn. They are an archipelago in the Baltic Sea at the entrance to the Gulf of Bothnia, consisting of 60 inhabited islands and over 6000 deserted islands. The unusual nature of this place attracts travelers from all over the world. This wonderful corner of Finland is perfect for cycling and hiking, camping, fishing in the open sea and bays of the archipelago, sailing. The islands are famous not only for their marvelous nature but also for their outstanding sights: the four-masted sailing ship Pommern, the only surviving vessel of this type in the world; Kastelholm Castle, a medieval castle from the XIV century, with many spiral staircases and passages, with preserved loopholes and knight's armor; Vita Björn Prison, which is a mysterious and exciting museum; the Åland Maritime Museum, as well as the village of Geta, with rocks of pink granite. The islands have a variety of bars, restaurants, cafes, where you can relax and warm up with a cup of hot coffee, which Finns love so much.

Ski tourism in Finland

Finland is an ideal place for skiing holidays, with more than 140 high-class winter resorts, professionally equipped slopes, and developed infrastructure. Finns recognize only high quality, and this is especially evident in the organization of skiing holidays. Every resort has schools with well-trained instructors.

In Eastern Finland, on the shore of Lake Kallavesi, there is a center of winter tourism — Kuopio, which has its own airport and where planes from Helsinki arrive every day. The climate of this place creates comfortable conditions for winter holidays, there is always a lot of snow, and the temperature does not rise above -4 °C. Kuopio has over 400 km of well-equipped tracks, some of which have evening lighting. In addition to skiing, snowboarding, and motorcycling, here you can try such leisure activities as snowshoe safari and Finnish sledding. This place offers excellent service, wonderful hotels, and delicious local cuisine. There are many restaurants, cafes, bars and night clubs in the city center.

In the north of the country, there are the popular Vuokatti with a snowboard tunnel; Levi with a gondola cableway; Kuusamo / Ruka with the oldest slalom school; Paljakka with an incredibly clear snow cover; and Pyhä, where there are many extreme slopes. 

The center of the country can boast of the Koli resort with its luxurious views of Lake Pielinen and Tahko, the venue for European championships in alpine skiing, and snowboarding. 

Ellivuori represents the south of Finland. This is a resort with a magnificent amusement park. The neighborhood of ski slopes with amusement parks is a distinctive feature of holidays in Finland. All the best water parks in the country are at ski resorts. Here you can ride water slides, take a sauna and return with renewed strength to conquer the slopes.

description.en: Montenegro is a small state on the Balkan Peninsula. It gained independence only in 2006, breaking away from Croatia and thus becoming the youngest country in the region. Montenegro consists of four mountain ridges sewn together by threads of road serpentines. This country will allow you to walk over the clouds on the Lovćen mountain range and take an extreme kayak raft on the Tara River in the canyon gorge; visit the Great Wall, which embraced the only fjord in Southern Europe and watch pelicans soaring carelessly over Lake Skadar. It opens the karst caves of Cetina and gives everyone the opportunity to admire the clear waters of the Blue Bay, hidden under centuries-old steep cliffs. You can also admire the white walls of the Monastery of Ostrog, half-eaten by the rock, the medieval bastions of Forte-Mare, and the Mamula Fortress.

geography.en: The state of Montenegro is located in the south-eastern part of the European continent, on the coast of the Balkan Peninsula, washed by the waves of the Adriatic Sea. Its neighbors are Croatia, Serbia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Albania, and Kosovo. The country consists of 14 islands. Geographically, the country is divided into three parts: the sea coast, the central region covered with almost flat landscapes, and mountains. Natural attractions include Lake Skadar, the Bay of Kotor, Mount Lovćen and the national park on it, the Budva Riviera, Montenegrin karst plateau, the Biogradska Gora National Park, mountain massif Durmitor, and Europe's largest canyon of the river Tara.Territorially, Montenegro is divided into 21 communities. All of them have the names of their central cities.

long_description.en:
Podgorica

The capital of Montenegro is Podgorica. This city is not as luxurious as Vienna, not as technologically advanced as Amsterdam; there are no great cultural relics as in Paris. Podgorica is calm and cozy. It will take you a day to walk around the Old Town, take a photo at St. George's Church, the Cathedral of the Resurrection of Christ, and mosques. Don't languish in the routine of a metropolis, and head right to the coast. 

The Riviera makes the soul of a tired clerk feel like it's covered in honey with these sweet sounds. The even rolls of waves begin to rumble in your ears, your feet whine from the lack of golden sand between your fingers and your skin goosebumps from the acute lack of sunshine. Do not panic: all these symptoms are quickly relieved by buying a ticket to one of the Montenegrin rivieras. But the choice will not be easy, there are five of them, by the way! 

Budva Riviera

The Budva Riviera is the most popular among tourists, with its 35 km long picturesque coastline. Throughout the season, Budva is buzzing with loud parties, beach discos, and clanging of glasses in cafes and restaurants. For those who prefer a calmer holiday, there are sun loungers prepared on the sandy beaches of Bečići and Rafailovići. At the same time, tourists with children will enjoy their holidays in Petrovac and Pržno. The pearl of the riviera is the St. Stephen Island, famous for its fashionable villas and medieval color. Only guests are allowed to enter the island, so make a reservation in advance at one of the resort's restaurants. 

Ulcinj Riviera

Ulcinj Riviera is the southernmost resort in Montenegro. The large beach of Ulcinj is famous for its healing basalt sands, and the waters near Ženska are said to improve women's health. The main thing is not to get lost and not to get out accidentally to Ada Bojana, one of the most popular nudist beaches in Europe.

Kotor Riviera

The Kotor Riviera has hidden itself in one of the most beautiful bays in the world - Boka-Kotor Bay. The central city of the resort is ancient Kotor, surrounded by high walls of a medieval fortress. The highest point of the protective structure offers a fantastic view of the fjord — such scenery sink right into the heart. The narrow streets of Kotor are very similar to Italy, and it's not for nothing — for almost half a century, the city had been under the rule of Venice. The whole region is a huge tourist attraction, and the beaches do not give way to the Budva ones. 

Herceg Novi Riviera

The Herceg Novi Riviera is an olive grove of the Luštica peninsula, azure beaches of Mirišta and cozy streets of Žanić. The Adriatic coast of the Riviera will be interesting for divers. Here you can look at shipwrecks and submarines, look at underwater caves, and admire the coral reefs. The center of the resort is Herceg Novi's botanical garden-town. It does not offer the best beaches, but its picturesque coast makes up for it. And in addition to the favorable microclimate, there are therapeutic mud and mineral waters of Igalo. 

Tivat Riviera

Sandy beaches are waiting for tourists in the Tivat Riviera. Quiet bays of the region are perfect for family holidays, and the snow-white beach of the Island of Flowers will delight even a sophisticated tourist. Tivat itself is a young, promising resort. It lives in the embrace of the hilly mountains, to the rhythm of swinging luxurious yachts at the marina.

The most pleasant thing about Montenegro is that you can relax here all year round. If in the middle of winter you suddenly feel a longing for the Balkans, come to one of the ski resorts. The most popular are the mountainous Žabljak, with three well-equipped slopes (Savin Kuk, Stutz, and Javorovača), and the Kolasin, which is not threatened by either storm or wind, as it is located in a kind of hollow, surrounded by mountains and forests. The slopes here are grassy and covered with snow, so they are safe for beginner skiers and children. All of them are equipped according to strict European standards, and it's hard to find more beautiful landscapes than here, and the prices are several times lower than in Italy and France.

description.en: The Czech Republic is a charming European country with the most vibrant traditions. It's one of the most frequently visited tourist destinations in the world. Picturesque parks, mysterious castles, and cozy châteaux, magnificent cathedrals and clock towers, Medieval villages, emerald thick forests, spectacular resorts, - every person will find a place to his liking. The Czech Republic cherishes the memory of histories of ancient tribes and great royal dynasties. People in South Bohemia and Moravia are very passionate about traditions and national culture. They love throwing fairs and festivals. Travelers come to the Czech Republic to rest and enjoy walking and cycling tours, improve health in splendid SPA hotels, and taste the beer. Brewery brought the Czech Republic fame far beyond its boundaries - they produce one of the best sorts of beer in the world.

geography.en: The Czech Republic is located in the central part of Europe. Germany, Poland, Austria, and Slovakia are its neighbors. The territory of the country unites several historical regions: Bohemia with Prague as its state capital, Moravia with a center in Brno, and Silesian Region with Ostrava as the capital. In return, these areas are divided into 14 regions knows as kraj.

long_description.en:
The Czech Republic has a feel of the refined Middle Ages. Every city, house, and castle tell their stories here. You need to visit different corners of the country to know it better. That's the only way to feel all the charm and riches of the Czech Republic. 

Prague

Prague is the capital of the Czech Republic, the cradle of the Czech culture. This largest city in the country has a centuries-old history. Its architecture is marvelous in its variety: the Gothic style, almost untouched by time, aristocratic Baroque, Rococo, and neo-classicism. Eighteen bridges lend a unique charm to the city. Charles Bridge, built in the XIV century, is the central pearl among them. It goes across the Vltava river and is decorated with numerous sculptures. A statue to St. John of Nepomuk is the most renowned among them. All tourists touch it and make wishes. On one side of the Vltava, you can find historic districts, Old Town Bridge Tower and the Powder Gate, a square, the Church of Mother of God before Týn, Prague Astronomical Clock, and the City Hall. The observation deck of the City Hall offers a stunning view of Medieval Prague. The Dancing House - a unique attraction created in the XX century - is situated not far from the historical center. On the other bank of the river, you can find a district called Malá Strana. Its buildings are mainly created in Baroque style. Owing to this, this neighborhood always looks ornate and creates a festive mood. Famous attractions of Malá Strana include Toscan Palace, Archbishop Palace at Hilltop Hradčany, and Prague Castle with all the adjoining constructions. One of them is St. Vitus Cathedral. It took 600 years to build this masterpiece of Gothic architecture. Prague is a fabulous city with incredibly beautiful streets, houses, plenty of cafes and confectioneries, tiny antique shops, and restaurants where you can try goulash, roast pork knee, and drink excellent local beer. 

Brno

Brno is the second-largest city in the Czech Republic and an important cultural center of the country. The town is famous for its modern architecture, and its masterpieces include Klein's Palace with metallic decorative elements; Mahen Theatre as the first electrified theatre in the Czech Republic and the world; Villa Tugendhat that became a significant milestone in the development of Modern style. Such sights as the Cathedral of Saints Peter and Paul, Špilberk Castle, New and Old City Halls are of great historical value. Brno also has a zoo, Botanic Garden, nightclubs, night cinemas, and amusement halls. The Moravian Karst is located north of the city. It is one of the most massive karst landscapes in Europe. Tourists from every corner of the Earth come to see its extraordinary caves. It's more than 25 kilometers in length and has around 1100 caves. Only 5 of them are open to the public. 

Karlovy Vary

Karlovy Vary (former Carlsbad) is a renowned world resort located on the bank of the Tepla river in a scenic corner of the Western Czech Republic. The water in the river is warm almost all the year round as hot springs warm it up. The city was founded 600 years ago by Emperor Charles IV. Karlovy Vary and its neighboring areas have over one hundred mineral water springs. Sprudel is the most renowned geyser among them. It is located in the same-name Collonade. Besides hydropathy, guests of the resort have a chance to play golf, tennis, or to ride horses. Walking tours along the picturesque routes are one of the best leisure activities in Karlovy Vary: to Diana Observation Tower, Goethe's Lookout Tower, and Vyhlidka Tri Krize.

Pilsen

Pilsen is another marvelous city in the Czech Republic and a real center of brewing. Its main square is the largest one in Western Europe. Brewery Museum, located on the territory of the beer factory, is the most significant attraction in the city. By the museum, you shall find an entrance to the XV-century dungeon. It is 15 kilometers in length and consists of underground passages united in one network. These caves served well to the city in various periods of its life. It used to be a storehouse and a bomb shelter. While visiting Pilsen, you should see the cathedral of St. Bartholomew and ascend to its observation deck; the XVI-century City Hall built in the Renaissance epoch style on the central Square of the Republic; the Franciscan Monastery and Great Synagogue. The city offers a wide range of bars and cafes that serve great beer. There are some rare sorts that you can find only here.

Český Krumlov

Picturesque Český Krumlov is located in the very south of the Czech Republic. The historical center of the city is in the list of the UNESCO World Heritage Sites. Travelers come here to see the renowned Český Krumlov Castle - the second in size in the country after Prague Castle; Gothic Church of St. Vitus with the surviving frescoes of the XV century; and also the museum and photo studio called Seidel that keeps photographs, equipment, and personal belongings of the XX-century photographer Josef Seidel. Český Krumlov offers a diversity of bars and cafes, and plenty of picnic zones equipped on the bank of the Vltava river. In winter, Krumlov looks like a fabulous decoration to a mysterious fairy-tale: the castle is covered with snow, the city is desolated and beautiful.

description.en: Synonym for Estonia is a charm. Ancient castles and high bastions keep the memory of chivalries, the spirit of romanticism rises up through the cobbled streets to the triangular roofs of houses, the even rolls of waves lull you away, and the kaleidoscope of prehistoric landscapes explodes your imagination. Estonia is the starting point for numerous cruises in the Baltics states. But is that fair? After all, you want to come to Estonia so much and do not want to say goodbye to it.

geography.en: The Republic of Estonia is a small Baltic country. It is located in Northern Europe and has access to the Baltic Sea through the Gulfs of Finland and Riga. It has land neighbors with Russia and Latvia, water neighbors with Finland, and Sweden. The territory of Estonia is divided into 15 counties. There are also 2355 islands in the Baltic Sea area. The largest are Saaremaa, Hiiumaa, Muhu, Vormsi, and Kihnu.

long_description.en:
Despite its modest size, Estonia will delight you with its diverse landscapes and abundance of historical sites scattered throughout the country. 

Tallinn

The capital of the country is Tallinn. It is a leisurely Estonian city that lives on the southern coast of the Gulf of Finland. It is truly a city of extremes, and the center of the capital is a real medieval island, clutched in the arms of modern glass skyscrapers. Kadriorg Palace, Great Sea Gate, Town Hall Square, St. Mary's Cathedral, Kalamaja and Nõmme districts will take you back to several centuries. The beaches in the Haabersti and Pirita areas will make your head spin with the sea breeze, while a techno rave in a nightclub will remind you that you are in the XXI century. And make sure you climb the observation deck of Patkuli, which is on Toompea Hill. After all, the best way to admire Tallinn is from a height. 

Pärnu

If you travel to Estonia in summer, it is a crime not to go to Pärnu, the country's main resort. The medieval town will welcome you with a carefree romantic atmosphere. Everything is relaxed here: numerous SPA and a water park, historic-style baths and cocktail bars, wide sandy beaches, and warm sea. In addition to sunbathing, make sure you include a bike ride along the picturesque promenade, sailing and canoe trips to the open sea by the river. 

Tartu

Tartu is the oldest city in the Baltics states and the intellectual capital of Estonia. In a couple of hours, you can see all the sights: Old Town, University, Dorpat Cathedral, "Falling House", Town Hall Square, the embankment of the Emajõgi River. And after that, you will find cozy cafes, craft shops, and sunset on Toomemägi hill with a chic view of the city. 

Kuressaare

Kuressaare (formerly Arensburg) is the main city of Saaremaa and the "island capital" of Estonia. Kuressaare, with its low-rise buildings, is more like a village with several gems in its box: the Baroque Town Hall, Vazhnya, St. Lawrence's Church, and, of course, the Kuressaare Episcopal Castle, from which the whole city grew up. But historical sights are not all that Saaremaa is rich in. Be sure to include a walk to the "witch's lake", Kaali Meteorite Crater, in your trip plan. Visit the picturesque coastline of the Panga Cliff and the Angla Windmill Park, a symbol of the region.

Rakvere

Rakvere divided the road between Tallinn and Narva in half. This humble city attracts tourists with the ruins of the medieval castle of Wesenberg. The place deserves attention by right: picturesque hills, the weight of fortress walls, cold dungeons, and historical theatrical performances will take you to the Middle Ages. You can test your inner knight's agility yourself. Here you will have an opportunity to shoot with an archer, try on ancient armor, feel the weight of the sword in the forge, and look into the torture chamber. 

Narva

If you want something Russian in Estonia, go to Narva. The city is on the very border with Russia, so when you walk along the streets, sometimes you get lost: is it already St. Petersburg, or is it still Narva? The question is easy to understand: if you can see the tall tower of Hermann Castle, you are still on the Estonian land. The rich history of the city has left a legacy of fortifications of XIV-XVI centuries, the Baroque Town Hall of 1668, the Orthodox Resurrection of Christ Cathedral, the complex of buildings of the famous Kreenholm Manufacturing Company. If you still have the strength after seeing all the sights, go out to the promenade along the embankment. The city from the river, lit by evening lights, looks simply fabulous.

description.en: Hong Kong is a special administrative region of China, located in the southeast of the country. The incredible combination of Eastern and Western cultures makes this metropolis unlike any other. Contemporary skyscrapers, where business people cut multimillion deals, luxurious restaurants with exotic dishes, large amusement centers for children, exciting attractions, picturesque parts, and cozy beaches - it's impossible to explore Hong Kong in just a couple of days. Still, you can easily fall in love at first sight.

long_description.en:
Hong Kong has a humid climate of a monsoon type with a strongly marked downpour season. It lasts from May to September. At the same time, the temperature reaches 28-30°C. From the middle of October, an amount of precipitations decreases, and the weather gets colder — +15-18°C. As far as temperature and rains are concerned, November and December are considered to be the best months for visiting Hong Kong. In January and February, the weather is also dry, but it's not that easy to capture those sunny days.

If you want to combine your trip to Hong Kong with some holidays or festivals, winter months are the best variants. They celebrate Chinese New Year and hold the largest Exhibition of Toys and Games in the world in January. February is the period of the Lantern Festival and Theatre Festival. In March, you can go to a film festival and a Gastronomic Art Festival, and in May tourists can attend an extraordinary Buns' Festival. All holidays and cultural events in Hong Kong are loud, fun, and spectacular.

description.en: Indonesia is a country of extremes. You can dive into the world of tropical jungles, watch active volcanoes, and walk down the concrete streets of large megalopolises. In different periods, India, China, the Netherlands, and Japan greatly influenced the culture and history of the country. The world recognized Indonesia as an independent state in 1949. However, the traditions of the former colonizers are deeply seated in the country’s culture. Only here, you shall find the biggest Buddha, Hindu temples, casteism, and ritualistic sacrifices. Moreover, Indonesia is the largest Muslim country in the world with the most peaceful citizens.

geography.en: Indonesia is the largest country in Southeast Asia and the only state in the world that consists of thousands of islands. There are more than 18 thousand of them, to be exact. More than 9 thousand of them are not just uninhabited but do not even have names. Only 1000 are inhabited. The largest Indonesian islands include Java, Sumatra, Borneo (Kalimantan), New Guinea, Sulawesi, Bali, Lombok, Halmahera. Due to the vast territories and a diverse relief, Indonesia has impenetrable rainforests and around 400 volcanoes (200 of them are active). Indonesia shares land borders with Malaysia, East Timor, and Papua New Guinea. Its maritime neighbors are Australia, the Philippines, Singapore, and plenty of small archipelagos. The country is washed by the Pacific Ocean and the South China Sea in the north and east. Waves of the Indian Ocean washes the southern and western shores of the state.

long_description.en:
The largest cities in Indonesia offer seeing a mix of cultures, basking in the sun on sandy beaches, and the best SPA resorts in Southeast Asia. Every town has its noise, fragrance, history, and spirit. Their honesty, innocence, and incredible generosity will win every guest’s heart.

Jakarta

Jakarta is the capital of Indonesia and the most loaded city in the country. Officially, over ten million people live here. Besides, hundreds of thousands of tourists from every corner of the planet visit Jakarta daily. It’s a multicultural city. Here you can see the largest mosque in Asia, a Buddhist temple, and a neo-Gothic National Cathedral. The main city attractions are located in the old districts like Kota and Sunda Kelapa. If your stay in the capital is limited in time, but you still want to dive into the cultural identity, visit Taman Mini “Indonesia Indah”. It’s an enormous complex with miniature attractions and architectural constructions from various provinces of the state. Taking into account the size of the park, we highly recommend you to rent a bicycle. Local citizens are desperate shopaholics. That’s why over 130 huge shopping malls work here round-the-clock. Just like any other Asian capital, Jakarta never sleeps. This loud and bright place can get your juices flowing for a year in advance. 

Denpasar

Denpasar is the capital of Bali. Unlike the island that gathers many tourists who come for a sense of peace and self-cognition, Denpasar is far from the notion of “relax”. At the same time, it is ready to offer an authentic culture to its guests. The ancient temples here are mixed with fashionable constructions made of glass and concrete. And at the Pasar Badung market, you will not only taste the exotic street food but also can purchase authentic household items that the Balinese people had been using thousands of years ago. It’s impossible not to visit the temples while you are in Denpasar. Pura Maospahit was made of corals in the XV century. It’s devoted to the Balinese supreme god Sang Hyang Widhi Wasa. You can’t skip Raja's Palace immersed in luxury grandeur. Denpasar is the city that managed to save its flavors and share it with its tourists.

Ubud

Ubud is a small but cozy town located in the highlands of Bali Island. Monkey Forest is the first thing that comes to our minds when somebody mentions this city. Primates freely wander around an enormous park and are more than happy to contact with human beings. A small life hack for travelers: Monkey Forest is a sacred place where they have daily rituals. Stay here till the evening, and you will definitely see one of the traditional Balinese ceremonies. This will help you dive even deeper into the local culture. Goa Gajah is another place with an ancient spirit. This temple complex with fonts is lost in the forest. You can explore this attraction for hours, enjoying the marvelous landscapes. 

Yogyakarta

Yogyakarta is a city on Java island. Sultans’ palaces, historical palaces included in UNESCO World Heritage List, museums, and beach resorts are located on the territory of 46 square kilometers. The magnificent Borobudur Temple that was built somewhere between 750 and 850, still impresses the scientists. These enormous constructions symbolize the system of the universe. Local citizens have a legend: “A person who touches all Buddhas on the top floor will find eternal happiness”. The Royal Palace of Sultan Kraton or Kraton Ngayogyakarta Hadiningrat (1755) is the main raisin of Yogyakarta. It’s still the official residence of the sultan. Fanciers of nature can go to the suburbs of Yogyakarta and visit Gembira Loka Zoo. It’s one of the best zoos in Indonesia with a diversity of rare birds and mammals. 

Surabaya

Surabaya is a port city on Java island. It is the second in size in Indonesia. This is a city of extremes where the colonial past mixed with skyscrapers, fishing villages, and ancient temples. Surabaya is divided into two districts: Chinese and Arabic. This area will appeal to the fanciers of architecture. Here you can observe a high concentration of churches, mosques, and temples. Ampel Mosque constructed in the XV century is the most iconic building. The artistic life of Surabaya is concentrated in the Old Town, where the Dutch colonial influence remains. If you are looking for an unforgettable atmosphere and exotics culinary delights, head to Pasar Ampel market. You can finish your tour near the longest highway bridge in Indonesia. It is 5438 meters in length. Its official title is Jembatan Nasional Suramadu. The bridge connects Java and Madura islands. 

Medan

Medan is the largest city in Sumatra and the fourth largest in the size of the population in Indonesia. This place became a starting point for tourists who want to travel to other islands. It undeservingly left behind! At first sight, the city looks dirty and noisy. Few, if any, understand English. However, if you are looking for real extremes and flavors, you should definitely stay here a bit longer. Medan’s streets still have the existing constructions in Art Deco style left from the Dutch colonizers: Maimoon Palace that used to be the residence of the sultan, the active Chinese temple Vihara Gunung Timur, and one of the oldest Hindu temples on the island. When you explore the streets of Medan, you realize that history is not in the books. History is right in front of you.

description.en: The People's Republic of China is the largest country in Asia. It is the keeper of the most ancient Eastern culture, the proud owner of the unique natural beauties, and a successful player in the world business industry. China captivates with the featheriness of the bells on pagodas and the rustle of bamboo parks, shrill of cicadas, and the roar of the high-speed monorails, wind's whispers under the skyscrapers' roofs and monks' prayers. They practice kung fu and throw tea ceremonies, live their lives following feng shui, and celebrate Chinese New Year in style. They invented paper, the compass, porcelain, gunpowder, typography, and thousands of other notions in the Celestial Empire that the world should be grateful for.

geography.en: China is located in the southeast part of the Asian mainland. The territory of the country is the third in size after Russia and Canada. Hills, mountains, and uplands constitute over 67% of the state's area. If you look down on Chine, it seems like a huge four-stage staircase that goes down from the west to the east. The length of the Chinese coastline is 14 500 km. It spreads from the borders with North Korea to Vietnam. The territory of the country is washed by the seas of the Pacific Ocean: the Yellow, South China, and East China Seas, and the West Korea Bay of the Yellow Sea. There are thousands of islands in the seas. The most renowned and largest of them are Taiwan and Hainan.In the south, the People's Republic of China borders on Laos, Myanmar, and Vietnam; in the southwest - Pakistan, India, Nepal, and Bhutan; in the west - Afghanistan, Kazakhstan, and Tajikistan. In the north, China borders on Mongolia, in the northeast - with Russia and North Korea, in the northwest - with Kazakhstan. The total length of the borders with all 14 countries is 22117 kilometers.As far as the administrative division is concerned, China is divided into 23 provinces, two special administrative regions (Hong Kong and Macau), five autonomous regions, and four self-controlled municipalities.

long_description.en:
China is multifaced and diverse. It offers a diversity of fascinating and unique things: from the stone peaks of the Zhangjiajie National Forest Park to the flooded stairs of the Longji Rice Terraces; from the cosmic skyscrapers of Guangzhou to pandas chewing bamboo in Giant Panda Breeding Research Base; from the Great Wall of China to the peak of Mount Fanjing hidden in the clouds; from the Pacific Ocean to the Tian Shan's ridges. Start your acquaintance with this country with the largest megalopolises:

Beijing

Beijing is the capital of the People's Republic of China and the most important political, educational, and cultural center of the country. The past, present, and future are closely intertangled here. The futuristic building of the National Centre for the Performing Arts, the glass tower of China World Trade Center, bankings of the road interchanges, the technological Planetarium, and fuss of the business world - this technological modernity changes for traditional Chinese pagodas literally right around the corner. The majesty of the largest Imperial Palace complex in the world, the Forbidden City, the terracotta vaults of the Gate of Heavenly Peace, Zen of the Temple of Heaven complex of religious buildings stand in stark contrast to the typical communistic constructions. Beijing, as a model capital, broadcasts the diversity of the Celestial Empire. You will need more than one day to get to know it closer. 

Shanghai

Shanghai is the city of sins and Chinese New York. Standing at the mouth of the Yangtze River, at the coast of the Pacific Ocean, it rules the country's financial flow and conducts multimillion international deals. You can't mix up the image of Shanghai with any other city: spherical buildings, skyscrapers of the Pudong district, multi-leveled road interchanges, avenues filled with luminescent light. It keeps its Chinese charm within the walls of the Jade Buddha Temple and houses of old Nanshi District. Still, Shanghai gets a peep of the west and tries to take the best of it. There is almost no communistic spirit here, and there are more bars and nightclubs here than temples in Beijing. 

Hong Kong

Hong Kong is a special administrative region in the south of China. Surrounded by the mountains and the ocean, it includes not only the same-name island, but also Lantau Island, the Kowloon Peninsula, New Territories, and around 260 smaller islands. It had been developing under the influence of Great Britain for such a long time, that it considers itself to be the Chinese-non-China. The region has a separate currency, writing system, electoral system, and economy. The built-up density in Hong Kong is so high that you don't understand where one skyscraper ends and another begins. But everything changes when you ascend to Victoria Peak. Myriads of sparkling lights of the big city look incredible at a set of sun, against the picturesque harbor, drown in the damp haze.

Island of Hainan

When the color of your skin turns grey and dims from the concrete landscapes of megalopolises, leave everything and come to the island of Hainan. This is a real paradise with its snow-white sands of the Dragon Bay, transparent waters of the Dadong Sea, fluffy palms of Sanya Bay. It's a genuine eastern version of Hawaii. Perfect ecological environment, a scenic coral reef, "Typhoon Corridor" that creates ideal waves for surfing, and the sun all year round make this island a perfect resort. 

Tibet

Have you found yourself among multilayered landscapes, peace, a mystical atmosphere, and Buddhist sacred songs? It seems that you have come to Tibet. The richness of this autonomous region hides in the snow cap of the holy Mount Kailash, white-stone walls of the Potala Palace, glass waters of Yamdrok Lake, high-mountain temples, and palaces of Dalai Lamas. Tibet does not look like the rest of China. And this is another proof of how one country can be so diverse and unpredictable.

description.en: On the coast of the South China Sea, in the delta of the Pearl River (Zhujiang), there is a special administrative region of the PRC Macao — "Asian Las Vegas", "Corner of Europe in Asia", a country-city with a high degree of autonomy. Due to the long Portuguese colonization, Macao is an amazingly harmonious blend of Chinese and European cultures, architecture, and customs. European-looking courtyards are cozily bordering the colorful Asian markets here. In Macao, you can legally play casinos, admire ancient Portuguese architecture and traditional Buddhist temples, engage in bungee jumping, and taste exquisite local dishes.

Few people seriously think about going on holiday to Malaysia. From all countries of South-East Asia, tourists are more likely to choose Thailand, Indonesia, Singapore, or even Vietnam. To say it's not fair to Malaysia is to say nothing. After all, this country is a real Asian cocktail of Indian, Chinese, and Malay cultures. It amazingly combines ancient temples and glass skyscrapers, high-speed space monorails and colonial mansions, technological computer factories, and virgin jungles, in which the whole country is buried. Every year, the popularity of Malaysia as a tourist destination is growing, so you should hurry and buy a ticket to Kuala Lumpur.

geography.en: Malaysia is a country in Southeast Asia. The South China Sea cut the country into two halves. Most of the Malay peninsula was taken over by Western Malaysia (the traditional name is Malaysia). In contrast, the eastern part (the traditional names are Sabah and Sarawak) "moved" to the northern part of Kalimantan Island (better known as Borneo). Small islands were scattered off the coast like ripped beads, attracting tourists with snow-white beaches and views from an advertisement for paradisiacal pleasure.

long_description.en:
Kuala Lumpur

The capital of Malaysia is Kuala Lumpur. In 140 years, the Malay people have managed to turn a village on a dirty river into a modern advanced metropolis. During the day, Kuala Lumpur is buried in greenery and exotic flowers, at night, it turns into a neon firefly. In the labyrinths of road junctions, the Petronas Twin Towers serve as a kind of landmark. The ancient temples and colonial houses are mixed up beneath the skyscrapers. Here, you never know what awaits you around the corner: a modern house made of concrete and glass or the gate tower of one of the Hindu temples, let's say — Sri Mahamariamman Temple, decorated with 230 colorful figures of deities. 

Malacca

Malacca is a no less important city in Malaysia. It is a UNESCO-protected nature reserve city and is out of the question of demolishing buildings. Malacca is a living monument to multiculturalism. The Portuguese fortress A'Famosa, the Taoist Cheng Hoon Teng Temple and the Sri Poyyatha Vinayagar Moorthi Temple, the Christian Church of St. Paul and the Sultan's Palace are situated peacefully in its streets. 

George Town

George Town is the central city on the island of Penang. It attracts tourists with its unique cyberpunk character. The main streets (Cannon Street, Armenian Street, Queen Street) are painted with bright graffiti until the rooftops. Modern hypermarkets have been built over, the protected from demolition, wooden houses, and all this cocktail is enriched by the religious temples of Khoo Kongsi, Snake, Eternal Bliss, and Ten Thousand Buddhas.

Malaysia's main treasures are outside the big cities. They are hidden in galactic accumulations of fluorescent plankton on the banks of the Sungai Sedili Besar, on the Turtle Islands of Sabah, on the growing Mountain Kinabalu, in limestone Mulu Caves, in the tunnel of fireflies over the Kampung Kuantan River, in Batu Caves, Malay jungle and dozens of marine and forest reserves scattered throughout the country.

Beaches

The beaches of Malaysia make a separate story about this tropical paradise. Snow-white sand blinds your eyes, palm trees gently rustle, and the azure sea merges with the sky on the horizon. Most tourists prefer to stay on the islands of Langkawi and Penang, known not only for its chic beaches and fashionable hotels but also for the rampant wildlife.

The beaches of Tioman Island are known worldwide for their cleanliness and rich water area. The hand of civilization has not reached this place, and the whole island is a vast protected area. Tengah Beach always welcomes tourists for a relaxing family holiday.

Diving

The divers are the real fans of Malaysia. They are attracted to the rich underwater world as well as flora and fauna. There is also a favorable climate, which allows you to dive all year round. If you have been dreaming of swimming with whale sharks for a long time, go to Tioman Island. Are you determined to see the world's largest single Mushroom coral? You should go to Redang. You can see World War II shipwrecks off the coast of Labuan. Sipadan Island is a treasure trove of underwater beauty: a lobster lie, coral gardens with cliffs deep in the reef, parrotfishes, rays, sea angels, barracudas, and at least 200 other marine creatures. If you have little diving experience, go practice to the Perhentian Islands. The island's coastline is ideal for snorkeling as you can watch turtles grow in the warm waters of the South China Sea at shallow depths.

Surfing

Of course, the beaches of Malaysia cannot boast of the awesomeness of the waves with Sri Lanka, but some of the spots are also popular with surfers. From November to April, the wind brings good waves to the east coast. Choose a beach near the villages of Cherating, Desaru, Kerteh, or Kota Bharu for this period. High waves usually go to the coast of Borneo, where brave and experienced surfers ride. Beginners should stop at the beaches of Kemasik, where the sea is relatively calm.

description.en: The United Arab Emirates is a country that can safely be called the newest wonder of the world. It is a hub of wealth and luxury, stunning beaches and blooming gardens, mosques and palaces, glass skyscrapers and shopping malls about the size of a small town. Here they have created islands of bizarre shapes, green parks, and even a ski resort, operating at a heat of 40 degrees Celsius. It is hard to imagine that there was a desert on the place of a modern cosmic-looking building some 50 years ago.

geography.en: The United Arab Emirates is located in the Middle East, in southwest Asia, in the eastern part of the Arabian Peninsula. The UAE's neighbors are Saudi Arabia in the west and south, Oman in the southeast and northeast. The Persian and Oman Gulfs wash the banks of the emirates. The state is made up of seven emirates: Abu Dhabi, Ajman, Dubai, Ras Al Khaimah, Umm Al Qaiwain, Fujairah, and Sharjah.

long_description.en:
The Arab Emirates is a place where you can't believe your eyes when you get to it for the first time. The country builds all the best: the highest hotels, the largest indoor ski park, the largest amusement park. Indeed, the UAE is one of the wealthiest countries in the world. 

Abu Dhabi

Abu Dhabi is the capital of the UAE, the largest and wealthiest emirate with the highest number of "wonders" created by man. It is a respectable, dignified, and luxurious city. Most of its attractions are built on Yas Island. Here you can find the Yas Marina racing track, which is one of the Formula 1 tracks, and the Ferrari World theme park. There is also a water park, an autodrome, and many other leisure options. Yas Island is considered to be one of the best tourist projects in the world. Another interesting attraction in Abu Dhabi is the Sheikh Zayed Grand Mosque. This relatively new building is considered to be the pearl of the Arab Emirates — made of white marble, hand-crafted, surrounded by artificial lakes and canals. 

Dubai

Dubai is the largest city in the UAE. This science-fiction fairy tale in the real world amazes with its large-scale ideas that can be seen from space — glass skyscrapers, artificial reserves, and Palm Islands. We recommend you to climb the highest skyscraper in the world, the Burj Khalifa. The ideal time to visit it is, of course, before sunset. At its foot, you will find the largest music fountain in the world, and next to it, there is the Dubai Mall, where you can buy everything from exclusive magnets to a car. There is also a large aquarium with sharks and many rare fish.

Sharjah

Sharjah is suitable for a more peaceful, relaxed family holiday. Here you can lounge on the cleanest beaches on the coast of the Persian Gulf, visit local oriental markets, and have fun in Aljazeera Park. Sharjah is considered to be a kind of cultural capital. The King Faisal Mosque and the ancient Sharjah Heritage Area are some of the main attractions. There are also many museums: ethnographic, artistic, archeological, and historical. 

Fujairah

Fujairah is the best choice for lovers of outdoor activities such as diving and snorkeling. This emirate is located on the shore of the Gulf of Oman with many mountainous capes, mineral springs, natural gorges, and green massifs. Due to the Al Hajar Mountains, this area has a microclimate with high humidity — the temperature here is a couple of degrees lower than in other emirates.

description.en: Singapore is a city-state in Southeast Asia. The area of the country with all its neighboring islands is 724.2 km². Taking all this into account, Singapore managed to become one of the busiest ports in the world, an important financial center, and the world's second oil refining state.

long_description.en:
Singapore is one of the safest countries in the world. In many ways, it is due to its strict observance of all rules and laws. The list of violations for which you are guaranteed to get a fine is so big, and there are so many banning signs on the streets that Singapore has been jokingly referred to as a "Fine City", where "fine" means both "wonderful" and a "penalty". 

Things that are absolutely common for us, and we do them unconsciously are punished by the Singapore dollar in this country. It is forbidden to bring chewing gum to the city, and you can't spit on the streets, litter and throw cigarette butts — you will not only be obliged to pay a fine, but also be enrolled in public works. You can't eat or drink on public transport, or smoke in public places. If you cross the road in the wrong place, you will get a penalty.

And do not expect violations to go unnoticed: there are security cameras and policemen on duty all over the city.

description.en: Thailand is the Kingdom of Southeast Asia that is ready to surprise you with its extremes. It’s one of the richest countries in Asia that has never been a colony. It is a country of another chronology and the most smiling people who honor heir king and consider him to be a god. In Thailand, a traveler is offered every imaginable leisure time activities: from the serenity of mind in the ancient temple and diving to unrestrained revels in local bars and erotic shows. The tourist industry here is sharpened and operates like a well-oiled machine. Experienced travelers recommend starting your acquaintance with Asia with a trip to Thailand. This country will show you all the benefits and amenities of Asian culture, amaze you with the diversity of local cuisine, shower with caresses with the warm waters of the Gulf of Siam. It will occupy a special place in the heart of every traveler who visits it.

geography.en: Thailand is located on the Malay and Indochinese Peninsulas in the south-eastern part of Asia. The country borders on Laos, Myanmar, Cambodia, and Malaysia. Thailand is washed by the Andaman Sea in the west and by the waters of the Gulf of Siam of the South China Sea. The country is prolate in form, therefore, there are several climate zones here simultaneously. This location allows local citizens to take in the harvest several times a year. In addition to this, it also makes Thailand one of the few Asian countries where the resort season lasts all year round. The majority of the Kingdom is occupied by fertile plains. The Thai Highlands is situated in the north of the country. Doi Inthanon(2565 meters) is the highest mountain in the range. Due to the diversity and abundance of geography, they tend to distinguish five main regions of Thailand: Southern, North-eastern, Northern, Eastern, and Central. On the administrative level, Thailand is divided into four management levels. Provinces (changwat) are the first level, districts (amphoe) are the second one, subdistricts (tambon) are the third level, and mubans are the fourth. There are 77 provinces in the country. Bangkok as the capital is also included in the list provinces. There are 878 districts and 50 districts of Bangkok (khet) that are comparable to amphoe.

long_description.en:
Every city of Thailand is ready to amaze with its atmosphere and developed infrastructure. Wide roads, moveable bridges, multilevel junctions, and tunnels can be seen not only in the large megalopolises but also far beyond. Another advantage for every traveler is a fact that the local population has excellent knowledge of English. This means you are not going to face any communication problems in this country.

Bangkok

Bangkok is the capital of Thailand. It’s a city of gorgeous temples and vibrant night-life. The city is often called Venice of the East. People come here to get acquainted with the culture and local cuisine of Thailand, visit a floating market and the largest Chinatown in the world. The number of temples per square meter surpasses the bare minimum. The Dragon Temple, Erawan Shrine, Wat Saket, Wat Phra Chetuphon - these constructions convey the authenticity of culture and impress with their observation decks with mind-blowing views. Wat Arun is a real pearl of Bangkok. Both the interior and exterior of the temple are decorated with porcelain. The central stupa or prang Phra Phai that is 79 meters in height is the main relic of this place. There are plenty of parks in the city where you can escape from the noise of the megapolis. In addition, the city offers an impressive number of museums telling about the past and present times. Moreover, you will be astonished by the vivid night-life with an abundance of erotic shows that have already become a part of the local culture. The city impresses with its atmosphere and is included in the top of the must-visit places for every adventurer. 

Pattaya

Pattaya is the most fast-growing city in the world. Only 40 years ago, you could find a small fishermen’s village on the spot of the modern city. Nowadays, it’s a popular resort with gorgeous villas, well-tended beaches, and extraordinary attractions. It doesn’t have any ancient temple. However, it offers unique nature and buildings that deserve travelers’ attention. Buddha Mountain (Khao Chi Chan), Mini Siam, Sanctuary of Truth, Wat Yansangwararam, Sukhawadee - this is just a tithe of what you should see in Pattaya. You can check out the beauty of the azure water and untouched clean beaches during a ship tour around the islands. There are hundreds of them nearby Pattaya. Some of them are touristic (Ko Lan, Ko Sak, Ko Khrok, Ko Phai, and others) while the others are deserted. Tourists should definitely spend one of their evenings attending the legendary “Tiffany Show”. It’s a bright cabaret with circus and cabaret performances that have already become the trademark of this region.

Phuket

Phuket is a picturesque island surrounded by rainforests, cliffs, and sky-blue waters. It’s one of the most popular resorts with renowned beaches that are included in the list of the most beautiful ones on the planet. It offers attractions and entertainment that can fit any taste. For example, Wat Chalong Temple and Big Buddha that stands 300 meters above the sea level. You can’t miss the Botanic Garden and the famous Phi Phi Islands. There is a wide range of observation decks in Phuket where you can admire the most beautiful sunrises and sunsets. They include Khao Rang Hill, Karon Beach, Promthep Cape, and the observation deck at Kao Khad Views Tower that offers a 360° panoramic view. You can also admire the area from the height trying a zip-line. A flight over 400 meters of jungles won’t leave anyone indifferent. At night, when the illumination is lit, tourists head to the FantaSea Show. It’s a combination of a circus and theatre in one place. In addition to gymnasts and illusionists, you shall also see performances themed on ancient legends. If you want to get acquainted with the local fauna, you should attend a snake farm, Kokchang Safari or the local zoo. 

Pa Tong

Pa Tong is a resort town in the west of Phuket Island. It offers a diversity of entertainments, vivid nightlife, and picturesque beaches. You should come here to enjoy a wonderful beach holiday. The town has plenty of places! Paradise Beach is a small beach with enormous granite stones. Freedom Beach is surrounded by dense jungles. You need to make some efforts to get here. It doesn’t have any loud amusements – only the sounds of nature and local boats that bring tourists. Kalim beach is a rocky landscape for the fans of surfing. The Tiger Kingdom is a new location where the Indochinese tigers live. You can find serenity at Wat Suwan Khiri Wong where the Buddhist monks hold services. Pa Tong is situated not far from Phuket. Thus, it’s easy to move from one location to another. 

Chiang Mai

Chiang Mai has been the religious and cultural capital of the Kingdom since the olden times. Here you can find a wide range of the untouched by time ancient temples and the most beautiful national parks on the background of gorgeous mountain landscapes. A tourist who plans to visit Chiang Mai should be aware of the fact that there are no beaches and nightlife here. The city offers only ancient attractions. The median number of temples in the city and its suburbs reaches 300. The Wat Umong or “Tunnel temple”, temple with an observation deck on the Wat Doi Suthep, Silver Sanctuary or Wat Sri Suphan – it’s not the full list of the wonderful architectural masterpieces. Wat Rong Khun or the White Temple makes you feel like nothing similar exists in the world. Wat Chedi Luang is located in the center of the city and is considered to be the oldest construction in the city. Elephants, tigers, and pandas live in the local zoo. It’s a pure delight to observe the animals as they live in spacious enclosures and not in cages. There are many traditional markets, an art street in the city. On the outskirts of the city, you shall find waterfalls and national parks. You can explore Chiang Mai endlessly. The mild climate only creates perfect conditions for this adventure.

description.en: Sri Lanka stands for the "blessed land" in Sanskrit. It's hard to imagine a better title for this small hospitable island famous for its tea plantations, marvelous beaches, exotic nature, and architecture. Some people come here to take a break from everyday life and hit the reset button, absorbing some energy in ancient Buddhist temples. Others look forward to intense sensations while catching waves on a surfboard or touring to the mountains. Someone else is attracted by the idea of laying on the warm sand and swimming in the waters of the Indian Ocean. Sri Lanka is marvelous even during the rainy season, and off-season periods. That's why the flow of tourists never grows weak.

geography.en: Sri Lanka is a South Asian country in the Indian Ocean. The majority of its territory is located on the same-name island, 650 km from the Equator. It also includes plenty of smaller islands. The most significant of them are Mannar, Velanai, Delft, Karaitivu, and Pungudutivu. The Palk Strait and Gulf of Mannar separate Sri Lanka from the Indian subcontinent. There is a version that a thin chain of islands and shallows called Adam's Bridge had united two countries till the end of the XV century. However, a part of it was destroyed by an earthquake and a storm. Sri Lanka's coastline compiles 1340 km. The island is 445 km in length and 225 km in width. Its territory occupies 65 610 km². It is the 25th largest island in the world. The country shares a maritime border with India in the northwest and with the Maldives in the southwest.  Sri Lanka's relief is exceptionally heterogeneous: the central highland, plains, and coastal lowlands.
