Due to this, the country has several climate zones with considerably different weather conditions. The central highland is the heart of the island. Pidurutalagala is the highest mountain in the southern end of the plateau that spreads for 65 km from north to south. The peak of the mountain reaches. 2524 m. However, the majority of the island is plains. They are not higher than 200 meters above sea level. The coast offers picturesque sandy beaches. Trincomalee and Galle natural bays are deeply cut into the land. The Mahaweli Ganga is the longest river in the country (325 km). Besides, there are another nine rivers on the island that are more than 100 km in length and an uncountable number of small streams. Bolgoda Lake is the biggest freshwater lake in Sri Lanka. Its depth reaches 15 meters. According to the administrative division, the territory of Sri Lanka consists of 9 provinces since 1987. In return, they are divided into 25 districts that have another two levels of administrative division. The Prime Ministers elected at a local level rule in provinces.

long_description.en:
Colombo and Sri Jayawardenepura Kotte

Colombo and Sri Jayawardenepura Kotte are two capital cities of Sri Lanka. Many people still don't know which of them bears the official status. Strange as it may seem, Sri Jayawardenepura Kotte or simply Kotte has been the capital of the state since 1982. It is located in the suburbs of Colombo, the largest city in the state. The Supreme Court of the country and its Parliament are situated here. The later is located on an island in the middle of a lake. Access to the building is closed and it is guarded by military forces. The water is teeming with crocodiles. Tourists admire the refined complex from the waterfront. You can hide from the heat in a splendid city park. There are plenty of ponds on its territory. Their surfaces are covered with lotuses which are the national flower of Sri Lanka. In addition to this, the park offers many pedestrian trails and juicy greenery. A monument to all the people who died during the Civil War is a significant attraction. Next to the memorial, you shall see enormous granite slabs with the names hammered out. Colombo that had had the status of the capital from 1802 to 1982, remains to be the business center of the state. President's residence is also located here. The architecture in the city is an impressive and beautiful combination of European and Sri Lankan culture, of antiquity and modernity. The business capital has dozens of religious constructions of various confessions: Buddhist, Catholic, Muslim. Gangaramaya Temple is the largest Buddha temple in Colombo. St. Anthony's Shrine is incredibly charming during the day, and the illumination makes its architecture even more spectacular in the evening. Jami-Ul-Alfar Mosque Sinhala is famous for its red and white coloration and architecture that is atypical for such constructions. Maritime Museum and Colombo National Museum will fascinate you with their insightful displays. And all fans of the arts can't miss the exhibition of the National Art Gallery. If you are one of those tourists who want to try their luck, there is a casino for this purpose in the city. Local citizens love Ancient Viharamahadevi Park. It is the most beautiful green zone in Colombo.

Kandy

Kandy is considered to be the cultural and spiritual center of the country and not without reason. The city, surrounded by the mountains, is located on the bank of the Mahaweli Ganga River in the very center of the island. That's why it is colder here than on the coast. For centuries, Kandy had been the capital for the kings of Sri Lanka. Some buildings of the old Royal Complex are now open for tourists. One of the last kings, Wickrama Rajasinghe, made it into history as a creator of the artificial lake Bogambara. It later became a real attraction. One of the most prized Buddhist shrines stands on its bank: Sri Dalada Maligawa or the Temple of the Sacred Tooth Relic. A few steps from there, you can find a complex of four Hindu temples. This is only the small extent of all religious constructions within city boundaries. If you want to get acquainted with the island's nature, it's not far to seek. The territory of Udawattakele Forest Reserve starts on the sides of the hills, right behind Sri Dalada Maligawa. And if you are not lazy and decide to drive 6 km from Kandy, you will be rewarded with the beauty of Royal Botanic Gardens and see the magnificent collection of orchids. At nights, several city squares and concert halls offer theatrical performances with traditional music and dances. But in general, Kandy can't boast of having an active and diverse nightlife.

Negombo

Negombo is one of the most amazing cities in Sri Lanka, at least because plenty of Catholics live here, and you can often see Christian churches and corresponding symbolics. Fish markets are another spark of the city. There are two of them (Fish Market и Old Fish Market), as Negombo is a large fishing center. Goods here are always fresh. Tourists can watch how boats with fresh catches arrive and being unloaded, or how the fish is getting air-dried on the sand. A long and quite broad sandy beach is located in the northern part of the town. There are plenty of comfortable hotels nearby. The diversity of water attractions is waiting for tourists, including diving, windsurfing, and kitesurfing. There is a charming mangrove park in Negombo, and a fascinating bird sanctuary is located 50 km from the city.

Galle

Galle is a port city in the west of Sri Lanka. You won't find a beautiful beach here but will be amazed by the marvelous Dutch fort of the XVII century. Its fourteen bastions are in a good state of preservation just like other buildings of that epoch in the Old Town. If you want to have a better understanding of Galle's history, you should visit the Dutch Museum and National Maritime Archaeology Museum. Their exhibits tell about the colonization epoch. The 27-meter lighthouse is a famous city attraction. It offers an excellent view, including Meeran Jumma Mosque. Of course, the city has a beautiful Buddhist temple called Shri Sudharmalaya.

After admiring and even getting tired of the architectural masterpieces of Galle, the best idea for a tourist is to relax on the beaches that are considered to be the best in the country. Fortunately, there are located only 5 km away, in a cozy and cute resort town Unawatuna. It resembles a small fishing village rather than a resort. Small hotels and guests houses gladly open their doors to their tourists. Unawatuna beach is enclosed from the city with the green jungle zone, and a coral reef protects it from the sea. The infrastructure is quite developed. There are plenty of cafes, rental bicycles and motorbikes, beach chairs, and umbrellas. This place is absolutely safe for swimming and is a perfect fit for beachgoers with kids. The sandy coast offers a shallow entrance to the sea, and the streamflow is subtle. Jungle Beach is a small beach for fans of full relaxation as there are even no waves here. 

Hikkaduwa

Hikkaduwa is a popular resort in the southwest part of the island. One can hardly say that the town is big, but it has a highly-developed tourist infrastructure. It always has many guests from Ukraine, Russia, and Belarus. People come here not to admire the attractions. There are more interested in the beach and sports activities. The ocean waves of Hikkaduwa Beach and Narigama beach are excellent for surfing. There are plenty of schools in their neighborhoods. The instructors teach tourists to catch waves, conquering water, and even give out the PADI Certificate. Hikkaduwa is famous for its coral reefs. Together with several shipwrecks, they make this resort a perfect place for diving and snorkeling. The nightlife is mostly concentrated in beach bars, small dance floors, clubs at hotels. Vibration Hotel is famous for throwing great Friday parties.

Bentota

Bentota is considered to be one of the most romantic cities in Sri Lanka. Just-married couples and pairs in love from all over the world like coming here for a vacation. It's not surprising as the resort is renowned for its beautiful and photogenic beaches, framed with coconut palms. Weirdly enough, but this resort is not crowded at all, and it's quite quiet. The government gladly finance the development of the city as an Ayurvedic center. Fans of active leisure activities won't get bored in Bentota. Confifi Marina is waiting for them. It's the largest center of water sports in the country. Guests are offered to surf, learn how to water ski, enjoy a ride in a paddleboat, canoe, banana, or scooter. Confifi Marina organizes cruises in a yacht and fishing tours. A list of the favorite tourist activities also includes a slow ride on a motorboat along the Bentota River, a visit to Bevis Bawa Garden (the most picturesque part of the city), and a Turtle Sanctuary.

description.en: South Korea is a country with a high level of economic development, an "Asian tiger", and a state that was able to make a leap from the Middle Ages not just into the XXI century, but into the distant future. It has the fastest wireless Internet in the world, free Wi-Fi, shops open 24 hours a day, there is no such thing as "vacation", and the IQ of the local population is considered to be the second in the world (after Hong Kong). This is a country where an incredible mix of history, culture, cuisine, traditions, and exciting attractions is waiting for tourists. Fans of sightseeing and beach rest, as well as lovers of diving and other extreme entertainment, will find here attractions to their liking.

geography.en: The Republic of Korea is located in the southern part of the Korean Peninsula. Its only neighbor is North Korea or the Democratic People's Republic of Korea (DPRK). The waters of the Korea Strait wash the state in the south, the Sea of Japan in the east, and the Yellow Sea in the west. The country is also comprising several islands, the largest of which is located in the south: Geojedo, Jejudo, and Jindo. The area is predominantly mountainous, so the islands are more attractive for climbing enthusiasts. By the way, the highest point of the country, Hallasan volcano (1947 m), is on Jejudo Island. The main mountain range of the country is Taebaek Mountains. South Korea's modern administrative and territorial structure retains a three-tier system that dates back to the XIX century: the provincial, municipal, and sub-municipal levels. The first tier includes the Special Status City (Seoul), metropolitan cities, provinces, special autonomous cities, and special autonomous provinces. The second level contains cities and municipal areas. The third level comprises ordinary districts, county towns, municipalities, townships, blocks, and villages.In South Korea, there are nine provinces and six metropolitan cities.

long_description.en:
Seoul

Seoul is the capital and a huge metropolis with a population of 10 million. It is a city of skyscrapers, ancient temples, and authentic streets. It's better to start walking from the Bukchon Hanok Village quarter to dive yourself in Asian culture immediately. This is where the traditional houses with tiled roofs of Hanok are located, and people in traditional costumes walk. Taking into account the immense size of the city, the 236-meter N Seoul Tower offers a colorful panorama. Architecture lovers will appreciate the Dongdaemun Design Plaza, a futuristic building designed by Zaha Hadid. Those who are crazy about deer should visit Seoul Forest Park. The fantastic places in Seoul do not end there. The Lotte World entertainment park, listed in the Guinness Book of Records, the largest water park COEX Aquarium, numerous cathedrals, and museums, are still waiting for you. 

Busan

Busan is famous for its beaches, lush mountain scenery, and temples. The Koreans call this city "the sea capital of Korea," but apart from the large port, there are unique skyscrapers, including the tallest building in the country (301 m), and the largest department store in the world. Tourists come here in summer to relax on the beaches and dive under the water to get acquainted with the rich underwater world. The most famous beach is Haeundae. It is covered with snow-white sand, and the coastline is 1.5 km long. You can start exploring the antiquity at the Dongnaeeupseong Fortress, which was built before our era. Beomeosa Monastery is also one of the five-most ancient temples in Korea. A three-level pagoda, entrance gate, and stone lamp, dating back to 1592, have been preserved on the site. Another pearl of religious architecture is the Haedong Yonggung Temple. There are hot springs with curative water and a unique Pagoda of prayers for safety on the roads. 

Incheon

Incheon is a developed economic center in South Korea that used to be a small fishing village. Despite its continuous development, the authorities have been safeguarding the city's historical past. There is a whole quarter here where the authentic architecture of the past centuries, buried in lush green parks, has been preserved. The holy place of the city is the Chamseongdan Altar. According to the locals, 4,000 years ago, it was the place where they used to make sacrifices to heaven. For Koreans, this is one of the iconic religious sites. You can get acquainted with the history of the country in the city museum, and with resort life — on the Eurwangni Beach. 

Daegu

Daegu is a conservative place where the great influence of Buddhism has been retained. Its traditions, temples, and the study of Confucianism were concentrated in the academy of the same name. Given the fact that mountains surround the region, you can enjoy a spectacular panorama even from small peaks. Mountain tourism is developed here at the highest level. You can start climbing from Palgongsan, one of the holiest places for Koreans. According to legends, there is a spirit that helps dreams come true. Tourists prefer to continue their mountain adventure in Apsan Park — the embodiment of wildlife, the kingdom of mountain peaks, and valleys. Souvenirs and local curiosities can be bought at Seomun Market, a traditional Asian market.

Gwangju

Gwangju is one of the oldest cities with a long history and the largest metropolis in South Korea. The first mention of the settlement dates back to 370 AD. There are many interesting sights, picturesque parks, and historical buildings. The main attraction of this area was Fort Namhansanseong. The building dates back to the time of Silla (58 BC). The height is 8 meters, and the length is 12 kilometers. It is incredible how a wooden fort of this size could have been built without special tools at that time. The city also has many marvelous streets selling antiques, various parks, and historical sites. 

Jeju

Jeju is an island in South Korea that attracts with its unique nature, vast ocean, sandy beaches, mandarin gardens, palm plantations, green tea, and waterfalls. Jeongbang Waterfall is the only waterfall that flows into the sea. To get close to it, you will have to climb a long staircase passing among rocks and lianas. Hallim Park is a botanical garden where you can visit caves with unique stalactites and stalagmites. Oedolgae Park stretches along the coast near a rocky cliff. Here stands a lonely rock, which, according to the legend, was a girl waiting for her beloved. Among the unique places on the island is the Green Tea Museum, where you can get acquainted with the technology of collection, production, and, of course, taste a drink. Orchid parks, miniatures, and a workshop of stone statues are also must-visit places the island.

description.en: Japanese is a glorious country with the richest history, unique traditions, etiquette, ceremonies, and rituals. Every year, it attracts the attention of millions of tourists. And the usage of high-technology solutions provides an opportunity to travel around the country with great comfort. Japan offers vacation to any taste: improve your health at hot mineral springs, ascend Mount Fuji, visit Himeji Castle, study the art of the classical Japanese tea-drinking, enjoy active pastime on tropical beaches and skiing resorts.

geography.en: Japan is an island country in East Asia. It is located on the Japanese archipelago, which includes more than 4000 islands. Hokkaido, Kyushu, Honshu, and Shikoku are the largest of them. Lands of Japan are washed by the waters of the Pacific Ocean, the East China Sea, and the Sea of Japan and Okhotsk. Highlands pre-dominate on the territory of Japan and include over two hundred volcanoes, both active and dormant. Mount Fuji is the highest peak in the country, a popular pilgrimage site, and an active volcano. There are two levels of the official administrative structure: prefectural and municipal. There are 47 prefectures in the country. In return, they are divided into districts (there are only 14 of them and only in Hokkaido prefecture), cities designated by government ordinance (they include cities with a population of over 500 thousand people), and towns. The municipal level consists of core and special cities, just cities, special districts of Tokyo, cities’ districts, villages, and wards.For the sake of convenience, unofficially, the country is divided into several regions: Hokkaido, Tohoku, Kanto, Chūbu, Kansai, Chūgoku, Shikoku, Kyushu, and Okinawa.

long_description.en:
The contiguity of ancient traditions and nanotechnologies makes Japan an absolutely unbelievable place. Every town in the Land of the Rising Sun is an ultimate attraction as it is. 

Tokyo

Tokyo is the safest megalopolis on the planet. It is situated on Honshu island. It’s a combination of the vivid urban style and national color with love and respect for ancient traditions. That’s the place where they create robots, the worldwide known anime, and get on the street to admire the bloom of the cherry blossom every spring. When you get to the observation deck of Tokyo Tower, you shall see not only the Tokyo Imperial Palace, surrounded by exuberant gardens but also the panoramic view of the city in its full scale and majesty. We also highly recommend you to visit the oldest Tsukiji Fish Market, where you can taste the authentic Japanese sushi. The old district of Asakusa will give you a chance to see Medieval Japan and admire incredibly refined and exquisite geishas’ performances in Nakamura-za theatres. 

Yokohama

Yokohama is one of the most modern and urban cities in the Land of the Rising Sun. It is located only 30 km from Tokyo. The majority of its sights are situated in Minato Mirai district, which stands for “the Port of the Future”. The observation deck of the Landmark Tower skyscraper offers a breathtaking view of the bay, suspension bridge, and the giant Ferris Wheel. We recommend you to visit this place in the evening to see the illuminated city at its best. Yokohama Silk Museum is another fascinating attraction that tells about silk production in Japan.

Osaka

Osaka is the amusement center of the country. It offers its guests a wide range of shopping malls, nightclubs, bars, the Universal theme park, an aquarium, and an observation deck on top of the skyscraper. The art of the Japanese puppet theatre was born in Osaka. Nowadays, you can attend their performances at the National Bunraku Theatre. Moreover, the city has plenty of the most beautiful castles and temples. The most significant of them include magnificent Sumiyoshi Grand Shrine and Osaka Castle built many centuries ago. It consists of three underground and five overland floors. A tour around this place can help you dive into the atmosphere of ancient samurais’ lives.

Kyoto

Kyoto is one of the most ancient cities in Japan. Almost one thousand years ago, it was a capital. And this fact makes it particularly attractive. Many people know about the local attractions. And if you don’t know for sure, you have at least heard about them: Rokuon-ji, Sagano Bamboo Forest, Nijō, Fushimi, and Fukuyama Castles. And, of course, it’s Ryōan-ji with its Zen temple and gardens - the most renowned location in Kyoto.

Nagoya

Nagoya is the megalopolis with flawless infrastructure. It’s a perfect choice for fanciers of active rest and travelers with children. Here you can attend the Atsuta Shrine, which is one of the oldest temples in Japan. It stores the sacred sword Kusanagi. The Toyota Commemorative Museum of Industry and Technology is another fascinating attraction. If you want to swift the urban landscapes for something more natural, there are plenty of places for outdoor activities in Nagoya. We highly recommend you to visit the port and see the show of dolphins, and National Museum of Ethnology in the open air. The main exhibits of the later are houses built in the second half of the XIX century, brought here from all over the country. Nagoya also can boast of an exciting zoo, Botanic Garden with a diversity of extraordinary plants, and the Monkey Park. 

Sapporo

You might be surprised, but Japan also has skiing resorts that are located in Sapporo, on Hokkaido island. Besides that, the city is famous for its Jozankei Onsen. These are gorgeous thermal springs. Just like in any other Japanese city, Sapporo has a wide range of sights: temples, palaces, Nakajima and Makomanai parks, and also a Salmon Museum, a clock tower, Odori Park, chocolate factory, and a Museum of Beer. Annually, at the beginning of February, Sapporo hosts the Snow Festival - Yuki-matsuri. In this period, streets are filled with ice or snow figures. Most frequently, these are Japanese and world architectural and art monuments.

description.en: Azerbaijan is the pearl of the Caucasus, which has grown up on the coast of the Caspian Sea. It is nowadays shocking with its pace of development. Modern Azerbaijan is a symbiosis of European and Asian cultures. Medieval fortresses are neighboring the Khrushchyovka buildings here, and mosques and ribats create an amazing architectural contrast to modern skyscrapers. Here the black blood of the earth — oil — is gushing in, and the eternal fire of Yanar Dag is dispelling the night darkness.

long_description.en:
Azerbaijan occupies high slopes of the Caucasus Mountains and faces the Caspian Sea. This country attracts tourists from all over the world with its history, diversity of flora and fauna, and rich cultural heritage. Such major international events as the Baku Shopping Festival, Islamic Solidarity Games, Formula 1 races encourage foreigners' interest in Azerbaijan even more.

Baku

It is worth starting your acquaintance with the country in its capital, Baku. The city began to form back in ancient times around the ancient fortress of İcheri Sheher. Today the architecture of buildings reminds a little of Vienna, Paris, Barcelona at the same time but with an oriental flavor: with minarets and mosques, typical balconies and caravanserais, tea and antique shops. Baku resembles a carpet woven from ancient traditions and modern trends, slightly burnt in the sun, but still retaining the brightness of colors. Here you want to get lost and explore every street by yourself without maps and navigators. You can go from the fortress of the Palace of the Shirvanshahs down the stony streets of the Old Town, admiring the ornate details of the facades. And then, admire the glass flame of towers and cosmic forms of the Heydar Aliyev Centre. You can also check out the patterns of the exhibits at the Azerbaijan Carpet Museum and see the believers going to the service at Bibi-Heybat Mosque. Absorb the good-natured atmosphere and plan your next visit before you leave the country.

Ganja

Ganja is the second-largest city in Azerbaijan. It is considered to be one of the most beautiful cities in the country. So, you should tune in to Eastern Zen and enjoy measured walks. Visit Sheikh Bahauddin's historical-architectural complex. Synchronize your watch over the sun rays falling on the white walls of the Juma Mosque. Honor the memory of those killed in the Great Patriotic War at the Bottle House. And make sure you have dinner in a traditional restaurant. They say that it is in Ganja that dishes of national cuisine are especially delicious.

Azerbaijan offers excellent conditions for a health-improving holiday.

Lankaran

In order to raise your vital tonus, sunbathe on the healing black sands in Lankaran. The large port city is famous for its thermal springs. Their water is used for treating diseases of nervous and cardiovascular systems, musculoskeletal apparatus, and for restoring immunity. After filling your body with health and energy, go and see local sights. It's worth visiting the Palace of Mir Ahmad khan, which the ruler ordered to be built for his wife; visit the Lankaran fortress of the XVIII century and be sure to taste fragrant tea from local plantations.

Naftalan

You can also improve your health at the resorts of Naftalan. This is the only naphthalene oil deposit in the world known for its unique curative properties. Its baths are recommended for treating ENT conditions, diseases of joints, skin, and urogenital system. Five-star hotels and sanatoriums of Naftalan offer a high level of medical procedures and all conditions for excellent recreation.

Sumqayit

Sumqayit is the center of Azerbaijan's petrochemical industry and a popular place for lazy beach holidays. This city is very young. It was founded during the period of the Soviet Union, so there are no significant historical monuments here. But it is possible to enjoy the warm Caspian Sea here in full. A 34-kilometer-long beach line stretches along the whole city. For tourists with children, there is a waterpark and a puppet theater, which gives performances on the water. And if you cannot go without antiquities, you can visit the neighboring Corat for a tour of ancient baths and Muslim temples, or Baku, which is ready to impress tourists around the clock.

Shaki

Halfway between Baku and Tbilisi, Shaki hides among sharp gorges and green valleys. Since the times of the Silk Road, this city has been a major handicraft center. Caravanserais, with the area of 8 thousand square meters, Juma Mosque and Minaret of Gileyli, Fortress of Nukha, and Palace of Sheki khans, have been preserved till nowadays. This is where lovers of historical relics can unburden their hearts! Sweet tooths will also like it in Shaki. Here they cook fragrant halva and baklava according to carefully-preserved ancient recipes.

description.en: Armenia is a unique country with an intriguing history. It has managed to preserve its religion, culture, and language throughout the millennia. There are the most ancient orthodox monasteries on its territory. The longest reversible ropeway in the world leads to one of them — the Tatev Monastery, which is located near the city of Goris. The oldest winery has been found in the vicinity of the town of Yeghegnadzor. Armenia amazes with its historical and architectural monuments, amazing landscapes, magnificent nature, and people with greatheartedness.

geography.en: Armenia is Transcaucasia located in the north-east of the Armenian Highland, in the north of West Asia, between the Black and Caspian Seas. Still, it has no access to the sea. But there are more than a hundred lakes here, the biggest of which is Sevan. Armenia is neighboring with Azerbaijan, Iran, Turkey, and Georgia. From the north and east, it is protected by the ridges of the Lesser Caucasus. The majority of the country's territory is mountains. The highest point of Armenia is Mount Aragats, which is 4095 m high.

long_description.en:
The opportunity to see one of the world's oldest civilizations year after year attracts thousands of tourists to Armenia. Each of its cities is filled with its unique charm. The local roads leave much to be desired, and the residents will sometimes speak only Armenian, but these small difficulties only emphasize the local color and identity. 

Yerevan

The capital of Armenia is Yerevan, a delightful city, one of the brightest and most charming in Europe. It spreads out in the middle of the Ararat plain. As the houses are made of amazing pink tuff, it is called a pink city and looks exceptionally beautiful at sunset. Yerevan amazingly harmoniously combines modern skyscrapers and small old houses — architectural monuments of Armenian architecture. The Haghtanak Bridge, which is built over the Hrazdan River, offers a beautiful panoramic view of the city. The region has the ruins of the Urartian Erebuni Fortress and Teishebaini town. The monasteries and temples of the capital start their chronicle in the XV century, and the Yerevan Cathedral is the most majestic of them. The residents of the capital are rightly proud of the fact that the Mesrop Mashtots Institute of Ancient Manuscripts is located in Yerevan. It is one of the largest repositories of this kind in the world. A museum has been opened at the Institute, which is visited by about 50 thousand people a year. The market in Yerevan is another bright and very atmospheric place. Carpets, which are the national pride of Armenians, deserve special attention. Yerevan has many great jazz clubs and trendy cafes, picturesque parks, waterfalls, and lakes. 

Etchmiadzin

Etchmiadzin, the spiritual capital of Armenia and a place of pilgrimage for Christians, is located 20 km from Yerevan. The residence of the Catholicos, Etchmiadzin Cathedral, which is included in the UNESCO list of cultural heritage, the churches of Saint Hripsime, Gayane, and Shoghakat are located here. Armenia was the first state to proclaim Christianity as its official religion in 301. The Echmiadzin Historical and Ethnographic Museum houses the most significant Christian relics: a piece of the cross on which Jesus was crucified and a fragment of Noah's Ark. This small town is of key importance to the whole Christian world.

Gyumri

Gyumri is considered the cultural center of Armenia. The first settlements on its territory appeared even before our era. The city was severely damaged by an earthquake in 1988. Many sights were destroyed or damaged, and the process of their restoration is still in process. There are many museums dedicated to local artists and poets, drama and puppet theaters, an art gallery, parks with lakes, and picturesque landscapes. Mother Armenia monument takes a special place among the local attractions. It is clearly visible from almost anywhere in the city. Nearby, you can find another attraction — the Black Sentry (Sev Ghul), which offers a magnificent view of the town.

Sevan

Sevan is the most favorite resort in sunny Armenia. The town is located on the shore of the lake of the same name with beautiful and well-groomed beaches. This area has a special microclimate, clean air, and transparent blue water, which is heated in summer to +24 ° C. The lake has a volcanic origin and is the biggest freshwater body of the country. Here you can go yachting, catamaran riding, water skiing, or surfing. One can go fishing in the lake, while the lovers of antiquities can visit Sevanavank Monastery. Fans of tasty and exquisite food should try baked Sevan trout and kebab made of crayfish necks.

Dilijan

Dilijan is a paradise place surrounded by Dilijan National Park. Everything is beautiful here: air, nature, landscapes. This climatic and balneological mountain resort attracts tourists all year round. The composition of the mineral water in Dilijan is similar to that of Borjomi and Vichy. Thanks to the unique combination of climate and beneficial substances in the water, Dilijan is one of the best places for people with respiratory diseases. Besides the healing effect on the organism, here you can also be culturally enriched by visiting ancient Haghartsin and Goshavank monasteries, as well as the Geological Museum and Art Gallery of Dilijan. 

Tsaghkadzor

Tsaghkadzor is located in a beautiful valley at the foot of Mount Teghenis. It is a dynamic ski resort, where new hotels are opened every year. Unique climatic conditions allow not only excellent skiing or snowboarding opportunities but also a chance to improve your health. The air is saturated with essential oils of pine trees, which increases the hemoglobin level in the blood and has a favorable effect on the overall work of the whole organism. On bright days, there is a beautiful view of Lake Sevan and Biblical Ararat.

description.en: Bangladesh is a fantastic place on our planet with incredibly beautiful nature, huge tourist potential and ... overwhelming poverty and dirt. Local people, without any embarrassment, ease themselves right on the streets in the laid sewerage system. Just next to this scene, street merchants cook and sell food that they eat here with their hands... The picture is terrifying, yet tourists come here because there are corners of mesmerizing nature among all this, dozens of kilometers of clean sandy beaches with a gentle entrance to the azure water... And except for the fact that the white man in these areas is "an unseen miracle" (people will want to take pictures with you, or at least look closely). Locals are amiable here, the crime rate is extremely low, and tourists are welcomed as dear guests. It is encouraging that the authorities are taking action in the direction of tourism development in this amazing country, rich in history, ancient monuments, emerald forests, blue rivers, and endless waters of the Indian Ocean.

geography.en: The People's Republic of Bangladesh is located in South Asia, in the fertile delta of the Ganges and Brahmaputra rivers. There are 58 rivers flowing through the country, and it is only a few meters above sea level. Therefore, if the water level rises by one meter, it is believed that 10% of the territory will be flooded.  India surrounds the country along its perimeter, except for small areas where there are common borders with Myanmar, and in the south, it is washed by the Bay of Bengal of the Indian Ocean. The relief here is mostly flat, excluding the southeast, where the western ridges of the Lushai and Chittagong Hills are spread. Bangladesh has eight administrative regions, which are called the largest cities. The regions are divided into 64 districts, which in turn consist of the sub-districts. The latter include areas with a police department, which are divided into communes and include several villages. In large cities, the police departments are divided into districts, and those districts are divided into quarters.

long_description.en:
Dhaka

Dhaka is the capital and largest city of Bangladesh, which stands on the Buriganga River. It is the most densely populated place on earth and also the poorest and dirtiest city in the world. It has an acute drinking water problem. Everything here is mired in garbage, stench, and ubiquitous flies. Sad statistics report high child deaths, so children under 10 are not even registered here. There are 52 universities in the capital, and most of the country's industry is concentrated here: cotton, food, metalworking manufactures. They also produce jute fiber, muslin, and rice here. The main attractions are the Pink Palace, Lalbagh Fort, and the Baitul Mukarram National Mosque.

Chittagong

Chittagong is the second-largest industrial city and the most important port in the country. Chittagong is known as the "ship cemetery" of Bangladesh, the world's largest fleet utilization center. The coastline, where thousands of wrecked ships are scattered, stretches for 40 km. The city has a concentration of oil refining, steel, automotive, and chemical industries. Just 20 km from Chittagong, there is a beautiful sandy beach of Patenga. It is a good place for a picnic, and there are also many marsh bird species.

Khulna

Khulna is an industrial and commercial center known for its jute production. Local factories have preserved "industrial relics" — water mills, passenger ferries, steam engines, presses, etc., which are over 70 years old. Mangroves and swamps surround the city.

Bagerhat

Bagerhat is the ancient "City of Mosques", which until recently had been considered lost. It is located near the modern city of Bagerhat (Khulna County). Now, there are about 2000 mosques with the age of more than 1000 years. The ancient city is of great historical value and has become a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Its main business card is the Gumbad Mosque, erected in the XV century and having 81 domes (77 of them identical).

Sylhet

Sylhet is the world's largest tea region with the city located in the green valley of the Surma River, close to the state border of India. Favorable climate, fertile soil, and abundant rainfall in this area have created ideal conditions for growing tea.

Cox's Bazar

Cox's Bazar is the tourist capital and the only sea resort in the country. It is located near the border with Myanmar. Delightful beaches with golden sand and clear water without sharks attract here tourists, including the foreign ones. Here you shall find the longest natural beach in the world, with a length of 125 km. There are many active Buddhist temples with monks in the vicinity of the city. Unfortunately, the infrastructure here is still poorly developed.

description.en: Some legends that have survived to this day say that this is where the Garden of Eden from the Bible was once located. As evidence, there's an amazing tree that has been growing lonely among the desert sands for centuries. Others assert that it was here that the fairytale country of the "One Thousand and One Nights" used to be where the Sinbad the Sailor lived. One way or another, Bahrain really took something from each of these legends. The oases, scattered in large numbers across the deserts, really remind us of the Gardens of Eden, while the old forts and fortresses are the witnesses of ancient heroic battles.

geography.en: The Kingdom of Bahrain is a small state located on an archipelago of 33 islands in the Persian Gulf, near the Arabian Peninsula. Its closest neighbors are Saudi Arabia and Qatar.  The area of the largest of the islands of the archipelago of the same name as the state is 590 square kilometers, which is about three-quarters of the territory of the whole country. There is a plateau in the center of the island, the highest point of which is Jabal ad Dukhan (134 meters). And it is the only island formed of limestone; the rest is of coral origin.  There are no rivers in Bahrain, but there are quite a few underground springs here, and each of them is the basis of blooming oases scattered in the desert. Only 5% of the country's land is suitable for cultivation and is mainly occupied by date palm plantations. Until 2002, Bahrain had been divided into 12 municipalities; today (after the reform), the country is divided into four administrative and territorial units - governorates.

long_description.en:
Manama

Manama is the capital of Bahrain and the largest city in the country, with about a quarter of its total population. Here you can feel the influence of British culture quite strongly: the enumeration of the floors is done according to the British system (from the second one), the bars are decorated in the style of Irish pubs, and taxis are exact copies of London cabs. However, the unique flavor of Oriental bazaars has been amazingly preserved here, and the towers of the Bahrain World Trade Centre are harmoniously combined with ancient palaces and mosques. You can wander around the old town for hours, watching the life of its inhabitants, choosing souvenirs and bargaining at colorful markets, or sipping coffee in small cafes. The capital has several key attractions — King Fahd Causeway (a 25-kilometer-long structure linking Bahrain with Saudi Arabia), several beautiful mosques such as the ancient Al-Khamis, and the XX century Al Fateh (considered to be the largest building in Bahrain). Other notable sites include the Al Fadhel Mosque and St. Christopher's Cathedral, the country's largest fort in Qal'at al-Bahrain, a UNESCO cultural heritage site. Another significant historical monument is the Royal Tombs archaeological complex, which has 85,000 ancient graves. The National Museum of Manama is one of the richest in the Persian Gulf. Its expositions allow getting acquainted with the history and culture of the kingdom. And there is also the Museum of Pearls, Oil and even the Museum of the Quran. 

Riffa

Riffa is also located on the island of Bahrain, just 7 kilometers from the capital. There are also many interesting sights and places worth visiting. The city itself is divided into two parts — western and eastern and is growing rapidly. In it, you just have to walk along the shopping streets, choose souvenirs, or even more necessary and useful goods. The most interesting sight in Eastern Riffa is Riffa Fort. It was founded back in the XVII century, and at the beginning of the XIX century, it became the residence of Sheikh Salman bin Ibrahim Al Khalifa. Nowadays, it is a museum, the entrance to which is free. Even the wind tower, an ancient analog of modern air conditioners, has been preserved here. From Western Riffa, tourists tend to bring selfies in front of the famous Clock Tower. This part of the city is also home to Bahrain's national stadium, where most football battles and other sporting events take place.

Muharraq

Muharraq was the former capital of Bahrain (until 1923). The city is located on a separate island of the same name, the second-largest after Bahrain. It is adjoined by the artificial Amwaj Islands — a kingdom of luxury villas, hotels, and even super modern office buildings. As for Muharraq itself, the most interesting places for tourists will be traditional buildings with colorful architecture — the house of Sheikh Isa ibn Ali Al Khalifa which served as a government residence and the Siyadi House with its refined lines and luxurious interior decoration. There are also two ancient forts that undoubtedly deserve the attention of Bahrain's guests — Abu Mahir Fort and Arad Fort, which protected the maritime trade routes. They are both undergoing extensive restoration. There is also a real camel farm in the city where race camels are being bred.

Sitra

Sitra is a small town, which is also located on a separate island of the same name. A thriving industrial center with a port, oil and aluminum processing plants and a desalination company has, in recent years, focused on the development of the tourist industry and has not failed. Comfortable hotels quickly became popular with tourists, as well as fish restaurants. In addition, you can rent a car here and drive around the island. Nature here is impressive, especially the whole groves of date palms, which are irrigated with freshwater springs. Lovers of sea walks and fishing also come here. 

Barbar

Barbar is a tiny town, but more like a village, which, however, deserves the attention of tourists. Here you will find an outstanding architectural monument — the ancient Barbar Temple. To be more precise, there are even several temples that were built on top of each other, the oldest of which dates back to 3000 BC. Archaeologists believe that they were erected in honor of the god of wisdom and freshwater Enki and his wife, the goddess of fertility Ninḫursaĝ. There are two altars in the Barbar Temple and a natural water source, which is of spiritual importance to believers. Unique findings were made during excavations here — weapons, ceramics, tools, jewelry, and the most resonant of them was the bronze head of a bull. 

Zallaq

Zallaq is another small village, which will be primarily interesting for fans of beach recreation and ecotourism. Its main attraction is the famous Jazaer Beach, with snow-white sand and tender, endless, blue sea. By the way, there is quite a long stretch of shallow water, which is convenient for tourists with children. It is allowed to organize picnics and even set tents right on the beach. Local fishers are quite willing to rent their boats; there is also a yacht club. And nearby, there is one of the national reserves — Al Areen Wildlife Park. But you need a permit to visit it.

description.en: Brunei is a small country on the island of Borneo, where the locals love their ruler, Sultan Hassanal Bolkiah, and never criticize him. There are good reasons for this — Bruneians are exempt from all taxes. Every citizen can get free education not only in the sultanate but also in any country in the world. And relatives will visit the student at public expense. The medical care is also covered, and the family receives a substantial allowance when the child is born. All residents of the country have their own cars (local people prefer expensive brands), so public transport is underdeveloped. All this prosperity was made possible after the discovery of oil deposits in Brunei ( at the beginning of the last century). But the untold wealth of the country has not helped its economy, education, or culture. The industrial products, consumer goods, and even food are imported, and about 40% of all workers are foreigners.

Bhutan is an exotic eastern kingdom, which only opened to the outer world in 1972. It is a mountainous country with smiling inhabitants, harsh climate, spicy dishes, and a hundred Buddhist shrines. You can't come here for no reason and whenever you want — only with a group and with the permission of the tour operator. That is why Bhutan is still a little-known destination for tourists, surrounded by mysteries and legends.

geography.en: Bhutan is a small Asian kingdom situated on the southern slope of the Greater Himalayas. It lies hidden between India and China.  Bhutan is considered to be one of the most hard-to-reach states in the world due to its complicated terrain. The country, slightly smaller than Slovakia, has a height difference of 6840 meters. There is still a dispute as to which peak is the highest — Kula Kangri or Gangkhar Puensum. Difficulties are connected with the blurred borders with China and the difference in measurements between Bhutanese and Chinese. Anyway, the height of these mountains is about 7550 meters. In total, there are nineteen seven-thousand-peaks in Bhutan.There are mountain rivers in the country. They have appeared as a result of the melting of glaciers and which occupy 10% of the country's territory. They all form four river systems — Manas, Sankosh, Wong Chhu, and Shil Torsa — and carry their waters to neighboring India. The Black Mountains in central Bhutan are a natural watershed. The kingdom also has a mountainous Thorthormi lake and many small reservoirs.The central part of the state is covered with forests, while the southern part is notable for its fertile lands and large-scale jungle, where tigers, leopards, and even elephants live.Bhutan is divided into four dzongdeys (Western, Central, Southern, Eastern), which include 20 dzongkhags. They, in turn, are divided into dungkhags and gewogs.

long_description.en:
Thimphu

The capital and largest city of Bhutan. It attracts tourists primarily by the Fortress of the Glorious Religion (Tashichho Dzong). It was built in 1216 as a Buddhist monastery, where 2000 monks lived. In the middle of the last century, the temple was rebuilt after a fire, and it hosted the government and the King's office. Another attraction is the Memorial Chorten, Thimphu. It is an important religious site not only for the capital but for the whole country. It was erected in 1974 to commemorate the third king of Bhutan. Chorten is made in Tibetan style, in the form of a classic stupa with an altar. Traditionally, to fulfill all the wishes, you have to go around the stupa in a clockwise direction, not forgetting to spin the prayer wheels.

Phuentsholing

It is the second-largest city of Bhutan, on the border with India through which runs the only highway in the state connecting the two countries. The majority of the population in Phuentsholing is Indian. This is where the first post office in the country was opened. Unlike other cities, it has more modern architecture, without monasteries or dzongs. Phuentsholing is famous for its Amo Chhu Crocodile Breeding Centre. Indeed, they are not grown for commercial purposes but to preserve the population of these reptiles. They release the grown specimens from the center to the wild.

Paro

This is the only town in Bhutan with an international airport that is one of the most inaccessible in the world. Paro is a major religious and cultural center of the kingdom. The main Buddhist shrine of Bhutan is the high-mountain monastery of the Tiger's Nest or Paro Taktsang. It is located at an altitude of 3000 meters, on a steep slope, and consists of seven temples and monastic huts. It can be reached only on foot, or by horse up to half of the way, and then still climb on your own. The Tiger's Nest was destroyed by a fire in 1998 and restored only in 2005. This temple is one of the few monasteries open to visitors.

Punakha

The old winter capital, which is located in the Wangdue valley. The city has a mild climate, with subtropical plants such as bananas, oranges, and cacti. This is why it is the winter residence of the head of Bhutanese Buddhism, the Je Khenpo. The city has its own monastery — the Punakha Dzong. It stands at the confluence of two mountain rivers — Mo Chhu and Pho Chhu. There is a pedestrian bridge across the Mo Chhu River, which meets tourists at the entrance to the temple. In the Punakha Dzong, there is a large bodhi tree, a traditional Tibetan stupa, a library with 108 volumes of Kangyur (a Tibetan canon written in gold letters), and the mausoleum of the founder of the Kingdom of Bhutan.

Jakar

This is another large religious center with an ancient temple built in the VII century, the Jambey Lhakhang. Legend has it that King Songtsen Gampo ordered 108 monasteries to be built in one day to nail all parts of the demon's body that covered Tibet and the Himalayas, thereby preventing the spread of Buddhism. Kurjey Lhakhang monastery, with the body imprint of the famous guru Padmasambhava, is also worth a visit. This complex consists of three small royal monasteries and a large chorten.

description.en: East Timor is a country in Southeast Asia, occupying the island of Timor with Indonesia. The state gained its independence from Indonesia only in 2002. The capital is the city of Dili. East Timor is not well-treated by tourists, and this is not surprising. The infrastructure is not very developed here, prices are inflated compared to neighboring countries, and the crime rate is high. One of the country's symbols is a 27-meter statue of Jesus Christ, presented by the Indonesians. There is a beautiful view of the coast and Dili near it. In autumn in East Timor, you can observe the migration of dolphins and whales. It is worth mentioning diving off the coast, where you can find sharks and barracuda in addition to the usual corals. On the deserted Jaco Island, you can feel like a discoverer walking through the pristine jungles and pristine beaches.

Vietnam is like an ancient dragon, stretches all the way to the eastern coast of the Indochina Peninsula. This multinational state plays a leading role in the economy of Southeast Asia, being the world's leading exporter of coffee beans, raw oil, clothes, and rice.

geography.en: Vietnam is located in Southeast Asia. It spreads along the eastern coast of the Indochina Peninsula for 1600 km. The country neighbors with China in the north, with Cambodia and Laos in the west. The South China Sea washes its shores in the south and east. Mountains occupy more than 80% of the country's territory, forests cover about 30% of the territory. The Annamese Mountains stretch in the west of Vietnam. There are basalt and socle plateaus in the south and central part of the country, which make up the Tây Nguyên Plateau.

long_description.en:
North Vietnam

North Vietnam is a concentrate of fantastic landscapes and cultural monuments — the alpine rice terraces of Sa Pa, the underground rivers of the Chang'an landscape complex, the François' langurs and rhinoceros hornbills hiding in the dense crown of Cat Ba National Park, lush waterfalls Detian, surrounded by mangroves and rocky peaks as if descended from the screens of "Avatar". 

Hanoi is the capital of Vietnam, a city on the Red River. It is a symbiosis of ancient culture, modern technology, socialism, traditions of East and West. After walking in the foggy garden near the pagodas of the Confucian Temple of Literature, you will suddenly find yourself at the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum. The glass skyscrapers on Trang Thi Avenue blind your eyes! And if you are looking for some serenity, you can find it at Hoàn Kiếm Lake. People pray and meditate at the Temple of the Jade Mountain, and in the bustling streets of the Old Quarter, which smells of fried delicacies and dust, they have breakfast, cut hair, and sell everything. All this makes Hanoi something particularly charming. However, for most tourists, the capital becomes just a starting point for a trip to North Vietnam.

Hạ Long Bay, the most famous tourist attraction in Vietnam, is located a hundred kilometers from Hanoi. It is a place of 3000 small islands, which, like the dragon skin, scattered on the water surface of the South China Sea. Spare no expense on tour! Swim under the stone vaults of karst rocks on kayaks, admire high green mountains and marble cliff slopes from the water, look into cold caves and spend one of the most unforgettable sunsets on the ship's deck.

Central Vietnam

The sandy beaches of Central Vietnam have become a favorite destination for tourists from all over the world. The main city in the region is Da Nang, a major port and industrial center of the country. The wide sandy beach of China Beach in Da Nang attracts thousands of kite surfers and windsurfers every year, which turns the coast into a kaleidoscope of bright sails and boards. 

Nha Trang is especially popular with tourists. The strip of its snow-white sandy beaches, warm sea, cold cocktails, which are poured in bars of fashionable hotels, encourage enjoying lazy holidays. Divers will love it here: there is a famous Moray Beach, a coral reef called "Rainbow", and many picturesque islands near the resort. 

A trip to Central Vietnam will also delight history lovers. We highly recommend Hội An for visiting. It is fully protected by UNESCO, as a model of an ancient trade and port city, and Huế, the capital of the last emperors of the Nguyễn dynasty. And do not ignore the Phong Nha - Ke Bang National Park, which has the largest cave in the world.

South Vietnam

The heart of the whole country, Ho Chi Minh City, is beating in the south of Vietnam. It is the largest business center and an important transportation hub of the country. The ancient Saigon has preserved its history and colonial spirit within the walls of the Reunification Palace and Notre-Dame Cathedral Basilica of Saigon. From Ho Chi Minh City, a maze of underground labyrinths stretches across the Củ Chi district, where Vietnamese hid from Americans during the war. 

If you're looking for a resort that's ideal for a vacation with a child, head to Phan Thiết. The city's 40-meter-long beachfront features a gentle entrance to the sea, shallow coastline, and no corals, rocks, or moray. Other attractions include the Crocodile Nursery, where you can feed reptiles, and the Van Thuy Tu Communal House, where the skeleton fragments of the world's largest mammal are kept. If you are looking for a more active holiday, choose the Mui Ne Peninsula. The east coast of an ancient fishing village has become the center of kiting and surfing in South Vietnam.

The island of Phú Quốc is a genuine pearl of South Vietnam. This paradise is simply designed for a measured rest: the white sandy beaches of Bai Sao, the meditative rustling of palm trees bent over the coast of Ong Lang, the even reel of azure waves and thick green jungle are waiting for the tourists here. But don't worry if you get bored. The Phú Quốc's tourist infrastructure is developing at a frantic pace, with bars, casinos, diving schools, luxury hotels, and even an international airport.

description.en: Israel is a unique state that declared its independence on the 14th of May 1948 but has a centuries-old history. It is the center of three world religions, an oasis erected in the middle of the desert and one of the most attractive tourist destinations in the world. Kilometers of golden sandy beaches, the warm Mediterranean Sea, the healing resorts of the Dead Sea and Tiberias, hot Eilat, and shrines of Jerusalem attract millions of pilgrims and tourists from all over the world. Compassionate people and varied international cuisine will fill your trip with warmth and make it even brighter.

geography.en: Israel is a country in the Middle East, located in southwest Asia. It is washed by three seas — the Mediterranean, Red and Dead, and Lake Kinneret (the Sea of Galilee). One of the largest rivers in the Middle East — Jordan — flows here. The Negev desert occupies the southern part of Israel, while there is the Hermon mountain range in the north. The country abstains from formally defining its borders due to various factors, but geographically Israel borders on Lebanon, Syria, Jordan, and Egypt.

long_description.en:
One can conditionally divide people coming to Israel into several categories: the first is the pilgrims; the second is the people who come for medical treatment; the third — and the most numerous — are the tourists who want to relax on the magnificent beaches and have fun in the nightclubs and bars on the Mediterranean coast. 

Tel Aviv

The largest airport in Israel is in Tel Aviv. Therefore, it is very likely that your acquaintance with the country will start in this city. Tel Aviv ("Mound of Revival" or "Hill of Spring" from Hebrew) is a city that never sleeps. Every day something exciting happens here: exhibitions, presentations, fashion shows, performances, concerts. It offers excellent themed bars, exclusive nightclubs, and parties, where you can meet all the Israeli celebrities and more. The main attraction of Tel Aviv is its beaches. They are all wide, clean, well maintained, and well-equipped. Tel Aviv combines the modern architecture of the Azrieli skyscraper and the army houses with the sincerity of the old Neve Tzedek and Jaffa neighborhoods. The city is a UNESCO World Heritage Site under the name of the "White City". It is here, in the very heart of Tel Aviv, that the majority of white buildings (over 4,000) are built in the international Bauhaus style are located. There is also the Bauhaus Museum in the city. 

Jerusalem

Jerusalem is one of the oldest cities in the world; the capital and heart of Israel, its spiritual and cultural center. The streets of white Jerusalem stone, stalls with fresh pastries and fruit at every turn, people in strict black clothing, girls with guns — this is what Jerusalem looks like today, a city with an incredible history. It saw Jesus' hard trip to Golgotha through the Via Dolorosa, the Templars, and King David. It is home to the Church of the Holy Sepulchre, the Wailing Wall (Kotel), the Ayyubid Mosque of Omar, the Mount of Olives, the Gethsemane Garden, and many other iconic historical sites. Annually, millions of people of all ages and religions come here to worship the holy places, to ask for health, or just to make a wish. Every tourist should also check out the Montefiore Windmill, walk through the streets of the Old City, visit the City of David, the Museum of Israel and Yad Vashem (Shoah Museum) in Jerusalem. Israel is a country that not only honors and preserves the memory of the past but also knows how to have fun and live a bright life. The Jerusalem market turns into a bar street at night. This place vividly conveys the character of the people and the country — do not miss the opportunity to see this with your own eyes.

Nazareth

In the center of lower Galilee, in the north of the country, stands Nazareth — the city where Jesus Christ spent his childhood and youth. It is a famous pilgrimage center for Christians and Catholics. Every year, thousands of Orthodox believers strive to come here and visit the Church of the Annunciation of the Blessed Virgin Mary, and those who profess Catholicism head to the Basilica of the Annunciation. Each of the temples claims to be the place where Mary learned about the blessing that had come upon her.

Haifa

Haifa rises on Mount Carmel above the Mediterranean coast. It is the third-largest city in Israel. Beautiful, green, with clean mountain air, forests, and white sandy beaches, it is a great place to spend your vacation. Life here is buzzing with an abundance of night clubs, excellent restaurants, cafes, shopping malls, high-class hotels, museums, and art galleries. The Shrine of the Báb and its garden are most famous and rightfully the most beautiful attraction of Haifa. It consists of 19 terraces. The tomb of one of the founders of the Bahá'í religion is situated in the center of the gardens. It is also worth visiting the Cave of Elijah, the Stella Maris Monastery, or the Monastery of Our Lady of Mount Carmel, which you can reach in a cable car. It offers the most breathtaking views of the city. 

Netanya

Netanya is a resort city with a picturesque waterfront and many fish restaurants that can fit any taste. It has a mild climate, beautiful green parks, comfortable beaches and hotels filled with tourists almost all year round. Netanya has everything for active leisure: windsurfing, sailing, fishing, hang gliding, horseback riding, etc. Art lovers will be pleased to visit the numerous art galleries the city offers. Those who love flowers will enjoy Utopia Park, which is located not far from Netanya. It is famous for its collection of orchids and plants' predators, which you can not only admire, but also purchase. There is also an indoor tropical plant park, a cave, and a mini zoo.

Herzliya

Herzliya is a fashionable city with luxury villas, modern skyscrapers, and design boutiques. It is a popular residential area of famous and wealthy people. Here you can find an elegant quay (marina) with yachts that have flags of all countries. Chic restaurants, parks, magnificent waterfront attract here both tourists and locals. The city lies among well-groomed orange and lemon plantations. Besides the chic spirit of modernity, Herzliya has traces of ancient history. There are remains of a port and Crusader fortifications in the northern part of the city.

Eilat

Eilat is a resort city on the Red Sea coast, which has existed since the reign of King Solomon. Here you can come for a vacation and swim in the sea all year round — the temperature of water never falls below + 22 °С. Eilat is a beautiful place for a family holiday. Everybody will find amusement to his taste: windsurfing, yachting, diving. Diving in the waters of the Red Sea is especially fascinating — its saltwater is a favorable environment for corals. Here you shall find the largest aquarium in the country "Coral World", "City of Kings" theme park and dolphinarium. The Timna Valley Nature Reserve is located within half an hour's drive from Eilat. There you can admire the natural copper mines called the "King Solomon's Spears". 

Tiberias

The resort of Tiberias is another place where you can not only relax but also improve your health. It is located on the western shore of Lake Kinneret, famous for its healing hot springs. Every year, millions of tourists come here to heal and enhance their well-being. Visiting outdoor and indoor pools with heated mineral water, enjoying mud baths and all kinds of cosmetic procedures, traditional "dry" massage, Vichy water massage will turn your stay in Tiberias into a pleasant and useful experience. After the procedures, take a stroll along the waterfront and try the tilapia, which is also known as St. Peter's Fish in the local restaurants. 

Ein Gedi Nature Reserve

In the Judaean Desert, on the west coast of the Dead Sea, there is the Ein Gedi Nature Reserve and the kibbutz (agricultural community in Israel) of the same name. There used to be an ancient city in this region many centuries ago. Its ruins are an interesting archaeological find. Kibbutz Ein Gedi is known for its mineral water source, which is over 3000 years old. While being here, you can visit the museum and garden of cacti, climb one of the panoramic decks, where you can enjoy a beautiful view of the Dead Sea coast and the Mountain Jews.

description.en: India combines fascinating cultural traditions, an abundance of religions, colorful festivals, incredible architecture, unbelievable scenery, and exotic cuisine. Its landscapes are fantastic: you can admire the snowy peaks of the Himalayas, the sunlit tropical beaches, and dense evergreen forests. Sacred places, a diversity of spectacular rituals, tell about the vivid religious history. The local cuisine is a separate chapter in the book about India. Every region of the country has its unique traditions and recipes.

geography.en: India is a federal republic in South Asia. The majority of its territory is located on Peninsula Hindustan. It neighbors on Pakistan, China, Nepal, Bangladesh, Bhutan, and Myanmar. It has a maritime border with the Maldives, Sri Lanka, and Indonesia. The country is washed by the Indian Ocean, the Bay of Bengal, and the Arabian Sea. The length of the coastline compiles 7000 kilometers. The Deccan Plateau occupies the majority of the state. Seven chains of mountains go through the territory of India. They include the largest chain in the world - the Himalayas. The two largest rivers — the Ganges and Brahmaputra, — also have their rises in the mountains. India consists of 29 states and seven union territories. All of them are divided into districts and sub-districts - talukas.

long_description.en:
Every traveler who comes to India sees this country differently: some are shocked by the blazing poverty, while others see the kindest people in the world living in harmony and peace. Indeed, the beauty, refinement, and grace of this country depicted in its history, architecture, clothes, and holidays can't leave anyone indifferent. Every region and city has its character, dressed with its unique spices, and offers a diversity of flavors. 

Delhi

Delhi is one of the oldest and largest cities in the world that was founded around five thousand years ago. There is a legend saying that it was destroyed and restored to life 11 times. Delhi is the National Capital Territory that includes the district of New Delhi, which is the official capital of India. The governments of both the country and the district of Delhi seat here. The capital of India impresses with its beauty, the richness of the colonial mansions and contemporary buildings. Life in the city fast and loud: the music from bars and cafes fuses with neverending automobile honks and voices of the passers-by in a constant hurry. Everything is flavored with the sharp odor of the spices. Old Delhi has bright, narrow streets that keep the spirit of the Mughal Empire. This part of the city is a genuine treasury of ancient architectural monuments, religious and cultural objects that remind all of the nations who used to inhabit India. The most significant of them include Raj Ghat memorial devoted to the legendary Mahatma Gandhi; the largest mosque in India — the Jama Masjid; the Lotus temple that amazes with its beauty and sizes; the Red Fort — the grandiose fortress dating back to the period of Mughal Empire; the Rashtrapati Bhavan President's residence; the Qutb Minar temple complex, famous for the highest minaret in the world. And if you want to learn more about this incredible country, you should head to the National Museum. It's the largest museum in the country that attracts over eight million people annually. 

Mumbai

Mumbai is the most densely populated city in India. It's a large industrial center, a cosmopolitan city that unites European and Asian cultures. It's located on several islands in the Arabian Sea. Despite its centuries-old history, Mumbai officially became a city only in 1672. It was the springboard for the colonization of India by the British East India Company. There are several districts in the town, but the majority of attractions are concentrated in two of them — South and North West Mumbai. When you travel to Mumbai, you can't miss one of its most legendary symbols and the shrine for all India's Sunni Muslims — the Haji Ali Dargah. The Gateway of India is another sight all citizens are proud of. The last British soldiers left the country through this gate after independence had been proclaimed. The marvelous railway station that bears the name of the national hero of India — Chhatrapati Shivaji is the only monument in Mumbai, included in the UNESCO List of World Heritage Sites. When you get to the historic Dadabhai Naoroji Road, you will dive into the atmospheric life of Mumbai. The city managed to keep the spirit of the colonial epoch. It has many constructions in the English neo-Gothic and neoclassical styles. Mumbai (formerly known as Bombay) became the homeland of the Indian cinema. The first movie was released to theatres in 1896. Besides visiting various cultural and historical sights, you can also enjoy your time on the clean beaches of the city — Girgaon Chowpatty, Juhu, Aksa Beach.

Agra

The city of Agra is located in the north of India, on the banks of the Jamna river. It's famous for one of the New Seven Wonders of the World and one of the most popular tourist attractions – the fabulous palace of the Taj Mahal. It was built by the padishah of the Mughal Empire Shah Jahan as a symbol of eternal love to his wife who had died giving labor to their fourteenth child. Later, the ruler himself was buried here. This palace is deservedly considered to be the pearl of the Muslim art in India and is included in the UNESCO List of World Heritage Sites. When you happen to be in Agra, you should also visit the ghost town of Fatehpur Sikri; the Aram Bagh, which is the first garden created by the Mongols on the territory of India; Tomb of Akbar the Great and Chini ka Rauza Mausoleum. A large SPA center Kaya Kalp is also located in Agra. That's an excellent chance to relax and try various procedures. 

Bangalore

Bangalore is one of the most renowned and densely-populated Indian cities. The city is popular among tourists for its architectural monuments, temples, and marvelous national parks. Here you shall find Bangalore Palace, a residence of the city's rulers; modern Sri Radha Krishna-Chandra Mandir Temple, dedicated to Radha and Krishna; Lalbagh Botanical Gardens and Tipu Sultan Palace. In just 30 kilometers from Bangalore, hid in the forest, you shall find Nrityagram – it's a small settlement with a self-explanatory title that translates as a "dancing village". It's actually a tiny training site where only the women who have come to study the art of dance, can live. The enrollment to school happens once every six years. This place does not have any modern communication facilities – only the atmosphere of dancing. 

Kolkata

Kolkata (had been known as Calcutta till 2001) is the capital of the Indian state, West Bengal. The city was founded in the 90s of the XVII century and was the capital of British India. Kolkata is rich in attractions and monuments dating back to the colonial epoch. The most legendary of them include the white-stone St. Paul's Cathedral; the Victoria Memorial erected in honor of the British Queen; Fort William, which is one of the first constructions of the Brits. Besides, the city offers the oldest zoo in India — Alipore — created in 1876.

Jaipur

Jaipur is another city in India that is worth seeing. People often call it a "pink city" due to the pale pink color of the stone that was used during the construction of the majority of buildings. This is a city with an extraordinary atmosphere, bright history, and marvelous architecture. A walking tour is the best way to get acquainted with the city as the majority of its attractions are located in the old part of the town, surrounded by a wall. The City Palace is the former residence of the Rajasthan's rulers. It occupies one-seventh of the ancient city. Here you shall find a museum that displays a rich collection of clothes, weapons, household artifacts. Hawa Mahal ("The Palace of Winds") is deservedly considered to be the main attraction of Jaipur. Its facade consists of almost one thousand small windows that allows the air to blow through the building on hot days. That's where the name originates from. A harem of Maharaja used to be located here once. You also can't miss Amber Fort that impresses with its luxurious interior design and severe outer fortifications; the Jantar Mantar observatory; Galtaji and Vrindavan temple complexes. And don't forget to admire the city from the height of Swargasuli Tower. Jaipur is a town of craftsmen and the jewelry capital of India. They produce pieces of jewelry of astonishing beauty! That's an excellent variant of a souvenir to bring from a trip to a faraway country. 

Goa

The smallest state in India and the most popular resort is located in the southwest of the country, on the coast of the Arabian Sea. Goa consists of the North and South parts. Panaji is the capital of the state, while Vasco da Gama is the largest city. It's a beautiful destination for diving: here you can come across turtles, rays, tunas, barracudas, sharks, and many other underwater citizens. Goa also offers plenty of architectural monuments, and a couple of important Hindu temples: Shanta Durga Temple, Mangesh and Mahalasa Temples. Goa attracts thousands of tourists with is unique sanctuaries: Bondla Wildlife Sanctuary, Bhagwan, Mahavira, Bhadra, and Anshi National Park.

description.en: The Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan (Jordan) is a young Arab state that gained independence in 1946. In recent years, the country has been actively developing its tourist potential and has become an alternative to Egypt. And it ranks fifth in the world in medical tourism. Here you can enjoy the Red Sea, take stunning photos of the desert and mountain scenery, feel the daily routine of local Bedouins. The trademark of Jordan is the ancient city in the rocks — Petra. It is also worth trying dishes of national cuisine and finding "your" precious jewel on the counters of souvenir shops.

geography.en: Jordan is located in the north-west of the Arabian Peninsula, sharing borders with Syria, Iraq, Saudi Arabia, Israel, Egypt, and the partially recognized State of Palestine in the West Bank of the Jordan River. Almost the entire territory of the country is covered with deserts and semi-deserts, it is impossible to carry out agriculture here. Jordan is located at an altitude of about 700-1200 meters above sea level. The highest point is Jabal Umm ad Dami (1854 m), while the Dead Sea (about 400 m below sea level) is the lowest.  Administratively, Jordan is divided into 12 governorates (provinces), headed by governors. The largest cities are Amman, Aqaba, Irbid, and Ma'an.

long_description.en:
In Jordan, you can enjoy resort and city recreation, as well as combine it with an active journey to the most significant sights.

In the capital of Jordan, Amman, you can see two different aspects of life in the Arab country. The city is divided into Eastern and Western. The former is inhabited mainly by conservative Muslims and the poor, while the latter is buzzing with life in fashionable establishments and bright shops. The capital is known for the Royal Automobile Museum. Even if you are not a passionate motor enthusiast, the look and history of these chic cars will surely surprise you. It is also recommended to take a walk in the Royal Garden and learn more about the history of Jordan in the Archaeological Museum. If you want to explore Arabic culture and art, head to the Museums of Folk Tradition and Folklore. A huge amphitheater is also a landmark in Amman, and the view from a hilltop, near the remains of the old city, is wonderful. 

The most famous attraction of Jordan is Petra, one of the seven new wonders of the world inscribed in UNESCO's heritage. This ancient city, carved into the rocks, consists of a large complex of temples. The most famous are the Al-Khazneh Palace, Ad Deir, the Street of Facades, the High Place of Sacrifice, and the Byzantine Church. Here you can dive into another era, take great photos on the rocks, buy bottles filled with colored sand in the form of drawings, and try to make them yourself. If you are offered to climb the mountains to visit other temples, do not refuse to use a donkey or horse. Otherwise, you will have to walk for hours in the heat up the stairs and paths along the rocks. 

The Kingdom's National Park, the Red Sands Desert, Wadi Rum is another World Heritage Site. Here you will walk on the hard, fossilized ground and take pictures that look like Martian landscapes. This is where many famous fantasy movies were shot. Some of the attractions in Wadi Rum include the Burdah Rock Bridge, Khazali Canyon with its rock inscriptions, Lawrence's Spring, and the Seven Pillars of Wisdom. Bedouins offer camel rides ranging from simple walks to long day trips. A ride on a camel takes you to the Nabatean Temple and Ain Shellalah Spring. You can also book a jeep safari tour in Wadi Rum, do rock climbing and spend a night in a tent, but you need a special permit for this. 

The only port city in Jordan, Aqaba, is known worldwide as a diving center with the most beautiful underwater world of the Red Sea. The most popular place for lovers of exploring the sea depths is the shipwreck near the coast, at a depth of 25 meters. In addition to diving, you can also take part in other activities: water skiing, snorkeling, windsurfing, or just fishing in a quiet corner of the bay. Sightseers can visit the Mamluk Castle, the Old Town (a Roman settlement), and the Archaeological Museum. Aqaba also has the largest flag in the world, included in the Guinness Book of Records. There are a lot of boutiques, and the whole city is full of Duty-Free as Aqaba is free of duties on trade. 

If you want to recharge not only with new experiences but also to improve your health, visit the healing springs in Ma'an. They have been known since biblical times and have a high concentration of minerals useful for the human organism. The water temperature in them is about +40 °C, and they look like 30-meter waterfalls.

description.en: In the Mesopotamian lowlands, in the valley of the Tigris and Euphrates rivers, Iraq is a mysterious and authentic country. This country is imbued with legends and myths. Moreover, the most valuable monuments of cultural and historical heritage have been preserved here. The capital of Iraq is Baghdad, one of the oldest cities in the world. Here you can see the most beautiful palaces and mosques and feel the spirit of different eras. If you want to dive into history, visit the National Museum, where priceless finds from Mesopotamia are collected, pay attention to Al-Ukhaidir Fortress, and see the main attraction — Babylon with the ruins of the Hanging Gardens. Also, don't forget to visit the colorful Iraqi markets, buy handmade souvenirs, and taste the local culinary masterpieces. It is better to travel around Iraq with sightseeing groups or local companions, avoiding deserted areas.

Kazakhstan (translated as "the land of wanderers") is one of the largest republics in Central Asia, occupying the ninth place in the world by area. Having received independence, Kazakhstan has stepped on a way of active development, including tourism. In 2018, the country was visited by more than 8.5 million people.
