Everyone finds something special here: picturesque nature, which in some places resembles alpine landscapes, large developed cities, famous Baikonur, and the Great Silk Road. The vast territory and friendly people provide guests with almost limitless opportunities for a fascinating journey.

geography.en: Kazakhstan is located in the heart of Eurasia, just south of the Ural Mountains. The territory of the republic covers the lands of Europe, Central Asia, and Siberia. Its closest neighbors are Russia, China, Kyrgyzstan, Uzbekistan, and Turkmenistan. The country's peculiarity is the lack of access to the World Ocean, but there are two intracontinental seas on its territory — the Caspian and the Aral Seas. Deserts and semi-deserts occupy more than 50 percent of Kazakhstan's territory, steppes and forest-steppes dominate in the north and mountains occupy 10 percent of the country's land. There are about 40 thousand small lakes in Kazakhstan, the area of which is less than one km². There are 21 lakes with an area of more than 100 km². In the south-east of the republic, there is one of the largest lakes in the world — Lake Balkhash. Its uniqueness is in the different chemical composition of water: it is almost fresh in the western part and salty in the eastern one. According to the administrative division, Kazakhstan consists of 14 regions. Three cities — Nur-Sultan, Almaty, and Shymkent — have republican significance. In addition, Baikonur, which is currently leased by Russia, received a special status.

long_description.en:
Nur-Sultan

Nur-Sultan is a city that had been known as Astana up until March 2019. The capital of Kazakhstan received the new name after the former President Nursultan Nazarbayev after he had announced his resignation. Nur-Sultan is a beautiful and rapidly developing city with stunning modern buildings and monuments as its main feature. Take the Khan Shatyr shopping mall alone! Forbes Style magazine has included in the list of the best eco-buildings in the world. Its construction resembles a transparent tent, and there is even a beach resort on the territory. Baiterek Tower — the famous "Chupa Chups" with a dizzying view from the observation deck — is no less delightful. You should also visit the Palace of Peace and Reconciliation in the capital of Kazakhstan; check out the scale of the entertainment center "Duman"; walk along the three-level bridge; go shopping at the eastern bazaar. There is also something to see on the outskirts of the city. There is a picturesque resort area Borovoye, with pine forests, mineral springs, and blue lakes, relatively close to the capital. Tourists who dream of seeing pink flamingos should visit Korgalzhyn Nature Reserve. Space lovers should definitely visit Baikonur — the first and largest spaceport in the world, where you can even see the launch of a real rocket. 

Almaty

Almaty is a city of apple orchards, beautiful fountains, and rapid development. Its name is translated as "Apple". It is the largest city of Kazakhstan, which is buried in greenery and attracts tourists with its diverse architecture. Here you can meet oriental steppe motives, old Soviet buildings, and modern constructions in high-tech style. A walk around the city is worth starting from Republic Square with the Monument of Independence in its center. The next point is the Central State Museum, with a collection of over 200 thousand exhibits. You can admire the picturesque view of Almaty from the top of Kok Tobe mountain (Green Hill), where the cableway leads. There is also a small zoo and a famous fountain, "Apple". Speaking of fountains, there are more than 120 of them in the city, and every year at the end of spring, when they all turn on, after winter, Almaty citizens celebrate the holiday "Day of Fountains". There are also fantastic sights on the outskirts of the city. The most famous is the phenomenon of nature "Singing Barhan" in the Altyn-Emel National Park. But it is necessary to go there in dry weather because, at other times, you risk not to hear the "singing" sands, similar to the sounds of a ringing organ. The Tract of Turgen is another natural beauty that deserves attention as well. 

Kostanay

Kostanay is a cozy and well-tended town, which should definitely be included in the list for visiting in Kazakhstan. Kostanay is located on the bank of the Tobol River, so you can't do without a walk along the waterfront. It will be no less pleasant to spend time in Central Park or Victory Park. Picturesque nature, shady alleys, attractions for children, a picnic in the fresh air — what could be better? In addition to walks around the city, in Kostanay, you can visit the Toy Museum, see the exposition of the Regional Museum of Local History, drop by the famous Ak Mosque (Maral Ishan Mosque). Another local entertainment is a walk on a double-decker bus № 18, giving the opportunity to get acquainted with the city from an unusual angle. 

Aktau

Aktau is one of the most amazing cities in Kazakhstan, which literally "grew" in the desert in 1963. Its construction was due to the active development of oil production in the local areas. Aktau is an incredibly hot city with almost no greenery. On the other hand, there is the Caspian Sea with its equipped beaches. The main highlight of the town is the snow-white mosque Beket-Ata with beautiful sky blue domes. The city port — the only one in Kazakhstan — also attracts the same interest. The lighthouse, which is located on the roof of a residential building — a unique construction that has no analogs in all of continental Europe, also continues the maritime theme. Among the obligatory places to visit in Aktau, it is worth mentioning the recreation center "Ivushka", where you can swim in a well with hot mineral water. You should also definitely visit underground mosques, numerous necropolises, historical monuments, and Muslim shrines in the vicinity of the city.

Alpine skiing destinations

People rarely mention Kazakhstan among the popular ski resorts in the world. However, experienced skiers claim that this country is being ignored in vain. This is easy to prove if you visit one of the many ski resorts in Kazakhstan.

Shymbulak. This resort is known far beyond Kazakhstan. Only 25 km from Almaty, you will find routes of different difficulty levels, unusual routes for tubing, downhill, mogul, and always sunny weather without sharp frosts.

Tabagan. It's about 17 km from Almaty and offers eleven routes of different levels, high-quality service — the resort is located on the territory of the reserve. Its main highlight is nighttime skiing when the illumination on the tracks is not turned off until 10 pm. 

Altai Alps. The most beautiful ski resort in Kazakhstan with a high level of service and affordable prices. You can choose from 13 slopes of various difficulty. In addition, here you can experience off-piste forest skiing.

description.en: Cambodia is a country with a rich history and a harsh fate, which made its way from ancient civilization to a French colony and gained independence only in 1953. But already today, it is ready to amaze travelers with the Asian mix of original culture, national cuisine, and ancient traditions. Despite the fact that the first settlements on the territory of modern Cambodia dated back to the II century BC, the country managed to rise from its knees and develop only in the last few decades. Now it is difficult to call Cambodia "the country of one dollar". Thanks to tourism, the economy is actively developing here, architectural sights are being restored, and locals are seriously determined to compete with neighboring Thailand for the title of the best resort state.

geography.en: The Kingdom is located in Southeast Asia, in the south of the Indochinese Peninsula. Cambodia borders with Vietnam, Thailand, and Laos and is also washed by the waters of the Gulf of Siam. Cambodia also includes islands, the largest of which is Koh Kong (100 km²). Most of the territory is located in the valley of the Mekong River and Lake Tonlé Sap. The relief of the country is mainly flat, but there are also mountains here with the highest point in Mountain Oral (1813 m). The typical landscape of Cambodia is separately standing low hills covered with dense impassable forest. On the territory of the Kingdom, there is the largest lake in the Indochinese Peninsula — Tonlé Sap. According to the order of the King of Cambodia Norodom Sihamoni of 22 December 2008, the administrative territory of Cambodia is divided into 23 provinces and the city of central — Phnom Penh, equated to them by status. Provinces are divided into districts consisting of communes comprising several dozens or even hundreds of villages.

long_description.en:
The cities of Cambodia are a mix of Asian and European culture, where ancient Khmer temples and French colonial buildings peacefully stand side by side. In the streets of major Cambodian metropolises, you will meet Buddhist monks, food traders, who cook literally on the road and, of course, millions of little mopeds.

Phnom Penh

Phnom Penh is the bustling capital of Cambodia, just like the main city of an Asian country should be. It still has a fantastic flavor and an impressive number of ancient buildings: temples, Phsar Thom Thmey market in the art deco style, various archaeological museums with artifacts of the Khmer culture. The Royal Palace is the current residence of the King of Cambodia. Tourists are allowed to visit the ceremonial halls, but the most interesting is the Silver Pagoda, where the King holds official meetings with the monarchs. In the evening, you can stroll along the embankment of the Tonle Sap River. This is the place where locals gather, music plays, and you can hear prayers and the smell of incense from the open doors of temples.

Angkor

Angkor is the cradle of Khmer culture, which is sure to appear on every tourist's route. The former center of the Khmer Empire has preserved the most beautiful monuments of antiquity, the famous Angkor Wat and Angkor-Thom temples, which are included in the UNESCO World Heritage List. The temple complex Angkor Wat is a magnet that attracts millions of tourists from all over the world. Exotic architecture, which has no analogs all over the world, was created back in the XII century. For a long time, the complex had been hidden in the impassable jungle. This place was the basis of the plot "Mowgli" as a place where Bandar-logs brought the "human cub". Unfortunately, the Siamese army and the Khmer Rouge destroyed a part of the complex. But even the remains makes people's heart miss a beating from its majesty and scale. Banteay Srei is another temple that deserves your attention. It is dedicated to the god Shiva and dates back to 967.

Siem Reap

Siem Reap is a city in the northwest of Cambodia and a starting point for tourists who want to visit the main attraction of Cambodia — Angkor Wat Temple Complex. Taking into account the fact that this city is a staging post on the way to the majestic landmark, there is a large concentration of restaurants and hotels. Local guides recommend tourists to visit the Royal Independence Gardens Park, walk around Promenade and meditate in the Buddhist temple Wat Preah Prom Rath. Siem Reap is not a tourist destination; it is an ideal place to stay before visiting Angkor Wat, eat, and have a break from the crowds of tourists. 

Sihanoukville

Sihanoukville (better known as Kampong Som) is the main seaport of the country and the city with the most picturesque beaches of Cambodia: Victory, Hawaii, Sokha, Ochheuteal, Otres Beach. Tourists say that deserted sandy beaches are the best attraction of this province. Ream National Park offers you an opportunity to get acquainted with the wildlife of the Asian country. There are rivers, two islands, wild and mangrove forests on its territory. Monkey Island is another place to get acquainted with the local nature and flavor. Legend has it that it was home to the mightiest monkey. There are waterfalls, wild beaches, bungalows, and rental services for snorkeling and kayaking. Fans of antiquities can visit the Wat Leu and Wat Krom Temples. 

Battambang

Battambang is a mysterious city in the northwest of Cambodia. There are ancient temples, museums, mysterious caves, and numerous remains of ancient structures. You can get acquainted with the history of the region in the Battambang Museum. You should definitely see Ek Phnom — one of the most beautiful temples of Cambodia with carved elements. At sunset, this place becomes an almost magical atmosphere. For the most picturesque views, it is better to go to Phnom Banan Temple with more than 300 steps leading to it. And for shopping, go to the Phsar Nath Market, which is located in the city center.

description.en: Qatar is a small state in the Persian Gulf. In just forty years, it has become the wealthiest country in the world and continues to develop at a frantic pace. Skyscrapers grow along the coast with beautiful beaches, and shopping centers and 5-star hotels are built in the middle of the desert with wild camels. Qatar does not claim to be the first in everything, and it remains faithful to its ancient traditions: falconry and Arab dhow boats.

geography.en: The Emirate of Qatar is the Arabian Peninsula, rich in oil and natural gas. The Persian Gulf washes it, and neighbors with Saudi Arabia and the UAE in the south. Almost the entire country is made of sand dunes and barkhans, without permanent rivers and lakes. Qatar is divided into 7 municipalities: El Doha, El Daiyan, El Hawr, Al Wakrah, Al Rayyan, Al Shamal, and Umm Salal.

long_description.en:
The main sights are located in or around the capital. Most other cities are Qatari oil quasi-communities built for foreign employees. 

Doha

Doha is Qatar's administrative center, home to more than half the country's population. It has confidently reached the world level thanks to its impressive highest skyscrapers, excellent museums, and traditional markets. The chic shopping malls are exhibition galleries with sky-high price tags of the world and local brands. To the west of the city, you shall find the only amusement park in Qatar with an artificial lagoon and attractions for both adults and children. Doha is also home to a large concentration of mosques. The most unusual of them in the form of a futuristic flying ship is located at the Education City Mosque complex. You can explore the historical heritage of Arab culture in the Katara Cultural Village, which has been open since 2010. There are concert halls, galleries, oriental mosques with blue and gold mosaics, and unusual pigeon houses. One of the most impressive museums in Doha is the Museum of Islamic Art, which very discreetly demonstrates the richness of its collection. The artificial island of Pearl Qatar, which is a perfectly round shape and is known as the most elite district, is the city's main highlight. It is best viewed from a height. This place offers significant hotels, branded boutiques, and famous restaurants that best remind you of the luxury and wealth of the country. And the surviving forts, towers, and the old market will dive you into the atmosphere of the ancient East.

Al Rayyan

Qatar's second-largest city, Al Rayyan, can boast of a new park with a children's playground, cafeteria, and date palms, as well as the headquarters and arena of the Equestrian Federation.

Al Wakrah

The rest of the cities are not so remarkable and remain less attractive to tourists. Al Wakrah is another center of the municipal district that deserves your attention. It is the former main pearling ground, with the historic architecture of mosques, old houses, and a fort.

Al Zubarah

A now-destroyed city of Al Zubarah stands in the middle of the desert. The UNESCO World Heritage recognized its ruins. 

And not far from the port of Mesaieed, you can stroll through the most extensive park or dive to the reef with flooded boats, cars, and a school bus.

description.en: Picturesque nature, ancient cities, exotics — all of this is gathered in one place called Kirghizia. It sounds amazing, but this country has not yet become a tourist center in Asia, although it has everything to spend an unforgettable holiday. Here you can marvel at the famous mountain ranges and the cleanest alpine lake, visit unique historical monuments, check out a real colorful yurt, go skiing or snowboarding, and even enjoy a beach holiday. Kyrgyzstan offers its guests a variety of leisure activities and welcomes every traveler heartily!

geography.en: Kyrgyzstan is located in Central Asia and can rightly be considered a country of mountains. They occupy more than three-quarters of its territory. The northeastern part of Kyrgyzstan is located within the Tian Shan range, and the south-western regions are within the Pamir-Alay range. Kyrgyzstan has no access to the sea but has more than 30 thousand rivers (the largest is Naryn) and more than 2 thousand lakes. The country's pride is Issyk Kul lake, which is the seventh-deepest in the world.Kyrgyzstan's closest neighbors are Kazakhstan (in the north), Uzbekistan (in the west), Tajikistan (in the south-west), and China (east and south-east).Officially, the Kyrgyz Republic is divided into 531 administrative and territorial units. The division is quite complicated and ramified:2 cities of national importance;7 regions;40 districts;29 cities;453 rural districts.It should be noted that cities of national importance (Bishkek and Osh) have a special way of organizing local self-government. They are included in the list of administrative-territorial units of the first level. They also include regions:Batken (administrative center at Batken city). It is located in the south-western part of Kyrgyzstan and is considered to be the most complex geopolitical region, as this is where the enclaves of Uzbekistan and Tajikistan are located.Jalal-Abad (city of Jalal-Abad). It is the northeastern part of the Fergana Valley and the third-largest region in Kyrgyzstan. It is here that the country's generating power is located, as well as mineral springs and natural attractions.Isıq-Köl (Karakol city). This is the easternmost region, where the famous Issyk Kul Lake is located. The region is actively developing a tourist industry, and guest houses and health resorts are being built, offering mud and thermal water treatment.Naryn (Naryn city). It is the largest region of Kyrgyzstan, which is situated in the central part of the country. The region is known for a large number of tourist routes, picturesque nature, and active development of agro-tourism.The City of Osh. It is situated in the south-western part of Kyrgyzstan and is a border region. The city of Osh is one of the oldest Asian cities and offers tourists a large number of historical and cultural monuments.Talas (city of Talas). It is situated in the north-west and is the smallest region of Kyrgyzstan by area. On the territory of the region, you can find a lot of archaeological and historical monuments, as well as picturesque natural spots.Chuy (Tokmok city). It is located in the northern part of Kyrgyzstan and is considered to b the most developed region in terms of industry and agriculture. The capital (Bishkek), which is an independent administrative unit, is located in the region.

long_description.en:
Bishkek

Bishkek is the capital of Kyrgyzstan, one of the most developed and interesting cities in the republic. The name translates as a "mixer to whip kumis", and this drink is really in great demand not only among tourists but also among locals. Bishkek is called the greenest city in Kyrgyzstan. It is worth getting acquainted with it from the central square of Ala-Too and the Erkindik Statue of Liberty. During the walk around the capital, tourists can see the Parliament building, watch the change of guard at the Flagstaff with Country Flag (every hour from 7 AM to 6 PM), admire the Manas Sculptural Complex, visit the Historical Museum. You should also pay attention to the urban green areas: Oak Park, Panfilov Park, Boulevard Young Guards, oaks, and silver poplars on Erkindik Avenue.

Osh

Osh is the second-largest city in Kyrgyzstan, which tourists from all over the world love. Its history is more than three thousand years, and it has managed to preserve the amazing oriental flavor to this day. The main attraction in the center of Osh is the sacred mountain Sulaiman-Too. It is also called "Throne of Sulaiman (Solomon)" and is often considered to be the second Mecca for Muslims. Legends say that Sulaiman-Too has healing properties, so tourists should definitely climb to its top. In addition, a museum was opened right in the mountain, and the largest mosque in the region was built at its foot. Another highlight of the city and its surroundings is a large number of caves, many of which are considered to be the largest in Kyrgyzstan. Another attraction for tourists in Osh is a walk in the city parks, a visit to a real medieval bath, guided tours of mosques and ancient cemetery, as well as shopping in the oriental bazaar.

Karakol

Karakol is a unique city, which is located at the crossroads between East and West and has absorbed all the brightest and most interesting of several cultures. Most tourists come here in winter when the ski resorts begin their work. Numerous slopes of different complexity levels, tracks for skiers and snowboarders, high level of service, and picturesque nature — for the sake of such a holiday, not only residents of different regions of Kyrgyzstan but also travelers from other countries strive here. In the warm season, Karakol also offers a lot to do. There is a famous Dungan Mosque in the city, which impresses not only with its appearance but also with a unique construction method. It was built without a single nail. Besides, in Karakol, you can visit the Holy Trinity Cathedral and the Tatar Mosque, admire gingerbread houses in the Russian Quarter, walk in Victory Park and River Park, visit the Museum of History of the city.

Jalal-Abad

Jalal-Abad is the third-largest city in Kyrgyzstan in terms of population, and one of the most peaceful and quiet cities in the country. Life here flows in a measured way, despite a large number of tourists. Travelers go to Jalal-Abad mainly for the sake of picturesque nature. On the outskirts of the city, you can walk in a real walnut grove with centuries-old trees, go hiking to waterfalls, scuba dive or paraglide, go fishing, and experience kumis treatment. However, the main reason why Jalal-Abad is popular among tourists is a medical resort with a sanatorium where you can improve your health with the help of mineral springs and mud baths.

Talas

Talas is a small town in the valley of the same name, often called the Land of Manas (the legendary hero of the Kyrgyz epos). In 1995, the Museum of the History of the Epic of Manas was built here. In it, you can see the mausoleum and other burials, as well as a rich collection of ancient artifacts: tools, clothes, military uniforms, leather dishes, and much more. The Talas Valley is a unique natural area, which is separated from other regions of Kyrgyzstan by a chain of mountains. It is no wonder that several tourist zones deserve attention here: Talas, Besh-Tash, Manas, Kirov, Sandalysh, Toktogul. All of them are located in the vicinity of the city and offer travelers picturesque gorges and caves, untouched forests and groves, rich wildlife, and flora.

Issyk-Kul

Issyk-Kul is a lake that every tourist in Kyrgyzstan should see. There are a lot of cities, towns, resorts, and recreation centers along the coast, but the northern part of the lake deserves the most attention. The area from the village of Tamchy to the village of Korumdu is best-developed in terms of tourism and beach recreation. Issyk-Kul is the seventh deepest lake in the world and fascinates with its beauty. The water here is very clean and has incredible blue color.

description.en: Kuwait is a great place to get acquainted with civilized Arab culture and to relax on the soft sandy beaches of the Persian Gulf. Thanks to oil production, the country is an economically developed state. Five-star hotels and business centers are adjacent to ancient mosques and luxurious shopping centers with colorful Arab bazaars.

geography.en: Kuwait is a state located in southwest Asia. It borders Iraq to the north and west, Saudi Arabia to the south. The Persian Gulf washes the coast on the east side; the length of the coastline is as much as 499 km. Most of the country is desert. The landscape is mainly flat, but there are also hilly areas. Kuwait also includes small reefs on the southern shore and several adjacent islands: Bubiyan, Failaka, Qaruh, Umm Al Maradim, and others. The administrative and territorial division of the country includes six governorships (governorates), which in turn are divided into districts.

long_description.en:
Kuwait City

Kuwait City is the capital of the country and the largest port located on the southern shore of the bay. The city is the economic, cultural, and entertainment center of the country. The main symbol of the town is the Musical Fountain, one of the largest in the world. In fact, it is a huge complex, which includes 220 fountains and three swimming pools. In the evening, every element of the construction is illuminated. The Kuwait Towers are another recognizable "trademark" of Kuwait City, constructed in 1979. An impressive architectural monument is Seif Palace of the Emir Kuwait, which was built according to all national traditions: an elegant tower with a beautiful clock, separated by beautiful tiles and gold. Tareq Rajab Museum, which houses art and ancient calligraphy, also attracts a lot of tourists. 

Al Ahmadi

Al Ahmadi is the oil heart of Kuwait. The city is located in the south of the country, 25 km from the capital. Its date of origin is 1946, and it is named after its founder, Sheikh Ahmad Al-Jaber Al-Sabah. This is where the headquarters of the Kuwait Oil Company is located. There is a museum on the territory of the city, which tells about how the oil business was born in this country. The whole city stands on the sand, but there is a city park where fresh air and greenery help to take a breath, relax, and recover energy. The locals love to spend their time here. 

Al Jahra

Al Jahra is a major agricultural hub of the state. The city is located in the central part of the country, on the territory of an oasis. Thanks to the mild climate and fertile soil, fruits and vegetables are actively grown here. The Al-Shabab Mubarak al-Aiar Stadium, the home arena of the Al-Jahra club, is of great importance to the local population. And the Red Fort stands out among the sights. This building is a symbol of patriotism, as in 1920, a historic battle took place here, which led to the defeat of the Saudis' troops. The fort consists of four towers and powerful walls made of mud bricks, and Kuwaitis explain its red color by the fact that it is the blood of soldiers who died here. 

Salmiya

Salmiya is a city on the shore of the Persian Gulf. It was destroyed during the Iraqi occupation in 1991 and rebuilt two years after the military events. The city hosts the Thamir Stadium, where matches of the local football club are often held. Salmiya is also a hub of student life. There are many educational institutions here: Pakistan School and College, French School, Indian Community School, Indian English Academy School, American University. 

Hawally

Hawally is situated not far from the capital, on the coast of the Persian Gulf. It offers not only stunning views of the sea surface and nature but is also equipped with everything for comfortable beach recreation and water sports. The majority of the population is Palestinian, so there are many buildings constructed here, taking into account national features. The cultural sites of interest include the Bait Al-Othman Museum, opened by the Emir of Kuwait in 2013. Its expositions are dedicated to the history and culture of the city.

description.en: "Kingdom of million elephants" and smiles. It is the most ecologically clean zone in Asia. There are still places where a European has not stepped foot. The former name of Laos is Lan Xang, which translates as "Million Elephants". If you are accustomed to malls with sales, skyscrapers and the active flow of life, forget about the trip to Laos, because people come here for a completely different reason. This is a place for genuine travelers who are tired of the noise of megacities and total industrialization. Laos attracts with its pristine nature, untouched places, and fabulous sunsets.

geography.en: Trapped between Vietnam, Thailand, Cambodia, Myanmar, and China, Laos resembles a coconut palm, due to its elongated shape. The country has no access to the sea, but this fact does not scare tourists at all. The sacred Mekong River flows on the border with Thailand and Myanmar, and the Annamite Range frames the boundary with Vietnam. The landscape of Laos is predominantly hilly.

long_description.en:
It is hard to call Laos a country with a lot of attractions. Nature has created the most valuable and beautiful of them. However, lovers of antiquity can also find something interesting, such as the Plain of Jars. One legend says that these pots of stone (one to three meters high) were made by giants who lived here millions of years ago. In 2019, UNESCO took over the protection of this unique and almost unexplored site.

Vientiane

Vientiane is the capital and largest city of Laos. It is a blend of Buddhist culture and the French colonial past. Buddhist temples are the city's main attractions. The most important sanctuary is the XVI century golden Temple of Pha That Luang. Tourists are also attracted to the ancient temples of Wat Si Saket and Haw Phra Kaew. The symbols of Vientiane are Patuxai (the local Arc de Triomphe) and the snow-white government building. The capital city of Laos will not impress sophisticated travelers; there are not many activities and monuments of antiquity. But it is worth visiting here for the colorful night market and national cuisine offered by cooks from restaurants on the Mekong waterfront.

Louangphabang

Louangphabang (formerly known as Luang Phabang) is the administrative center of the Lao province of the same name, located at the confluence of the Mekong and Nam Khan Rivers. It is famous for its Buddhist shrines and is popularly referred to as the "City of Golden Temples". They are located within walking distance from each other and offer tourists an opportunity to explore the wooden buildings and temple museums of different eras. Travelers can appreciate the beauty of Asian nature on various tracking routes in the Pak Ou Caves. During the hike, there are gorgeous views and landscapes. There are waterfalls, one of which is Kuang Si Falls. The trail winds through jungles and mountains, and during the rests, you become a guest of the local tribes.

Kaysone Phomvihane

Kaysone Phomvihane (Savannakhet until 2005) is a city on the Mekong River, the second-largest center of Laos and the capital of Savannakhet Province. In ancient times, the area was crossed by major trade routes linking China, Cambodia, and other regions. French colonizers strongly influenced the architecture of the old city: wide blossoming boulevards neighbor Buddhist temples and Asian flavor. The main attraction — the Ho Chi Minh trail was formed during the presence of colonizers and the Vietnam War. The Temple of That Ing Hang is a landmark building with a golden umbrella that dates back to the XV century and symbolizes the past of Laos. Women are strictly forbidden to enter the temple. Kaysone Phomvihane is the best city to get acquainted with the culture and history of the country.

Vang Vieng

Vang Vieng is a popular tourist village 16 km from the capital of Laos, Vientiane. It is located on the Nam Song River. A vacation in Vang Vieng will be interesting for active travelers, lovers of hiking, and rafting. There is a wide range of activities to choose from: kayaking, tubing (down the river in an automobile inner tube), hot-air balloon flights. Main attractions include the blue lagoon of the Tham Poukham Cave, caves in the surrounding area of Vang Vieng, Pha Poak Mountain, which offers a magnificent view of the city. You will need training and willpower to reach some of the sites through the jungle and flooded rice fields. One of the most popular activities is hot air ballooning. You should sign up for the "attraction" in advance. The ride lasts one hour. There is a developed infrastructure, internet, hotels, restaurants, and bars.

Pakse

Pakse is the unofficial capital of the southern regions of Laos, the center of the province of Champasak. In the past, it was the main center of the French colonizers. This had a strong influence on its architecture and appearance. Unlike other Asian cities, life here is slow and measured: the locals drink real Laotian tea in the morning and take their time. The main attractions are the temples of Wat Luang, Wat Phra Bat, and the Champasak Palace, which has now been converted into a hotel and welcomes visitors from all over the world. Other locations near Pakse include waterfalls, tea plantations, and lost in the jungles Khmer temples of Vat Tomo and Vat Phou (UNESCO World Heritage sites). The city is a staging ground on the way to other cities in Laos. It has an airport with flights to Vientiane, Siem Reap, and Bangkok.

description.en: Lebanon is the cradle of history and the most tolerant country in the Arab world. Despite its neighborhood with two warring states, the long civil war (1975-1990), and the total destruction of the capital, Lebanon has preserved its kindness, cordiality, and amiability. People here respect different faiths, nationalities, speak French and English. They are open and kind and are always glad to see tourists. The first settlements discovered on the territory of the state date back to the VIII-VII centuries B.C. Every powerful empire, that the history knew, ruled here. This is the birthplace of the Phoenicians who gave us the first alphabet. Modern Lebanon is ready to surprise its guests with large metropolises, five-star hotels, the cleanest beaches, and unique historical artifacts.

geography.en: Lebanon is a tiny country located in the Middle East. It borders Israel in the south and Syria in the east. The waters of the Mediterranean SeaIn wash the west of the country. Lebanon's relief is mostly mountainous, but there are small plains along the coast. Besides the sea, the country is rich in other water resources: rivers and lakes, but there are no navigable rivers. Administratively, the country is divided into eight provinces (muḥāfaẓāt): Beirut, Akkar, Baalbek-Hermel, Beqaa, Mount Lebanon, North Lebanon, South Lebanon, and Nabatieh. The governorates, in turn, consist of 26 districts (qadāʾ), and those districts are divided into municipalities.

long_description.en:
Before the civil war that happened in the XX century, Lebanon was a prosperous country with a developed economy, financial, and banking system. It was called Switzerland of the Middle East. After the war, most of the cities were rebuilt, but they have not lost their historical charm and are ready to welcome travelers from all over the world. 

Beirut

Beirut is the bustling capital and the most cosmopolitan and religiously diverse city in the Middle East. It is a place with a rich history, where majestic sights of different epochs are preserved. The first exciting building, Al-Omari Grand Mosque, dates back to 1187. Previously, the Byzantine Church of St. John the Baptist was located on the site of the mosque. The brightest representatives of ancient culture — the Roman Thermae — have also survived in the city. They are located in the Archaeological Park, which is very popular among tourists. In addition to architectural ensembles, there are natural attractions in the vicinity of the city. Nahr Kadish Gorge is one of them, surrounded by rocks, thick forests, and unique trees that are over 3500 years old. Walking along the streets of Beirut, the tourist should not be surprised by the strange neighborhood of ultra-modern skyscrapers and semi-destroyed houses. Thus, the Lebanese want to show tourists the horror and consequences of war. 

Tripoli

Tripoli translates from Greek as a "triple city". Previously it included Tyre, Sidon, and Arwad, and the place was the capital of the Phoenicians. Today, Tripoli is the second-largest city in Lebanon, where unique cultural monuments preserved. It is proud of the production of olive soap, which is handmade here using traditional tools of the last century. Experienced auto-tourists will be delighted with the ideal quality of the roads. Perhaps this is because there are no buses in the city, and people move either on foot or by bicycle. Unlike other cities in Lebanon, there are no ancient buildings and ancient mosques here, but there are authenticity and flavor, which are definitely worth checking out. 

Jbeil

Jbeil is an ancient Phoenician city located on the Mediterranean coast, near the capital of Lebanon. It is better known as Byblos. Scientists call Jbeil "the entire history of the ancient world". It's the only place that people have never left. The appearance of Byblos is believed to date back to the 5th century B.C. It used to be one of the trade routes between Egypt and Greece. The landmarks of the city include the Church of St. John (1115 A.D.), the Crusader Fortress (dating back to the Phoenician era), the Roman Theatre (218 A.D.), where graves of Phoenician kings were found, and a mosaic depicting Bacchus god. You cannot miss the Temple of Baalat Gebal, the Temple of the Obelisks, and the Well of the God, where Isis mourned Osiris. There is the Archaeological Park in the city, where you can walk among the stones of the ancient city, which "saw" the biblical prophets.

Ṣūr

Ṣūr (also known as Tyre) is the fourth-largest city in Lebanon and the oldest shopping center in Phoenicia and the Mediterranean. It went down in history as the city which had the most prolonged siege. The troops of Alexander the Great had been standing under the walls of Tyre for seven months. It was the only city that did not want to obey the king. It is better to move around Ṣūr on foot as the main locations are close to each other. The Roman Hippodrome or Al Bass Archaeological Complex is the leading tourist destination. There is the Necropolis on its territory, the oldest burial place where human remains are still being found. Some sarcophagi, a monumental arch, an aqueduct, and a Roman road have also been preserved here. The hot springs are a vivid example of Roman architecture. It is better to visit them during sunrise or sunset. A small town of Qana is situated not far from Tyre: it was here where Jesus had turned water into wine. The rock drawings of the first Christians were discovered in caves a couple of kilometers from Qana. Since then, the cave itself has been considered one of the holy places on Earth. 

Baalbek

Baalbek is one of the oldest cities in Lebanon, located near Beirut. This place is famous for its ancient temples, which are impressive in their colossal size and can be rightfully called a "wonder of the world". The Baalbek temple complex is the primary and central attraction. It has seen many civilizations! But initially, the temple belonged to the Phoenicians, as they had built an incredibly large stone terrace. The building itself was dedicated to the sun god Baal. Afterward, the city was taken over by the Ancient Greeks, and the place was named Heliopolis, after the sun god Helios. When the Romans came, they called it the Temple of Jupiter, and then the building passed into the hands of the Crusaders, Turks, and Arabs. Nowadays, there are only six columns left of the temple of Jupiter. But even touching one of them can take you back to several thousand years. Today, the Baalbek temple is a masterpiece of ancient Roman architecture, and can only be compared with the Egyptian pyramids by its greatness.

Sidon

Sidon is one of the oldest cities in Phoenician and the third-largest city in Lebanon, which is also famous for its ancient buildings that have survived to this day. The place has been inhabited since ancient times: archaeological digs discovered artifacts from the Acheulean culture and the early Palaeolithic period. Sidon became the largest center of the ancient world in the XX century B.C. Even Homer wrote many times in his texts about the masters of the area who had created embroidery and glass. Interesting sights are preserved here: the Sidon's Sea Castle, the Phoenician temple complex of the 6th century B.C., the Temple of Eshmun. The pedestal for sacrifice and capitals, which are included in the UNESCO World Heritage List, are also remarkable. One can also find one of the oldest synagogues in the world in this city. 

Jounieh

Jounieh is a resort city on the Mediterranean coast, which can pleasantly surprise not only with its high-class beach recreation but also with its diversity of attractions. A cableway to Harissa Hill is one of them. It leads to the bronze statue of Our Lady of Lebanon. There are various monasteries and temples around the statue. Considering that it is a resort town, a casino with an area of 34 000 square meters is one of the attractions. The casino was opened in 1957 and is one of the largest gambling establishments in Lebanon. Hunters of antiquities can go to the Jeita Grotto. Their appearance dates back to the Paleolithic era. Throughout the existence of the caves, nature has managed to create bizarre forms and fascinating stalactites. There are also many springs and the Dog River inside. Tourists who want to get a better overview of history can go to the ethnographic museum. It tells about the reign of eight eras in Lebanon.

description.en: The Maldives are numerous coral reef islands, the name of which consists of the words "mahal" (palace) and "diva" (island). For the first time, divers discovered this tourist destination in the early 70s of the last century. But the real popularity for these paradise islands came after the advertising of Bounty chocolate bar. Turquoise ocean, white sandy beach, palm trees — the picture impressed people around the world so much that it became an ultimate dream and a place where everyone aspires to get. And even the fact that the advertisement was shot somewhere in Thailand does not bother travelers at all. Everybody wants to get into this ideal world and experience what a "paradise pleasure" feels like.

geography.en: The Republic of Maldives is located in the equator area, south-west of Sri Lanka and India. All its islands are washed exclusively by the waters of the Indian Ocean. It consists of 1,192 islands, divided into 26 atolls. However, only 200 islands are inhabited, and only half of them are tourist resorts. The Maldives is officially recognized as the most "flat" state. The highest point here does not exceed 2.5 meters above sea level.

long_description.en:
A unique feature of the Maldives is that it has only one city — the capital of Malé, and no land public transport. Some islands are so tiny that they can accommodate only one hotel in their territories. The Maldives is not a country where people come for historical attractions. They urge for passive recreation, the best diving in the world, and the most outstanding impressions.

Malé

Malé is the capital and one of the most densely populated cities in the world. It welcomes tourists and remains a transfer point for further travel to the paradise islands. It's fascinating that the town itself is much smaller than the majority of the Maldives islands, but the largest part of the population (about 133,019 people) lives here. The capital is located on the south coast of North Malé atoll, which is part of another atoll - Kaafu. The Maldivians themselves lacked space in the small capital, so they created a new island, Hulhumale, which they began settling in 2004. There are not so many beaches or paradise landscapes in Malé, but it is worth taking a stroll through its streets. The attractions include the National Museum, the Presidential Palace, the court building, Friday Mosque, and many other exciting places of worship and tombs, as well as the central square, the waterfront, and city parks. It is safe in the city, but do not forget that it is a Muslim republic, and you should behave and dress accordingly here.

North Malé

North Malé is the largest atoll that includes the capital of Malé and 50 other islands, of which only eight are inhabited. Each of the islands included in the atoll has its own purpose — an airport island, a poultry farm island, and a storage island where the Maldivians keep fuel. The capital of the Republic is the main attraction in North Malé. Despite a large number of people and heavy boat traffic, there are untouched corners where complete silence reigns. All beaches on the islands belong to the hotels. The wild Villingili beach is the best place for retreat. You can reach it by boat. North Malé is a popular destination for diving enthusiasts. It offers numerous XIX-century shipwrecks on the seabed. 

South Malé

South Malé Atoll consists of 30 islands. People inhabit only three of them. The other seventeen islands are resorts, and the rest are uninhabited. The islands attract tourists from all over the world with their luxurious beaches, pure azure water, mild climate, and vibrant sea world. Surfers come here for the big waves — Kandooma Resort has become a bulwark of this movement. The Guraidhoo Nature Reserve is located nearby. People come here to relax from the fuss of the city, celebrate the New Year, or to a wedding. The islands remain a favorite destination for families with children, newlyweds, and older people. 

Alif Atoll

The Alif Alif Atoll (aka Ari) consists of two parts: the northern region — Alif Alif, and the southern part — Alif Dhaalu. It includes 70 islands: 18 of them are inhabited, 25 are luxurious resorts, and the remaining 27 islands are so tiny that no one lives there. Each island of Alif Alif Atoll impresses with lush vegetation and amazing beaches.

Angaga

Angaga is a favorite island of Europeans, Asians, and Australians. The canonical Maldivian landscapes surround the place with azure water, white sand, and coconut palms. The island's main attraction is its bungalows, covered with palm branches and sand instead of the floor.

Bathala

Bathala is a place where you can get acquainted with sea inhabitants. It attracts mainly divers, and it doesn't provide any other entertainment besides sports activities. Palm trees are rare here, but coral reefs are not far from the shore.

Dhiffushi

Dhiffushi is a place where you can see powerful waves crashing into coral reefs. Luxury bungalows overlooking the ocean attract fans of both passive and active recreation.

Dhaalu Atoll

Dhaalu Atoll or Southern Nilandhe Atoll comprises 46 islands, with a total population of 1,500 people. The rich underwater world and abundance of coral reefs attract divers and tourists who come for relaxation. In addition to relaxing on a beach, you can go on exciting tours.

Dhaalu has preserved the ruins of ancient mosques and temples from the Buddhist period, as well as mysterious mounds that are known as Hawitta. The native population is friendly and offers unique handmade souvenirs.

Velavaru

Velavaru Island has preserved its wild, untouched nature: bushy thickets, tall palm trees, a lagoon, and clean beaches are an authentic charm. The island is home to giant turtles, whose numbers are, unfortunately, declining every year.

Meedhiffushi

Meedhiffushi is a part of the Maldives that is just starting to host travelers. However, those people who have already visited this place consider it to be ideal for a vacation. Tourists shall find here fashionable hotels, restaurants, and a diversity of activities. 

Baa Atoll

Baa Atoll charms with ocean turquoise coastlines, white sand, and lush vegetation. The Maldivians themselves and many travelers consider Baa to be the jewel of the entire region. The archipelago is 40 kilometers long. It consists of 51 islands: 10 of them are inhabited, and 41 have untouched nature.

Eydhafushi

The island of Eydhafushi is the capital of Baa Atoll. It is the largest fishing center in the whole Republic. UNESCO has not neglected the unique nature and diversity of its marine world. Nowadays, it is a biosphere reserve, where fish of amazing colors, whale sharks, rays, and sea turtles live.

Olugiri

In the south of Baaa, Olugiri Island is located. It is home to sea frigates, and green turtles rest on the coast. It offers a wide range of activities for holidaymakers, and diving is one of the most popular. Only here can you see the babies of whale sharks, tuna, and various representatives of the fauna.

description.en: Mongolia is a country where little has changed since ancient times. Most of the population still live in yurts, but lead a nomadic lifestyle not on horses but Japanese trucks, moving from place to place in search of better feed for the cattle. Tourists come here to see beautiful, almost untouched by man, steppe landscapes, the majestic Altai Mountains with snowy peaks and crystal clear lakes. Mongolia amazes and, at the same time, gives a sense of tranquillity.

geography.en: Mongolia is an independent country with no access to the sea. It borders on Russia in the north, China in the south, west, and east. The relief of the country is mountain peaks in the north and west, picturesque plains in the east, and hilly deserts in the south. The Mongolian Altai is the highest mountain range in the country, with a length of 900 km. Rivers start their way to Siberia and flow into thousands of lakes in the Far East. The administrative and territorial division of the country includes 21 aimags and the capital Ulaanbaatar. Each aimag is divided into sums (districts), with its administrative center, settlements, and baghs (brigades).

long_description.en:
Ulaanbaatar

Ulaanbaatar is the capital of Mongolia, and Sükhbaatar Square is the central point of the city. This is a bustling town: noise, bustle, and countless tourists. The main attractions are located in the square: museums, government buildings, and business centers. If you want to see the panorama of the city, it is enough to climb the Zaisan Memorial, which was opened in 1979, in honor of the 50th anniversary of the victory of the Soviet-Mongolian troops in the Battles of Khalkhin Gol. The Gandantegchinlen Monastery (translated from Mongolian as "a great place of absolute happiness") is one of the most frequently-visited attractions and the architectural symbol of the city. Buddhist ceremonies are held here daily, so the local population often visit this place. Tourists like to take pictures in front of a 26-meter tall Buddha statue, covered with gold and containing 2 million scrolls with mantras written on them.

Darkhan

Darkhan is the second-largest city in Mongolia and a manufacturing center. The first enterprise in the country, a metallurgical plant, was built here. Darkhan is also called the "city of friendship" because it maintains tolerant relations with many countries of the world. The territory of the city is conditionally divided into two parts — Old and New City. There is a famous Buddhist monastery Kharagiin Khiid in the Old part — the center of Buddhist pilgrimage. In New City, a Buddhist complex was built, attracting many newlyweds from around the world. But the architecture of "new buildings" does not surprise with elegance: usual grey houses made of bricks, but with a zest — traditional Mongolian vertical inscription, which was used before the Cyrillic script. 

Erdenet

Erdenet is a small town that's just started to be built up with "skyscrapers." The main attraction is the Friendship Monument, which strengthens friendly relations between the Russian and Mongolian peoples. From above, you can enjoy a beautiful view of the city and its picturesque surroundings. There is a Mining Museum in the central square and a monument to the builders of the town — a T-100M tractor on a pedestal. There are several Buddhist monuments here: the temples of Gandanshaduvlin and Norovlin and a chapel on a mountain slope with a giant Buddha statue. You can buy national clothes and souvenirs at the local market. You should head to the "National Park Mongolia XIII Century" for the main sights, natural beauties. This place will demonstrate what the nomad camps were like in ancient times. In the Gorkhi-Terelj National Park, you can see full-sized skeletons of dinosaurs, which inhabited the territory of modern Mongolia exclusively. 

Choibalsan

Choibalsan is a town located at the Kherlen River and named after the Mongolian Marshal Choibalsan — the national hero who led the Mongolian army in the Battles of Khalkhin Gol. In honor of this outstanding event, an entire museum complex was built, which includes a historical museum, a memorial to the winners, and a monument to the marshal. The government is doing its best to keep the complex in proper condition. The Danrag Danjalan Monastery is another famous historical landmark of the city, erected in 1840. Previously, 800 monks had been living within its walls, and the structure included three northern and four southern temples. Over time, the monastery was destroyed, and the monks were arrested. But, in 1990, the building was restored, and there are two small temples with 35 monks here today. 

Khovd

Khovd is the oldest and most multicultural city in Mongolia. Its main feature is the river of the same name, which carries its waters through the Mongolian Altai, being born from Khurgan Lake. The uniqueness of the water artery is that no ocean embraces its waters, they end up in the drainless areas of the center of Mongolia. Nature lovers and active tourism enthusiasts will be interested in the Khoit Tsenkher Cave, a natural structure of a landslide type consisting of two passages. It is 220 meters long. This place is remarkable for its mysterious rock inscriptions. There is a museum of Khovd, which displays national costumes, archaeological finds, Buddhist relics, statues, and ancient manuscripts.

description.en: Myanmar, better known in the past as Burma, is at the crossroads of trade routes between India and China. An excellent location was the key to the rapid development of ancient civilization, but Myanmar became open to tourists only a few years ago. Before that, the country's borders were strictly guarded and only selected people could get an entry permit. The land itself is a fantastic combination of majestic gold pagodas and, at the same time, a low standard of living of local people. It retains a special flavor of tastes, traditions, and even religions. This amazing and mysterious country attracts sophisticated travelers and adventurers.

geography.en: The Republic of the Union of Myanmar (the full official name of the country) is situated in the south-east of Asia and shares borders with China, Thailand, Laos, India, and Bangladesh. The west and south of the country are bounded by the Bay of Bengal and the Gulf of Martaban as well as the Andaman Sea. The country's territory is predominantly mountainous; the highest point is Mount Hkakabo Razi (5880 m). The mountain ranges are covered with forests, which makes the scenery of Myanmar particularly fascinating. Myanmar is divided into seven administrative regions, seven states (National Districts), and six self-governing zones, which were declared under the 2008 Constitution.

long_description.en:
Naypyitaw

Naypyitaw has been the main city of the Asian state of Myanmar and the most atypical capital in the world since 2005. It is situated on the site of the former village, between two mountain ranges of Shan Yoma and Bago Yoma. Unlike other Asian cities, life here flows in a measured way, and there is no traditional noise and fuss. Roads and streets look deserted, which is bewildering for tourists. This is not surprising, as Naypyitaw is one of the 10-most unusual capitals and ghost cities in the world. The main attraction is the Uppatasanti Pagoda, with its 99-meter-high spire rising above the town. It is located on a hill, which offers a panoramic view of the capital. There is a lot of greenery in the city, sprawling with lush colors. These landscapes look particularly colorful, surrounded by mountains.

Yangon

Yangon is the former capital of Myanmar and the largest city in the entire region. It is famous for its identity and is loved by tourists for its special flavor: the streets are full of British colonial architecture, skyscrapers rise next to each other, and gilded Buddhist pagodas shine. Yangon's trademark is the golden Shwedagon Pagoda. One can review carvings, stupas, and temples endlessly. Colonial structures are scattered throughout the city but are in a pitiful condition. In the region, it is worth visiting the Sule Pagoda, the Hindu Temple, the glass Sein Yaung Chi Pagoda, the Catholic Cathedral of St. Mary. You can learn about the history of former Burma in the National Museum. Yangon is considered to be the cleanest settlement among Asian capitals. Here the urban style is in harmony with the jungle and developed infrastructure with comfortable hotels, restaurants, and boutiques, ready to provide tourists with everything they need.

Pagan

Pagan (or Bagan) is the ancient capital of the kingdom of the same name on the territory of modern Myanmar. At present, on the site of the ancient city, there is an archaeological zone with thousands of pagodas, temples, stupas, and monasteries. Since 2019, it is included in the UNESCO World Heritage List. It is interesting, but the city of Bagan itself does not exist, there is a small airport, and then begins the zone with archaeological excavations. This place is called "the city of thousands of temples," and there is talk about the magical influence of local land on travelers. The date of origin of the Bagan kingdom is considered to be 850 BC. Here lived alchemists and palace revolution and bloody battles happened. In 1975, there was a powerful earthquake, which destroyed Bagan. Attempts to restore the ancient city were unsuccessful, until recent times. Tourists are offered interesting excursions through caves and display the most significant monuments of architecture.

Mandalay

Mandalay is a majestic city that spreads out on the Irrawaddy River in the north of Myanmar. It is known all over the world as the center of the Buddhist religion. There are 700 pagodas here, each of which is notable for its unusual architectural beauty. Mandalay was founded in 1857 by Mindon Min, and 30 years later, the city was occupied by British colonizers, which influenced the general appearance of the town. The main attractions are Buddhist temples and palace buildings. Mandalay Hill, Royal Palace, Shwenandaw Monastery, Sandamani Pagoda, Kuthodaw Pagoda, the Atumashi Monastery, Kyauktawgyi Pagoda are just a small part of the temples located in the city and its surroundings. The infrastructure of Mandalay is well-developed, and there are five-star hotels of famous networks and guest houses to choose from. Restaurants prepare national dishes and delicacies of Chinese cuisine. There are a huge jewelry market and tourist resorts.

Mrauk U

Mrauk U, the oldest city in the Rakhine State, is now part of the county in Myanmar. It was founded in 1431, and for a long time had been closed not only to tourists but also to locals. Mrauk U itself is lost between mountains and hides the secrets of past centuries. The area attracts with its unique pagodas and temple complexes, the main of which are Shittaung, Htukkanthein, Andaw-thein. In the vicinity of Mrauk-U, there is Koe Thaung pagoda, which contains 90,000 images of Buddha. Today, active restoration works continue, thanks to which the pagodas and temples regain their former grandeur. The city has a symbolic place to visit, the U Bein Bridge. It's a place where people tend to meet sunsets. Going beyond the horizon, the sun colors temples and military buildings in a warm shade, making the constructions even more picturesque. This is a fantastic area where the descendants of the ancient Arakans, the Rohingya, and the Bengali sub-ethnos still live.

Resorts of Myanmar

It is not only the fans of antiquities and Buddhist culture who go to the picturesque Asian country. Tourist destinations are actively developing here, where snow-white beaches of the Bay of Bengal and the Andaman Sea are breathtaking.

Ngapali is a resort located on the Andaman Sea coast. Transparent water, snow-white sand, and luxurious bungalows await fans of beach recreation. Locals say that in Ngapali, "land and sky have switched places". It is one of the most beautiful resorts in Myanmar.

Ngwesaung — the resort's sandy beaches stretch along the Bay of Bengal. It is a kingdom of peace, silence, and relaxation. The coastline is generously covered with greenery: palm groves shelter from the sun, creating a pleasant rustle from the gentle breeze.

Inle. Here, the rest on the lake, surrounded by mountains, will be unforgettable. There are 17 original villages here, water buffalo bathes in the lake, and in the middle of the water, on piles, rises the Jumping Cat Monastery. Entertainment includes a floating market, hot springs, and learning how to make clothes from lotus stems.

description.en: The highest mountains and the deepest gorges, stunning landscapes, and amazing people — it's all about Nepal. It is the birthplace of Buddha, the spiritual capital of the world, the country of thousands of temples and monasteries. Here come those who are tired of the hustle and bustle and are looking for meaning in life. Those who have decided to challenge the harsh reality and conquer one of the highest peaks in the world. Those who want to get acquainted with one of the ancient cultures of the world, preserved to our days in an almost primordial form. And Nepal is also a paradise for ecotourists, fans of getting to the very heart of the wildlife. This country seems to be hiding from the prying eyes behind high mountain ranges. Not everyone can get here, but only those who know exactly why they are attracted by the solitary, sometimes even medieval Nepal, living by its traditions.

geography.en: Nepal is located in South Asia. Its neighbors are the most populous countries in the world — India and China. The Great Himalayan Range covers almost the entire area from the north, making Nepal the highest mountainous country in the world. Eight of the world's fourteen highest mountain peaks, the so-called "eight thousandths", are in Nepal, including Mount Everest. However, 20% of all of Nepal's land is covered with national parks and sanctuaries. The climate of the country, without exaggeration, is unique — from tropical and subtropical to freezing and lifeless ice zone, which starts at 5 thousand 200 meters above sea level.In Nepal, bamboo, and cedars, snow leopards and rhinoceroses live together on a rather small territory. There are also tropical jungle and alpine meadows.Nepal is not rich in mineral resources and has no access to the sea.Today, it is one of the poorest countries in the world. The Kathmandu Valley, the life center of Nepal, is located between the Great Himalayas and the Mahabharata Range. It is home to three of the country's oldest cities, including its capital.Administratively, Nepal is divided into seven provinces, which in turn consist of 77 districts. It is further divided into cities and municipalities.

long_description.en:
Kathmandu

Kathmandu is the capital of this mountainous region and one of the unique cities in the world. It was included in the list of Seven World Heritage Sites by UNESCO. Majestic temples erected hundreds or even thousands of years ago, palaces, squares, and labyrinths of narrow streets that can capture the imagination of a traveler both with their grandeur and poverty — all this is waiting for travelers in Kathmandu. You should definitely take a walk in Durbar Square. At least fifty temple structures and palaces are concentrated there, the walls of which remind of coronations of monarchs, wars, epidemics, and devastating earthquakes. Climb to Swayambhu or the Temple of the Monkeys to see the largest stupa of a temple with Buddha's Eye. It is believed to be about 2,000 years old. You should definitely visit the sanctuary of Shiva, the Pashupatinath Temple, one of the main Hindu sanctuaries in the country. The cremations made it world-famous, as the dead are burned here right in the open air. Visit the Buddhist temple complex Boudhanath, which has long been the center of Tibetan Buddhism in Nepal. In this city, you come across something ancient and unique at almost every step, something that still inhabits the spirit of that very ancient Nepal.

Bhaktapur

Bhaktapur is another ancient city located in the Kathmandu Valley, 16 kilometers from the capital. Its name translates as "city of believers" and, indeed, it has almost two hundred temples and a huge number of Hindu religious monuments. One of the main Hindu gods Vishnu, is especially honored here, and more than a dozen local temples and many other religious buildings are dedicated to him. This city was once the capital of the Malla Kingdom. It was at this time that unique palaces and religious buildings appeared here, which today have become the main tourist attractions. Just like in Kathmandu, Bhaktapur's central palace square is surrounded by temples, pagodas, and palaces. They include the Royal Dynasty Palace of Malla, decorated with marvelous wood carvings. Particular attention should be paid to the Lions' Gate and the Golden Gate. Bhaktapur is also called the city of potters and craftsmen. It is their products, which are sometimes sold right on the ground by the workshops. They can become beautiful souvenirs reminding you of your journey. 

Lalitpur

Lalitpur ("The City of Beauty" or Patan) is rightly considered to be one of the most beautiful cities in Nepal. In it, as in many other cities of the country, the central square of Durbar is a collection of the most exciting sights. First of all, it is a former royal palace, the roof of which, along the perimeter, is guarded continuously by dozens of wooden heroes and deities, painted in bright colors. Next to it, there is the stone temple of Krishna Mandir, with magnificent carvings depicting scenes from "Ramayana" and "Mahabharata". The terracotta temple of Thousand Buddhas, four stupas of King Ashoka, and the only zoo in Nepal — Jawalakhel — these places undoubtedly deserve the attention of tourists. Patan is really very beautiful as it has long been a city of artists, architects, and jewelers who have always decorated it. 

Pokhara

Pokhara is the third most populous city in the country. First of all, it attracts tourists not by architectural and cult masterpieces, but by the magnificent nature. Situated on the shore of Phewa Lake, it delights its guest with its stunning Himalayan landscapes. It is from Pokhara that most of the mountain routes start. Nearby, there are several "eight thousandths" and the only mountain museum in the world. Not far from the city, there is a unique Mahendra Cave, which is home to a real army of bats. There is also a huge bazaar in Pokhara that stretches for 7 kilometers. As the locals state, you can find anything you want at this bazaar. However, there are also cult buildings here. It is the most beautiful Buddhist Peace Pagoda, located on one of the hills, Tal Barahi Temple, situated on an island in the middle of Phewa Lake and Dakshinkali Temple near Pokhara. By the way, locals come here twice a week with bloody gifts — sacrificial chickens, sheep, or goats for six-armed Kali, wife of Shiva.

Lumbini

Lumbini (Sanskrit for "favorite"), located 12 kilometers from the border with India, is considered to be a place of worship for every Buddhist. This is where Gautama Buddha, the founder of this religion, was born. In 1896, archeologists discovered a stone column with inscriptions of King Ashoka notifying about the birth of Buddha in this area. Nowadays, it is a place of pilgrimage and great interest to tourists from different countries. Next to it, there is Maya Devi Temple with a bas-relief depicting the birth of Buddha and the Puskarni pond, where his mother performed the ceremony of ablution. Every country with the Buddhist faith can build a temple in Lumbini. Cambodia, Thailand, China, and even Germany have already done that. It is in this city that they sell a unique souvenir, which is almost never seen in other regions of the country — a statue of a Buddha baby.

Janakpur

Janakpur is a city that used to be called Mithila, a former center of Maithil culture that had its own language and script. Mention of this city is made in the text of the Ramayana, which states that Ram's wife, Sita, was from these regions. According to legends, the king Janaka found Sita in the field as a baby, raised her as his own daughter, and promised to give her as a wife only to the one who could bend the sacred bow of Shiva. Rama did not just bend it, but broke it and took the girl as his wife. It seems that you travel in time when the city celebrates holidays dedicated to Rama. Janakpur is a pilgrimage site for Hindus from all over the world. It's also believed to have been home to the Buddha and Mahavira for some time. By the way, Janakpur is one of the few regions in Nepal that has a railroad.

description.en: Oman is one of the most ecologically clean countries in the world. It amazes with a great variety of natural attractions: impressive deserts, lush oases, sunny beaches, clear waterfalls, picturesque mountain landscapes. Oman has managed to preserve its ancient identity, but at the same time, it has become a comfortable resort with developed infrastructure. The country where the Queen of Sheba ruled, attracts tourists with magnificent palaces, majestic forts, well-groomed national parks, excellent conditions for beach recreation, and scuba diving.

geography.en: The Sultanate of Oman is located in the south-east of the Arabian Peninsula. In the south of the country, there is the Yemen Highlands, and the Al-Hajar Mountains is in the north-east. A narrow strip of the coastal plain of Al-Bāţinah stretches along the coast of the Gulf of Oman. The middle part of Oman has a plateau with a large area covered in sand. There are no permanent rivers in the country. The state is washed on both sides by the waters of the Gulf of Oman and the Arabian Sea. It is bordered by three countries — Yemen, Saudi Arabia, and the United Arab Emirates. According to the administrative division, Oman consists of 11 muḥāfaẓahs.

long_description.en:
A trip to Omar is a great opportunity to get acquainted with ancient Oriental culture, ancient Islamic traditions, and amazing Arabic architecture. And all this can be easily combined with a great beach holiday with a lot of active entertainments.

Muscat

Muscat is the capital of the country, located on the coast of the Gulf of Oman. The main sights of the city were erected in the second half of the XX century during the reign of Sultan Qaboos. One of them is the Sultan Qaboos Grand Mosque, a snow-white building stunning in size, the main minaret of which rose to a height of 90 m in the sky. The interior amazes with its luxury — a chandelier with Swarovski pendants weighing 8 tons, a beautiful prayer carpet consisting of 1.7 billion knots. A striking example of modern Arabic architecture is the Royal Opera, which is a complex of buildings of cultural space. The Al Alam Palace, the monumental Al Jalali Fort, the Bait Al Zubair: Ethnographic Museum, and the Sultan's Armed Forces Museum will also appeal to tourists.

Salalah

Salalah is an ancient city where the legendary Queen of Sheba ruled. Here you can dive into the atmosphere of traditional Oman, get acquainted with the life and habits of local people. Salalah is a real paradise for lovers of historical artifacts. On its territory and suburbs, there are archaeological sites: the famous Nabi Ayoub's Tomb, the oldest settlement of Taqah, and, of course, Samharam with the ruins of the palace of the Queen of Sheba. On the slopes of the mountains surrounding the city, there are flowers and orchards. It was here where rose water first began to be made, which later became popular throughout the world. Beautiful white beaches, active water entertainments, camel and jeep safaris — this is not a complete list of what Salalah offers tourists.

Nizwa

Nizwa is the cultural capital of the country, "the pearl of Islam". The ancient capital of Oman carefully guards the unique architectural monuments — the formidable Jibreen Castle of the XVII century, the mosques of So'al, Ash-Sharja, and Ash-Shawathinah. There is also a UNESCO World Heritage Site here, the Falaj Daris Irrigation System. Lovers of natural wonders can go on an excursion to Al Hoota Cave, which is about 3 km long, or a jeep safari in the Wahiba Sands. Those who are interested in the history of the region will enjoy a trip to the nearby village of Al Hamra, where the way of life has not changed for almost 400 years.

Sohar

Sohar is a port city where, according to legend, the famous Sinbad the Sailor was born. It attracts tourists with snow-white beaches and active sea entertainments. Not far away is the island of Sawadi, a favorite diving spot for divers. The main architectural attraction of Sohar is the monumental snow-white fort, erected back in the XIV century. If you go up to its observation deck, you can admire the incredibly beautiful panorama of the city with its narrow streets, marvelous mosque, and surroundings. Here you can also see a copy of a ship from the era of Sinbad the Sailor.

Sur

Sur is a small seaside town, the center of the construction of the local dhow boats. The city is remarkable for its large number of ancient houses with skillfully carved decor and mosaic windows. Another wonder of Sur is the giant sea turtle reserve. Extreme lovers do not miss the poorly explored Majlis al Jinn Cave, which is up to 120 m high. But only people who are physically well-prepared and with an experienced guide can descend into it.

Bahla

Bahla is an old town that was the capital of the country for 500 years. It is surrounded by majestic 12 km long walls, with 15 gates and numerous towers. Bahla Fort is inscribed on the UNESCO World Heritage List and is considered to be the oldest in the country. In its southwestern part, one can see a Friday mosque, built in the XIV century, with a graceful sculptural mihrab.

description.en: The Islamic Republic of Pakistan is a South Asian state formed by the division of British India. Despite the very tense relations with its neighbor, this country is considered to be a trendy tourist destination. Ruins of ancient cities, mountain fortresses, and priceless monuments of architecture, Islamic sanctuaries, and relics have been preserved here. Islamabad, the capital of the country, deserves special attention. The city is the center of pilgrimage, where believers come every year to visit temples, including the Faisal Mosque — one of the largest in the world. Holidays on the beaches of the Arabian Sea are very popular. Here you can not only sunbathe and swim but also improve your health at medical resorts.

Saudi Arabia occupies more than 80% of the Arabian Peninsula and is its largest state. It is home to Mecca and Medina, sacred Islamic cities near the Red Sea, for which Saudi Arabia is called "the Land of the Two Holy Mosques." Millions of Muslims make pilgrimages here — the entrance to the temples is closed for representatives of other religions. Here is the Masjid al-Haram, which is decorated with nine minarets, the height of each is about 100 meters. It is one of the main Muslim temples in the world. The second most important religious structure of the state is Al Masjid an Nabawi, where the Prophet's tomb is located. The architecture of this building is a standard for mosque builders all over the world. Saudi Arabia, washed by the Red Sea and the Persian Gulf, has many beautiful landscaped beaches, but it must be borne in mind that strict Sharia laws apply here to tourists also — no open clothing or swimsuits are allowed.

geography.en: The Kingdom of Saudi Arabia occupies more than 80% of the Arabian Peninsula. The country is washed by the waters of the Persian Gulf in the northeast and the Red Sea in the west. Much of its territory is desert populated by nomadic Bedouin tribes, and the Al-Asir and Al-Hijazi mountain ranges are in the west. Such countries as the United Arab Emirates, Yemen, Qatar, Oman, Kuwait, Iraq, and Jordan border Saudi Arabia. About 75% of the kingdom's income comes from oil exports. Its proven reserves were considered the largest in the world until 2011 and are now second only to Venezuela.

long_description.en:
Riyadh

Riyadh is the glittering capital and largest city of Saudi Arabia and its financial center. It is located in the heart of the country, on a vast desert plateau. Riyadh, sparkling with lights and adorned with slender minarets, is an extraordinary fusion of ancient Arabian traditions and modern architecture. The achievements of the XXI century are intricately blended with the Arabian fairy tale and antiquity. The splendid twinkling Kingdom Centre and Al Faisaliah harmoniously coexist next to the mud-brick walls of the ancient Al-Masmak fortress, and the luxurious Al Faisaliah Mall and the buzzing Souq al-Thumairi. Those wishing to immerse themselves in Eastern exoticism fully can go to a camel race, and gourmands can sample the signature Arabian dish of khash made from camel meat.

Mecca

The noble Mecca is located in the western part of the country. This holy city is the center of pilgrimage for Muslims, their main shrine. It is home to the largest Masjid al-Haram and the most massive skyscraper complex in the world, the Abraj al-Bait. Even though Saudi Arabia is becoming an increasingly open country that welcomes tourists, only those practicing the Hajj may see the architectural wonders and relics of the city; for those of other religions, access to the city is closed.

Medina

Muslims consider Medina the second most important holy city after Mecca. Many pilgrims come here because it contains the tombs of the Prophet Muhammad and two caliphs who were later recognized as righteous. The first mosque in the world, Al-Haram, is located on the outskirts of Medina. Just like Mecca, only members of the Muslim religion can visit the city.

Jeddah

Jeddah is an ancient multicultural port city. It is located in the western part of Saudi Arabia, on the shores of the Red Sea. Most tourists are interested in the resort area of Corniche with its luxurious hotels, beautiful beaches, and skillfully-made sculptures which decorate this part of the coast. There is also the famous King Fahad's Fountain, throwing jets of water to a height of 312 meters. Inside the city, be sure to visit the historic Al-Balad neighborhood and the starkly contrasting modern Kingdom Center neighborhood, with the towering Kingdom Tower skyscraper at its center.

Al Khobar

The small and cozy town of Al Khobar is located on the coast of the Persian Gulf. It used to be a tiny fishing village, but after discovering oil, it turned into a beautiful and quite prestigious resort. Beautiful beaches, gorgeous parks with fountains and unusual landscaping, large entertainment complexes — everything here is focused on a comfortable and unhurried eastern-style vacation.
