The most popular tourist spot is the Corniche embankment. It is decorated with fountains, openwork pavilions, and decorative pools. In addition, Al Khobar has a lot of interesting excursions to museums, historical and architectural monuments, and other significant places in the city.

Dammam

The thriving metropolis of Dammam is known for its beautiful beaches and scenic views of the Persian Gulf. But even when the bathing season ends, it is well worth coming here. The green parks and wide landscaped promenades are ideal for strolling and relaxing. In recent years, the increasing openness of Saudi Arabia to visitors has turned Dammam into a cultural, sporting, and entertainment center. There are many interesting museums and frequent art exhibitions. A favorite place for tourists is Half Moon Bay. It is located several minutes from the city and perfectly suitable for small children and diving recreation.

Yanbu

The large oil port of Yanbu consists of two very different cities. Its new southern part is built up with oil refineries and industrial plants. The Old Town, with many historical monuments, a great beach area, and an old port, is located north. Nearby is the Souk al Leil night market. Oriental flavor, the freshest seafood, and traditional Arabian food make it very attractive to visitors. The coastal infrastructure is designed for comfortable beach holidays and diving. The most beautiful dive sites in Saudi Arabia are located near Yanbu.

Taif

The amazing and beautiful Taif is often called the City of Roses. In April, the surrounding mountainsides and valleys are covered in a carpet of colorful and fragrant flowers. It's a great pleasure to drive here, especially in the heat of summer. The winding serpentine road ends in a high plateau with a glorious mild climate. In addition to the spectacular views from the peaks of Jabal Dakkā and Al Hada, there are plenty of activities for those who like to get out and about. Here you can spend the day in the water park tourist village of Al Kar, drive the race track and cable car, and admire the fantastic flora and fauna of the picturesque Lake Ghadir Al Banat.

Abha

A trip to ancient Abha is a chance to see the highest mountain peaks of Saudi Arabia. Located over 2,000 meters above sea level, the city is known for its cool climate and serene atmosphere. Its viewpoints offer stunning scenery, and a trip to Asir National Park reveals the amazing nature of the region. The main attraction of Abha is Shadda Palace. Once home to the country's rulers, it now houses a historical museum.

description.en: Taiwan is an island inhabited by the Chinese, who managed to build their ideal world. Taiwan is an unrecognized state. For the majority of countries in the world, it's a province of China. It's funny that Taiwanese consider the inhabitants of the Celestial Empire to be "fake Chinese". If we put aside political differences, the island that was once called Formosa (translates as "a beautiful island") by Portuguese conquerors fully justifies its name. Bamboo forests, waterfalls hidden in dense forests, mountain rivers, sea landscapes — all this is like a real paradise on earth. The cult of a healthy lifestyle reigns everywhere. For example, they clean, wash and disinfect trains right at the station after each trip. The streets are perfectly clean, and in the mornings, locals practice tai chi in parks. Taiwan is also famous for its healthy food and unusual themed restaurants. Some of them may even shock European tourists, such as the Modern Toilet, which is a toilet restaurant.

geography.en: Taiwan is a picturesque island just 150 km from the mainland of China. The East China Sea washes its northern part, the South China Sea and the Philippine Sea wash the southern region, and the Pacific Ocean crashes its waves upon the shore in the east. The island is located at the junction of two tectonic plates. This position makes it prone to frequent earthquakes that cause fires, floods, and storms.  Taiwan's virgin forested mountains stretch along the island, with extinct volcanoes in the north. Fast-mountainous rivers cut wet rainforests on the mountain slopes of Taiwan, but there are very few lakes. Flora and fauna in these regions are plentiful and diverse. And about 20% of the island's territory is allocated to national parks and reserves.Taiwan consists of two provinces and six cities of central subordination. The first ones, in turn, are divided into counties and provincial municipalities. Almost 90% of the island's total population lives in its western part, where the coastal plain is. According to statistics of 2011, the total population is approximately 23 million.

long_description.en:
Taipei

Taipei is the capital of Taiwan. It is known as one of the most populated cities in the world. However, there are no traffic jams due to the many huge overpasses that unload the highways. Two- and three-leveled overpasses entangle the whole metropolis. The city is very young by modern standards (it is only about 100 years old). It is full of greenery, skyscrapers, wide sidewalks, and looks more like the city of the future. The most famous local landmark is the "Taipei 101" skyscraper with the corresponding number of floors. This is the first high-rise building constructed in the area of earthquakes and hurricanes, with a unique system that captures the fluctuations of the earth and leveling the building. Other attractions of the capital of Taiwan include the National Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall, the Imperial Palace Museum, and the zoo. Taipei is a city of ancient medicinal practices, gastronomic abundance, and unusual entertainment.

Shenkeng

Shenkeng is known as the culinary capital. There are numerous snack bars in the main street of the ancient town, where you can taste unique local doufu (tofu) - a dish made of soy curd. It is cooked in a special way: steamed, boiled, fried on fire, pan, or deep-fried. There is even an extraordinary Shenkeng Tofu Festival, held in early November, devoted to this dish. 

Beitou

Beitou is a northern suburb of Taipei, known for its sulfurated hot springs. A river with hot water flows through the city. It has special slopes and wooden decks on its banks so that you can put your feet in warm water and relax. 

Kaohsiung

Kaohsiung is the main port and the second-largest city on the island. It can also be called the main tourist destination in Taiwan. It has the largest and best shopping and entertainment centers, parks, unusual bars, and restaurants — nightlife is booming here. It is interesting that the Ruifeng Night Market is the main party place in the city. Other popular attractions of Kaohsiung include is the Fo Guang Shan Buddha Museum. It is a modern temple under the world's largest seated Buddha (in the center of the complex), where you can write messages to the deity in electronic form. It also includes a museum and a school.

Taichung

Taichung is the third-largest settlement, whose name is translated from Chinese as "the center of Taiwan". It contains the best sights in the country. Among them, you will find the National Museum of Natural Science, Buddhist Paochueh, and Henan temples with a golden statue of Buddha, Taichung aquarium, and city park. 

Tainan

Tainan is the cultural and religious center of Taiwan, one of the oldest cities in the country and the former capital. This small and modest city has more than two hundred temples of different confessions, historical, and cultural monuments. Tainan also can boast of the oldest temple on the island, the State Temple of the Martial God. 

Tamsui

Tamsui is one of the first commercial ports in the nearest suburb of Taipei. Come here to walk along the waterfront or take a ride on one of the many cycling routes, take a picture on the "Lovers' Bridge", taste street Taiwanese fast food, or try Turkish ice cream.

Kenting National Park

Kenting National Park in southern Taiwan is one of the oldest on the island. More than 300 km² of emerald forests, sandy beaches and waterfalls, and coral reefs have made Kenting National Park famous.

Taroko Gorge

The Taroko Gorge is considered to be one of the most picturesque places on the island. It has a second name, "the Marble Gorge," and is a part of the Taroko National Park. In the 50s of the last century, a highway was laid here. Two hundred people died during its construction. The road to the gorge is among the top-10 most dangerous roads in the world.

description.en: Uzbekistan is an ancient and authentic country. The indigenous population has never been nomadic and has been living a sedentary lifestyle. The Uzbeks had been building houses for years, developing trade and agriculture. Life was always in full swing here, and all thanks to the advantageous geographical location of Uzbekistan — almost in the center of the Great Silk Road. In ancient times, endless caravans of camels with goods from Asia to Europe and back walked through its territory across vast deserts. Today, tourists come here to taste lamb pilaf, manti, and chorba, to buy real works of art at the local market — painted earthenware, leather bags, and colored carpets, and just feel the spirit of the east against the background of spectacular nature.

geography.en: The Republic of Uzbekistan is located in the center of Central Asia, between the rivers Amu Darya and Syr Darya. The republic borders with Kazakhstan in the northeast, Kyrgyzstan and Tajikistan in the east and south-east, Turkmenistan in the west, and Afghanistan in the south. The nature of the country combines mountains and plains, with picturesque valleys between them. The administrative and territorial division of Uzbekistan is characterized by several levels. The first level includes 12 provinces, the autonomous Republic of Karakalpakstan and Tashkent, a city of central subordination. In turn, the provinces and the Republic of Karakalpakstan are divided into districts and cities of regional subordination.

long_description.en:
Many cities in Uzbekistan began to exist even before our era. Of course, the buildings of that time didn't survive till our days. But it is quite real to see the architecture of XIII-XIV centuries here.

Tashkent

Tashkent (translated from Uzbek as a "stone city") is the capital of Uzbekistan and the largest city in the country. As life in the East is bustling around bazaars, the Chorsu Market is a must-visit for tourists in Tashkent. It has been thriving since the Middle Ages and allows you to dive into the atmosphere of the oriental world truly. On its counters, one can see huge watermelons, melons with captivating aroma, red-ripe tomatoes, deep-green herbs, colorful fabrics, carpets, and incredibly beautiful painted dishes. The Botanical Garden holds a leading position among the most visited places in Tashkent. Thanks to its mild climate, it is open to visitors all year round. Its territory is divided into five zones, each of them modeling natural complexes of East and Central Asia, North America, Europe, and the Far East. The best way to get around the city is by subway. Not only because it is a fast and comfortable option, but also because the Tashkent subway is magnificent.

Bukhara

Another major city in Uzbekistan is Bukhara, which the Uzbeks themselves call a sacred one. An old belief says: "On all Muslim cities a gracious light descends from heaven, and over Bukhara, it rises to heaven". This is because there is an incredible number of mosques and tombs of Islamic saints. The old part of the city, where more than 170 monuments of architecture and history are concentrated, deserves special attention. Walk around Lyab-i Hauz Square, visit Kalan Mosque, medieval baths, admire the beauty of Nadir Divan-Begi Madrasah, and stay here for dinner. Bukhara gives a sense of a fairy tale — everything here is magical and beautiful.

Samarkand

Samarkand is the third-largest city in Uzbekistan and one of the oldest on the planet. For more than 2000 years, it has been a central point on the Great Silk Road, connecting China and the Mediterranean countries. Many come here to see with their own eyes the famous Registan, which served as the central square in the Middle Ages. It is an architectural ensemble of three stunning madrasas — Tilya Kori, Ulugh Beg, and Sherdor. The Bibi-Khanym Mosque and the Shah-i-Zinda Mausoleum complex, which locals call the "cemetery street", also deserve tourists' attention. Muslim saints, relatives of the famous Timur ruler, religious figures, thinkers, and philosophers rest in the mausoleum. The complex is on the UNESCO World Heritage List.

Khiva

Khiva is a unique city, which has a centuries-old history. It's not easy to get to it. You have to overcome the Kyzylkum desert. It is convenient for tourists because most sights are concentrated in the inner city, Itchan Kala. There are 60 monuments here, dating back to the XVI-XX centuries. The majority of madrasas, mosques, minarets, and palaces of Khiva belong to the epoch of existence of the Khanate of the same name (XVII-XIX centuries). Architects have created unique architectural buildings in the city, so you can enjoy their diversity, leisurely strolling through its narrow streets. The Kalta Minor Minaret, an ancient monument 29 meters high, is a symbol of the city. The building is unfinished, so the local population has created many legends, each of them explaining its incompleteness. Hurry up here for a tour, and you'll learn everything for yourself.

Termez

Termez is the southernmost city in Uzbekistan. Not far from it is the famous "Friendship Bridge", which connects Uzbekistan with Afghanistan. It was used to carry out the withdrawal of troops after the 10-year war. Many tourists come here to pay tribute to the memory of fallen soldiers. This city was repeatedly literally washed off the face of the earth. Therefore, it is worth to start acquaintance with the Archaeological Museum, which was opened in 2002 and collected a huge number of artifacts of different times. It will also be fascinating to see the Buddhist temple complex Fayaz-Tepe ( the I-III centuries BC), to visit the Aral-Paygambar nature reserve and the family burial vault of local sayyids.

description.en: The Philippines is a large island state that unites more than seven thousand islands within a single republic. It is a real paradise for lovers of picturesque nature, beautiful beaches, and turquoise water. In the Philippines, you can engage in water sports, arrange a romantic trip, experience the wonders of a healer, and even visit an uninhabited island. It is an ideal place to get in touch with nature and find answers to essential questions. No wonder that tourists from all over the world are happy to come here.

geography.en: The Republic of the Philippines is located in Southeast Asia, in the western part of the Pacific Ocean. The country consists of more than 7,000 islands, only one-third of which are inhabited. However, even the wild islands can be reached on a guided tour. Taiwan, Indonesia (Sulawesi Island), and Malaysia (Sabah Island) are the nearest neighbors of the Philippines. The Philippine archipelago stretches for 3000 km from north to south and 900 km from east to west. There are four large islands within the republic, the most famous of which is Luzon.

long_description.en:
Luzon

Luzon is the most densely populated island in the Philippines, located in the northern part of the country. It is worth getting acquainted with the capital, Manila, which has a fantastic ancient district of Intramuros. Churches and temples, monasteries, and palaces, as well as just beautiful buildings, constructed more than 200 years — all of this is certainly worth seeing. A visit to Fort Santiago where all kinds of galleries, restaurants, shops, and even an aquarium are located will give you an equally vibrant experience. Tourists will also enjoy all the fascinating places outside of Manila. Here you can dive, swim with whale sharks, swim in the crater of the volcano, see the remains of warships, visit national parks, and rice terraces.

Mindanao

Mindanao is located in the southern Philippines and is the second-largest island in the republic. Its main peculiarity is the unique untouched nature that civilization has had minimal impact on. Different cultures and nationalities blend here, giving tourists the opportunity to enjoy the unique flavor. Cozy beaches with black volcanic sand, exotic fruits, national parks, mountains, extreme entertainment — all this turn a vacation on the island into a bright and memorable experience. 

Mindoro

Mindoro is another big island in the Philippines. The majority of the entertainment here is related to water. Snorkeling and scuba diving, boat or jet skiing, fishing, as well as excursions to the neighboring small islands and picturesque waterfalls — these activities are quite affordable. Moreover, you can bargain.

Palawan

People often call Palawan a protected island paradise. Complete solitude, serenity, and peace — here, you can feel the harmony with the world and with yourself. The island has several attractions, including an abandoned monastery, a waterfall, and a lake with mountain water. You can also dive into the unique Barracuda Lake, visit the complex of the Tabon caves or climb to the top of Mount Mantalingajan. 

Bohol

Bohol is one of the unique islands in the Philippines, as here you can find the renowned Chocolate Hills and the smallest monkeys. Tourists can take a walk on bamboo boats, admire the beautiful waterfall, explore the caves, and dive. 

Boracay

Boracay is a popular island, famous for its picturesque White Beach. You can also walk around the vibrant village of the locals, see the famous Willy's Rock, check out the Butterfly Garden, climb to the top of Mount Luho, and admire unique live corals. 

Cebu

Cebu is another small island with the city of the same name, the oldest in the Philippines. It was here that the famous traveler Ferdinand Magellan landed and set a cross that everyone today can see. Cebu Island offers quite a diverse holiday options. Here you can enjoy the picturesque beaches and live in comfortable hotels, or you can organize an educational vacation with a visit to the basilica, fort, temples, and waterfalls. For the lovers of active pastime, the island offers diving, jet-skiing, and walks to neighboring islands.

description.en: Canada is the largest country in the Western Hemisphere. Here the developed industrial zones neighbor upon wild forests, modern megalopolises turn into prairies. There are more azure lakes than glass skyscrapers, and the surf of the ocean sounds in tune with loud parties. Canada gave birth to hockey, Keanu Reeves, Jim Carrey, and Celine Dion. The British Crown reigns here and the policemen hand out “positive tickets” for good deed. Canada is such a hospitable and friendly country that it even has a landing spot for aliens. So don’t be shy, take a vacation, and head to conquer the hiking trails of the Canadian National parks.

long_description.en:
Ottawa

Ottawa is an unexpectedly unpretentious capital of this large country. Downtown is the most interesting district in regards to attractions. The most important building in Canada - the Parliament - is located here. More than 3 million tourists come here annually to watch a change of guards by Parliament Hill. The National Gallery of Canada with a vast collection of arts and the magnificent Fairmont Château Laurier castle also deserve tourists’ attention. Ottawa won’t let families with children get bored! The Canadian Children’s Museum and the farm on the territory of the Canada Agriculture and Food Museum work for little travelers. Romantics set their hearts on the central Rideau canal. In summer, they enjoy going boating, and in winter they prefer skating on the frozen surface of the canal holding hands.

Toronto

Progressive Toronto is a so-called Canadian New York. The megapolis does its best to surpass its American opponent. We should say, the city is doing great in this! The glass business district with black towers of the Toronto-Dominion center, bright advertising banners on Yonge Street, futuristic shapes of the CN Tower which offers a fantastic view on the city, cold shadows of the trees in High Park, art exhibits at Harbourfront Centre — it definitely looks like New York in miniature. However, the city has its raisins on the cupcake! You can see them in the bastions of Fort York, the picturesque castle of the first European colonists Casa Loma, and the Hockey Hall of Fame. But the megalopolises share Niagara Falls for two. And the best views on the most powerful waterfall in North America can be seen from the Canadian side.

Vancouver

Beautiful Vancouver lives on the coast of the Pacific Ocean, in picturesque Burrard Inlet. Thought out to the last detail in regards to the infrastructure, clean and safe, it is rightfully considered to be one of the best cities for living. This city is young and you won’t find here any historical monuments. Among all the attractions, Stanley Park deserves special attention. It is so large, interesting, and diverse, that you should devote a full day to exploring it. In addition to that, find some time to visit the historical center Gastown and Chinatown, Queen Elizabeth Park and VanDusen Botanical Garden with its odd green mazes, and, of course, relax at city beaches. Tolerant and ecological Vancouver will become a perfect starting point to explore the province of British Columbia. It’s a stone's throw away from the old-growth forest of the Pacific Rim National Park Reserve and the Great Bear Rainforest. You can also head to the beach to surf or to the Whistler skiing resort. Nothing can stop you from drinking excellent wine in the Okanagan Valley or to go on a safari to the Haida Gwaii archipelago. 

Montreal

If you suddenly feel the unbearable craving for Europe, you should come to Montreal. The bricked streets of Old Montreal will take you to the times of the French colonization. The splendid ornamentation of the halls at Notre-Dame Basilica of Montreal, the sharp spires of the Notre-Dame-de-Bon-Secours Chapel, ancient mansions and prestigious universities, masonry vaults of Windsor Station that only a hundred years ago accepted immigrants from the whole continent on its platforms — all of this add coziness and nobility to the typical modern city landscapes. 

Quebec

Quebec is the most French city in Canada. It’s the capital of the homonymous province. It grew on the banks of the Saint Lawrence River and saved the unique atmosphere of the port cities of the Old World. Tourists love it for walks along its bricked streets, for the spires of the Château Frontenac that seems to have just appeared from the screens of the “Grand Budapest Hotel” movie. They love it for the austere vaults of the Cathedral-Basilica of Notre-Dame de Québec, for the successful symbiosis of modern technologies and Parisian charm. Without exaggeration, Quebec can be called the most musical city in Canada. One festival is hardly over, and they are already getting ready for the next musical fairy show. The winter carnival in the ice castle at Place Jacques-Cartier is replaced by the musical Festival d'été roaring all over the Old Town for 11 days! The heartful festival of jazz and blues gives in its scene to the traditional festival of New France. 

Alberta

Perhaps, only Alberta can beat the beauty of Quebec’s landscapes. Every summer, when the snow starts to melt, the water of Peyto Lake in Banff National Park turns into genuine azure. Bison wander among the dense forests of Wood Buffalo National Park. Beavers construct dams on rivers, and fossils come to Lake Athabasca to drink some water. The rocky mountains of Jasper National Park are so picturesque and unique that they were taken under UNESCO’s protection. 

Edmonton

Edmonton is the capital of Alberta. The city might seem to be slightly mediocre after traveling through the province. But don’t underestimate it. Displays of the Royal Alberta Museum, World of Science Center impress even the most sophisticated travelers. And more than 40 festivals that take place in the city throughout a year won’t even give a single chance of getting bored. The extravagant Fringe Theatre Festival, authentic Edmonton Folk Music or heartful Symphony Under the Sky — choose an even to your liking and come for a visit.

description.en: The United Mexican States is a country in Central America where a rattling mixture of Spanish, Indian, and Caribbean cultures has accumulated throughout its history. In Mexico, you will conquer waves on a surfboard, dive into underwater caves, enjoy the splendor of colonial architecture, dance to the accompaniment of Mexican mariachi ensemble, try to read Mayan hieroglyphics on the walls of ancient temples, sunbathe on the beaches of Cancun and dance till you can't feel your feet at mind-blowing parties in Acapulco. Besides, at least 300 sorts of tequila will inspire you to achieve all of those, as mentioned earlier.

geography.en: Contrary to popular belief, Mexico's landscapes are far from the desert people imagine. The relief of the country is formed by the Sierra Madre mountain ranges, which are part of the Rocky Mountains. The Pacific Ocean and the Gulf of California wash the west coast of Mexico. The east side is washed by the Atlantic Ocean, the Gulf of Mexico, and the Caribbean Sea. The country shares a border with the United States of America in the north and with Belize and Guatemala in the south-east. The territory of the country is divided into 31 states and one federal district. Each of them has its own Constitution and Congress. Resorts are especially popular with tourists: the Yucatán Peninsula, cities of the South Pacific region, as well as Chiapas and the Central Region, are known for their natural and cultural attractions.

long_description.en:
Mexico City

Mexico City is the capital of the country, one of the largest megalopolises in North America and, at the same time, the most densely populated region. The Aztecs founded it back in the 14th century. Nowadays, it has grown to the size of the city with 20 million people! So, consider renting a hotel or an apartment in the center of the town and take at least five days to explore the capital. We recommend listening to the mariachi in Plaza Garibaldi; take a boat ride on the canals of Xochimilco and see the creepy Doll Island; see the Aztec pyramids in Teotihuacán; check out the frescoes of Diego Rivera in the Palacio Nacional and the vaults of the Mexico City Metropolitan Cathedral; visit the House of Frida Kahlo — an artist and famous feminist; and enjoy views of the city from Chapultepec Castle. 

Guadalajara

Guadalajara is home to everything Mexican. Explore the Old Centre, walk along the gorgeous Baroque buildings of the colonial era, intertwined with images of conquistador times. In these streets, centuries ago, folk tunes of Spanish Andalusia and American Indian songs merged into the mariachi — Mexican national music. Life here goes slower than in the rest of Mexico, but it's easier to breathe thanks to the abundance of parks and gardens. Once, the craftsmen from Guadalajara invented sombreros and tequila, and today the city is called the "Mexican Silicon Valley". Here, people honor traditions and keep up with the progressive world. Guadalajara is ready to amaze and delight you, so don't hesitate to include this city in your list of must-visit places.

Cancun

Cancun is the most popular Mexican resort. The entire city is 22 km of snow-white beaches, the sparkling Caribbean Sea, and fashionable hotels. Usually, wealthy tourists choose Cancun for lazy sunbathing, diving, drinking a couple of cocktails, playing golf, and so on around. But if this type of holiday is not for you, and you have already booked accommodation in Cancun, do not worry. From here, you can take one-day trips to one of the Seven New Wonders of the World — the pyramids of Kukulkan, in the ancient city of Chichen Itza. Visit the ruins of the town of Tulum and the settlements of El Rey; see the natural attractions in Xel-Ha Park and the Sian Ka'an Biosphere Reserve, known for its picturesque barrier reef and lush rainforests and mangroves.

Mérida

Mérida is a beautiful "White City", which was the first in the Yucatán Peninsula, where the Spanish conquerors had arrived. It has no direct access to the sea, so only numerous museums, gastronomic evenings, bookshops, and an odd number of architectural attractions are available for tourists. The neoclassical Casa Museo Montes Molina, the plantations of Hacienda Sotuta de Peón, the Colonial-era Cathedral, the Church of Iglesia El Jesus, the Merida Theatre, the halls of Nahualli Casa de Los Artistas and dozens of other yellow, blue, pink and white elegant facades — walks through the streets of the city guarantee an incredible aesthetic pleasure. 

Oaxaca

The ancient Mayan culture is concentrated in Oaxaca. As a part of your one-day visit, be sure to go see the majestic Church of Santo Domingo de Guzman, where the "elite" get married, visit one of the museums of local culture, listen to a concert on Zócalo Square. Don't forget to taste the mezcal and drink as much hot chocolate that is produced here as you can.

Acapulco

In the 50s, the resort with the sonorous name Acapulco was especially popular among the American film elite. Nowadays, Acapulco is open to everyone who wants to relax on the Pacific coast. Luxurious and standard hotels, wide sandy beaches, expensive restaurants, and affordable cafes, cozy picturesque bays, and mind-blowing nightlife — each guest here will find a holiday option fitting his pocket. If you are bored with a measured beach holiday, visit the Chapel of Peace, Papagayo National Park, San Diego's 17th-century fortress, La Quebrada Cliffs Bay, and Isla de la Roqueta, where nature has created fantastic conditions for diving.

description.en: The United States of America is an alluring and multifaceted country in North America. It includes 50 states. They snug between the Appalachian Mountain range in the east and the snow-white cold-desert of Alaska in the north-west. The USA is the world’s third-largest country according to its territory. It definitely uppermost in its political, economic, and cultural impact on the modern world. The territory of 9,5 million km² comprises plenty of historical attractions, museums and art galleries, amusement parks, beach and skiing resorts, unique natural reserves. But the special charm of the USA is hidden in the deep countryside, in small villages, and in agricultural areas.

long_description.en:
If you want to understand the US and discover the contrasts of this country, you have to travel all over its lands from one coast to another. We recommend you to start your adventure from the north-east. That’s the region, where the colonization of America began back in the XIV century. Washington is the capital of the USA and the center of the world’s democracy. The main administrative buildings of the country are concentrated here: the White House, the headquarters of the US Congress, the Pentagon, Supreme Judicial Court, and other governmental organizations. The city looks pompous and is in marked contrast to any other megalopolis in the USA. Unlike New York, it doesn’t have a single skyscraper. At the same time, the Big Apple is a city of opportunities and making the American dream come true. Isn’t it wonderful to go jogging into Central Park and stroll under the neon signs at Times Square? Drink a cup of coffee on the Brooklyn Bridge and ascend the Statue of Liberty; shake the forepaw of the T-Rex at the American Museum of Natural History or listen to some jazz in Greenwich Village. We are all familiar with all of these owing to the diversity of movies and songs devoted to this megapolis.

The North

In the north, the enormous horseshoe of Niagara Falls united Canada and America. It’s neither the highers nor the widest waterfall in the world. However, the power of this water flow falling down with great force from the cliff is truly impressive.

The specialists for the stock exchanges in New York and governers of the Capitol study on the east coast. Harvard, Yale, Brown, Princeton, Cornell — all these names traditionally associate with prestige and high quality of education. Every year, the universities of the Ivy League offer scholarships for education. So, anyone can enter the society of the young American elite, even you.

Florida

The seriousness of the north-eastern region can be easily dispelled with a trip to the south. Here, in the state of Florida, you can watch, gasped, the launch of the rockets, spend the whole day having fun at Legoland and Walt Disney World, relax on snow-white sandy beaches, and search for the rare species of a cougar in the mangroves of Everglades National Park.

If you can smell a sharp odor of the hydrogen sulfide, you have probably arrived at Yellowstone National Park. Hot springs, painted with dozens of bacteria; geysers that are more than 2000 meters in height; sky-blue lakes - the picture is mind-blowing! In addition to everything, all this water around you is boiling and bubbling, getting warmed up from the active supervolcano.

The West

Let’s go further to the west. Here, the red rocks more than two kilometers in height and bitten by a wild river meet you. You stand on the top and can’t decide won’t deeper: the blue sky with the cry of the falcon, or Grand Canyon which echo reflects the original song of the feathered hunter.

California

Passing by the stone canyon, moving through the forests and waterfalls of Yosemite National Park, you find yourself in California. Sunny Los Angeles will meet you with the landscapes of Beverly Hills and Melrose districts. They seem to be so familiar after watching those renowned series in the 90s. One a year in Hollywood, the worldwide known movie stars tremble with excitement and get jitters on the red carpet aspiring to get the Oscars. Long Beach and Santa Monica are never tired to please their visitors with golden beaches, fluffy palm trees, and perfect waves for surfing. When the tan has firmly stuck to your skin, head to get more impressions at Universal Park and Disneyland. Believe us, these places entertain and amaze not only children!

Places You Can’t Miss

When you travel across the US, there are several places you can’t miss. Don’t forget to add Millennium Park in Chicago, the mountain lakes in the suburbs of Seattle, the city of sin and depravity Las Vegas, and, of course, Hawaii, the island of songs to ukulele, and silk velvet sunsets to your route. In general, just improvise! No matter what direction you choose, you will always find something interesting and incredible!

description.en: The American Virgin Islands is one of the most charming and pleasant places in the Caribbean Basin. It is always warm and sunny, and the stunningly beautiful wildlife of the tropics and the bright underwater world will gladly reveal their secrets to you. Take a magical scuba diving trip in search of pirate treasures, admire bright birds of all imaginable colors and shades in the evergreen forests or just lie on the chic beaches of the Caribbean — it's impossible to be bored here. Late at night, you can sit on a lounge chair with a glass of rum and admire the mysterious sparkle of Crux, the guiding thread of many great travelers of the past.

Anguilla is a British Overseas Territory consisting of several islands in the Caribbean Sea. Puerto Rico, the Virgin Islands, and Saint Martin are the closest to it. The Valley is the capital of the country. Anguilla is not just an island with miles of white beaches and coral reefs. Beyonce, LeBron James, Brad Pitt, Paul McCartney, Justin Bieber, and many others enjoy a holiday here away from the annoying paparazzi. Anguilla does not yet have crowds of tourists, so you can enjoy a peaceful holiday. The main historical attraction is the oldest house on the islands — Wallblake House, located in the capital. In the fishing village of Island Harbour, you can eat fresh seafood and get acquainted with the life of the islanders. And Shoal Bay offers diving and spending evenings out in a cozy restaurant.

Antigua and Barbuda is an independent state between the Caribbean Sea and the Atlantic Ocean. It consists of three islands — Antigua, Barbuda, and Redonda. Saint John's is the capital and the largest city. Nelson's Dockyard is the main attraction of the country. It is the largest national park in Antigua, where the most important British naval base in the Caribbean was located. Some historical buildings have been preserved here, and there is a museum dedicated to the dockyard. Antigua and Barbuda is most famous not for its historical heritage, but for its beaches, which are often ranked among the best in the world. The fans of sailing — windsurfing, kitesurfing, and yachting — have long loved the local coasts. Since 1968, it has been hosting the annual international regatta, the Antigua Sailing Week, with over a hundred yachts participating.

Aruba is a small island and public entity in the Caribbean Sea off the coast of Venezuela, owned by the Kingdom of the Netherlands. Oranjestad is the capital city of Aruba. There is no Duty-Free Zone at the local airport because the whole island is declared a free-trade zone. One of the most beautiful places in Aruba is the beach on the private island of Renaissance. There are pink flamingos, which are not afraid of people. They eagerly take food from their hands and pose for photos on the background of turquoise water and white sand. The waters around Aruba are full of sunken ships, coral reefs, and tropical sea creatures that attract divers. A must-see include Arikok National Park with fascinating caves (Fontein, Quadirikiri, and the Love Tunnel), a Dutch farm, colonial houses, remains of Dutch settlements, and gold mines.

The uniqueness of the Bahamas is that its tourist infrastructure is intentionally very diverse. One part of the archipelago is ideal for fashionable holidays, organizing unforgettable celebrations for newlyweds and honeymoon. There are islands simply created for diving or fishing, while the others have become centers of ecological tourism, famous for unique architectural objects or beautiful wild beaches. But there is also something that unites all the resorts of the Bahamas — a tourist will find on any of them precisely what he was looking for!

geography.en: The full name of this independent state is the Commonwealth of The Bahamas. It is located in the Atlantic Ocean on the archipelago of the same name, which consists of 700 islands (only 40 of them are populated) and more than two thousand coral reefs. The total area of the Bahamas is 13,940 km² while the area of inhabited islands is 11,400 km². Administratively, the State is divided into districts. At the moment, there are 31 of them, and each has its own self-government bodies. The island of New Providence, where the capital of the Bahamas (Nassau) is located, is under direct government control.The coast of the archipelago is washed by the warm current of the Gulf Stream. With its closest continental neighbor, the peninsula of Florida (USA), which is only 90 km away, it is separated by the strait of the same name. The Old Bahamas Channel separates it from the island of Cuba.The relief of the islands is mainly flat. The highest point of the archipelago is Mount Alvernia (63 m) on Cat Island. There are almost no rivers in the Bahamas, which causes certain difficulties with fresh water. The west coast of the islands is torn with salt lagoons, and there are also many mangrove swamps. The eastern islands are arider. They are covered with savannas and thickets of thorny evergreen bushes. Some of the islands have preserved tropical forests.

long_description.en:
Nassau

The capital city of Nassau is located on the small island of New Providence. And it has literally everything that a traveler can dream of. Its architecture is an unforgettable mixture of buildings of XVIII-XIX centuries and ultramodern constructions. The most unusual museum of the capital is stylized as a pirate ship and is fully dedicated to these sea bandits. In 1706, they founded a quasi-state - the Republic of Pirates on the islands. The Paradise island, connected to the city with a bridge, has everything for a variety of recreation — casinos, luxury hotels, golf fields, a dolphinarium, and a water park. Nassau beaches offer white silk sand, turquoise water, and picturesque reefs. People here can go yachting and water skiing, diving, snorkeling, and sport fishing. And you can admire a diverse sea life in the Crystal Cay Marine Park Aquarium. Lovers of exclusive shopping should definitely visit Bay Street and the Straw Market. The Queen's Staircase is the most visited attraction. Its 65 steps are carved into the rock, the top of which offers a beautiful view of the city. The Royal Victoria Garden and Ardastra Gardens, Zoo and Conservation Centre (a nature reserve in the heart of the town) are tourists' favorite green areas.

Freeport

Freeport is a resort city on the island of Grand Bahama. Mangrove swamps and rainforests surround it. Its parks and gardens are full of bougainvillea, orchids, and jasmine. Freeport never sleeps. Beaches are an absolute priority for daytime entertainment. The most popular are Lucaya, Tiger Beach, Taino, and Paradise Cove. Here you can go snorkeling, diving, surfing, and underwater hunting. Gold Rock is the most beautiful wild beach in Lucayan National Park, an ideal place for photoshoots. Lovers of active recreation will appreciate the golf fields, tennis courts, and sea fishing centers. A trip to the perfume factory Fragrance of the Bahamas is one of the most exciting excursion programs of the resort. Here you can create your own fragrance and get it as a souvenir. A favorite gastronomic attraction of tourists is the restaurant Le Chicken Snack, which serves the perfect chicken barbecue. Both local and guests go to "Lucayan Market" for shopping. As the sun goes down, nightclubs, bars, and discos with foam parties, cocktails, and live music come into play. You can try your luck and tickle your nerves in one of the Freeport casinos.

Marsh Harbour

Marsh Harbour is situated on the island of Great Abaco. It is the third-largest city in the country and an important tourist center. It is also known as the world's sailing capital. Hundreds of beautiful yachts and boats are moored on its shores. Many of them can be rented to go searching for deserted beaches or to travel the vast Atlantic Ocean. There are chic villas, hotels, and guest houses built near the water's edge. The beaches are covered with pure white sand, and the coral reefs off the coast are the best place to dive. Walker Cay Reef, the main center of sport fishing in the Bahamas, is one of them. Don McKay Boulevard has the highest concentration of the best cafes and duty-free shops. The most popular restaurant in the city, Native Pork Roast, is waiting for the real fans of gastronomic experiments. The exotic yellow building of the Seaview Castle is the main historical attraction of Marsh Harbour. It is a mansion built by the American Evan Cottman, who was in love with this city. The lighthouse of the same name is located in the village of Hope Town, very close to the center. Tourists love taking pictures of this bright red-and-white building. And when you take the 101 steps to the observation deck, you can enjoy the marvelous views of the surrounding area. Tilloo Cay National Reserve is located near the coast. Many people come here to watch seabirds.

Matthew Town

Matthew Town is the only inhabited area on Great Inagua Island, the southernmost point of the Bahamas. The city was founded in the middle of the XIX century. Its streets have well-preserved buildings of the classical colonial architecture of that period. The Great Inagua Lighthouse is the main historical attraction. This elegant white building on Mortimer Hill not only performs its direct functions but also serves as an excellent observation platform. On a clear day, you can even see Cuba from here. Before the appearance of the lighthouse, at the beginning of the XIX century, many ships crashed on the rocky shores and reefs of the island. Moreover, it was often raided by pirates. The legend that there are Spanish galleons that had sunk in the XVI-XVIII centuries and rich English and French vessels, which are hiding near Matthew Town, still stirs up the minds of treasure hunters. Lovers of diving, snorkeling, and sea fishing appreciate their leisure time in this city. But it is even more attractive for eco-tourists. There is a large bird sanctuary in the center of the island. More than 80 thousand exotic birds — flamingos, roseate spoonbill, Bahama pintail, pelicans, white and gray herons — live here. There is also a sea and land parks on the neighboring inhabited island of Little Inagua. Here, among other things, you can see whole herds of wild goats and donkeys.

Alice Town

Alice Town is the capital of a group of Bimini islands that Ernest Hemingway adored. It's the most famous sea fishing center. It attracts visitors from all over the world to find wahoo, tuna, shortfin mako shark, barracuda, garfish, or blue marlin. The city provides its guests with comfortable marinas, hotels, and guest houses. There are a lot of fishing clubs, but the most famous of them is at the Compleat Angler Hotel. It's where Hemingway wrote his novel "To Have and Have Not". The club has a collection of rare photos of the author and his personal memorabilia. Alice Town Beach is an uninterrupted fine sand line, but the locals divide it into Radio Beach and Blister Bay. The first one boasts of plenty of bars and fast-food restaurants, while the second has more privacy. The city also has an architectural highlight, the Dolphin House Museum. It is a concrete building on a handmade steel frame. It is decorated with many panels and mosaics of tiles, stones, shells, beach glass, and other items found on the coast. Near Alice Town, in the ocean, lie two natural or human-made (scientists are still arguing) stone formations — the Bimini Road and the Wall of Bimini. Many even believe that these are the ruins of Atlantis. You have to scuba dive to see them with your own eyes.

description.en: Barbados is an island nation in the Caribbean Sea near Saint Lucia and the independent State of Saint Vincent and the Grenadines. Bridgetown is the capital and the largest city. Barbados was a British colony and preserved traditions of those years — five o'clock tea, golf, cricket, and polo. It's not for nothing that the island is still called "Little England." You can't come to Barbados without tasting the local light rum and coconut "Malibu" liqueur. There's even a museum dedicated to the pirates' favorite drink. Like many Caribbean resorts, this island is famous for its tropical beaches with palm trees and white sand. The wildlife sanctuary is renowned for its collection of animals and plants. Here you can see unique green monkeys, red deer, caymans, turtles, raccoons, pelicans, etc. In Barbados, there are many colonial buildings, where there were plantations and shelters for pirates.

Belize is a mysterious country, hidden under the crowns of dense equatorial forests. The tiny state is located in Central America and until 1981 had lived under the British rule and was called British Honduras. Belize began to gain popularity in the last decade. First of all, due to ecological tourism. After all, national parks and reserves of Belize are home to unique species of fauna and flora. Combine it with the ruins of ancient Mayan settlements, divine white beaches, and the choice of destination for your next holiday will be obvious.

geography.en: Belize is situated between Mexico and Guatemala on the Yucatan Peninsula. The Caribbean Sea washes its rugged coastline. The north of Belize is predominantly flat, with many rivers and swamps. Hilly Maya mountains characterize the south, and the coastal area is dotted with countless islands and lagoons. According to the administrative division, Belize consists of six districts: Belize, Cayo, Corozal, Orange Walk, Stann Creek, and Toledo.

long_description.en:
Belmopan

Belmopan is probably the smallest and youngest capital on the planet. They have tried to make it an ideal main city of the state. It has many parks, clean streets, elegant buildings of the National Assembly and government agencies, Independence Monument, enlightening City Museum and Art Gallery. One can easily explore Belmopan in one day. But you won't have time for boredom, because there are many exciting places in the Belmopan neighborhood. For example, Guanacaste National Park, where the trees of the same name grow. They make canoes out of epiphytes, the yields of guanacaste. Or St. Herman's Blue Hole National Park, where the flow of the Sibun River goes into the underground caves in some places. One of them contains a unique karst lake, after which the whole park is named. The St. Hermann's Caves, a famous site for the sacrificial ceremonies of the ancient Mayan people, will not disappoint you either.

Belize City

Belize City is a picturesque city founded back in the XVIII century by English settlers. Let its name not surprise you because this town used to be the capital of the state. But tropical storms forced the authorities to move the capital inland, leaving Belize City as the largest port and economic center of the country. Tourists will not be bored here. The city is famous for its museums, the main of which (Museum of Belize) is located in the building of the former colonial prison of the middle of the XVIII century. There are also interesting expositions in the Maritime Museum, Coastal Zone Museum, National Handicraft Centre, and the Maya Center Mayan Museum. You can also visit the ruins of settlements of the ancient Mayan civilization, admire the picturesque lagoons, dive on the beach in Caye Caulker, which is surrounded by reef islands with many underwater caves and unusual corals, and enjoy the Great Blue Hole — a huge funnel in the middle of the ocean. If you are a desperate daredevil, try to dive in and see what mysteries this underwater hole hides. 

San Pedro

San Pedro is one of the major cities located on Ambergris Island. The main attraction of this area is the gorgeous beaches on which tourists from all over the world warm their bones. The town, tired of the sun, begins to live right after the sunset. San Pedro is one of the most hangout cities on the coast, a paradise for young people and lovers of dancing until morning. The main task after the disco is to have strength for other activities: diving to the Coral Gardens, where parrot fish and barracuda live, visiting the diving sites of Shark Ray Alley where you can swim with stingrays and nurse sharks and, of course, a trip to Hol Chan Marine Reserve in the south of the island. 

Punta Gorda

Punta Gorda is the southernmost city in Belize, located in the autonomous region of Toledo. Punta Gorda is of more value to locals rather than tourists, as it is a large agricultural center and an important customs point. The city is quite dull, and you can easily explore it in an hour and a half. But there is something to see in its surroundings: Port Honduras Marine Reserve, where you can see clumsy manatees and thousands of other sea creatures; Snake Cayes Reef, which represents the southern end of the Barrier Reef and attracts divers with its underwater scenery; the small Mayan city of Nim Li Punit, famous for its steles and royal graves with records of ancient people.

Placencia

Placencia is a small resort town in the county of Stann Creek, in the extreme south of the country. It is a truly heavenly place, a green oasis in the middle of the blue ocean. Placencia is chosen for its spectacular sandy beaches and enchanting date with nature. Be sure to visit the jaguars at the Cockscomb Basin Wildlife Sanctuary, the tiger sharks at Gladden Spit and Silk Cayes Marine Reserve, and dive by the Barrier Reef, the longest coral reef in the Western Hemisphere. And try to see fantastic manatees in the picturesque lagoons of Placencia at dawn and dusk every day. 

San Ignacio

San Ignacio is located in the west of the country and is the center of Cayo County. Those who prefer hiking and historical sightseeing should definitely come here. San Ignacio is sinking into the greenery of the rainforest of the Mountain Pine Ridge Forest Reserve. Here, you can enjoy murmuring mountain rivers and waterfalls, wandering cougars and tapirs, and learn the secrets of Barton Creek and Che Chem Ha Caves. When you have enough of exploring the forest trails, make sure you visit the ruins of Tipu, one of the last Mayan strongholds of resistance to Spanish conquerors.

description.en: Bermuda, the British Overseas Territory, is located in the Northwest Atlantic Ocean. It is 1046 km from its nearest neighbor's coast (USA). The country is situated on an archipelago of 7 large and about 130 small land areas (53.3 km²). Only 12 of them are inhabited. In the center is an island group — Main Island — united by a system of bridges. The capital of the overseas territory is Hamilton, and the town of St.George's is the most beautiful and ancient one. Picturesque reefs of Bermuda are an ideal place for diving and snorkeling. And the bays of Great Sound and Little Sound are just perfect for windsurfing and sailing. Beautiful beaches cover almost all of the coastline with the cleanest water. Two of them, Horseshoe Bay and Elbe Beach, attract tourists with the sand of a delicate pink shade.

Some Dutch island territories in the Caribbean Sea, such as Bonaire, Sint Eustatius, and Saba, have the status of special communities. They are often called the Caribbean Netherlands. All three islands are perfect for ecotourism, diving, snorkeling, sailing, and relaxing beach holidays. One-fifth of the largest of them, Bonaire, is occupied by the Washington-Slagbaai National Park. Here you'll find cacti-covered hills, mangroves, salt marshes, and lagoons where pink flamingos live. And the island's coastline is considered one of the best places to dive. Tiny Saba is the residence of the sleeping Mount Scenery volcano, where the slopes are covered with rainforests. Sint Eustatius' main tourist bait is the beautiful reefs and shipwrecks of the National Marine Park.

The British Virgin Islands is a volcanic archipelago located in the Caribbean Sea. Tourists choose this place for unforgettable adventures or a quiet family holiday. That's because everyone here will find entertainment to their liking. The Botanic Garden, with a huge collection of exotic plants, is located on the largest island of the archipelago, Tortola. The island of Anegada is famous for its coral Horseshoe Reef, which is about 30 km long. While diving, you can see not only the beauty of the underwater world but also the remains of ancient shipwrecks. The ancient Road Town, with its architectural monuments and old craft shops, is considered an important historical landmark of the state. In addition to all of these, the British Virgin Islands also offers magnificent beaches, untouched natural areas, and unique flavor.

The French Overseas Department — Guadeloupe — comprises several Caribbean islands. It has two larger islands, Basse-Terre and Grande-Terre, as well as a whole patchwork of smaller ones. Tourists here will find picturesque villages and towns with beautiful colonial architecture, green tropical forests, and a lot of entertainment. But the real treasure of Guadeloupe is its beaches. Plage de Malendure is a diving paradise. It is located within the capital city of Basse-Terre, near the XVII-century fort of Saint Charles. The nudists love the Plage de Cluny. Anse Accul, Capesterre, and Saint-Anne are ideal locations for a relaxing holiday in the shade of palm trees. A trip to the top of the active volcano La Grande Soufrière will give you a lot of impressions. And the various routes in Guadeloupe's National Park will introduce you to the beautiful nature.

The name of this country comes from the word "Cuauhtēmallān", which from Aztec means "the place of many trees". Guatemala is full of mysteries and ancient rituals of the legendary people who once created a mystical and amazing civilization in the middle of the humid jungles of Central America. Going to Guatemala, you can take part in the pagan festivals, dive into the life of Mayan descendants and watch the sinister rituals of harsh witchcraft shamans in bizarre costumes.

geography.en: The Republic of Guatemala is situated between two oceans, the Pacific and the Atlantic. The country is bordered by Mexico, Honduras, Belize, and El Salvador. More than half of its territory (about 54%) is covered by a tropical jungle with volcanoes rising among them. Only three of them are active — it is their activities, combined with the specific structure of the Pacific floor, that cause frequent earthquakes. The highest point in the country is the peak of the extinct volcano Tajumulco (4,211 m). Guatemala has quite a few lakes, the largest are Atitlán, Izabal, Amatitlán and Peten Itza.Guatemala is divided into 22 departments, which vary significantly in size and the density of its population. Petén, for example, occupies about one-third of the country but is very poorly populated. But a relatively small department of Guatemala is home to more than 20% of the country's total population. The main administrative units, in turn, are divided into municipalities.

long_description.en:
The name of the capital of Guatemala is the same as that of the country. It is the largest (more than one million people) city in Central America. The most visited attraction is Tikal National Park. On its territory, there are ruins of an ancient town and sanctuaries, built more than 2000 years ago. Here you can also see the famous pyramids, the purpose of which is still a mystery.

Quetzaltenango

Quetzaltenango (Xelajú) is the second-largest city in Guatemala. Tourists come here to visit the hot springs in its neighborhood and take a stroll to the nearby villages. There you can buy national costumes and even see how the local wool they are produced from is made. There is almost nothing exciting in the town itself, except for the beautiful park in the central part. From here, you can enjoy a magnificent view of the volcanoes that surround Quetzaltenango from all sides.

Antigua Guatemala

The city of Antigua Guatemala was the capital during the colonial period, and now it has become a huge museum. It has preserved many Spanish buildings and monuments in the Baroque style. If you like a leisurely holiday without noise and extremes, then this is the right place. There are many ancient buildings, cozy restaurants, and almost no crime in the city. It is also worth noting the beautiful climate of Antigua Guatemala — the eternal spring reigns here.

Monterrico

Monterrico (the Pacific coast) and Playa Blanca (the Caribbean Sea) are considered the most attractive beach resorts. Another one of the most beautiful beaches in the country is called Punta de Palma. It is located in the southern part of the Caribbean — in the city of Puerto Barrios. The beaches of Guatemala are not very well adapted for recreation — many of them do not even have sun loungers and basic facilities.

description.en: Honduras is called the most dangerous state in Central America. The criminal situation in the country often scares away tourists, but its unique nature is worth one day of coming here. Waterfalls and mountains, gardens and tropical forests are only a small part of all the beauties of Honduras. Here you can get a dose of adrenaline in the capital, eat bananas in a provincial town, or get some privacy on a quiet island.

geography.en: The Republic of Honduras occupies the northern part of the Central American isthmus. It borders Nicaragua to the south, Guatemala to the west and El Salvador to the south-west. The north and east of the country are surrounded by the Caribbean Sea, where the remote islands belonging to the state are located. The Pacific Ocean washes black sandy beaches in the south-west of the country. Almost the entire territory of the country is covered with mountains. The highest peak is the Sierra de las Minas (2870 m). There are plains with banana plantations along the coast. The tropical jungle of north-eastern Honduras is on the UNESCO World Heritage List.The Ulúa River is the longest in the country (358 km). Lake Yojoa is the largest lake.The territory of the country is divided into 18 departments and one central district. The latter includes Tegucigalpa, the capital of Honduras, and its suburb, Comayagüela.

long_description.en:
Tegucigalpa

Tegucigalpa is the administrative center of Honduras. It is located on the Choluteca River near the picturesque slopes of Mount El Picacho. Here you will find the world-famous and second-largest tropical Lancetilla Botanical Gardens — home to many exotic birds and plants. In addition to natural landscapes, the city stands out for its architectural features. It is home to the beautiful church of Iglesia de San Francisco, Plaza Morazan, and many pedestrian streets with cafes, restaurants, and shops. The city has one of the most unsafe airports in the world (the airstrip is very short and located near the mountains). There is a monument to la Paz built near the main stadium of the country, Estadio Nacional, to commemorate the end of the so-called "football war" (the armed conflict occurred after the loss of the team of Honduras to the team of Salvador in 1969 and had lasted only six days).

San Pedro Sula

San Pedro Sula is the industrial capital of the state, with a population of about one million people. Thanks to the increasing number of banana plantations and the construction of the railway, people from all over the country have come here in search of work. It has a beautiful administration building, the Museum of Anthropology, and St. Peter the Apostle Cathedral. 

La Ceiba

The city of La Ceiba is called the ecological and tourist capital of Honduras. Every year it hosts a festival in honor of Isidore the Farmer, which gathers hundreds of thousands of visitors from all over the world. While being in the city, you can also visit the famous butterfly museum in Colonia El Sauzal, visit the Pico Bonito National Park and admire the beauty of the Rio Maria and Los Chorros waterfalls. 

Puerto Cortes

Puerto Cortes is famous for its modern port on the Caribbean coast. It is considered to be one of the safest in the world. There is a small square in the city center with a monument to the fisherman and a market where you can taste the delicious local bryndza, corn cakes, or fried chestnuts.

Comayagua

Comayagua is nestled at an altitude of 1650 m above sea level and impresses its guests with panoramic views. This city has managed to preserve the best examples of colonial architecture. 

Roatan

Roatan Island attracts hundreds of thousands of tourists with its green hills and crystal clear water, which shows spectacular coral reefs. Diving enthusiasts can also see tropical fish, sea turtles, stingrays, moray, and whale sharks in spring. Most of the islanders live in poverty, mostly on $1 a day.

Guanaja

Guanaja is a quiet tropical island with numerous small waterfalls scattered throughout the island. Tourists are also interested in the colorful houses, mangrove swamps on the north coast and beaches of Bayman Bay and Savannah Bight on the east coast.

description.en: The Island State of Grenada is located in the West Indies, in the group of Lesser Antilles. The country attracts tourists not with the typical for the Caribbean parties, but with a measured pace of life and natural beauty. Here you will find luxurious beaches, secluded coves, waterfalls, beautiful coral reefs, and lush tropical forests. And the colorful houses above the water, giant palm trees, and white yachts will remind you that you are on vacation — and may the whole world wait! The main attractions in Grenada are related to the sea. Diving, snorkeling, fishing, and boat trips are popular here. Nearby is one of the most unusual attractions — the Underwater Sculpture Park. There are also golf clubs, restaurants, and national parks on the island where you can see exotic plants and animals. The most popular are the Grand Etang, Grenada Dove, Antoine, and Levera.

The beautiful volcanic island of Dominica is part of the Lesser Antilles. Its nature is literally mesmerizing with its beauty. Tropical forests surround Dominica, and there are geysers, hot springs, waterfalls, beaches with black and white sand. In the capital of the state — the city of Roseau —, you should definitely visit Old Market Plaza and walk through the ancient streets soaked with colonial spirit. For natural attractions, head to Cabrits National Park, where the country's largest swamp, beautiful coral reefs, and coastlines are located. And in Northern Forest Reserve, you'll find exotic birds and parrots of rare species. Dominica is among the top five diving destinations in the world. But in addition to exotic landscapes, the country offers bright carnivals, festivals, and an active nightlife.

The Dominican Republic is bright, characterful, and extraordinary. Since the XVI century, it had been attracting conquistadors from Europe, and today it attracts millions of tourists from all around the world. The Dominican Republic has stunning beaches, magnificent mountain scenery, lush forests, impressive colonial architecture. Here you can see humpback whales of Samana, exotic parrots, American crocodiles, go down 27 waterfalls of Puerto Plata, relax on the beaches of Playa Rincon. Thanks to the climate conditions, people harvest fruit in the Dominican Republic all year round. There are over forty species of mangoes, sweet papaya, and juicy passion fruit.

geography.en: The Dominican Republic is located in the Caribbean region. It is the largest country of Haiti islands, situated in the West Indies, and being a part of the Greater Antilles archipelago. The Dominican Republic is made up of many small islands. The largest of them include Saona, Catalina, Beata, and Cayo Levantado. The country neighbors upon the Republic of Haiti and Puerto Rico. The Atlantic Ocean washes it in the north and the Caribbean Sea in the south. The country consists of one national district — the capital Santo Domingo, 29 provinces, 50 municipal counties, and 110 municipalities.

long_description.en:
Annually, millions of tourists strive to visit this paradise, an island of happiness and exotic to enjoy the silence, magnificent beaches, and azure lagoons. Once you come to the Dominican Republic, you can feel the spirit of freedom, the joy of life that is manifested in everything: the music sounding from cafes and bars, the smiles of passers-by, and the unique atmosphere of each city. 

Santo Domingo

In the south of the country, you shall find the oldest city in the New World and the capital of the Dominican — Santo Domingo. It is the cultural and economic center of the country. The town was founded in 1496 by Bartholomew Columbus, the brother of the famous navigator Christopher Columbus. Here you can find the first fortress in the Western Hemisphere — the Ozama Fortress, the first Cathedral of Santa María la Menor, and the first hospital, which once had been the royal residence. Dam Street is the oldest street in the city where you can still see colonial buildings and mansions from the Columbus era. Small winding roads lead to the most spectacular attractions, tropical parks with bizarre butterflies and rare trees. 

Santiago

Santiago is the second-largest city, an industrial and agricultural center. Melodic and fiery merengue music was born in this city. The city spreads out on the banks of the Yaque Del Norte River. It is considered to be the noblest city in the Dominican Republic. Its full name sounds like Santiago de Los Caballeros, which means "city of knights". Santiago has many interesting historical sites: the Fort of Saint Louis, the former Town Hall, and Leisure Club, and the Santiago de Compostela Cathedral. A visit to the Moca Zoo, the Cibao Theatre, and the Folklore Museum will give you the most pleasant impressions. The Monumento a Los Héroes de la Restauración is the most significant attraction in the Dominican Republic. On Calle Del Sol Street, you will find colorful restaurants and cafes serving the dishes of the national cuisine. Spit-roasted pork is the most popular one. There are several worldwide known tobacco and cigar factories here, which include Juan Clemente Factory, Grupo León Jimenes, Tabacalera, and the Cigar Museum. The suburb of Santiago — Moca — is considered to be the capital of coffee production. The Samana Peninsula is located three hours away from Santiago. Gorgeous beaches on the Atlantic coast are a great place for romantic holidays or a trip with children. It offers such water amusements as diving, snorkeling, windsurfing, catamarans, and water skiing.

Jarabacoa

The resort of Jarabacoa is located next to Santiago, surrounded by forests and mountain rivers. In its neighborhoods, tourists can admire the whole complex of waterfalls, alluring its beauty. Moreover, the natural treasures of the José Armando Bermúdez National Park are spread near Jarabacoa. There is another equally famous reserve next to it, José del Carmen Ramírez National Park. In this natural tandem of two parks, you can find the highest peaks in the Dominican Republic: La Pelona, La Rucilla, and the record Pico Duarte (3098 m). Mountain climbers from all over the world come here to conquer it. Every year, thousands of eco-tourists, as well as extreme and exotic lovers, visit this resort for hiking and horseback riding.

Punta Cana

One of the most famous resorts — Punta Cana — is located in the east of the Dominican Republic. It also has the largest airport in the country. Here you will find amazing beaches with tiny white sand, azure waters of the Caribbean Sea, and the Atlantic Ocean, coconut palms. There are several parks in Punta Cana. Manati Park is one of the most popular here where you can see exotic animals. In this resort, there are many gorgeous hotels with spacious and comfortable bungalows. With the most beautiful coral reefs, this place is especially popular with divers.

Puerto Plata

Puerto Plata is another magnificent resort of the Dominican Republic. It is washed by the waters of the Atlantic Ocean in the north and the Caribbean Sea in the south. The Cable Car Puerto Plata goes above the resort. It offers a breathtaking view of the Atlantic Ocean coast. As you go up, you will see a smaller copy of the statue of Christ the Redeemer in Rio de Janeiro. A visit to the colonial fortress, walking along Victorian mansions, or a visit to the Amber Museum will not leave you indifferent. Puerto Plata has a vibrant nightlife. There are many clubs and bars where you can watch traditional dances. You can relax with your family in Ocean World Adventure Park. It is a large entertainment complex with a dolphinarium, many shops, cafes, and discos. 

Boca Chica

Boca Chica is the city where the Dominican elite have settled since the early twentieth century. It is 37 km from Santo Domingo. It is a respectable resort spread among lemon and orange groves, with pure velvet sand, a warm lagoon protected by a coral reef, and magnificent five-star hotels. The resort of Boca Chica has excellent facilities for windsurfing, diving, water skiing, scuba diving, fishing, sailing, and horseback riding.

La Romana is a charming town on the south coast of the Dominican Republic with its own airport. It is famous for its grand hotel complex Casa de Campo Resort & Villas with a huge spectacular area right on the Caribbean Sea coast and a lot of entertainment for everyone: SPA, fitness centers, a yacht club, water sports and riding centers, etc. The landmark of La Romana is an artificially created medieval town of artists and craftsmen with its own school of design. It will also be interesting to visit the Saint Stanislaus Church, the Archaeological Museum, and the amphitheater, where Frank Sinatra and Julio Iglesias performed.

Saona

Saona, or "Bounty Island", is located in the south of the Dominican Republic and is washed by the Caribbean Sea. Its rich flora has given it the status of a national reserve. Unique mangroves with trees going into the water, which protect small fish and birds from predators, create a unique spectacle. Saona is home to gulls, parrots, storks, exotic fish, rays, sea urchins, moray, and dolphins. On land, you can find iguanas and turtles. Local beaches are shallow enough; sometimes, the depth does not exceed one meter, which is very convenient for diving training. It is an excellent place for the whole family to relax and get acquainted with a fantastic animal world.

description.en: The Cayman Islands is a British overseas territory situated in the Caribbean Sea. Green paradise islands have gathered a huge collection of tropical plants and amazing natural areas, which will seem like an exotic fairy tale to tourists. Among the main local sights, there are indescribably beautiful beaches with pure azure water and snow-white sand. Also, the coasts here are ideal for diving. If you want to go deeper into the history of the Cayman Islands, head to the capital, George Town. In the city, you can see the ancient Fort George, constructed in 1790, check out the museums, visit the city's botanical garden, and appreciate the local architecture. While you're on the islands, be sure to take a trip to Turtle Farm, National Parrot Park, and Pirate Cave.

Costa Rica owes its name to Christopher Columbus himself, who, after he had seen the amount of gold jewelry on the local Indians, exclaimed "Costa Rica!" which means "rich shore". However, later on, his words were not confirmed, and no gold was found here. On the other hand, the Spaniards were quite successful in growing coffee, cocoa, and bananas. Today Costa Rica can be rightfully called the most tourist country in Latin America. And its virgin nature, with its stunning biodiversity, is considered to be the main attraction. Forests cover 2/3 of the country's territory, so ecotourism is the main focus of this industry in Costa Rica. About 30 percent of the country's area, which contains more than 70 reserves, is protected by the state. And, of course, coffee lovers from all over the world come here, as it is believed that Costa Rica has one of the best coffees in the world.

geography.en: Costa Rica is a small reserve country in Central America, situated in the narrowest part of the neck of the land that connects two continents. It borders upon Nicaragua to the north and Panama to the south-east. The Caribbean Sea and the Pacific Ocean wash its shores. The total length of the coastline is almost 1,300 km. The country is famous for its vast diversity of landscapes. A mountain range stretches practically all over the country from north to south. Between the mountains, there is a huge Central plateau with fertile soils and a variety of flora and fauna. Costa Rica is also full of volcanoes, and some of them active. The country also includes several uninhabited islands, the largest of which is Cocos, known worldwide as "Treasure Island". However, more than 300 treasure hunting expeditions could not find a single coin. The real treasure, in fact, is its nature. It is so diverse and unique that the state has made this territory protected. It is possible to visit the island only with a special permit. Recently, its clean and calm waters have attracted more and more diving enthusiasts from all over the world.Costa Rica is divided into seven provinces, which, in turn, consist of the cantons. There are 81 of them in general.

long_description.en:
San Jose

San Jose is the capital of Costa Rica and, at the same time, its largest city. It is located in the heart of the country, where almost all tourist routes start. In San Jose, ancient buildings quite organically adjoin modern constructions made of glass and concrete, creating its own unique style. Both in the city itself and its surroundings, there are many exciting things for visitors: the majestic Cathedral, Parque Nacional Simón Bolívar, the museums of gold, jade, and even the university museum of exotic insects. Small markets and streets are filled with a unique atmosphere, and in the surrounding neighborhoods of the city, tourists can find coffee plantations, butterfly farms, and even volcanoes. Annually, on December 15 (or preferably on Saturday, closer to December 15), San Jose hosts an evening carnival — the "Festival of Light".

Cartago

Cartago is a city that managed to save its history. It's also called "the city of thick fogs". Once it was the capital and even until now, it is here that you can see the most beautiful ancient buildings and ruins of the colonial era. This city was often affected by earthquakes, which actually destroyed most of the unique constructions. But one of them — the Basilica of Our Lady of Angels — survived and is still considered to be the country's main shrine. It is here, where pilgrims from all over the world come to worship the statue of the Black Madonna, which is believed to be the patron saint of Costa Rica. Picturesque mountains surround Cartago, and 30 kilometers from the city, you shall find an active volcano called Irazu.

Alajuela

Alajuela is the third-largest and one of the most beautiful cities in Costa Rica, that has retained its traditional colonial style. In addition to its stunning architecture, the Poás Volcano, with its two craters, is a significant attraction in Alajuela. The smaller one has a tiny lake with cool water. Tourists can walk up to the very mouth of the volcano and even smell the sulfur coming from its depths.

Heredia

Heredia is the coffee capital of Costa Rica. Coffee plantations are literally all over the region. The precious bean for the fragrant drink is the number one reason why a tourist should come here. Special tours to the plantations allow you to get acquainted with the full process of producing the most popular drink in the world — from growing coffee trees and harvesting beans to preparing the coffee itself and its tasting. And the ancient fort is the leading local architectural attraction. 

Puntarenas

Puntarenas is the main sea gate of Costa Rica and a paradise for ecotourists. This is where the country's main seaport is located, from where coffee is sent all over the world. Magnificent beaches and lush forest thickets, mangroves where crocodiles swim peacefully, herons, and other exotic birds — all this natural diversity can be seen in one place. A boat ride around Puntarenas will give you am unforgettable impressions.

Liberia

Liberia or a "white city" as it is called by Costa Ricans, owing to the abundance of white buildings in colonial style. The Spanish culture and traditions such as siesta are presented here like in no other cities in the country. The majestic Cathedral of the Immaculate Conception is one of the city's main attractions. Liberia is also a starting point for exploring Costa Rica's protected wildlife sanctuaries, mainly the Rincon de la Vieja National Park, with its fabulous waterfalls and picturesque volcanoes.

Puerto Limón

Puerto Limón is a port city on the east coast. The majority of the population comes from Jamaica, whose ancestors once built a railway to the port to simplify coffee exports to Europe.
