Therefore, the city bears the imprint of African-Caribbean culture, which is not typical of Costa Rica. Puerto Lemon offers the most convenient access to the Parque Nacional Tortuguero, and its main wonder is the giant leatherback turtles. Cahuita National Park, with its unique beaches, attracts surfers from all over the world. Also, Limón, as the Costa Ricans themselves call it, offers tourists the most beautiful coral reefs. However, it's strictly forbidden to take raw corals out of the country.

Quesada

Quesada is one of the major cities in the north of the country. It is also a fascinating destination for ecotourists. Here you can watch the bird world in Juan Castro Blanco National Park. Arenal Volcano is located within a one-hour drive from the city. Every April, there is an agricultural exhibition accompanied by a carnival and a horse parade.

description.en: Curaçao is a paradise island in the Caribbean Sea. It attracts with its colonial architecture, perfect climate, exotic nature, and stunning beaches. This picturesque corner is designed for a lazy, leisurely holiday on the coast, mixed with scuba diving and exploring the surrounding area. Curaçao is a location that looks like it's come off a postcard. When you get here, it is hard to believe that the water can really be so blue and the sand — snow-white.

Martinique is the French overseas department. It is located in the Caribbean Sea of the Atlantic Ocean and is part of the Lesser Antilles. There are many beautiful resorts with magnificent beaches, picturesque nature, and an active volcano. More than half a million tourists come to Martinique every year. Not only beach vacation attracts travelers here, but also numerous sights. It is definitely worth visiting the Museum of Rum with a tasting of an excellent drink, the miniature town square of white sandstone in the town of Sainte-Anne, listen to the organ in the St. Louis Cathedral. The charming capital of Martinique — Fort-de-France is called the "Little Paris", for the French charm and similarity of the cities. An interesting historical fact is that the first wife of Napoleon Bonaparte, Joséphine de Beauharnais, was born here.

Montserrat is the British Overseas Territory. It is situated on an island of the same name in the Caribbean Sea, in the Lesser Antilles group. Few tourists come here to watch migratory birds (this is their wintering place), enjoy the pristine flora and fauna, and see the consequences of the Soufrière Hills volcano's eruption occurred in 1995. Ashes and lava destroyed Montserrat's capital, Plymouth. Luxury villas on its outskirts miraculously survived. People were leaving their homes in a hurry, leaving things behind and saving lives. Decades later, everything has remained in place, but only now nature dominates the area, invading the abandoned land. The southern part of the island, where the disaster occurred, is closed to the public. It's dangerous as the volcano is still active. The curious intruders are found and fined.

Do you know where the most beautiful nature in Central America is? Those who go to Nicaragua know. There are breathtaking views — wooded mountains, rapid waterfalls, volcanoes, dense jungle, and captivating ocean coast. But that's not all! Nicaragua is a cheap country for tourists, where you can taste unusual cuisine, visit bright festivals, and get acquainted with the traditional culture of the colonial society.

geography.en: The Republic of Nicaragua is the largest country in Central America. It is washed by the Pacific Ocean in the west and the Caribbean Sea in the east. The country's northern neighbor is Honduras, and Costa Rica is its neighbor to the south. The Nicaragua highlands occupy most of the territory. To the east, off the Caribbean coast, the landscape is characterized by lowlands, jungles, and mangroves. In the south, along the land border, there are also lowlands, while in the west, there is a volcanic zone, which is the most populated because of the fertile soils and drier climate. Nicaragua has been a unitary republic since 1986. It is divided into 15 departments and two autonomous regions.

long_description.en:
Managua

Managua is the capital of the country, which, in fact, has few tourist attractions. First of all, it is the Old and New Cathedral, the Parliament Building, the National Palace, and the Ruben Dario National Theatre. Walk around Tiscapa Lagoon Natural Reserve, visit the National Arboretum and the Salvador Allende Port. The Juan Paul II Museum opened here a few years ago. The city's marketplace offers bargaining and shopping for fresh products, metal, and wooden handicrafts and jewelry. But it is better to go shopping in the Plaza Inter mall. The active Masaya Volcano (in the National Park of the same name) is 20 km southeast of Managua. It hasn't erupted in a long time, but there are regular volcanic gas emissions. The crater looks impressive, and the view from the observation deck is beautiful. We recommend you visit this amazing creation of nature. 

Granada

Granada is considered the most touristic city in the country. Unlike the capital, the buildings here have a more "European look", and the prices here are higher. The town has a fresh lake, where you can swim by boat, but you should not swim in the water yourself as it is not very clean. Here you can order a tour at the local agency, but it is easier to see everything yourself. The main sights of Granada are Iglesia La Merced Church, from whose tower you can see the whole city, the Museum of Chocolate, Park Central de Granada.

Leon

Leon is the former capital and second-largest city in Nicaragua, and it has many ancient churches and Spanish mansions. In the central square is the León Cathedral (UNESCO has protected it since 2011). Visit the Museum of the Revolution and the University. On the west side of the city is the old El fortune Fort, which had served as a prison for a long time. Graffiti and mural lovers will appreciate the art of local artists who depicted the Civil War era on the city walls, in paints. Leon is in one of the hottest regions in the country, and beautiful beaches are only half an hour away. Like any city in Nicaragua, there are beautiful temples here: the Nuestra Señora de Guadalupe and the Church of Xalteva. We recommend visiting the Chocolate Museum, the cultural center of the Monastery of St. Francis, the Maria Romero House Museum and the railway station (previously the railway was the main transport of the country). Ten kilometers from the city, there is a Mombacho volcano, but you will have to climb to a height of 1200 meters on foot or by truck. It's cold upstairs, but the view is worth it!

Estelí

Estelí is significantly different from other cities in the country. It is in the north of the country, 150 kilometers from Managua, about 2-3 hours by bus. You can also get here from Leon. The climate here is colder than the rest of the country, and the locals are more like Europeans by the color of skin and hair. Prices for accommodation are higher than in other cities, so it makes sense to look for it in advance. We recommend excursions to the Tisey Estanzuela Natural Reserve and the tobacco factory. The first one offers the waterfall of Estanzuela and La Garnacha farm, where cheese is made. In the factory, you can see the whole procedure of tobacco processing and cigar making. There are several museums worthy of your attention in the city: Heroes and Martyrs of May 18th Museum and the Museum of History and Archaeology. They are small, so you will definitely have time to see the Cathedral of Our Lady and walk in Central Park. A few tens of kilometers from the city, there are the Miraflor, Tepesomoto-Pataste Natural Reserves, and the Ecological Park of Cantagallo. The best way to get to them is by car.

In general, all cities in Nicaragua are built up to 3 floors due to seismic activity. The population is religious, mainly Catholic, and each town has at least two cathedrals.

description.en: Turks and Caicos is a common name for 40 islands located in the Atlantic, southeast of the Bahamas. Their territory is under British administration, although it is not part of it. Providenciales is considered to be a tourist center, and fans of the secluded and quiet holiday can stay at any of the neighboring islands-resorts. They are uninhabited, but there are beaches, hotels, and rental properties to choose from. There are no interesting monuments or attractions on Turks and Caicos. People come here for beach holidays, surfing, and unforgettable dives near the largest coral reef in the Caribbean Basin. There are many predatory and poisonous creatures in the waters, but swimming on the beaches is absolutely safe — all of them are located in areas safely closed by reefs.

The Republic of Panama is a Central American state situated on the isthmus of the same name. Being at the confluence of two continents, the country has gained fame and prosperity thanks to an artificially created channel — the shortest route between the Pacific and Atlantic Oceans. Hundreds of glass skyscrapers with offices of international banks, offshore companies, hotels, and restaurants have grown next to tropical forests, the highest volcanoes, and quiet provinces. Panama really surprises with its contrasts, mesmerizes with its beauty, and beckons with the aroma of coffee.

geography.en: Panama is located on the isthmus of the same name in Central America. It is washed by the Caribbean Sea and the Pacific Ocean and borders with Costa Rica and Colombia. The Cordillera de Talamanca mountain range in the west and the hills in the central part of the country that form the continental watershed are among the mountain systems. The highest point is the Volcán Barú(3 475 m). Hundreds of rivers permeate the territory of Panama. The most important of them is the Chagres River, which is the primary source of hydroelectric energy. A dam blocks its central part — as a result, the largest artificial Gatun Lake was formed. The world-famous Panama Canal is the shortest route connecting the Pacific and Atlantic Oceans. One of the longest rivers is the Tuira River (230 km). It flows into San Miguel Bay and is another major artery for cargo ships. There is an impassable jungle between Panama and Colombia, which forms the Darién Gap. There are Colombian partisans and drug dealers based in this area, which undermine the country's reputation.Panama is divided into ten provinces and three autonomous regions.

long_description.en:
Panama City

Panama City is the capital of the Republic and a city of over one million, surrounded by rainforests. This huge metropolis can boast of architecture to suit every taste and color — from colonial buildings to modern skyscrapers. The Panama Canal is the most important attraction not only for the city but for the whole country. It is the primary source of income for the state. Every day, 48 ships pass through it — from private yachts to huge tankers. In the area of Casco Viejo, there is the Castle of Las Bovedas, which in its history, has managed to be both a protective wall against conquerors and a military prison with torture rooms. Chagres and Fort San Lorenzo are located not far from the city, where you can feel like a real pirate of the Caribbean Sea.

Colón

Colón is the second-largest city in the country and home to the main port of the entire Caribbean coast. Among the main attractions are the Episcopal Church, the statues of Jesus Christ, and Christopher Columbus, the discoverer of America. It is home to the world's largest (after Hong Kong) duty-free trade zone. 

David

David is the third-largest city in Panama and the capital of Chiriqui Province. It is a major commercial center of the country and is not famous for many attractions. It is worth visiting the Jose Obaldia Museum of History and Art when you come here. 

Bocas del Toro

Bocas del Toro is the center of the Archipelago of the same name and the province of Panama. This paradisiacal town with snow-white beaches and a lot of restaurants, hotels and entertainment centers attracts thousands of tourists in search of a better holiday. 

Boquete

Boquete is a mountain town popular among emigrants, located near the border with Costa Rica. It is the "flower capital of Panama", nestled on the slopes of the highest Volcán Barú, where some of the best coffee plantations in the world are concentrated. The warm and mild climate has made the city a place of "eternal spring". In the surrounding mountains and forests, beautiful flowers bloom all year round: orchids, lilies, roses, sunflowers, hibiscus, carnations. Boquete is often called "the main place to retire" because there are special benefit programs for elderly people and warm weather all year round. 

El Valle de Anton

El Valle de Anton is nestled on the crater of a huge extinct volcano and surrounded by green forests. The city is famous for its waterfalls, natural pools, ecological hiking trails, and horseback riding tours. Here lives the endangered species of amphibians - the Panamanian golden frog (rana dorada), and you can see the national flower of the "Holy Spirit" — a peristeria elata orchid.

Chitre

Chitre is a large city occupying the Asuero Peninsula in the south of the country. In recent years, it has been actively developing the tourist business, opening shopping centers and restaurants, casinos, and parks. 

Portobello

The small fishing town of Portobello attracts travelers and diving enthusiasts with its underwater coral reefs, ancient Spanish forts, picturesque local houses, and stunning nature. 

Taboga

Taboga Island is located near the coast of the capital. It is often called the "Island of Flowers". The main highlight of Taboga is a diverse bouquet of flowering plants and incredibly beautiful beaches with golden sand. It is perfect for lovers of quiet and secluded rest.

description.en: Puerto Rico is the oversea territory of the United States. The official name is the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico. The citizens of the country have U.S. citizenship. However, some rights of the Americans are not available for them. This island state used to be just a plantation. Nowadays, it is the Caribbean paradise for tourists and fans of resort vacations.

long_description.en:
On average, people divide Puerto Rico into five tourist regions — northern, central, southern, eastern, and western. 

San Juan

You will most definitely visit the northern region as its central city is the capital of San Juan. You can arrive at this place in a line boat as it is one of the largest cruise ports in the world. You may also fly to Luis Muñoz Marín International Airport. Other airports provide civil flight connections between the islands. In San Jose, tourists admire the ancient architecture (Old San Juan) where they attend old castles and forts: Castillo San Felipe del Morro, San Cristóbal, El Morro, Santa Catalina's Palace, Monastery Convento de Los Dominicos. Just like any other capital, San Juan is the cultural center with a diversity of museums and art galleries. You can also explore the Luis Muñoz Rivera Park with the XVIII-century Armoury Chamber and Pavilion of Peace that has many displays. Enjoy a ride in a cable railway in Parque Luis Muñoz Marín and admire impressive views. And don't forget to get a tour of Bacardi Rum Factory. If you are looking for something extraordinary, go to the cock-fighting club and check out the traditional local entertainment. However, keep in mind that this is quite a violent spectacle that is done for the sake of bets.

Carolina

The municipality of Carolina is located in the northeastern region. Here you can relax in luxurious hotels or head to the private Hacienda Campo Rico Rancho. It offers a chance to feed exotic animals, go horse riding, do archery, and head to a trip to jungles in special quadricycles. 

El Yunque National Forest

The eastern region is renowned for El Yunque National Forest that is situated 40 km southeast from San Juan. The local citizens frequently call it the main attraction. Here you can enjoy a walk around tropical jungles, get to the Yokahú Observation Tower, swim in the waterfall, taste water from the mountain stream, or drink some coconut milk. 

Fajardo

A large city-port Fajardo is also located in the east. It treats its guests to beautiful beaches where they can admire stunning sunsets every evening. The local cuisine is renowned for its freshly-cooked and delicious seafood. Take a special tram to take a tour of the beautiful mangrove of Las Cabezas de San Juan Nature Reserve and the historic Cape San Juan Light. Besides the architecture of the old town, Fajardo is famous for its proximity to one of the five bioluminescent bays of Puerto Rico. To see the neon, illuminated by plankton bay, you can take a tour in a kayak and admire this incredible spectacle in Laguna Grande. A similar place is nearby the island of Vieques, where the plankton is considered to be the brightest. This island also has marvelous beaches that are not so famous due to its remoteness. Besides, it has beaches for swimming, snorkeling, and surfing. By the way, in Fajardo, you can find a ship to get to Vieques and Culebra. You can also reach the latter by place as there is a small airport there. Dewey is the principal city in Culebra. The island itself is small and attractive to travelers who can't wait to lay on snow-white beaches (Flamenco Beach and other), admire the reefs, and dive.

Ponce

Ponce is a central city for a visit in the south part of Puerto Rico. It had been the capital till 1898. It can be deservedly called the center of historical and cultural monuments. In this matter, it can even compete with the current capital. When you wander around Ponce, you will literally breathe in the spirit of the epoch as the ancient cathedrals (the majority of citizens of Puerto Rico are Catholics) neighbor on buildings in the Colonial style and fountains. The Tibes Indigenous Ceremonial Center recreates the village of the Arawak tribe — the first settlers of the city. In various museums, you can get acquainted with the history, culture, and music of Puerto Rico. The themed Parque de Bombas stands out significantly on the background of other attractions. This museum is devoted to the history of fire fighting on the island dozens of years ago. You can leave for a small Gilligan's Island from Ponce. Lovers of diving will appreciate the coral reefs and exotic fish in the neighboring waters. 

Parque Nacional de las Cavernas del Río Camuy

Not far from Ponce, you shall find one of the largest complexes of karstic caves in the world — the Parque Nacional de las Cavernas del Río Camuy. Once, the Indian tribes used to hide in this cave system. Nowadays, tourists admire the stalactites, stalagmites, and ornaments made of calcareous rocks. Here you can use ropes and go down into the famous Cathedral Cave where the Taino Indians' petroglyphs were found. And the local underground river called Camuy is one of the largest in the world. 

Mayagüez

Though every beach in Puerto Rico is lovely, the west coast offers the best of them. The best beaches for water sports and diving can be found nearby Mayagüez. The city has the only zoo in Puerto Rico that has animals from North America and the Caribbean Sea Basin. The main attractions include the oldest Catholic church called Porta Coeli, which was built in 1609, Cabo Rojo, and Punta Higuera Lighthouses. By the way, you can take splendid landscape photographs from the lighthouses, especially at sunset. Mayagüez is one of the largest seaports in Puerto Rico. That's why there is no problem taking a motorboat tour or even visit another city from its harbor if you don't mind traveling by water.

The Arecibo Observatory is the attractions that made Puerto Rico famous in terms of scientific-researches. It has one of the largest radio telescopes in the world (304 meters in diameter). The observatory is located almost 500 meters up in the mountains, fifteen kilometers away from the town of Arecibo in the northwest of the island. Here you can admire the views and learn more about how humanity is trying to explore space with the help of an enormous aluminum "plate".

description.en: El Salvador is the official name of the state, which means "savior" in Spanish. Perhaps, the very name of the republic kept it from natural disasters? After all, numerous earthquakes failed to destroy the cultural monuments of the country. Despite the small territory, almost every traveler will find a lot of exciting things for himself in El Salvador. Someone will be impressed by the timeless beauty of the abundance of colonial buildings in the cities of El Salvador, and someone will be pleased with clean beaches, plenty of sunshine, high-class hotels and villas on the coast. Lovers of ancient cultures will be interested in the ruins of Mayan cities, and fans of active water recreation will find excellent conditions for surfing or diving. There are amazing places for both extreme tourism and the quiet enjoyment of nature.

geography.en: The Republic of El Salvador is the smallest state in Central America but has the highest population density in the region. It is located on the Pacific coast and is the only Central American country that does not have access to the Caribbean Sea. El Salvador borders Guatemala and Honduras and is separated from Nicaragua by the Gulf of Fonseca. The majority of the country is situated on a volcanic highland with mountain lakes with several extinct and active volcanoes rising above. For this reason, El Salvador is also called the "country of lakes and volcanoes". Rainforests have been preserved on the Pacific coast, but they were cut down for coffee plantations in the central part of the country.The country is divided into 14 departments. More than a quarter of its population lives in one of them, the Capital City.

long_description.en:
San Salvador

San Salvador, the country's capital, is the main city in all aspects. The town is located near the volcano of the same name, and it has often suffered from earthquakes in its history. However, in recent years, the capital is building only earthquake-proof buildings, and constructions of the medieval era have mostly survived, despite the violent temper of the volcano. San Salvador has preserved quite a few examples of colonial architecture; at the same time, there are many modern high-rise buildings. There are undoubtedly many churches in the Catholic city, and some of them are very original despite the antiquity. The most unusual church in the town, El Rosario, does not look like a religious institution at all. There are plenty of restaurants and nightclubs to see and enjoy in San Salvador.

There are also a lot of exciting things in the suburbs of the capital. There are the ruins of Cihuatán, a Mayan city founded in the X century, 39 kilometers from San Salvador. The ancient settlement of Hoya de Ceren, which is called the American Pompeii, is 25 km away. In the year 600, a large Mayan village was buried under a layer of ash, just like an ancient Roman city.

Santa Ana

Santa Ana is the second-largest and most important city in El Salvador. The first settlement here was founded before the Spanish, and it was called Sihuatehuacán (Place of the Priestesses). The city is located in a very picturesque area, in the Chiautehuacan Valley, which is surrounded by three volcanoes. Santa Ana has always attracted wealthy Salvadorans who have been living here for a long time and built luxury villas. The most prosperous quarters of the city are located on the shores of the charming Lake Coatepeque.

The magnificent Gothic Cathedral of Santa Ana is a fascinating building of the local theatre, in the appearance of which one can guess the features of classicism and neo-Gothic. And the exquisite construction of the local municipality has a patio turned into a small botanical garden. The city has many restaurants and cafes where guests can taste the masterpieces of local cuisine. There are plenty of shops, street markets and places for entertainment.

However, the human-made beauty of the city cannot surpass the majesty of the surrounding natural landscape. Three volcanoes (Santa Ana, Izalco, and Cerro Verde) rise above the plain like the teeth of a giant crown. The Cerro Verde crater, located 14 km from Santa Ana, is a National Nature Reserve.

Suchitoto

The small town of Suchitoto is located on the shore of Lake Lago de Suchitlan. Despite its modest size, it is considered to be the most beautiful city in the country. The city amazes with the abundance of pretty colonial buildings, tidiness, accuracy, and provincial calmness. And what about the magnificent landscapes around! By the way, from the language of the Nahua people, Suchitoto is translated as the "city of flowers and birds". This romantic name fits it perfectly. As a cultural site, it is included in the UNESCO World Heritage List. The ruins of Ciudad Vieja, the country's first capital, are located eight kilometers from Suchitoto.

San Miguel

San Miguel will inevitably attract those in search of entertainment. This bustling and fun city is one of El Salvador's major commercial centers. The town has both large shops and very attractive markets where you can buy interesting souvenirs. The main street of the city, Roosevelt Avenue, splits it into two parts — old and modern. The ancient town impresses everyone with its colonial architecture, while the new town consists of more modern buildings. Roosevelt Avenue itself is the apotheosis of the entertainment industry, with numerous restaurants, discos, cafes, and nightclubs along the way. The Nuestra Señora de la Paz, which begins in November and lasts almost two months, bring the most fame and popularity to the city. It is one of the main cultural events, not only in El Salvador but in Central America as a whole

Costa del Sol

El Salvador will please the beach lovers with numerous resorts located on the Pacific coast. Costa del Sol is probably the most popular beach in El Salvador. It gives tourists a wonderful combination of pure sand and mangroves. There is a well-developed infrastructure. There are plenty of chic and quite budget hotels, cozy villas, restaurants, and cafes in the coastal zone. As Costa del Sol often hosts many international congresses and seminars, the resort has high-class amenities. Among other things, this area allows you to tour the mangrove canals, and discover the fantastic world of tropical nature

Ilopango

The small town of Ilopango, located near the capital of the country, will not surprise tourists with its ancient architecture. It simply does not have any. But the city is located on the shore of a huge crater Lake Ilopango and is one of the leading resorts of El Salvador. People come here just to lie on the beach, and for diving, riding a yacht, kayak, or scooter. And the landscapes around Lake Ilopango are simply mind-blowing!

description.en: Cozy and luxurious Saint Barthélemy is among the Antilles and is an overseas community of France. Many consider it one of the most beautiful in the Caribbean Sea, and it is difficult to disagree with them. It seems that nature has awarded the island everything it needs for a perfect holiday away from the hustle and bustle. Here you can sunbathe on chic beaches, get acquainted with the peculiarities of local culture, and get secluded with exotic nature. Saint Barthélemy is known as a fashionable resort, so celebrities often come here for a vacation. Also, the island has a well-developed infrastructure. There are many elite hotels, restaurants, clubs, and boutiques. You should explore Gustavia's architecture, conquer the peak of Morne de Vitet, try the delicacy made from the sea urchin, swim with turtles, and listen to the sounds of the tropics to have bright impressions.

French Saint-Martin and its neighbor Sint Maarten, owned by the Netherlands, have been coexisting peacefully on one small piece of land for over 350 years. And the border between the territories of two different countries is simply marked by flags. That is why the island of Saint-Martin in the Caribbean Sea is called the "friendliest". Its northern part, the French overseas community of Saint-Martin, is an extraordinary place. For example, it is the gastronomic capital of the Caribbean Islands, where there are about 30 fine restaurants. But this is not the community's main city (as expected), but a small seaside village. The variety of Saint-Martin's beaches is astonishing and pleasing. It has chic, fashionable white sand resorts, rugged rocky coastlines, coral reefs, and wild deserted islands. That's why everyone will find a place to relax here.

The islands of Saint Pierre and Miquelon are an overseas community of France and are located in the Atlantic Ocean, near the Canadian province of Newfoundland and Labrador. There is no heat, bright sun, and cozy beaches. It only offers the eternally gloomy weather, cool winds, and high humidity. But for fans of outdoor activities and extreme sports, Saint-Pierre and Miquelon are the best. The rugged hillsides and cliffs of the rocky coastline, with the waves raging below, offer unlimited opportunities for conquering new summits. Even the sanatoriums here are specific — the main focus is on cold training, the ability to take strength from the air, water, and land, merging with wildlife. Cities of the islands are very similar to Norway — colored, like toys, they stand out sharply against the background of lead-gray waves of the ocean.

All the islands of Saint Vincent and the Grenadines are so different from something familiar and everyday-grey that a holiday on any of them is like a separate short life. The man's influence on their natural beauty is very smart and dosed. Enough so that the stay here was comfortable and pleasant. But at the same time, there is still a feeling of disconnection from civilization. Maybe that's why these beautiful places have more than once become a location for shooting Hollywood movies and a reality show "Survivor".

The Federation of Saint Christopher and Nevis belongs to the Lesser Antilles and is located in the eastern part of the Caribbean Sea. There are plenty of opportunities for recreation here. It offers excellent beaches with golden, white, and even black sand, gentle azure Caribbean water, yachting, and excellent surfing conditions. Fans of swimming can scuba dive, watch sea creatures while rocking with a mask and snorkel on the waves or go on exciting underwater fishing. And on remote wild beaches, you can easily meet little turtles and swim with dolphins. The cities of St. Kitts and Nevis are no less interesting. There are fascinating museums and ancient monuments, and the streets are decorated with buildings of XVIII-XIX centuries in the Georgian style.

Saint Lucia is a picturesque green island that claims to be the most beautiful in the Caribbean Sea. This amazing part of the world attracts travelers from everywhere with its pristine beauty and the opportunity to be completely united with nature. After all, it has everything you need — extraordinary landscapes, jungle, waterfalls, fruit plantations, medicinal mineral springs, and excellent beaches. On the territory of the country, there are several national reserves, where endemic animals live. During the trip, a tourist will be able to explore a new exotic world, get acquainted with local customs, learn to fish, discover the secrets of the underwater world, and just drink a glass of good rum. Saint Lucia is a great place for family or romantic holidays, which guarantees a lot of new experiences.

geography.en: Saint Lucia is situated on the island of the same name within the Lesser Antilles archipelago. It borders on the island of Martinique to the north (along the Saint Lucia Channel) and Saint Vincent to the south (along the strait of the same name). The Atlantic Ocean washes it in the east and the Caribbean Sea in the west (the total coastline length is 158 km). The area of the country is 617 square kilometers. Saint Lucia is of volcanic origin and is, therefore, more mountainous than the majority of other islands in the Caribbean Sea. In the south-west, there is the Pitons volcanic range, which includes the volcanoes of Gros Piton and Petit Piton. The highest point of the island is Mount Gimie (950 meters).There are traces of volcano activity on the territory of Saint Lucia — hot springs, lava fields, and sulfur deposits. The slopes of the volcanic massif are covered with tropical forests. The coastline is indented with numerous lagoons, bays, and harbors. There are small but gorgeous coral reefs along the coast.Saint Lucia is divided into 11 regions (parishes). Each has its own local government — city and village councils.

long_description.en:
Castries

Castries is the capital of Saint Lucia and is located in a natural harbor. The resort's trademark is its gorgeous beaches. Vigie Beach is the most favorite among locals and tourists. Here you can enjoy the best views, swim in the warm azure waves, put your feet in the snow-white sand, and watch the passing ships. After sunbathing, take a walk along the hospitable Castries. Among the architectural monuments, here you can see Fort Charlotte, constructed in the XVIII century, the Cathedral Basilica of the Immaculate Conception — the largest in the Caribbean — and visit the Le Pavillon Royal Museum. Another unique place is Pigeon Island National Park. It has become home to many exotic plants, animals, and birds, including the famous grey parrot.

Gros Islet

Gros Islet is a quiet, picturesque town with simple wooden houses and small shops where you can always buy a bottle of rum. Its shores are covered with many colorful boats with smiling fishers. The main attraction of Gros Islet is the St. Joseph the Worker Church (XIX century), which rises on the outskirts of the city. There is also an authentic local market where you can buy something as a souvenir. Pink coral reefs can be spotted off the coast of the island and are best seen while diving. And most importantly, the beaches, beaches, and beaches again! One of the most beautiful is Reduit Beach. Its wide strip offers wonderful views of Pigeon Island and the green coastal hills.

Soufrière

Soufrière is the oldest and incredibly picturesque town in Saint Lucia. It spreads out in a beautiful deep bay by the extinct Petit Piton. Its landscapes have made Soufrière famous in the film industry. It was here that the scenes of "Superman 2", "Water", and "White Scream" were shot. It's impossible not to fall in love with the contrasts of this place. Bright houses, standing against the background of green hills, create an atmosphere of a fairytale. You can walk around the city in an hour and a half. During the stroll, you can explore the architecture and visit a cozy local cafe. Next to the town's seafront, there is a small handicraft center where you can buy handmade souvenirs by local craftsmen. Soufrière is a great place to get to know the island's life and enjoy its natural beauty.

Vieux Fort

The bustling city of Vieux Fort is a harmonious blend of ancient wooden buildings, modern architecture, and natural attractions. The second international airport of the country, Hewanorra International Airport, is located here and as well as St. Lucia's largest fishing fleet. The seaside highway of Vieux Fora is packed with restaurants, shops, and bars, where the nightlife is bustling. Major attractions include the Maria Islands Nature Reserve, Coconut Bay, and Des Sables Beach on Des Sables Point and the Cape Moule a Chique Lighthouse on top of a 250m hill (near the city). And if you want to conquer the wave, welcome to Mistral Club. It's the best place on the island for windsurfing. The Mankote Mangrove protected forest strip is another fantastic natural attraction in the surrounding area.

Dennery

Dennery is the fishing center of the island and a great place for ecological tourism. The city itself will not surprise the traveler with a large number of attractions and developed infrastructure. Still, it will allow you to dive into the local flavor, go fishing in a canoe, and enjoy the exotic. Another advantage of the city is that it serves as a starting point for visiting the most picturesque places on the east coast. For example, from here you can go on a tour of the old plantations of the region, learn about traditional ways of growing and processing cocoa, fruits, and other fruit crops. The wide Grand Anse Beach is 10 km north of Dennery, where the endangered species of sea turtles lay their eggs. In the near future, there are plans to create a nature reserve here.

description.en: Sint Maarten is a self-governing public entity within the Kingdom of the Netherlands. It occupies the southern part of the island of Saint Martin in the Caribbean Sea. This heavenly place attracts tourists from all over the world. Here you will find luxurious white beaches, developed infrastructure, and cheerful nightlife in all restaurants, discos, and casinos. One of the local attractions is the airport, which is among the most dangerous on the planet. This is due to the very close proximity of its territory to the beach. Therefore, planes literally take off above the heads of holidaymakers. Those tired of beach holidays will be curious to visit Fort Amsterdam (1631). It is funny that American brown pelicans have chosen this place for their habitat. About 280 hectares near the fortress are recognized as key ornithological areas, where you can see many species of birds.

long_description.en:
Несмотря на крошечные размеры государства, здесь есть на что посмотреть. Синт-Мартен готов удивлять шикарной природой, интересными и уютными городками и массой активностей для любителей серфинга, каякинга и других водных видов спорта. 

Филипсбург — единственный город нидерландской части острова и его столица. Главная диковинка, привлекающая туристов — пляж Maho Beach, где самолеты заходят на посадку и пролетают максимально низко над головами людей. Всего в Филипсбурге насчитывается более 17 живописных пляжей. Наиболее популярные — Mullet beach, Orient beach и уединенные пляжи Friar's Bay и Bay Rouge. Местные гиды предлагают два типа экскурсий: по торговым центрам и пляжам, поэтому внимательно изучайте маршрут. Гуляя по городу, можно оценить колониальное влияние прошлых лет и насладиться знакомыми европейскими черепичными крышами, церквями и монументами. По острову можно передвигаться на муниципальном транспорте, такси или арендовать машину. 

Симпсон Бэй — место уединенного отдыха для всех, кто не любит шумные курорты, но хочет насладиться живописной красотой песчаных пляжей и сервисом класса люкс. Симпсон Бэй расположен на острове Сан-Мартен. Это лагуна с островами, которая представляет не только историческую ценность, но и географическую, поскольку расположена между голландской и французской частью острова. Здесь ждут гостей люксовые отели и чистейшие пляжи с лазурной водой, а также восхитительные карибские пейзажи. В самой лагуне нет достопримечательностей, но у туристов есть возможность отправиться на одну из экскурсий. Вам предложат побывать в других частях острова, где сохранились уникальные постройки колониальной эпохи, старинные церкви и крепости. Поклонники активностей могут заняться снорклингом, дайвингом и другими водными видами спорта. Отели предлагают всевозможные туры-прогулки на яхтах.

Мариго — расположен на западном побережье острова Сен-Мартен, на французской стороне. Это новый городок, основанный в 2007 году. Главная достопримечательность этих мест — порт Сен-Луи, построенный во времена Людовика XVI. Местность живописная и колоритная и привлекает многих путешественников. Однако рассчитывать на развитую инфраструктуру не приходится. В городе отсутствуют различные туристические заведения и дорогостоящие отели, но сохранилась самобытность маленькой и уютной Франции, с ее узкими романтичными улочками, музыкантами и картинными галереями. В Мариго множество бутиков, модных магазинов и французских ресторанов. Архитектура оформлена во французском и итальянском стилях. Главная особенность — тёплый и мягкий климат, позволяющий посещать курорт круглый год.

Гран-Каз (Grand Case) — небольшой городок на французской стороне острова Сен-Мартен. Расположен на Ангильском канале, на западном побережье острова. Главная достопримечательность — длинный песчаный пляж, а также роскошные курорты для лучшего отдыха. Туристическая инфраструктура развита на высшем уровне: здесь большое количество люксовых отелей, ресторанов, баров и различные активности для поклонников водных видов спорта. Мягкий климат позволяет посещать западную часть острова круглый год. В городе работает множество центров дайвинга, как для начинающих, так и для сертифицированных специалистов. Также доступны индивидуальные дайвинг-чартеры.

description.en: Trinidad and Tobago is a small island nation in the southern Caribbean Sea region. Tourism is one of its most important economic industries. That is why guests here are welcomed by kilometers of luxurious beaches, almost untouched nature, excellent service, and a wide range of amusements. The capital city of Port of Spain can delight with a bizarre mixture of historic and modern buildings. Stollmeyer's Castle and National Academy for the Performing Arts are excellent examples of this contrast. The most popular beach locations are in Maracas Bay (Trinidad) and Buccoo (Tobago). Caroni Bird Sanctuary, Asa Wright Nature Centre, and Caroni Swamps are ideal for ecotourism. History and exotic lovers will enjoy a trip to the oldest settlements on the islands — the fishing village of Charlotteville and Arima Town.

Jamaica is an island kingdom in the Caribbean Sea. In its long history, the country had to endure many things: the long struggle for the island between colonizers, the period of buccaneers, and the miserable years of slavery. But the dark times are over! Modern Jamaica is happy to welcome tourists with picturesque cascades of waterfalls, emerald mountain horizons, the azure surface of the warm sea, golden sands of wide beaches, relaxing melodies of reggae, and intense taste of rum.

geography.en: Jamaica is the third-largest English-speaking state in the Western Hemisphere. The Caribbean Sea washes the island's shores, and its neighbors include picturesque Haiti and Cuba. The territory of Jamaica is divided into three counties: Cornwall, Middlesex, Surrey. The counties, in turn, consist of 14 parishes. It's easier for tourists to navigate in these parishes: the north and northeast coasts, the southwest coast, Kingston, and the Blue Mountains.

long_description.en:
Kingston

Kingston is the capital of Jamaica. A rare example of a central city in the country that's difficult to overpraise. There are no outstanding historical attractions and unusual museums, it can not boast of the title of a popular beach resort, and strolling down its streets is not always safe, to be honest. But Kingston is still worth a visit for its unique atmosphere of the Jamaican capital. For a memorable city experience, go to Caymanas Park race track and bet on a quick and beautiful horse, drink a cocktail on Nutsford Boulevard, dive into the roots of reggae culture at the Bob Marley Museum. Don't forget to check out the main attraction — the home of the first black millionaire George Stiebel. And remember, either hang out in the center before the sunset or jump in the shuttle bus and go to a more popular and safe resort like Montego Bay. 

Montego Bay

Montego Bay is a large port city and a popular beach resort in Jamaica. Here you will find restaurants, hotels, bars, and loud nightclubs. At sunset, you can stroll to the sea along the half-ruined streets in the Gregorian style. Make sure you visit the Museum of St. James, where you'll discover the history of slavery. For those who love active leisure, there's plenty to do: float on the Martha Brae or Black Rivers, hike in the Blue Mountains, or dive. 

Negril

If you get tired of faceless skyscrapers, dirty enterprises, and the noise of Montego Bay, head to cozy Negril. The main attraction of the resort is 10 kilometers of wide white beaches. A vacation in this paradise corner will be really carefree. Being away from the excesses of civilization, all you will have to do is to admire the colorful sunset from the rocky terrace of Rick's Café, scuba dive by the picturesque coral island Booby Cay (the best diving spot in Jamaica) and lounge in the warm sun on the beach. You can only have fun on a trip to the nearby town of Appleton, where you'll be told how the traditional Jamaican rum is produced.

Ocho Rios

Ocho Rios is a resort town that is lost among a dozen cozy bays and picturesque capes of fishing villages and ancient towns, on the shore of Discovery Bay. The main attraction in Ocho Rios is the opportunity to gaze at the huge cruise liners that stop at the city port. Otherwise, the resort is quite typical for Jamaica: it has its own reggae museum, a quiet city park, and a huge selection of hotels. For a change, you can visit Dunn's River Falls, the Valley of Fern, and coffee plantations.

Mandeville

The most English city in Jamaica is Mandeville. There are many old colonial buildings in the city center. The parish church and clock tower, North Caribbean University, and English pub the Manchester Arms deserve your attention. Mandeville is the only major settlement on the island with no street access to the sea or river. The lack of beaches here is more than compensated for by the eco-tourism opportunities, as in recent years, Mandeville has gained fame as a mountain climate resort. Local guides offer various options for hiking in the Blue Mountains. If you're on a coffee plantation, make sure you buy a pack of the fragrant black beverage to remember Jamaica while sipping coffee on the couch at home. 

Port Antonio

Every country has an extraordinary place of recreation for wealthy people. In Jamaica, this is Port Antonio — a cozy town on the east coast of the island. A former Spanish colony is nowadays famous for its luxurious hotels and restaurants according to local standards. The city is surrounded by jungle with exotic animals. In the surrounding areas, you will find waterfalls falling from the rocks directly into the sea, and the coastal waters are a marine reserve area. But the renowned Blue Lagoon, where the film of the same name was shot, is the most attractive place for tourists. 

Runaway Bay

Another resort town, Runaway Bay, is buried in the lush greenery of the harbor. Many years ago, the sea pirates shouted "Yo-ho-ho" in the caves of Runaway and the Green Grotto and shared their loot. Nowadays, it is a tourist destination, where the sun-dammed vacationers head for a tour. Active leisure opportunities at the resort are very diverse. You can sail on a yacht, windsurf, and if you get bored, try water skiing or gain experience from diving and snorkeling. Besides, Runaway Bay is the first city that Columbus saw and where Bob Marley was born. At the same time, it is also a world-famous nudist resort. So, choose the beach carefully, especially if you're on vacation with your children.

description.en: Australia is the largest country in Oceania. It covers an entire continent in the Southern Hemisphere and is washed by three oceans — the Indian, the Atlantic, and the Pacific Oceans. People here do not live upside-down as our ancestors once imagined. But the monolith of Uluru, bloody red in the rays of the setting sun; the picturesque scenery of the Great Ocean Road; the azure of the sea surface and the foam crashing upon the cliff of the Twelve Apostles; the fantastic mix of snow-white beaches, dry bushes, lush colors of the Barrier Reef, tropical forests and lifeless deserts definitely blow the minds of every tourist. Aboriginal traditions, colonial culture, and modern technology blend seamlessly together here.

long_description.en:
Canberra

Canberra is the capital of Australia. It doesn't have its own international airport, so many tourists don't even come here. They are pretty much satisfied with Sydney and Melbourne. However, they make a huge mistake, as Canberra is the embodiment of Australia's true spirit. It's a peaceful, measured, green city, where every street is designed in detail. Canberra's main task is to govern the country fairly. That's why there are no toxic industries, no bustling business quarters, and no indefatigable resorts. First of all, it's worth visiting the Parliament Building buried in luxurious gardens, the Australian National Gallery, the Botanical Garden which occupies 50 hectares and displays unique species of plants, the Australian War Memorial and Black Mountain, which offers a great panoramic view of the city.

Sydney

Sydney is the business center and financial capital of Australia. It seems like the postcards come alive here: the Harbour Bridge floating over the harbor, the petals of the Sydney Opera House, the sparkling wheeled ferries and the beautiful surfers of Bondi Beach. The Rocks district in Sydney literally marks the beginning of a new history in Australia. Here you can eat delicious dinners and simply stroll the streets laid down by the first colonizers; try on the bohemian mood in modern museums and art galleries of the Darling Harbour district; relax from the hustle and bustle of the big city in the Royal Botanic Gardens; watch hilarious sea lions performing in Taronga Zoo and attend an organ concert in St. Mary's Cathedral. 

Melbourne

Melbourne is Australia's cultural and sports center, located on the shores of Port Phillip Bay. It has been recognized as the most comfortable city to live in and deserves this status. Believe us, you don't want to leave a kind, clean, intelligent Melbourne. Here you can admire the mystical glow of thousands of mirror balls during the White Night, bet on the Melbourne Cup Carnival and laugh from the heart at the Melbourne International Comedy Festival. You can also check out the colorful graffiti at the Rutledge Lane open-air gallery, drink cocktails at the bars on Chapel Street and support your favorite on Australia's Formula 1 Grand Prix tour. 

Brisbane

Brisbane is the largest city on the east coast. Despite its charm, the state capital of Queensland has a transit function. The local airport hosts many local and international airlines, so tourists usually stay in Brisbane waiting for a flight or spend a day or two before heading to the Gold Coast. But since you are here, do not waste your time in a hotel. Visit the largest koala sanctuary in the world called "Lone Pine", Sir Thomas Brisbane Planetarium, Brisbane Riverfront, an old windmill and make a lap on the Ferris wheel in the South Bank Parklands. If you have some extra time, take a day trip to the paradise Fraser Island and the rainforests of Lamington National Park. 

Adelaide

Adelaide is a green oasis of Australia. The city floats in the parks of the Lofty and Montefiore hills, fragrant with the flowers of the Wittunga Botanic Gardens, refreshes with the full-flowing waterfalls of Morialta Conservation Park and spins your head with the best wineries in the country. Here you will find the South Australian Museum, the most visited one in the country. Its unique exhibition reveals the continent's history and culture. It is also worth visiting the Tandanya National Aboriginal Cultural Institute where you'll learn about Australia's Aboriginal traditions. If you're bored of bohemian life, take a ferry to Kangaroo Island. Here you can spot long-legged marsupials in the wild, as well as New Zealand seals, koalas, and sea lions.

Why should you come to Australia?

The Land of Oz offers many leisure options. If you are looking for lazy beach holiday resorts, welcome to the Golden Coast or the wild beaches of the Fraser, Bruny and Trinity Islands. The Great Barrier Reef is a true Mecca for divers. Here you can admire underwater coral castles, colorful fish, sharks, whales, and huge turtles all year round. The lands of Australia are also full of amazing places. On a safari tour, you can visit the red Macdonnell Ranges, Barramundi Gorge, and hot springs, see blood-thirsty crocodiles in the Crocodylus Park, kangaroos and black-footed wallabies cutting through the desert. And how can you not surf in a country where it is almost a national sport! Here you'll find soft waves on Long Reef Beach for beginners and closed tubes on South Curl-Curl Beach for kamikaze surfing. And for dessert, Australia offers you the snowy slopes of the Great Dividing Range, where you'll find the Thredbo, Perisher Blue, Falls Creek, and Buller ski resorts.

Flora and Fauna of Australia

Australia's flora and fauna have been forming in isolation from other continents for a long period. So the continent is populated by more than 75% of endemic plants and animals. Teddy-like pandas, perky kangaroos, funny platypus and wombats, long-legged emu ostriches, loud cockatoos, Tasmanian devil, and Dingo wild dog — you won't find all these animals on other continents except for zoos. Australia's plant world is also rich in unique species: dense eucalyptus groves, slender bamboo forests, giant curry and jarrah trees, acacia that exhale fragrance along the entire northern coast, screwpine and much, much more.

description.en: The Republic of Vanuatu is a unique place where one can make oneself feel away from civilization. All you need to do is to get to Tanna Island, where tribes worship an ancient deity — Yasur volcano. Even in the capital of the republic, Port Vila, one can feel a general relaxation and leisurely atmosphere. There are no high-rise buildings or modern shopping malls, and the locals spend their days lying under palm trees drinking kava and playing a game brought by the French, pétanque. It is not for nothing that the people of Vanuatu are considered to be the happiest people on the planet.

Guam is a small American island located in the west part of the Pacific Ocean. It was formed by two ancient volcanoes that went underwater many thousands of years ago. Guam welcomes tourists all year round. This region is famous for its favorable climate, unspoiled nature, excellent beaches, and a duty-free trade zone. However, visitors come here for more than just natural attractions. There are ancient history monuments, rock paintings, and traditional Chamorro aboriginal dwellings, which lived here about 3500 years ago. Here you can find entertainment for every taste. Conquer the deep sea, explore the jungle, go shopping in Tumon, follow in the footsteps of Magellan in Umatac village, go hiking, visit one of the national parks, and try the local delicacies.

If you're bored with a monotonous holiday, welcome to Kiribati, an island nation in the center of the Pacific that spreads over 33 coral atolls. It is here that you can see the untouched nature, get closer to the exotic culture of the inhabitants of Oceania, and make your holiday unforgettable, thanks to a variety of entertainment. This country knows how to surprise. Surfing, diving, fishing, and seclusion with the ocean on beautiful beaches are popular in Kiribati. Jarvis Island, Kingman Reef, and Palmyra are perfect for exploring the rich flora and fauna of the island. There are no museums or monuments in these parts of the world, but you can participate in a variety of rituals and festivities as you get acquainted with the locals. And the main thing is to have a rest from civilization, surrounded by unique natural landscapes.

Despite the common misconception, the Cook Islands are not the place where the famous traveler died. His stay on this archipelago ended quite safely for him. After all, its inhabitants are renowned for their cordiality, cheerfulness, and affability. Adventures on the oldest island in the Pacific Ocean, wonderful beaches and lagoons, and corners of almost untouched nature await tourists.

The Federated States of Micronesia is a nation in Oceania, located in the east and west of the Caroline Islands, in the western part of the Pacific Ocean. During the Second World War, hundreds of ships and planes sank here, which attracts divers. Tourists also come here to relax among the magnificent nature, picturesque waterfalls, beautiful beaches. Tourist infrastructure is developed here, and there are night entertainments — discos, restaurants, and casinos. The paradise islands are like another planet for guests from the Big Land. The indigenous people have preserved unusual traditions that even the authorities do not argue with. According to the customs, if a person has committed a crime punishable by death, the police will not interfere with the murder. The only way to save a miserable man is to buy him out for a stone coin, the price of which is human life.

The Kingdom of Niue (Savage) is an independent island country within New Zealand. It is located in the south part of the Pacific Ocean, east of Tonga Island. The climate here is hot and humid. The main tourist entertainments are beach recreation, diving, snorkeling, fishing, canoe trips, and hiking in the tropical forests of "tapu." There are several interesting reserves in Niue — Huvalu, which keeps the secrets of the ancient tropical forest, and Anono, with its exotic coral reefs and sea caves. The most interesting architectural sights are concentrated in the capital, the village of Alofi. The island is famous for its extraordinary cuisine based on fish, seafood, and coconuts, which are used here to cook delicious and unusual dishes skillfully.

New Zealand is one of the most impressive places on the planet. The untouched wild nature attracts millions of tourists here. The fabulous landscapes of this country became the decorations of the legendary "Lord of the Rings" and "Hobbit" trilogies directed by Peter Jackson. An extraordinary village named Hobbiton was created for filming the movie. It is a local attraction that has become a pilgrimage for tourists and fans of the trilogy from every corner of the world.

geography.en: New Zealand is located in the south-west part of the Pacific Ocean. The country consists of two large islands — the North and South Islands which are separated by Cook Strait. The territory of New Zealand is divided into seventeen districts. Nine of them are located in the North Island, seven are in the South Island, and another district is situated in the Chatham Islands Group.  From north to south, the Southern Alps go through the South Island. Mount Cook is the highest peak of the chain and is 3724 meters in height. The west coast of this island is abundant in fjords. The North Island is less mountainous and is more suitable for dwelling. Here you can find large cities and important ports in the country. New Zealand also owns around seven hundred smaller islands. The majority of them are uninhabited.

long_description.en:
Wellington

Wellington is the capital of New Zealand. It's a cozy and beautiful city that impresses travelers with its abundance of tunnels, viaducts and bridges, snug garden squares, and fascinating attractions. You can check out the round building of the parliament which form that reminds a bees hive. In front of it, there is the former residence of New Zealand's government. It's a unique wooden construction which was built in 1876. There are plenty of tours to the movie sets of the "Lord of the Ring" in the city. They include visits to museums and favorite places of actors that were featured in the film. The Botanic Garden is located on the hillside. You can easily reach it in the cable car, admiring marvelous landscapes as you go. 

Auckland

Auckland is the largest city in the country. It was numerously ranked as one of the best towns for living in the world. It is also considered to be the unofficial capital of Polynesia as it has the biggest Polynesian community here. You should definitely attend the Auckland Art Gallery and Kelly Tarlton's Sea Life Aquarium. You can admire the panoramic view od the city and its neighborhoods from the tallest construction in the city — the Sky Tower. Fans of active sports and extreme can check their courage and jump from a height of 192 meters. There are over fifty extinct volcanoes in the neighborhoods of the city. The most renowned natural attraction in New Zealand is located not far from Auckland. This is an old volcanic Rangitoto Island. 

Christchurch

Christchurch is the largest city of the South Island. Tourists should visit such attractions as Cathedral Square, aquarium, botanic garden, public Orana Wildlife Park. The International Antarctic Centre is another exciting place. It has the most extensive collection of exhibits dedicated to the exploration of the South Pole. Most of the Antarctic expeditions start in Christchurch, in Lyttelton port town, to be exact. Inside the museum, you can take a ride in real snowmobiles and off-roaders, or experience a real Antarctic storm. 

Dunedin

Dunedin is the second in size city in the South Island. It is located 360 km from Christchurch. It's considered to be little Scotland as the Scottish gold-diggers founded it and formed the corresponding architecture. Dunedin is believed to be a students' city and a center of eco-tourism. Here you can watch seals, albatrosses, and penguins in wild nature. Once you are in Dunedin, you should definitely walk down Baldwin Street — the steepest street in the world. The road is 359 meters in length and rises for 80 meters.

Queenstown

Queenstown is one of the most beautiful towns in New Zealand. It is located on the bank of Lake Wakatipu, in the South Island of New Zealand. The picturesque wild nature attracts fanciers of extreme and adventure seekers here. Here you can try rafting on fast mountain rivers and bungee jumping. Queenstown is called "the world capital of extreme sports" for a good reason.

description.en: New Caledonia is a piece of France in the Pacific Ocean, discovered in 1774 by the British discoverer James Cook. Caledonia is the ancient name of Scotland, the birthplace of the famous traveler. Therefore, without further ado, he gave this name to his next ingenious discovery. Archaeologists suggest that the island existed already in the XIII century BC. It was inhabited about 3.5 thousand years ago. Today it is a popular trendy resort with evergreen forests, snow-white sand, luxurious palms, and juicy turquoise Coral Sea. Only on this land, restaurants serve "Dumbea" — the rarest oysters, which are bred in the bay of the same name nearby. That's why gourmets from all over the world come here. Ordinary tourists go to New Caledonia not only for this reason. They want to walk around the islands on a lavishly equipped yacht and swim hugging giant green turtles. And they also want to see the famous Heart of Voh from a helicopter.

Norfolk is a small island located in the Pacific Ocean between Australia, New Zealand, and New Caledonia. Tourists are attracted by its stunningly beautiful nature, mild climate, and reasonably low prices. Norfolk Island National Park has preserved endemic rainforest plants and several rare bird species. The reserve covers one-tenth of the territory, and the rest is a pastoral type of pasture and arable land. There is no public transport here. Locals move around by cars and bicycles. The southern part of the coast, with its cozy bays and the colorful underwater world, is of the greatest interest. Most beaches on the island are not protected from the whimsical ocean winds, so there are high waves. Emily Bay is the best place to dive and is sheltered from storms by a coral reef.

Papua New Guinea is an independent state in the Pacific Ocean occupying the eastern part of the island of New Guinea. Until 1975, it had been part of Australia. It is a land of amazing natural vegetation, coral reefs, centuries-old swamps, and picturesque rocks. People come here to see thousands of unique animals — from tree-kangaroos to giant butterflies. Also, to get to know the indigenous peoples, at least a hundred of them. History tells us that the first people appeared in Papua New Guinea 50,000 years ago. The capital, Port Moresby, is surrounded by stunning mountains. There are 18 active volcanoes on the territory of the state, and the peaks of the largest of them reach 4500 m. The area is perfect for relaxing on white sandy beaches, ocean fishing, and windsurfing.

The Pacific Archipelago of Samoa comprises two large islands, Savai'i and Upolu, and eight small islands. Most of the small islands are uninhabited. Beautiful secluded beaches, splendid forests, high mountains, and volcanoes await tourists in these places. The inhabited part of the independent state of Samoa — Savai'i, Upolu, Manono, and Apolima — provides comfortable services with hotels, shops, and restaurants. Excursions and eventful walks are organized from here regularly. In the capital Apia (Upolu Island), the historical district of Mulinu'u, with many historical monuments, entertainment centers, and colorful markets with excellent souvenirs, is of particular interest. Having visited Samoa, you will learn everything about Polynesian culture, taste exotic dishes, get a charge of vivacity and energy, and successfully enrich the coin jar of life impressions.

The Northern Mariana Islands is an unincorporated organized territory associated with the United States. They are located in the western part of the Pacific Ocean and include 14 islands famous for their pristine nature, excellent diving and surfing, nice fishing, and white sandy beaches. The islands are also not deprived of historical attractions. This is where the battles for the Pacific Ocean took place during World War II. It will be interesting to see the traces of Japanese and American shipwrecks. Tourists are delighted to go on short hiking trips, during which they discover picturesque places. They also visit the bird sanctuary and Tonga Cave, where you can see stalactite and stalagmite formations, as well as clusters of ritual stones of the ancient people of the sea.

The evergreen Solomon Islands are situated in Melanesia and are washed by the Pacific Ocean. This state consists of almost a thousand small islands with impassable jungle, where truly pristine nature reigns. You can enjoy the views of the world's largest saltwater Marovo Lagoon, see rare hawksbill sea turtles, and admire the largest elevated coral atoll on Earth. Not far from the capital of Honiara, at the bottom of the ocean, there have been sunken ships and planes since World War II. The most avid divers come here to see them. Some of the unexplored islands are covered in mysteries and mystical stories. The legends about the spirits of the dead and mythical creatures "kakamora" are hidden in the most remote and uninhabited villages. In Solomon Islands, you can simultaneously enjoy tranquility and a bright dose of adrenaline.

Tonga is a small island state, rarely visited by tourists. It is a paradise where not only pristine nature and unique flora and fauna reign but also the colorful identity of traditions. Only on these islands, lost in the blue waters, the most beautiful girls weigh about one hundred kilograms. Here, as nowhere else in the world, there is an incredible amount of respect for the King and his family. Tonga is one of the last absolute monarchies on the planet. A couple of centuries ago, its citizens, who took part in the burial of the ruler, had their hand cut off so that it would not be desecrated in everyday life after touching the monarch. This rule does not exist now, but still, people do not use their hands for more than 100 days. They do not work or even eat with this hand, and they are fully served at home. Travelers come to Tonga for great diving and fishing, to enjoy the solitude on the beautiful wild beaches where it is rare to meet tourists, to get acquainted with fascinating, unusual local culture and customs. And, of course, to be the first people on the globe to meet the sunrise.

geography.en: The Kingdom of Tonga is located in the south-western part of the Pacific Ocean on islands forming three main groups — Tongatapu, Haʻapai, and Vavaʻu. In addition to them, it includes more than 170 separate islands. Tonga's archipelago consists of volcanic or uplifted coral islands and reefs. There are no major rivers or lakes on these islands. Tonga neighbors with the waters of Samoa in the north, Fiji in the west, and the territorial waters of Niue in the east. The state has five administrative districts, with the King at its head.

long_description.en:
Nuku'alofa

Nuku'alofa is the capital of the state, located on the coral island of Tongatapu. The city has no industry at all, and its main attraction is the Royal Palace. However, it is inaccessible to locals and tourists, who can only see its facades through the fence. All year round, orchids growing here are a real highlight of the capital. Nuku'alofa is also known for its white sandy beaches. The largest of them is Ha'atafu Beach. It's popular with surfers. From April to November, the trade winds blow here, raising waves. They also come here for diving activities. In the coral reef area, there are shipwrecks where you can swim next to humpback whales. In the suburbs of Nuku'alofa, there are ruins of defensive constructions of ancient civilizations of Oceania.

The Vava'u Island Group

In this corner, nature has created unique opportunities for fishing and diving. Throughout the year, the water transparency here exceeds 30, and in some places — even 50 meters. The islands are also famous for their caves. Their walls are covered with soft multicolored corals, and extraordinary fish swim in the water. The Mt Talau National Park and the Ene'io Botanical Garden are also worth seeing. From May to October, the islands have a yachting season. The administrative center of the Vava'u Island Group is Neiafu, the second-largest city in Tonga. Travel agencies offer whale watching tours here. However, such tours should only be accompanied by a guide accredited by the Ministry of Fish Resources. Humpback whales come here to mate and breed, and their activity peaks are in July and September. Diving is prohibited near these marine mammals, but it is possible to swim at a distance of 30 meters.

Niua Islands

Niua Islands are located 400 km from the capital of Tonga. It is difficult to get here as transport does not operate regularly. The local landmark is an active volcano. Last century, it erupted four times, and now there is a lake with hot springs in its crater. The isolation of the local population allowed them to avoid western influence and preserve their identity. It is here that you can see traditional Polynesian culture in the villages, climb to the top of the extinct Tafahi Volcano, relax on volcanic beaches.

ʻEua Island

ʻEua Island is the only one with a river. It can be of interest to hikers. This hilly stretch of land is the largest tropical forest in Tonga. It has wild sandy beaches on the west side and cliffs on the east side. It is also a paradise for diving and snorkeling enthusiasts, with whales coming to its shores. James Cook has been to ʻEua twice, in 1773 and 1777.

description.en: Fiji is an island with white sands, high palm trees, and unique coral reefs. The past meets the future here as the 180th meridian neatly divides one of the islands in half. This is where the sunrise begins. These are areas of fantastic beaches, surrounded by luxurious villas. Here, wild thickets and waterfalls sit next to modern restaurants, where you can try something that is not served anywhere else in the world. It is hard to believe that, 200 years ago, Europeans were afraid to land on the islands even for a short time. The reason for that is the fame of cannibals, which is firmly anchored in the natives of Fiji. Today, their ancient settlements particularly attract many tourists. And questions about cannibalism cause only good-natured laughter among both guests and residents. People also come here to see high mountains, wide rivers and to get acquainted with their new selves.

geography.en: The Republic of Fiji consists of 332 Pacific islands. Of these, only 110 are inhabited, while the rest preserve the beauty and charm of untouched nature. The island groups are concentrated around the inland Koro Sea in the South Pacific and form a "horseshoe". This unusual form is a consequence of Fiji's volcanic origin. The soils here are fertile, especially near the rivers Singatoka, Rewa, Nandi, Mba, Nawua, and Lambasa, which are part of the area. The Rewa River is the largest in the country (it is 145 km long). There are few lakes in Fiji. The most remarkable is the Tagimaucia on the island of Taveuni and the Ngalongalo, Ngasauva, and Ndrano reservoirs at Vanua Levu. The Republic of Fiji is divided into four districts: Eastern, Western, Northern, and Central. These, in turn, are subdivided into 14 provinces. The island of Rotuma stands out separately. It has the status of a dependent territory with partial autonomy.

long_description.en:
Viti Levu Island. It is the capital of the Republic of Fiji and one of the two largest cities - Suva. The second city of Nadi is located a few hours away. These territories are home to the majority of Fiji's population — about 550 thousand people, which is more than half of the total number of islanders (about 1 million). Here are the best beaches of the famous "Coral Coast" and the most comfortable hotels. It is worth visiting the Fiji Museum in Suva. It displays exhibits that will tell you about the island's history and culture. In particular, there is a 13-meter watercraft in the museum that locals used to travel on more than 100 years ago. From Viti Levu, you can make an excursion to neighboring islands, such as Beqa. It is worth getting to know the Sawau tribe, whose representatives entertain tourists by walking on hot rocks. The Sri Siva Subramaniya temple in Nadi is a must-see. This Hindu sanctuary is considered to be the largest in the Southern Hemisphere.

Vanua Levu

Vanua Levu is Fiji's second-largest island. It attracts tourists with coral reefs and picturesque nature. Here you can go scuba diving, which captivates with the visibility up to 50 meters deep. This is probably the only place on earth where so many shark species can be seen. In order to put on a show, specialists attract them by fish scraps. On the whole, this entertainment is safe, but you should take into account that bull, tiger, and grey sharks, which are also found here, are not harmless at all. Don't forget to explore Mount Nasorolevu — it is the highest point in the area. And if you want to see the Floating Island, which moves on the surface of a large lake during the day, visit the city of Labasa.

Taveuni

Taveuni. This is the island where the past meets the future. It's where the 180th meridian runs, which means the international date line is here. So if it's Tuesday on the west side of the island, it's Wednesday on the east side. There is even a place where tourists take pictures with one foot in "today" and the other foot in "yesterday". Taveuni is also called an "island of soft corals". After all, here you can see the picturesque views of beaches and tropical forests. Mount Uluigalau (1,241m high) is also an eye-catcher, which you must definitely climb to enjoy the views. Visit the village of Waiyevo. Only here, you can see rare birds — predatory hawks, peregrine falcons, endemic parrots, and wild pigeons. Visit the Bouma National Heritage Park, where the delightful nature and the waterfalls will meet you. You can even have a picnic here. 

Kadavu

Kadavu is the fourth-largest island in the archipelago. The remarkable coral reefs of Astrolabe, Namalata, Solo, and Tavuki, stretching for tens of meters. The unique nature of the tropics, mountain slopes, and snow-white sandy beaches are the hallmarks of this area. The neat houses of local villagers complete the picture. It is an ideal place for diving, snorkeling, sea fishing, and leisurely nature contemplation.

Ovalau

Ovalau. This island will be interesting for lovers of exotic holidays. Here is the city of Levuka — the capital of Fiji until 1882. Mount Nandelaiovalau attracts tourists, the height of which reaches 626 m. Other attractions include the buildings in the style of the Wild West. The beaches with stony bottoms are not very attractive, and there are few of them.

description.en: French Polynesia is an island nation in the Pacific Ocean, which is rightly called its gem. The fabulous beauty of the underwater world, virgin nature and original culture of indigenous people reign here. It is an amazing corner of mystery, where local women wear flowers in their hair, men have authentic tattoos, and walk on burning coals at weddings. People come here to spend their honeymoon, get away from the bustle of the city, and enjoy the pristine, incredible beauty of nature. Besides, you can become an explorer while discovering ancient idols and feel like Mowgli by feeding sharks and rays from your hand.

The country owes its name (from the Latin word "argentum"), to the colonizers who hoped to find silver deposits here. These hopes did not work out, but Argentina always manages to capture the imagination of tourists who come here for exotics. It is a country of movement: temperamental tango, high-speed football, competitions of the local cowboys-gaucho. It has given gourmets all over the world the healing mate and delicious meat. In this country, original traditions, sights, and modernity were blended so carefully that they turned out to be a fascinating cocktail for a tourist. But its main treasure is the magnificent nature, surprising with its diversity.

geography.en: Argentina covers the entire south-eastern part of South America and part of the Tierra del Fuego archipelago. It neighbors Chile in the west, Bolivia and Paraguay in the north, Brazil and Uruguay in the northeast. The Atlantic Ocean washes the country's east coast. It is the second-largest country on the continent after Brazil. The vast area stretches along the meridian, representing almost all landscape zones, from plains and mountains to deserts and jungles. The Andes, one of the longest and highest mountain systems in the world, passes through the country. In the South Andes, there is also the highest peak of Aconcagua ("The Guardian of Time"). This mountain is an extinct volcano, with over seven thousand meters in height. Climbers from all over the world come to conquer it. Argentina will delight travelers with magnificent and diverse landscapes: severe mountain peaks covered with eternal snow, glaciers, lakes, waterfalls, tropical forests, and semi-deserts of Patagonia and Puna. Administratively, Argentina is divided into 23 provinces and one federal district, Buenos Aires. Remarkably, each of them has its own constitution, under which local self-government is established. There is another system of division based on natural and cultural-historical features, which includes six large regions — Patagonia, Pampas, Cuyo, Gran Chaco, Greater North Argentina, and Mesopotamia.

long_description.en:
Buenos Aires

The capital of Argentina, Buenos Aires, is translated from Spanish as "Good Winds" or "Good Air". Its inhabitants themselves often call it "a city with different names" and use the abbreviated name Baires or Capital Federal. Till the XVII century, the city had borne a difficultly remembered name given to it by the founder of city Pedro de Mendoza: "City of the Most Holy Trinity and Port of Saint Mary of the Fair Winds". The citizens of the capital call themselves, "Portenos", which means "inhabitants of the port".
