As Buenos Aires stands on the shores of a giant bay, it has remained the largest port in the area for centuries. The city is so multifaceted that you need at least a week to get to know it. Old quarters with ancient mansions, churches, and narrow paved streets stand side by side with districts with skyscrapers made of glass and concrete. Although it may look a bit unusual, tourists are often offered to attend a cemetery as one of the attractions. It bears the same name as the quarter does, Recoleta. There are burial places of many celebrities of the country, some of which are recognized as historical monuments. The real tourist pilgrimage centers are the colorful La Boca Quarter, Piazza San Martin, the Teatro Colón, the Cathedral, the Congress, the Casa Rosada Pink House, and the Obelisk on the broadest July 9 Avenue. You should also definitely attend the traditional tango shows and cozy city cafes. 

Salta

Salta is like a beautiful lady. Perhaps, that's what the Argentines call Salta. The city, located in a cozy valley between two mountain ranges, and is extremely popular among tourists. It was Salta that managed to preserve the extraordinary colonial charm of beautiful mansions and temples, cozy houses with toy balconies, and winding streets buried in orange trees. Traveling on one of the world's highest mountain railways is especially popular with tourists. It is called the "Road to the clouds" because most of the way the train really does travel in the clouds, finishing its route in the mountains at an altitude of more than four thousand meters. The route passes through 29 bridges, 12 viaducts, 21 tunnels, and many spirals and zigzags, so the experience of such a journey remains unforgettable. In the city itself, the central square is the best place to start sightseeing. There you shall find the Cathedral, built back in the XVI century with the miraculous statues of the Virgin Mary and Jesus Christ. Locals believe that they can save their city from earthquakes and cure any disease. The Monastery of St. Francis, built in the style of neoclassicism by Italian Luigi Giorgi, is another attraction of the city. It is also worth visiting the local Town Hall, where the History Museum is now located. And if you want to buy souvenirs, you should go to the colorful city market. 

Rosario

Rosario is the third-largest city in the country and home to the legendary Latin American revolutionary Ernesto "Che" Guevara. It still has the house where he was born with the memorial plaque and a four-meter-long monument to a famous countryman. This city also gave the country many prominent football players: Lionel Messi, Maxi Rodriguez, Angel Fabian di Maria, Mauro Icardi, and many others. Football is like a cult here. Rosario even held matches of the 1978 World Cup. A journey through the city should begin with the center, where the Parque de la Independencia (Independence Park) spreads for over a thousand square meters. In addition to the beautiful gardens, fountains, and sculptures, there are several museums, a children's garden, a racetrack, and a municipal stadium. The city is also famous for being home to the national flag of the country. In honor of this event, a Memorial of the same name was opened in the city. The highest part of the monument is the 70-meter tall tower, where you can admire the magnificent panoramic view of the town. We advise you to plan time for a walk through the historic city center and admire the architecture of the Cathedral Basilica Shrine of Our Lady of the Rosary, the famous Palace of the Lions, and other attractions. Rosario will not be boring at all. There are many shopping centers, night clubs, restaurants, and casinos. 

El Calafate

El Calafate is a town located on the banks of Lago Argentino, the country's largest freshwater lake. El Calafate owes its name to a plant common for Patagonia, box-leaved barberry knows as "el calafate" in the local language. This bush with yellow flowers and black berries grows everywhere, and the locals make extraordinarily tasty jams from its fruits. The city was founded in the late 1920s but became popular only after the creation of the Los Glaciares National Park, a UNESCO World Heritage site. Glaciers, mountain peaks, clear waters of lakes Lago Argentino and Viedma, as well as graceful cougars — all this attracts tourists from all over the world in El Calafate. 

Puerto Iguazú

Puerto Iguazú is another city whose treasury is filled mainly by tourists visiting numerous restaurants and hotels. It is from here they go on excursions to the famous waterfalls of the Iguazu River, which are on the border with Brazil. The river flows for almost 3 kilometers from here, forming a cascade of 270 individual waterfalls. This spectacle deserves your admiration. 

Ushuaia

Ushuaia is the port city in Argentina and the capital of the province of Tierra del Fuego. Ushuaia is considered to be the southernmost city on Earth, although, to be fair, there are several other small villages to the south. Tierra del Fuego National Park and the Martial Glacier are the main tourist attraction here. The local prison is not quite ordinary, but a fascinating object to visit. It houses a museum nowadays. You can even take a ride on the "Prisoner Train", an exact copy of the ones that once transported prisoners.

description.en: Brazil is an incredibly beautiful and interesting country in South America, which attracts tourists from all over the world. The first association connected with Brazil draws a bright carnival and fiery samba in the imagination. Picturesque beaches, untouched nature, parks with exotic animals, unusual local cuisine, and a unique flavor that meets here literally at every turn should be added to this list. Brazil is the magic aroma of the coffee, the endless noise of famous waterfalls, the dangerous Amazon, and impassable jungle. A country that you can't help but love from the first time you meet it.

geography.en: Brazil is the largest in South America by area. It ranks fifth in a similar world ranking. Brazil can boast of numerous neighbors: Venezuela, Guyana, Suriname, French Guiana, Uruguay, Argentina, Paraguay, Bolivia, Peru, and Colombia. The Republic consists of 26 states and one federal district, and the entire territory is conditionally divided into five geographic areas. The largest city in Brazil is São Paulo, with a population of over 12 million people. According to studies, urbanization in the country is in full swing. Even today, 8 out of 10 Brazilians live in cities.

long_description.en:
Rio de Janeiro

The most famous city in Brazil is Rio de Janeiro. Until 1960, it had been the capital of the republic. Tourists are attracted here by the largest carnival, the famous statue of Christ the Savior, and no less popular beach Copacabana, stretching along the coast for 4 km. Rio de Janeiro is a paradise for fans of sightseeing. You can admire the city from the Sugarloaf Mountain observation deck or Mount Corcovado. In addition, it is worth visiting the Botanical Garden and the world's largest urban forest Tijuca, the Museum of Modern Art, and the Art Museum in Rio. The Escadaria Selarón, which steps are lined with mosaic tiles, can add bright colors to your trip. If we talk about beach destinations other than Copacabana, other beaches also deserve your attention. They include Ipanema (calm and safe), Leblon (respectable and luxurious), Arpoador (stony but not crowded), Joatinga (hard to reach but deserted).

Brasilia

Brasilia is the capital of the republic, which is inscribed on the UNESCO World Heritage List. In its layout, Brasilia resembles an airplane or a bird with open wings. The city was built in 3 years and designed to be as convenient and comfortable as possible for living. There are practically no industrial enterprises, but many parks and architectural sights. The most famous and beautiful buildings in the capital are the result of the work of architect Oscar Niemeyer. Here you can walk around the Palaces of Supreme Court and Justice, check out the Presidential Palace, evaluate the exposition of the National Museum, visit the National Theatre. Attention should also be paid to the largest urbanized National Park, which is considered to be the pride of the region. The beauty of the sunset is another highlight of the capital. 

Salvador

Salvador is one of the most colorful and fun cities in the country. The atmosphere of colonial Brazil reigns here. One can guess the features of African and Portuguese culture in local architecture. The city is divided into upper and lower parts, which are connected by a special city elevator. Here you can admire the beautiful squares, cathedral, fort, walk in the park of Costa Azul or visit the Garden of Lovers. Salvador can boast of a large number of museums: numismatics, archaeology and ethnology, Afro-Brazilian Museum, and others. Fans of capoeira, a martial art that is demonstrated daily by masters in the Pelouriño squares and near the Mercado Modelo market, will definitely love this city.

São Paulo

São Paulo is the cultural capital of Brazil, a center of entertainment and vibrant life. The city is beautiful both day and night. It is worth starting the walk from the central square of Praça da Se, where you can easily reach Brazil's largest campus. The Government House, the Ibirapuera Park, the Cathedral, and the Museum of Painting also deserve your attention. The highlight of the city is the unique Liberdade district. It's the center of Japanese culture in Brazil. Here you can dive into Japanese traditions, admire whimsical arches, check out Japanese restaurants, pamper yourself with various purchases. In the evening, the city of Sao Paulo does not fall asleep, and meets tourists in dance clubs and the night wholesale market, which is called "The Belly of Paris".

Foz do Iguaçu

Foz do Iguaçu is a small town that would not be remarkable for tourists if it were not for two facts. The first one is the proximity of the famous Iguazú Falls, which are only 20 km from here. The second fact is that there are three national borders (Brazil, Argentina, and Paraguay). You can get to Iguazú Falls by bus or by taxi. The park of the same name is located on the territory of two countries — Brazil and Argentina. Still, it is from Foz do Iguaçu that the most picturesque views are opened, including Devil's Throat. You can admire the waterfalls from the observation deck, or while a tour on a motorboat or helicopter. Visitors can also visit a museum and a bird park. 

Manaus

Manaus is a city on the banks of the Amazon, the capital of Amazonia. One of the most fascinating, ecologically clean, and, at the same time, frightening places on earth. The city is inhabited mainly by Indians, and the wild nature is the essential feature of these places. Exotic lovers come here for day and night tours of the Amazon, as well as walking in the tropical forest. Another highlight of Manaus is the so-called "Wedding of the Rivers". It is a unique natural phenomenon, the confluence of two rivers (the Rio Negro and Solimoes). Their waters do not mix and flow in parallel for 2 kilometers. In addition to the natural attractions, Manaus offers the opportunity to admire the local architecture decorated with blue ceramics and go shopping at a real floating market.

description.en: Bolivia is the full enjoyment of the authenticity of nature: mountains, jungle, volcanoes, canyons, salt marshes — all in one country! It is also known for its capital, located high in the mountains, a high-mountain navigable lake, and the most dangerous "Road of Death". Tourists also come here to see the enormous salt flat of Salar de Uyuni and take fantastic photos sitting on its mirrored surface.

geography.en: Bolivia is located in central South America. It borders Spain to the north and northeast, Paraguay to the south-east, Argentina to the south, Chile, and Peru to the south-west and west. The country has access to the Atlantic Ocean by the Paraguay River. Bolivia's highest point is the extinct volcano Nevado Sajama (6542 m). A great variety of landscape zones characterizes Bolivia's nature. The western highlands of the country, including the Altiplano, are located in the Andes. The eastern lowlands are in tropical forests and the Gran Chaco. Lake Titicaca, the largest freshwater resource in South America, is located at the border between Bolivia and Peru. Bolivia is also known for the largest salt marshes in the world, located near the town of Uyuni. The official name of Bolivia is the Plurinational State of Bolivia. It ranks first in the world by the number of official languages. According to the 2009 Constitution, there are 37 languages. More than 50 percent of the population speaks Spanish, while the rest speaks indigenous languages. The most common languages are Quechua and Aymara. The territorial and administrative division of the country consists of nine departments and 112 provinces, divided into cantons.

long_description.en:
Sucre

Sucre is the constitutional capital of Bolivia, but the main state institutions are located in La Paz. There are many snow-white buildings with fiery red roofs, so it is often called the "white city". Its architecture has no analogs in the world. In 1991, the old, historic part of the city was inscribed on the UNESCO World Heritage List. Compared to other cities in Bolivia, it amazes tourists with its pure and unusual beauty of architecture. The main square is home to the Government Palace, built in Baroque style in the late XIX century. Today, it houses the building of the Prefecture of the Department of Chuquisaca. Lovers of more secluded rest can walk around the surroundings with charming streets, and visit La Glorieta Castle — national treasure with octagonal towers, arched portico, and a high minaret with a dome. There are also several fascinating museums in the city: historical, ethnographic and folklore, and military. 

La Paz

La Paz (Nuestra Señora de La Paz) is the actual capital of the country because it is home to the residences of the President and Government of Bolivia, and also has the status of the highest mountain capital in the world. Millions of years ago, this place was the crater of a huge volcano at an altitude of 3,600 meters. The mountainous terrain that has survived since then gives the city a unique feature: it resembles a large bowl in which roads "flow" into the city through the top and "flow" downwards. If you are going to visit La Paz, don't forget to bring warm clothes. The average annual temperature ranges from +7°C to +11°C, and in July, it's only +4°C. Palacio Quemado, which means "Burned Palace", is of particular interest to tourists. In the historical center, on Plaza Murillo, there is the Capitol. Along the square, there are many houses and churches decorated with sculptures. A small street, Calle Jaen, which is famous for its colonial-style buildings, gives the city a special charm. You can buy souvenirs from magicians and shamans at the Witches' Market (El Mercado de las Brujas).

Cochabamba

Cochabamba is a huge metropolis, 220 km southeast of La Paz, nestled in a valley surrounded by mountains. It is called a "garden city" for its numerous parks and gardens. The mild climate allows the cultivation of grapes and cereals, as well as citrus fruits. The symbol of the city is the statue of Jesus Christ (Cristo de la Concordia) installed on Mount San Pedro. The height of the monument is 34.2 m. You can climb the mountain with a cable car. A staircase with 1399 steps leads to the observation deck, which offers a magnificent panorama of the city. The central square of the town is interesting with its colonial buildings, which are surrounded on all sides by palm trees. One of the most impressive buildings is the Santa Teresa convent. It is worth taking a tour to see this ancient architectural structure. From the top of the monastery chapel, you can easily see all the beauties of the city. You will not regret it if you visit the most interesting archaeological museum.

Santa Cruz de la Sierra

Santa Cruz de la Sierra is the largest city in the country and its economic center, located in the eastern part, on the Piraeus River. A mild foothill climate, a large number of different artifacts from the colonial era, and the status of "Gateway to Brazil" have made the city a major tourist destination. Plaza 24 September is one of the main attractions. Since cars are not allowed to pass through the square, walking on it will be a real pleasure. The Santa Cruz de la Sierra Cathedral is also the city's main Catholic temple. Visitors can climb the bell towers and admire the surroundings. Inside the temple, there is a Museum of Church Art with unique collections of attributes of church life. Locals love spending time in Parque El Arenal, where there is an Ethnographic and Folklore Museum with collections of Indian household items. Flora and fauna lovers should definitely visit the Biocentro Guembe. Here, under a giant net dome, is located the world's largest butterfly nursery. And, of course, nobody will leave indifferent by the wealthiest collection of orchids that the park is famous for. By the way, all necessary infrastructure is created for visitors: hotels, bungalows, tent towns, cafes, and restaurants. The city also has the largest water park in Bolivia. 

Tarija

Tarija is another fascinating city in Bolivia. Once, traveling around the country, the nomadic Indians found a beautiful valley, which later was called Tarifa (translated as "happily found"). This is where they settled. The city is famous for its "bodegas" — distilleries that make excellent wines and win prizes at various competitions. As the city is close to the border with Argentina, there are parrilladas — establishments specializing in cooking different kinds of grilled meat. Many cafes and restaurants are located on the banks of the canyons, so after a delicious lunch, you can take a boat ride admiring the local beauties.

description.en: Venezuela is one of the most beautiful and wealthiest countries in terms of the volume of unique natural resources and mineral deposits. Snowy peaks of the Andes Mountains; the former piratic island of Tortuga; the jungly valley of the Orinoco River; golden beaches, coral reefs, and the most beautiful atolls; a pearl of the Caribbean Sea and a resort paradise — Isla de Margarita; incredible fauna and fantastic fauna — all of these can be found in Venezuela. The natural variety of the country attracts more and more tourists from all over the world here every year. Owing to its natural treasure, Venezuela is one of the fascinating countries in South America. The name of the county translates as “Little Venice”. The thing is that the houses of the Indians built on piles and standing in the water looked like the Italian town to the European colonizers. Nowadays, colonial architecture is the heritage of those times and another tourist attraction of Venezuela’s cities. But, we should say that the majority of tourists come here for the sake of the natural wonders.

geography.en: The Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela (the official name of the country) is located in the northern part of the South American continent. Its territory is so big that five or six average European countries could have easily fit here. It is washed by the Atlantic Ocean and the Caribbean Sea in the north, borders on Brazil in the south, with Guyana in the east, and Columbia in the west. Venezuela also owns forty large islands, more than seventy smaller ones, and almost two hundred reefs. The country is figuratively divided into four regions: the Andes, Guiana Shield, the hot plains of Los Llanos that spread through the whole state, and valleys of Mérida with numerous coffee plantations that grow the high-grade coffee. According to the administrative division, Venezuela consists of 23 states and one federal Capital District of Caracas. States are grouped into nine regions.

long_description.en:
Caracas

Caracas is the capital of Venezuela, its heart, the ancient and modern city at the same time. It grew on the place of the settlement of the Indian tribe “caracas” that was destroyed by the Spaniards in 1567. The old colonial site of Caracas was practically destroyed during the oil crisis in the XX century. Back then, the giant skyscrapers used to grow here like mushrooms after the rain. However, you can still find plenty of fascinating architectural objects here. Thus, you can’t miss Caracas Cathedral at Bolivar Square; the house where Simón Bolívar was born, who was the liberator of the country from the Spanish domination; the Miraflores Palace; the Capilla de Santa Rosa where the independence of Venezuela was proclaimed; the National Pantheon of Venezuela. Besides, Caracas offers a diversity of museums with quite interesting and valuable collections.

Maracaibo

Maracaibo is the second in size city in the country. Till the beginning of the XX century, it had been a shabby provincial township. However, when deposits of oil and gas were found here, it transformed dramatically. Many industrial corporations, a port, airport, contemporary multi-storied quarters appeared in the city. At the same time, Maracaibo has some colonial buildings in an excellent state — the XVII-century Basilica of Our Lady of Chiquinquirá and neo-Gothic Saint Barbara Church. The Palace of the Eagles and Plaza de Toros Monumental for fifteen thousand spectators also attracts plenty of tourists. However, the majority of travelers head to Lake Maracaibo in the first place. They aspire to see the famous Catatumbo lightning that occurs 150 times per year in the estuary of the same-name river that flows into the lake. The local citizens call this extraordinary natural phenomenon “the Lighthouse of Maracaibo”. Usually, you can observe it during the raining season when it’s dark. However, it may also occur throughout the year. The best way to admire the flashes of lightning is to stay in the Indian house built on piles or simply lay in the hammock (they are hanging between the trees here), and… wait. 

Coro

Coro is the former outpost of Venezuela’s colonization and its first capital. The architectural and historical monuments in a good state of preservation helped to include the city to the UNESCO List of World Heritage Sites. Colorful houses, bricked streets, the famous House of the Iron Windows, Balcón de Los Arcaya, Treasure House, and the oldest Jewish cemetery on the South American continent — the ancient city offers all of these and more to every traveler. You can wander around Coro for days come across fascinating sites, buildings, and attractions literally at every corner. 

Ciudad Bolívar

Ciudad Bolívar is one of the centers that participated in the struggle for independence at the beginning of the XIX century. That’s why it bears the name of Simon Bolivar. Nowadays, it’s a large industrial center and a river port located on the right bank of the Orinoco River. The historical center offers colonial buildings in a good state of preservation: San Isidro House Museum with a marvelous park, an ancient house of the governor, a former building of a prison, the XIX-century Cathedral. In Ciudad Bolívar Airport, you can see the restored Jimmie Angel’s plane parked forever in front of the building. He was the one who discovered the tallest waterfall in the world. Angel Falls is 979 meters in height. During the raining season, it transmits 300 thousand liters of water every second. However, at the same time, Angel Falls is also an almost inaccessible waterfall on the planet. It’s a real challenge to reach it — there are no roads or hotels nearby. However, this fact doesn’t stop all the adventure-seekers who are ready to overcome all the difficulties to admire it. 

Isla Margarita

Isla Margarita is a genuine pearl of the Caribbean Sea. It received this nickname not only for the abundance of pearls in the nearshore zone but also for several hundred kilometers of golden beaches, pure water, tropical forests, mountains, waterfalls, and rivers. It seems that the comparatively tiny territory of the island gathers everything one may desire for a marvelous vacation. The tropical climate, the average year-round temperature of +30, and plenty of sunny days create perfect conditions for full relaxation. This place attracts fans of surfing, windsurfing, and kiting as there are winds of the required intensity almost the year-round. Experts explain that this happens due to the particular direction of the circulation in the atmosphere. Moreover, guests can try horse-riding expeditions, cycling, flying on hydroplanes, sea fishing, and fascinating excursions. In addition to that, it’s hard to resist the tax-free zone. In other words, Margarita can steal a way into the heart of every tourist once and forever.

description.en: Guyana is one of the world's least-visited countries in South America. Various European peoples have tried to colonize it three times. In the end, the British did so and built their world with their usual pedantry. When the colonizers left (in 1965), Guyana's development stopped. Even the capital city has no buildings higher than three floors. Now it is a poor, extremely superstitious state, where you can still see unusual magical rituals. And at the same time, it is a religious state where every Sunday its citizens diligently attend church. There are no indigenous people in cities — they live in forests and most often lead a nomadic life. The main Guyanese wealth is unique nature. Virgin forests occupy almost 80% of its territory, and the abundance of water arteries provides the necessary humidity for the life of rare species of birds, animals, and plants. This country is a leader in the number of waterfalls, rivers, and lakes. It is not for nothing that in the language of one of the indigenous tribes, Guyana stands for "big water". But there are no seaside resorts here. Guyana's coastline is marshy and covered in mangroves, and excellent beaches are rare. One of the best beaches is Shell, which is 140 km long and is home to eight species of sea turtles.

geography.en: Guyana is located on the north-eastern coast of South America. Its neighbor to the east is Suriname, Venezuela to the west, Brazil to the south, and the Atlantic Ocean to the north. The country is situated in the eastern part of the Guiana Shield, with a hilly surface. A heavily swampy area stretches along the coast of the Atlantic Ocean. In some places, its width reaches up to 100 km. Guyana's highest point is Mount Roraima (2875 m). The largest rivers are the Essequibo, Courantyne, Berbice, and Demerara. The largest waterfall in the country and the world is Kaieteur Falls (226 m). It is almost five times higher than Niagara. The Co-operative Republic of Guyana consists of 10 regions. The President is the Head of State.

long_description.en:
Georgetown

Georgetown is the capital and a major port of the country. The city has no beaches, and it is not desirable to swim in the ocean. Its coastline is swamped with household waste, and it has boggy soil with an abundance of rivers carrying garbage into the ocean. Since the metropolis is situated below sea level, there are no burial grounds. Graves are elevated above the ground. The population of Georgetown compiles almost one-third of the state. It used to be a center of piracy and the slave trade. At various times, it was owned by the French, Dutch, and English, which affected its architecture. There are many striking temples of different confessions. One of the main attractions is St. George's Cathedral. According to the Guyanese themselves, it is the highest cathedral in the world, built of wood (43 meters in height). However, this is not true. The zoo and botanical garden also deserve your attention. Here you can see a unique, water lily — Victoria amazonica. Its flower exudes the scent of pineapple and banana, and the diameter of the plant leaf can exceed 2 meters and can withstand a weight of 30 kg. 

Linden

Linden is the second-largest settlement in Guyana, located on the Demerara River. It is home to miners who extract bauxite. It became a city in 1970 by merging three villages. Its population is about 30 thousand people. About 26 km from Linden, there is Gluck Island, which attracts scientists from all over the world. They come here to observe the unusual lily - Victoria amazonica (regia), as well as rare species of birds, animals, and plants in the natural environment. Here you can see exotic macaws, caymans, and giant otters.

New Amsterdam

New Amsterdam is a large port on the Atlantic coast, off the east bank of the Berbice River. At the beginning of the last century, it gained fame as a resort but lost this status later. Today, there are several resort towns in the vicinity of New Amsterdam. First of all, there are river sites like Rosignol and Mara, while the sea ones (Almond Beach and Shell Beach) are about 100 km away. Although the city is the third-largest in the country, it is, in fact, a small town with three main roads and well-developed agriculture. Some of its main attractions are the Town Hall and Public Hospital buildings, as well as the ruins of Fort Nassau.

Bartica

Bartica is a mining town on the left bank of the Essequibo River, founded by an English missionary. It is from here that tours to Kaieteur Falls, the national park of the same name, and the savannas of Roraima go. Not far from the city are the ruins of the oldest Dutch fort in the country, Kyk-Over-Al, where you can take a ferry to the famous Marshall Falls. This place attracts kayaking and rafting enthusiasts as well as fans of other water sports. During the Easter weekend, there is a regatta in Bartica. Many entertaining events accompany the holiday. They include a talent show, during which Miss Bartica is chosen, and a colorful street parade. 

Lethem

Lethem is a small town located on the Takutu River, near the border with Brazil. It has mixed colonial architecture and has gained fame thanks to one of its inhabitants. In the century before last, one of the cowboys moved here, who managed to inspire the locals with his love for rodeos. Soon, the competition became a tradition and an annual celebration. Now, during the Easter weekend, the famous rodeo in Lethem is visited by participants and guests from all over Latin America. In addition, there is ecotourism in the vicinity of the town, including horseback riding in the unspoken beauty of the savannas with numerous springs and groves. The townspeople are proud of their own Museum of Anthropology, as well as the Rupununi Weavers Society Museum, which displays the history of the indigenous people.

description.en: Without exaggeration, Colombia is a unique country that has been able to preserve the mysteries and riddles of antiquity to this day. In the impenetrable jungle of the Amazon, where no man has set foot, there are still rare plant and animal species. Only the "red-book list" of the latter is approaching six hundred points. Indeed, the damage caused to local nature by mining (mainly oil) is also enormous. By the way, it is in Colombia where over 90% of all emeralds in the world are extracted. The tribes of Indians known as Ticuna, Maku, Inga, Sicuani sill live here, as well as hundreds of years ago, in unison with nature, fishing, hunting, and farming. There are only about 60 tribes. According to rough estimates of scientists, each of them has not more than a thousand people.

long_description.en:
Bogota

Bogota is both the capital and the largest city in Colombia. It is often called the city of extremes. Masterpieces of magnificent colonial architecture stand next to super modern skyscrapers and dirty huts. The narrow streets climbing the mountain slopes are equally indifferent to luxury cars and mule driven carts. It has many pocket thieves and drug dealers, but at the same time, Bogota amazes with the number of museums. It is a museum of gold and emerald, with the zest represented by a 265-carat crystal. Moreover, there are national, archaeological, religious art, maritime, numismatics displays. Besides, the city has several houses-museums of outstanding Colombians: Simon Bolivar and Gabriel Garcia Marquesa. People in Bogota treat their historical heritage very reverently. For example, if the owner of an ancient building preserves and maintains its original appearance, he is exempt from paying taxes. In 50 kilometers from the capital, you will find the unusual cathedral carved in salt rock. Its vault and walls covered with salt crystals create an absolutely fantastic atmosphere. The temple can accommodate up to ten thousand people at a time.

Medellín

Medellín is a former mining village that today has grown to be the second-largest and most important city in Colombia. It is also called the "City of Eternal Spring" because of its comfortable climate, and the "Silver Bowl" because seven picturesque hills surround it. Medellin is always ready to offer its guests the most exciting things. There are beautifully preserved buildings from the colonial era — the Basílica de Nuestra Señora de Candelaria and the Metropolitan Cathedral, known as the largest bricked church in South America. The inhabitants are proud of the famous Botanical Garden with its unique collection of orchids and the 175-meter high needle-shaped tower, symbolizing the achievements of the textile industry. And of course, Medellin is known for being the place where Pablo Escobar had founded and had been ruling his bloody drug business for almost a quarter of a century. You can even see the slums where the drug lord ran his business. It is true that now the authorities are doing everything to make this page of history forgotten. The original system of escalators and the ropeway made life much easier for slum residents glued to the mountain slopes. Schools, libraries and theatres have been opened here — the interests of young people have gradually shifted from wars between groups to sports.

Cartagena

Cartagena is a port city on the shores of the Caribbean Sea, also known as "Latin American Venice". The date of its foundation is considered 1532, when during the "gold rush", it was through its port that gold and gems were exported to Europe. At that time, these waters were dominated by the Flibustiers. That's why Cartagena is an extremely fortified city. The walls of one of the local fortresses are 12 meters thick. The Palace of Inquisition, with its exposition of instruments of torture, and Las Bovedas prison, which now houses a shopping center, are well preserved. And the former convent of Cartagena now houses a history museum. The Rosario and San Bernardo Corals National Natural Park is 40 kilometers away from the city, where tourists can see picturesque beaches and the only underwater park in the country. For scuba enthusiasts, the island of Baro has become a real magnet, with its diving center and a beautiful coral garden. 

Cali

Cali has been an unremarkable quiet town for quite a long time. But nowadays, it is the third-largest metropolis in the country, dynamically developing due to coffee and sugar production. And Cali is also called the "capital of salsa", the most popular Latin American dance. You can watch its performance, or even take a couple of lessons in the numerous salsa-halls. And if you're lucky, you can get to the annual festival, where the best city dance schools are presented. The handmade monuments of the city are also worth seeing. First of all, these are the temples of the XVI century and numerous ancient hacienda mansions. It is also worth visiting Cerro de Las Tres Cruces, which offers a stunning view of the city. And on Easter, it becomes a traditional pilgrimage site.

Popayán

Due to the abundance of perfectly preserved mansions painted in light colors, Popayan is often called the "white city". It has managed, better than many others, to keep the appearance of the colonial period as if it had stopped the running of time. And now visitors of the city can admire the many ancient churches - Iglesia de Santo Domingo, Iglesia de San Francisco, Iglesia de La Ermita, and the Convento de San Agustín. This city is also home to one of the oldest universities in the country, founded in 1827. You should also visit the museums, including the natural history, colonial and religious art, as well as the museum devoted to the poet Guillermo Valencia.

Barranquilla

Barranquilla is the sea and air gate of the country. Port city and the cradle of Colombian aviation. This is where the first airport in South America appeared, and the famous Colombian coffee begins its journey around the world from the seaport. But the real hallmark of the city is the world-famous carnival El Joselito. It is held four days before the Great Lent. At this time, Barranquilla attracts a huge number of Colombians and tourists from all over the planet. After all, this carnival is called one of the most spectacular events on the planet, not worse than the famous festival in Rio de Janeiro. By the way, there is a lifetime monument to Shakira, because the famous singer is from Barranquilla.

description.en: Paraguay is a poor country with a rich history and luxurious nature. It is worth coming here to stroll through the streets of Asunción, admiring ancient mansions and temples, to buy amazing Indian artwork of artisans and to enjoy the taste of real mate. In this country, you can take a break from civilization in the virgin forests of national parks, on the shores of the huge Ypacaraí lake, or by the Monday's Falls. You can also marvel at the greatness of modern technical thought by visiting the world's largest hydroelectric power plant, the Itaipu Dam. Along with the ruins of Jesuit monasteries, Paraguay is home to one of the largest shopping centers in the world, Ciudad del Este.

geography.en: The Republic of Paraguay is a state in South America that shares borders with Bolivia in the north-west, Brazil in the north-east, and Argentina in the south and south-west. The country has no access to the sea. The Paraguay River crosses the country from north to south and flows into the Paraná River on its border with Argentina. The lands that lie to the east of the Paraguayan River (Paraneña) are fertile and inhabited by a majority of the population; to the west of the river stretches the Gran Chaco desert, which covers almost 60% of the country's total area. Approximately 95% of the country's population is mestizo from mixed marriages between local Guaraní Indians and Spaniards.

long_description.en:
Asunción

The capital of Paraguay is Asunción. It is not only the largest city in the country but also its cultural and educational center. In the capital itself and its closest surroundings, you will find the largest number of attractions of Paraguay, ancient churches and monasteries. The central part of the city has preserved the style of the medieval period. Here you will see the beautiful Presidential Palace, the majestic National Pantheon of the Heroes, and examples of colonial architecture. In addition, the city is very green. You can find parks, squares, palm alleys at every step. In shopping malls and markets of Asunción, you can buy a variety of products of local artisans — unique lace, hand-embroidered national clothes, fine leather, silver, and wood products. Cafés and restaurants in the city offer many delicious dishes of national cuisine and, of course, the famous Paraguayan tea mate.

Ciudad del Este

The second-largest city of Paraguay is Ciudad del Este (Eastern City), with over 300,000 inhabitants. It is located on the banks of the Paraná River, near the borders of Brazil and Argentina. Ciudad del Este is a duty-free zone and is actually one large market. Its entire economy is trade-oriented, which is why the city is often referred to as "South American Hong Kong". It was founded in 1957, although it was initially called Puerto Flor de Lis. Then dictator Stroessner "gave" his name to the city, and only since 1989, it has its present name. Unlike other cities in the country, Ciudad del Este is multinational. The majority of its population is made up of foreigners, primarily from Asian countries: Koreans, Thais, Arabs, Iranians. Accordingly, one can find mosques and pagodas in the city. And the main local attraction is a huge Friendship Bridge, connecting the Brazilian and Paraguayan banks of the Parana River. It is worth visiting Ciudad del Este, at least for shopping. Everything is much cheaper here than in other South American cities.

Encarnación

Encarnación is a city that is close to the Argentine border. It was founded in 1615. Every year in February, a colorful festival is held here. Moreover, festive processions are held every Sunday of the month. There are several old colonial-style buildings in the city. The city park is also of interest, which is dedicated to migrants who came to Paraguay from different countries. There is, for example, an Italian piece of land and a small Japanese park. But the main attractions are located near the city. These are the Jesuit missions Misión Jesuítica de la Santísima Trinidad and Jesuit Mission of Jesús de Tavarangüe, both of which are on the UNESCO World Heritage List. One of them is located 28 km away and the other 31 km from Encarnación.

Caacupé

The city of Caacupé, located in the southern part of the country, is known for its unique Catholic temple - the Cathedral Basilica of Our Lady of Miracles. It is one of the main sanctuaries of Paraguay, which is visited by about a million pilgrims annually. According to legend, in this place, in 1600, the Virgin Mary presented herself to one of the local Indians. The cathedral was visited by Pope John Paul II and the present Pope Francis.

Itaugua

Itaugua is a small town, but it' s quite remarkable in its own way. Firstly, it is famous for being the birthplace of many famous people in Paraguay — artists, musicians, singers, and poets. Secondly, Itaugua is the capital of Paraguayan nandutí lace weaving. The name itself translates as "cobweb". And these lace is really so thin that it looks like a spider web, and besides, they are also colored!

description.en: Peru is one of the most beautiful countries in South America. Sprawling on the slopes of the Andes, stretching on the Pacific coast, it attracts tourists. The heritage of the Inca Empire is its main attraction. The giant pyramids that were built thousands of years ago, the legendary Inca trail, the mysterious hieroglyphs used on the desert surface, the world's largest city made of clay — all these intrigues and fascinates travelers. And of course, the nature that amazes visitors with its diversity — from mountain peaks, canyons, and glaciers, to lush tropical forests on the Amazon shores and beautiful beaches of the Pacific coast.

geography.en: Peru is the third-largest country in South America. It shares borders with Colombia, Brazil, Ecuador, Chile, and Bolivia. According to the administrative division, Peru consists of 25 regions. Geographically, it is divided into four natural zones. The first is the coastal zone, or "Costa". It has a comfortable temperature from +16 °C to +25 °C almost all year round. Though "Costa" is very poor in terms of vegetation, the diverse animal world adds charm to this region. Here you can find flamingos, penguins, and even sea lions. However, for this area (which, by the way, involves the capital Lima) is characterized by a very unusual type of precipitation - very thin drizzle, "garua". It complicates the life of the metropolis. The Andean zone or "Sierra" is the next zone. The temperature range is from +5 °C in winter to +20 °C in summer. The "pune" begins above the level of 3.5 thousand meters. It is a zone of highlands, with a characteristic harsh climate and sharp daily temperature differences from + 28 °C during the day to -12 °C at night. The peaks are covered with eternal ice, mountain sickness, avalanches, and other "delights" attract lovers of active and extreme rest here. And, the Amazon Valley is the fourth geographical zone of Peru. "Selva" is a real paradise for lovers of a hot and humid tropical climate, as well as for biologists and zoologists who study the rarest and most endangered species of flora and fauna.

long_description.en:
Lima

For obvious reasons, tourists get to know Peru from Lima. The capital of the state rightfully takes the leading role in the business life of the country. It is a modern city that whimsically combines the latest achievements of civilization and traditions of the ancient Indians. In its streets, skyscrapers made of glass and concrete stand next to wooden huts, and business suits of clerks with colorful traditional clothes. The unusual relief of Lima is one of its main features: its slopes, steep cliffs, and hills. The historic center of the city is a real monument of the Spanish colonial era, which is added to the UNESCO World Heritage List. The Presidential Palace, the catacombs of Saint Francis Monastery, the Cathedral are the real tourist Mecca of the capital. The value of real estate here is calculated in millions of dollars. Lima is also called a megalopolis of beaches, and there are more than five dozen of them here. 

Cusco

Cusco is the capital of the ancient Inca Empire, which is the most visited by tourists. The famous mountain lake Titicaca Near is located near the city. It is surrounded by a thousand legends, mysteries, and fables. According to them, it was from the waters of Lake Titicaca that the first Incas came to shore and founded the city of Cusco. The conquistadors spoke with admiration about the beautiful town, with gold and silver temples, about the water pipeline, about the magnificent stonework. The new modern houses still stand on the remains of their foundations. This is what attracts tourists today — a mixture of new and old, which has become a unique style peculiar only to this country. When you are in the heart of the city, on the Plaza de Armas, you should see the magnificent colonial-style buildings and the majestic Cathedral with its black Saviour statue. The San Blas slope is another scenic spot. This is almost a vertical street with numerous souvenir shops, craft workshops, and exhibition salons.

Machu Picchu

The main highlight is located near Cuzco. It is the ancient town of Machu Picchu, one of the most mysterious places on Earth, belonging to the "New Seven Wonders of the World". Due to its remoteness, it was not destroyed by conquistadors, and its stone walls could not be damaged by earthquakes or landslides. And yet, science has not been able to unravel the main mystery of Machu Picchu, the reason for the puzzling disappearance of all its inhabitants until now. 

Trujillo

Trujillo is another beautiful city in Peru, located on the Pacific coast. The culture of the ancient Indians, intertwined with the colonial style, made this city truly unique. There is another tourist attraction in Peru less than 10 kilometers from Trujillo, the ruins of Chan Chan, once considered to be the capital of the Chimu Indians. Excursions to the ancient pyramids of the Moon and Sun are another must-see during your stay here. Besides tourists, surfers from all over the world are also more than happy to come here.

Iquitos

Iquitos is the administrative center of the Loreto region, the largest city in the Peruvian Amazon. Surrounded by impassable countryside, it is interesting for its unique and inimitable nature. The town owes its origin on the map of Peru to the so-called "rubber fever". The extraction, processing, and trade of the rubber tree juice gave a sharp boost to its development in the XIX century, and oil deposits were discovered in the XX century. However, most of the historical monuments here date back to the times of "rubber fever", when rapidly becoming wealthy planters tried to impress the imagination of their neighbors, building fabulous mansions. The so-called Iron House" is, perhaps, the brightest of them. The famous Gustave Eiffel designed this building. Less than 50 kilometers from the city, there are two natural attractions at once - the Ayapuayo-Mishana National Reserve and the butterfly farm. By the way, there are many medicinal plants, from which local pharmacists produce various drugs in the tropical forests around Iquitos.

Arequipa

Arequipa, Peru's second-largest city, is located in the mountainous area at the foot of a sleeping volcano. It is so compact that most of its attractions can be accessed even on foot, using the services of local taxi drivers only occasionally. The Arequipa attracts not just tourists, but also fans of outdoor activities such as climbing and rafting. There is a Valley of Volcanoes nearby. This is a place of pilgrimage for tourists attracted by a peculiar "lunar" landscape of the area. Travelers bring products made of alpaca wool and vicuña from Arequipa - here they are of the highest quality.

description.en: Suriname is a small country on the north-eastern coast of South America, famous for its wide variety of flora and fauna. This exotic and completely unique part of the world is ideal for those who need not just sunbathing on a chaise lounge chair. Here you can make friends with wild animals, wander through the thickets of tropical forests, take a boat ride under the starry sky, and drink a glass of rum with the locals. Paradise beaches, cozy restaurants, and breathtaking views are always at your service. Holidays in Suriname is an explosive cocktail of extreme and romance that will spin the head of any tourist. It also offers the opportunity to feel like an explorer and turn your holiday into a little adventure.

The Eastern Republic of Uruguay is a small country in South America. There are no loud headlines about this country in the morning newspapers, there are no world-famous historical monuments, and tourists do not stick around, hurrying to get acquainted with more famous neighbors. And we say that they are doing it in vain. Uruguay is hospitality and buzzing holidays, delicious cuisine and vibrant flea markets, picturesque Atlantic coast, and fantastic colonial culture. If you have a chance to spend at least a weekend here, you should agree! You will be pleasantly surprised.

geography.en: Compared to neighboring Brazil and Argentina, Uruguay is a small country. The coastline, washed by the waters of the Atlantic Ocean, is 660 kilometers long. On land, the border stretches for 1564 kilometers. Territorially, the country is divided into 19 departments; each of them consists of municipalities. There are four distinct tourist regions in Uruguay as well: the ethnically colorful Northern one, the calm and agricultural Central area, the Rio de la Plata region in the southwest of the country, which is the main tourist Mecca, and the harmonious Atlantic coast.

long_description.en:
Montevideo

The river plate of Rio de la Plata is decorated with the capital Montevideo, a stronghold of Europe in the middle of the Latin American continent. It is ornamented by Spanish colonial architecture and the cobblestone Old Town. Here you can admire fluffy palm trees resembling frozen salutes in the air, lush greenery of parks and squares, and marvel at the quiet rhythm of life, which is not so typical for a capital. Tourists with cameras and open mouths wander from the luxurious Salvo Palace to the symbol of democracy Palacio Legislativo; from the red walls of the Pittamiglio Castle to the Gothic towers of the Church of the Carmelites; from the national shrine - the Church of Victory to the top of the Cerro de Montevideo hill. The feet trampled on tours of museums, cathedrals, and theatres, all you have to do is dive them into the sea and lay your body on a sandy beach, then drink a couple of cocktails at the local bar and the feeling that Montevideo has settled in your soul forever will not leave. 

Salto

Salto is the second-largest city in the country, which attracts tourists not only with the bustling parties and glamorous nightlife but also with the incredible surrounding scenery, picturesque lagoons, majestic hills, lush green fields. There is a fleur of citrus, watermelon, and grape plantations constantly floating over Salto. This city has no unique architecture or long lists of historical monuments; tourists come here exclusively for the healing thermal springs. One of the most famous is the resort of Fuente Salto, opened on the banks of the Uruguay River. Termas del Arapey in the district of Salto is also popular, where wealthy Argentinians, Brazilians, and Paraguayans come for treatment. After procedures at thermal resorts, we recommend taking a walk in the picturesque Solari Park of the city and having a rest on local beaches.

Paysandú

Breweries, sugar factories, woolen fabrics and citrus productions, harvesting eucalyptus raw materials — Paysandú has dutifully taken over the responsibilities of the industrial center of the country. Despite its businesslike character, tourists here will have a quiet and measured rest. The excursion program includes visits to the Basilica of Our Lady of the Rosary and St. Benedict of Palermo, the Florencio Sanchez Theater, Constitution Square, and the Old Cemetery. And if you are lucky enough to come to Paysandú during Easter, make sure you attend the internationally-renowned Beer Festival. 

Tacuarembo

Tacuarembo is a northern city that attracts tourists with its unique historical attractions. The peaceful, idyllic Tacuarembo is the cultural center of the country and home to many famous writers, artists, and musicians. The Plaza Colon, Plaza 19 de Abril and Plaza Bernabe Rivera, the Saint Fructuosus Cathedral, and the Indian and Gaucho Museum are considered to be outstanding historical and cultural monuments. The city is also famous for its many festivals, the most popular of which are the Gaucho Culture Days in March and the Tango Festival in June.

Punta del Este

You should go to Punta del Este for a luxury beach holiday. It is a prestigious seaside resort, comparable in luxury to Spanish Marbella. There are practically no historical sights, but comfortable hotels and apartments are in excess. Surfers love Punta del Este for the excellent waves that drive the ocean current to the coast all year round. Fashionistas come for affordable, compared to Europe, shopping and chic products made of natural leather and fine wool yarn. Young people visit for loud nightlife and the Wine Festival, which is held here every year. And families with children love Punta del Este for its gentle coastline, the abundance of natural parks in the suburbs, and Lobos Island, where you can watch seals from a distance. 

Colonia del Sacramento

Colonia del Sacramento is a tiny town that preserves the romantic spirit of Portugal. Cobbled streets and mossy fortress walls, old cathedrals and cozy street cafes, art galleries, and a lighthouse that has seen many views — this port city will easily charm tourists tired of the bustling carnivals. And the effect is enhanced by the fact that the Colonia del Sacramento is considered to be one of the best places in Uruguay for beach holidays. The snow-white sands of Playa Ferrando and the purest water of the bay of Río de la Plata will delight fans of relaxation in the warm sun.

description.en: The Falkland Islands are an archipelago in the South Atlantic Ocean. It is a British Overseas Territory, the rights to which are being disputed with Argentina. The Falkland Islands consist of about 780 islands. Stanley is the capital city. The archipelago is a real animal paradise where endemics can be found. It is home to sheep, black-browed albatrosses, crested penguins, sea lions, orcas, dolphins, and whales. On the archipelago, you can see the traces of British battles with Argentina — minefields and burned helicopters. When visiting Stanley, it is worth checking out the Government house, where you can leave a note about your visit in a special guest book. Another important building in the Falkland Islands is Christ Church Cathedral. It is the southernmost Anglican cathedral in the world. Next to it is an arch of the jaws of two blue whales. It was erected in 1933 to mark the century of British leadership.

Chile is one of the most amazing and unusual countries in the world. It stretches along the Pacific coast of South America and combines scenic nature, incredible sights and exciting entertainment in its territory. There is a beautiful legend that after the creation of the world, God has the purest lakes and fascinating glaciers, high mountains and wild rivers, volcanoes, forests, beaches, fjords, valleys, and deserts. He gathered it all in one place — exactly where Chile is today. The country is visited by more than 2 million tourists every year, and this number keeps growing. You should come here to admire the natural beauties, to solve the mystery of the statues on Easter Island, to taste local cuisine, to walk through tiny villages, and bustling metropolises. Chile is a different world, and every tourist can be part of it for at least a short while.

geography.en: The Republic of Chile is located in southwestern South America. It looks like a long narrow strip on the map, which borders the Andes on one side and the Pacific Ocean on the other. The length of the territory from north to south is 4630 km, from west to east - only 430 km. Argentina, Peru, and Bolivia are the closest neighbors of Chile. The Republic consists of fifteen regions, and each of them is divided into provinces and communities.

long_description.en:
Santiago

Santiago is the capital and one of the largest cities not only in Chile but also in all of South America. Many tourist routes start from here. The city is located in the zone of increased seismic activity and has already experienced more than 40 earthquakes. That is why not all the sights and historic buildings have survived to our time. However, here you can still walk around the Plaza de Armas, see the Governor's House, the Main Post Office, the municipality, the Royal Auditorium building, visit a performance at the Opera and Ballet Theatre, explore the city museums and appreciate the beauty of La Moneda Palace. Mount San Cristobal deserves special attention. You can reach it on foot, by cable car, or by taxi. There is the Metropolitano Park at the top of the mountain, a comfortable recreation area with outdoor pools, walkways, and a zoo. One of the features of Santiago is its unique administrative system. Prestigious and respectable regions are on the outskirts, not in the center. One of them is Bellavista, which is considered to be the most bustling and lively area and where restaurants, bars, and numerous nightclubs are concentrated.

Valparaiso

Valparaiso is a city of sailors and poets, the pearl of the Pacific Ocean, a paradise valley. Each of these titles reflects the features of the town, its free spirit, cheerful mood, and bright colors. Valparaiso is located on the hills, so it uses quite unusual public transport — funiculars. There are 15 lifts in the city, and some of them were built over 100 years ago. When coming to Valparaiso, tourists can enjoy the beach holiday, admire the surrounding nature, and visit local attractions. You can start exploring the area from the Hill of the Immaculate Conception, which offers a stunning view of the city. Beautiful houses with bright roofs and forged fences are another feature of this place. In Valparaiso, tourists should also visit the Fresco Museum, visit the Pablo Neruda houses, see the display of the Marine Museum, and walk around Plaza Sotomayor.

Talca

Talca is a small town, which can hardly be called attractive from the point of view of tourism. It will not offer you amazing monuments and world-famous sights. But Talca is a special city for every resident of Chile, because it is here, in 1818, the country gained independence. The attractions of the town include prestigious universities, the Cathedral, the unique Church of the Sacred Heart of Mary. Visiting the suburbs will also be a fascinating experience, especially in the Radal Siete Tazas National Park, where you can admire waterfalls, beautiful cypress groves, and unusual plants.

Iquique

Iquique is Chile's largest fishing port and has a unique free trade zone in addition to exciting sights. It is located in the northern part of the city and covers an area of 240 hectares. Prices for goods in this zone are 19% lower than standard, but one person can spend here not more than $1000. Besides shopping, Iquique offers its guests fantastic local museums, to stroll along Baquedano Street and to admire unusual houses with carved shutters, ornate verandas, and balustrades. The surrounding area is also worth seeing, especially the Atacama desert and the huge saltpeter factories that can be visited on tour.

Valdivia

Valdivia is one of the most beautiful cities in Chile, which attracts tourists with its picturesque nature. The city is located on four rivers, which means that the river walk is an obligatory point of the cultural program. During this tour, you can admire the Botanical Garden, see Teja Island, Austral University, and also visit the fish market. In addition, when you come to Valdivia, you should visit the German beer restaurant called "La Cerveceria Kunstmann", see the colony of sea lions on the waterfront, visit the neighboring towns of Niebla and Corral. If you plan a trip in the second half of February, you can get to the famous "Valdivian Night" — a brilliant performance with decorated boats, fireworks, and music.

description.en: Ecuador is the smallest country located in Central America. The state owes its name to the equator that crosses it in the north. However, the tiny size of Ecuador has not prevented it from becoming one of the continent's most interesting countries. It was here, five centuries ago, that the gentlemen of fortune and adventurers hurried to find El Dorado, a country where gold lies in the streets and children play with bullions and gems rather than stones. Nowadays, tourists are attracted by the magnificent nature, which amazes with its diversity of climatic zones and, as a result, a lot of opportunities for active recreation.

geography.en: The Republic of Ecuador is located in the north-western part of South America. It borders on Colombia in the north and Peru in the south and east. Geographically, the country is divided into a mountain zone, coast, the Galapagos Islands, and Amazonia. Here, mountain peaks and majestic Andean volcanoes neighbor the golden beaches of the Pacific coast, unique Galapagos islands and tropical jungles of the Amazon. Volcanoes, stretching into two mountain ranges and crossing the whole country, are also one of the state's attractions. They are called the Avenida, or Avenida of Volcanoes. They add a kind of extreme to a visit to Ecuador because there are about 200 earthquakes in a year. As for the administrative-territorial structure, modern Ecuador consists of seven autonomous regions. And each of them, in turn, is divided into provinces.

long_description.en:
Quito

Quito is the capital of Ecuador, located at the height of almost 3000 meters above sea level, in a picturesque valley on the Andean slope. Today, it is considered to be one of the most beautiful cities in South America. Its historic center was one of the first sites in the world to be inscribed on the UNESCO World Cultural Heritage List. It is the old part of the city, with its colonial buildings, that enjoys well-deserved attention of tourists. However, it would be best if you were in good physical shape to explore the city. The fact is that the streets of Quito are famous for their steepness, and after running up and down the avenues, not every tourist will have enough strength to admire the local sights. But, the Moorish-style Carondelet Palace, Plaza de la Independencia, and South America's oldest church, the Church and Convent of St. Francis, are must-see!

Guayaquil

Guayaquil, the country's largest city, is also its main commercial center. An international airport, oil processing plants, a seaport, and modern skyscrapers stand side by side with monuments of antiquity. There are lots of resorts for beach lovers. Machalilla National Park, with huge colonies of albatrosses and frigates, is of great interest. From June to September in the old port of Puerto López, you can watch whales. An excellent observation deck was equipped for this purpose.

Cuenca

Cuenca is Ecuador's third-largest city. Like Quito, it is listed by UNESCO for its unique historical colonial buildings. Cuenca is by right called the most beautiful city in the country. It is also a city of students, as it is home to several major universities, including the oldest one in the country. Cuenca has a famous hat factory, as well as many small businesses producing hats, which are supplied to almost all countries on the continent. Another highlight of the city is the hot springs, where you can find the entire SPA-empires. 

Riobamba

Riobamba is a real colonial town, with narrow, paved with uncut stone, streets and pastel houses. This is what gives the city its own unique flavor. There is a huge market on Saturdays, right in the streets, where you can buy everything - spices, herbs, food, animals, national clothes, and souvenirs literally. You should also check out the St. Peter Cathedral, the municipality, and Maldonado Park. 

Ambato

They call Ambato the "Garden-City of Ecuador". Oranges, peaches, apples, grapes, and strawberries are grown in the vicinity of this city. The city regularly hosts flower and fruit fairs. Tourists will be offered a glass of fragrant locally produced wine in almost every street cafe.

Galapagos Islands

The Galapagos Islands are often the main reason why people visit Ecuador. The archipelago of volcanic origin, consisting of 13 islands with a total area of about eight thousand square kilometers, is rightly considered the main attraction of the country. Tourists can also take yacht cruises, diving tours to underwater beauties, as well as walks around the islands. By the way, they have the status of the World Biosphere Reserve and are protected by UNESCO. Here you can meet giant Galápagos tortoises, sea iguanas, endemic species of penguins, sea lions. In coastal waters, one can meet sharks, whales, and orcas. Almost the entire territory of the Turtle Islands is part of the National park of Ecuador. An adult tourist will have to pay100 dollars to enter it while it is half cheaper for a child. After a visit to this place, the famous explorer Charles Darwin created his theory of evolution. And not the less prominent Thor Heyerdahl tried to find Inca treasures on the islands in the middle of the 20th century.

description.en: Algeria is a state in North Africa by the Mediterranean Sea. It borders Morocco, Mali, Mauritania, Niger, Libya, and Tunisia. The capital has the same name as the country. The Sahara Desert occupies most of the territory (80%). It is a rather free Muslim country, where women sit in parliament, drive cars, work as lawyers and doctors. Algeria offers tourists to travel by camel or jeep through the majestic Sahara, explore ancient cities and ruins, and get acquainted with the life and traditions of the Berber people. Despite the fact that the country is located on the Mediterranean coast, beach vacation here is not particularly developed, compared to the nearest neighbors. The best places to relax are the Turquoise Coast, where you can not only sunbathe lazily but also practice water sports, Palm Beach, Zeralda, Oran, and Jijel.

Angola is a country with enormous tourist potential. Paradise beaches stretch for 1650 kilometers, stunning landscapes, rich cultural traditions, and a great variety of flora and fauna — all this makes the former Portuguese colony very attractive to investors. This means that the country will meet the tourists with well-developed infrastructure and a decent level of service. Every year, the situation improves, gradually bringing this once underdeveloped country, even by African standards, to the same level as such leaders of tourism on the continent as South Africa, Namibia, and Botswana.

They actively mine diamonds in Botswana. But they are not its main treasure. What they really value here is its unique nature and wildlife. One-sixth part of the state is a reserved area. And it is not surprising, because the arid plains of the Kalahari Desert are as beautiful as swampy shallows, canals and green islands of the Okavango Delta. This country is Africa itself in a miniature. Governments strictly control the inflow of tourists to preserve its eco-balance. The price for a holiday here does not yield to the European level, but Botswana's beauty is worth every penny spent.

Gabon is a country in the west of Central Africa, which is among the most economically prosperous countries of the continent. Its bright and modern capital is often compared to Miami Beach. The National Museum of Arts and Traditions, the unusual wooden Church of St. Michael Nkembo, and the colorful market in the Mont-Bouët district are among the must-visit places here. The best resorts for beach holidays, water sports, and nightlife are Pointe Denis, Ekwata Beach, and the Cape Lopez area near Port-Gentil. You should also go to the mountainous peaks of Makokou to visit the nearby village of pygmies, ride mountain bikes and go rafting. There are 13 national parks in Gabon. They are open to the public and offer many unforgettable experiences.

The Republic of the Gambia in West Africa cannot boast of large size but has access to the Atlantic Ocean and as many as seven national parks. Its small capital Banjul is proud of the colorful Albert Market known far beyond the country; the epic 35-meter white stone construction called "Arch-22"; and the National Museum, which has a significant collection of archaeological and ethnographic artifacts. The trip on a pirogue to the bay of Oyster will become a bright impression. Here you can admire thousands of birds and go sport fishing. Resorts on the Atlantic coast of the country — Bakau, Kololi, Fajara, and Kotu — are famous for their excellent service, beautiful beaches, and golf courses. And you can learn more about the ancient traditions of the Gambian people in the Village Museum of Tangi.

Ghana is an unusual, colorful country in West Africa. During the day, locals wear heavy lockers on their heads in its streets, and in the evening, the light of neon signs and lanterns wraps everyone in endless nightlife until morning. People honor the memory of history and are proud of their liberation from colonialism, the symbol of which is the "black star"; they mine gold and gemstones and make coffins in the form of a bottle of Coca-Cola, an eagle, iPhone, corn, or spoon. The wealth of the country's lands has not helped it to gain wealth. But the locals, despite the surrounding smog, a huge amount of garbage and crumbling shacks, smile to all passers-by and are ready to help any tourist. Ghana is the place to start a journey into the world of West Africa, along with the rhythm of hiplife in headphones, the aroma of rich spices of local cuisine, and the freshness of lush greenery that surrounds the world's largest artificial lake.

geography.en: The Republic of Ghana is a member of the Commonwealth of Nations in West Africa. It borders Côte d'Ivoire to the west, Burkina Faso to the northwest and north, and Togo to the east. The waters of the Gulf of Guinea in the Atlantic Ocean wash the southern coast. Almost all of the country's territory is flat. In the east, there are mountains with the top of Afadja (885 m). In the north, forests and bushes transform into open savannahs with fertile soils.  It is in Ghana that Lake Volta, the largest in the world, is located. It was artificially created on the river of the same name, where the hydroelectric power plant now operates.Ghana is divided into ten regions, which includes 170 districts, with 40 urban formations and six metropoles.

long_description.en:
Accra

Accra is the capital and the largest city in the country. Its name translates as "ant". And it's not for nothing. Accra really does look like an ant town, literally and figuratively — with bustling streets and a unique flavor. The trademark of the city is the Independence Arch, on top of which is a black star. It reminds of the liberation of the country from the oppression of colonizers. On the outskirts of the city, in the poor district of Jamestown, many beautiful colonial buildings are adjoining the corrugated iron huts. There is also the ancient Osu Castle and Ussher Fort in the town. The nightlife on the streets of the capital buzzes until morning, and fresh coconuts are sold on every corner.

Kumasi

Kumasi is the royal city where the residence of the Ashanti dynasty is located. When tourists come here, the first thing they visit is the museum in the Manhyia Palace. It displays the collections of swords and armor, which tell about numerous victories of local tribes. In addition, the center features Wesley Methodist Cathedral and Kwame Nkrumah University of Science and Technology. A few kilometers from the city is the magnificent crater lake of Bosumtwi, with breathtaking scenery around it. 

Tamale

Tamale is a growing city with developed tourist infrastructure. A large number of new hotels and small inns have been built there, as well as financial companies, offices, and educational institutions. The city has a modern football stadium. 

Cape Coast

Cape Coast is nestled on the coast of the Gulf of Guinea around the castle of the same name. The symbol of the city is a crab, in honor of which a sculpture was erected in the main square. Every two years, Cape Coast hosts the Panafest Festival, dedicated to traditional music and dance.

Obuasi

Obuasi is the golden well of the country. In the vicinity of the city is one of the largest mines for this precious metal. The sights of the town include a mosque, Methodist church, local lake, several sports clubs, including golf courses. 

Teshie

The small town of Teshie is famous for its unusual workshop. It produces original coffins of all kinds of shapes and colors. The rest of the cities cannot boast of exciting sights.

description.en: The Republic of Guinea attracts travelers with the beautiful landscapes that characterize this West African country. The capital of the state is the port city of Conakry on the Atlantic coast. Next to it is the picturesque island group Ile de Los, an excellent place for picnics and beach holidays. But the main tourist bait of the country is the beautiful green plateau Fouta Djallon. People come here to climb Mount Loura, to get acquainted with the local flavor in the towns of Mamou, Dalaba, and Mali, to see the waterfalls of Kinkon Falls and Bafara. Explore the almost unspoiled nature of Guinea in the reserves of Mount Nimba and Badiar and the National Park of Upper Niger. The latter is home to the fishing village of Somoria, where tourists are offered to live in an authentic African house.

Egypt is a real paradise for those who love a "lazy" vacation. The local population knows how to satisfy the whims of fastidious tourists by offering them a holiday in the system of all-inclusive. The sun shines here all year round, and the sea is madly beautiful and always warm. The sea depths enchant with coral shelves and rich marine flora and fauna. Tombs of pharaohs, majestic pyramids, the mysterious Sphinx have kept Egypt a popular destination for many years.

geography.en: The Arab Republic of Egypt is a transnational state. It is situated on two continents: North Africa and the Sinai Peninsula in Asia. It also includes islands in the Gulf of Suez and the Red Sea. The Mediterranean Sea washes it in the north and the Red Sea in the east. It borders with Sudan in the south, Israel and the partially recognized State of Palestine in the north-east, and Libya in the west. Egypt's maritime borders are with Jordan and Saudi Arabia. The Suez Canal, owned by Egypt, allows ships to pass both ways between Europe and Asia, without bypassing Africa. The main ports of the channel are Port Said in the north and Suez in the south. The second-largest river in the world, the Nile, flows through the whole territory of Egypt and has become the cradle of ancient Egyptian civilization. More than ninety percent of the country's total population has lived in its coastal strip since ancient times to this day.

long_description.en:
Cairo

Start exploring the country from Cairo, the capital of Egypt. This city is of special importance to the Islamic world. It's often called the city of thousands of minarets. It's home to about ten million people. In Cairo, the branches of history are intertwined: modern skyscrapers do not create dissonance with ancient mosques. Cairo is roughly divided into two parts: historical and contemporary. The old city is located on the east bank of the Nile. There are practically no new buildings on its territory; it is an area of ancient mosques. But the modern part of Cairo does not differ from the usual urban landscapes. There are government buildings and office skyscrapers made of glass and concrete. 

Alexandria

Alexandria is the largest port city in Egypt, combining ancient Egyptian architectural structures and buildings in the Victorian colonial style. Comfortable beaches allow you to have a rest for the body, and rich culture offers attractions for the soul. Start exploring the city by visiting the National Museum, which is located in the center. The exhibits represent four historical eras: ancient, Greco-Roman, Coptic, and Islamic. Be sure to visit the catacombs of Kom el-Shouqafa. An unusual structure stores a whole network of funerary halls. The Pompey's Pillar — a famous monument of ancient times — is also popular with tourists. You should also admire the extraordinary architecture of the Egyptian Khedive's palace, the Abu al-Abbas al-Mursi Mosque and the Citadel of Qaitbay, built on the ruins of the lighthouse in Alexandria. 

Sharm El Sheikh

Lovers of comfortable holidays go to the famous Sharm El Sheikh — a beautiful resort on the coast of the Red Sea. It is nominally divided into several areas. Sharm el Maya is the Old Town, where the famous oriental Old Bazaar with all kinds of goods and souvenirs is located. There is a beach with a gentle entrance, which especially pleases travelers with children and those who can not swim. The Hadaba area is also home to a dolphinarium and water park, brand boutiques, and the prestigious Dolce Vita nightclub. The Naama Bay area is home to cozy outdoor cafes and restaurants, nightclubs, high-end shopping malls, and a casino. It's also known as "Arab Las Vegas." The renowned Cleo Park and the Promenade — a pedestrian walkway along the sea — are also situated here. Sharks Bay is 5 km from the airport and is famous for its hotels and diving center. Once you are at any of the beaches of the bay, you can see beautiful corals and many colored fish. So you should choose this area if you are planning to go snorkeling.

Hurghada

Hurghada is the place where the brilliant "career" of Egypt in the tourism business began. The construction of hotels in this area started in the 1980s and has not stopped until now. The dry climate all year round allows having a beach vacation almost without feeling the 40-degree heat. A flat entrance to the sea provides comfortable holidays with children. Those who will get tired of lying on the beach can go on excursions to the pyramids, in the Valley of Kings, or go scuba diving, surfing, and ATV racing. 

Marsa Alam
