Marsa Alam is a young resort, which many people have not yet heard of. It is located 300 km from Hurghada. The temperature here is a few degrees higher than in other resort towns. If recreation in Egypt always seems noisy and crowded, Marsa Alam is a quiet paradise. A small fishermen's settlement was located here not long ago. Nowadays, it is turning into a popular international resort. The main entertainment infrastructure is situated only in hotel complexes, but this does not prevent tourists from coming here and enjoying the warm waters of the Red Sea. Marsa Alam is also one of the best places in Egypt for kitesurfers.

Giza

When we hear about Giza, the imagination immediately draws the outlines of the Great Sphinx as well as the well-known pyramids: Cheops, Khafre, and Menkaure. The place is exciting because of the great history of ancient Egyptian burials. Not only the pharaohs, but also all their closest circle were buried here: wives, brothers, sisters, children, and servants. It's also worth coming here to see the Village of the Pharaohs. The tour starts with a barge ride along the canals. Moreover, Giza offers the largest zoo in Egypt, where the natural habitat for animals is created. 

Luxor

Luxor is the city that once housed the capital of Ancient Egypt, Thebes. The city contains numerous treasures and architectural monuments included in the UNESCO World Heritage List. The territory of the city is roughly divided into "City of the Living" and "City of the Dead". The "City of the Living" is a typical residential area, which occupies the right bank of the Nile. Tourists come here to see how ordinary Egyptians live and how the Luxor's temple looks like. "The City of the Dead" is located on the opposite side of the Nile. The wide diversity of archaeological sites beckons tourists. But you should mind that the climate here is hot enough, precipitation is a rare phenomenon, which is most often manifested in the form of dew.

description.en: Zambia is a landlocked country of South Africa. It is known for its largest waterfall on the mainland, Victoria, on its borders with Zimbabwe. Thousands of tourists come to the country for it to enjoy the beautiful views of the powerful flows of water falling down with iridescent highlights. Its lands are rich in precious metals and stones — gold, copper, emeralds, uranium, lead, and zinc. In national parks and reserves, you can feel like a wild savannah with elephants, tigers, giraffes, zebras, and other "must-see" participants of any safari tour. A trip to Zambia will be a real adventure in a world of southern and such an extreme Africa.

Cape Verde is one of the safest countries in Africa with a special Afro-European flavor. For several centuries, the archipelago has remained a colony of Portugal. Europeans gave it its name, the islands of Green Cape. Probably, in those distant times, they were buried in the green and now deserted "lunar landscapes" prevail here. You shouldn't be upset. It's quite a task to find seashores as beautiful as here. It's a small country where the ocean is of fantastic color. Its abysses offer great diving opportunities, and the windy weather raises the waves necessary for surfing and other water sports. There are an active volcano and unusual beaches with black sand. Seafood is cheap and always fresh. The locals are friendly and hospitable.

long_description.en:
Прая — столица и самый крупный город Кабо-Верде, расположенный на острове Сантьягу. Он известен как центр фестивалей в Африке. Наиболее известные — Международный фестиваль креольского джаза (в апреле), музыкальный фестиваль «Гамбоа» (в мае), Табанка — праздник святых, почитаемых в Кабо-Верде (в июле) и фестиваль Божьей благодати (в августе). В Прае можно посетить этнографический музей, прогуляться по площади Алехандро де Альбукерке с ее симпатичными домиками в колониальном стиле. А еще — увидеть в Старом городе первое европейское строение на архипелаге — крепость святого Филиппа. 

Минделу, расположенный на острове Сан-Висенти, входит в число красивейших туристических городов Кабо-Верде. Именно здесь родилась певица Сезария Эвора, принесшая некогда мировую славу своей стране. Город имеет статус музыкальной столицы. Кроме того, туристы получат здесь полный набор удовольствий: релакс на великолепных пляжах, активные водные развлечения, яркую ночную жизнь и, если повезет, участие в одном из фееричных местных карнавалов.

Сал — самое туристическое место среди островов Зеленого мыса. Его считают мировой столицей кайтсерфинга, благодаря постоянным сильным ветрам. Здесь занимаются дайвингом и спортивной рыбалкой, посещают питомник лимонных акул Shark Bay и рассматривают остатки затонувшего корабля. Уникальная достопримечательность острова — соленое озеро в кратере потухшего вулкана. Окружающие его пейзажи кажутся инопланетными, а вода в озере по своему составу почти такая же, как в Мертвом море. 

Остров Фогу привлекает одноименным действующим вулканом. Именно эта достопримечательность манит сюда туристов. Здесь можно подняться по тропе к кратеру и посетить вулканические пещеры. Интересен остров своим пляжем с черным песком. Он образовался в результате извержения лавы, которая была остановлена прохладными водами океана и распалась на мельчайшие песчинки.

Боавишта — один из крупнейших островов Зеленого мыса, наполняющий умиротворением. Здесь особенно прекрасны бирюзовая вода и бесконечные песчаные пляжи с белым песком, на которых обитают колонии черепах. На острове — великолепный дайвинг и серфинг. Кроме того, туристы не оставляют без внимания и древнюю пустыню, отправляясь туда на сафари.

description.en: Cameroon is a country that was discovered by Portuguese sailors in 1480. The event took place near the Wouri River, which flows in Central Africa. Travelers did not think long about the name. After they had seen lots of shrimp in the river waters, the name came right away — Rio dos Camarões. It was later transformed into "Cameroon", which literally means "the River of Shrimps". Today it is a major tourist center, which attracts by the fact that here you can see all the natural areas of Africa: evergreen forests, savannahs, and semi-deserts. Anyone who has visited Cameroon believes that this country is called Africa in a miniature. The locals love their guests and welcome them with pleasure. You will be told about ancient crafts and the love of football. They will show you the palaces of kings and sultans. They will also feed you with a delicious national dish called ndolé (stewed fish or beef with bitter herbs and nuts). You can only taste it in Cameroon. After visiting this country, the impressions are bright and ambiguous, just like Africa itself.

geography.en: Cameroon is located in the western part of Central Africa, in the embrace of the Bight of Bonny, part of the Gulf of Guinea of the Atlantic Ocean. The coastline stretches for 320 km. The country borders Nigeria, Chad, the Central African Republic, Gabon, the Republic of Congo, and Equatorial Guinea. Mount Cameroon, which rises to 4,095 m, is considered to be the highest point of the territory and is one of the most interesting sites for tourists. From the end of the XIX century until the end of the First World War (1918), Cameroon was a German colony. After the war, it was divided into two mandated territories, which were under British and French administration. In 1960, Cameroon became an independent state. It has two official languages, English and French. At the same time, there are at least a hundred dialects of local residents. The capital of the country is Yaoundé. The largest city is Douala. The population of Cameroon is approaching the mark of 25 million.

long_description.en:
Yaounde

A megapolis with a population of about two million people and the capital city of Cameroon. The Presidential Palace, the Gothic Church of N'Djong Melen, and the Palace of Atangana, the leader of one of the most influential African tribes in the country, are the first places to see. You can also visit the Cameroon Arts Museum, which houses a collection of weapons, ritual masks, and unique jewelry. To experience the local flavor and purchase souvenirs for friends and family, visit the Centre International de L'artisanat shopping mall. It's close to Kennedy Square.

Douala

It is the largest city in the country with the status of economic capital. It combines the beauty of ancient buildings with the luxury of modern constructions. Walk down Douala's main street, Boulevard De La Republique. Visit the picturesque promenade and bustling with urban vibrancy Craft Market in the Bonanjo district. The city has a Chinese Pagoda. It is building from the beginning of the XX century. You have to go to Government Square to see it. The Cathedral of Saints Peter and Paul, which was built in 1936, is considered to be the decoration of the city. The largest market in Cameroon — Eco Market — is also located here, and you can do great shopping.

Buea

This is a city with unique landscapes, 80 km from Douala. From here, you can climb Mount Cameroon (4095 m high). The excursion usually lasts for 3-4 days, but it is worth it. According to many people, this mountain is the main attraction in the country.

Bafoussam

That's the city where you can get acquainted with representatives of Bamileke people. They are divided into groups, each controlled by a headman. The world's Bamileke population exceeds two million people. Traditionally, these people are considered to be masters in the production of wooden utensils, including figurines and calebasses. The center of the diocese of the Roman Catholic Church is located in Bafoussam.

Maroua

There is a beautiful Waza National Park in the vicinity of this city. This place was glorified by poet Nikolay Gumilev ("Giraffe", "Lake Chad"). Here, in the area of 1700 km², buffalos, gazelles, warthogs, lions, leopards, hyenas, elephants, giraffes, antelopes live. Besides, you will see ostriches, cranes, ibises, owls, griffins. Moreover, all these animals inhabit the reserve in huge numbers. For example, it's no surprise to find a herd of 1,500 elephants here. All of this is against the backdrop of amazing nature and unique vegetation.

Bamenda

It's a big village where you can meet African handicrafts. All you have to do is visit a pottery factory. You will see how real masterpieces are born in the hands of artisans, from ordinary sand and black clay. The town of Bafut is located 20 km away from this settlement. It is a paradise for admirers of English naturalist Gerald Durrell. Here you will also find the Royal Palace with a guest house, where Darrell stayed during his expedition to pick up rare animals. Later he described these places in his works "A Zoo in My Luggage" and "Bafut Beagles". On the territory of the palace, one can also see one of the oldest buildings in Africa — Achum Shrine (it is over 600 years old). It is a place of prayer for the king and his entourage, as well as for his "beloved" wife.

Foumban

A tourist center where museums and shops are concentrated. It is located 200 km from the capital of Cameroon. Visit the Sultan Museum to see royal clothing, a collection of weapons, masks, and jewelry. The Museum of Arts also deserves a visit. There you will find items of national life. Craftsmen's stalls are nearby, where you can buy handmade souvenirs. Products made of wood are especially valued.

Kribi

This town has won fame as the best sea resort in the country. The distance to it from Yaounde is 270 km. Tourists are attracted by dozens of kilometers of golden and white sand, as well as many entertainment facilities on the Atlantic coast.

Limbe

This is another beach oasis surrounded by coconut palms on the coast of the Gulf of Guinea. Get ready to see the black sand. The reason for this unexpected phenomenon is Cameroon Volcano, located near the city. It is itself a spectacular sight.

description.en: The country got its name from the mountain range of Kenya. It is the second-highest mountain in Africa after Kilimanjaro. Having visited this mountain, lovers of aromatic coffee will be able to see with their own eyes how beans grow and fill with invigorating juices at numerous coffee plantations. Kenya is one of the main exporters of this product in the world. Tourists are also attracted by local rich natural reserves and clean white sand beaches stretching for 500 km along the country's coastline. Right on them are comfortable hotels with well-developed infrastructure, as well as many healthy and delicious restaurants. Kenya attracts with its endless vastness of wildlife where antelopes, giraffes, and zebras stroll. These are the best areas for a bright, memorable safari. It is interesting that many celebrities choose this destination for their honeymoon. For example, Ivanka Trump (the daughter of the 45th US President) and American actress Paris Hilton used to take a rest here. It is known that Queen Elizabeth II of Great Britain also adores Kenya. After all, it was here, during a short vacation, she received an offer of hand and heart from Prince Philip.

geography.en: The Republic of Kenya is a large state in East Africa, with a population of over 46 million people. Until 1963, it was a British colony. The state borders with Ethiopia, Somalia, Tanzania, Uganda, and South Sudan. In the western part of the country, there is the world's largest freshwater Lake Victoria. The total length of its coastline is over 7000 km. In the south-east, the Indian Ocean washes Kenya with its waves. In general, the water surface occupies more than 11 thousand km² of the 583 thousand km² of the total area of the state. Geographic areas of Kenya include the Lake Victoria Basin, the East African Rift Valley with adjoining mountain ranges, eastern plateaus, semi-arid and arid territories in the north and south, and the coast.Its earth interior contains a wide range of minerals: gold, rubies, and barytes. A few years ago, oil reserves were discovered in the north-western part. Kenya is developing most dynamically among all eastern African countries.The main features of Kenya are its wide long beaches and abundant wildlife with a stunning variety of birds and mammals. Over 450 species of animals and over 600 species of birds are officially registered here. A few decades ago, people used to hunt antelopes and elephants here, and as a result, their numbers decreased many times. Now it's strictly forbidden, and the animals are protected by law.

long_description.en:
Nairobi

It's the capital of Kenya and the biggest city in East Africa. It is home to the famous National Park. It is the only place where you can observe the life of lions, giraffes, and many birds in such close proximity to the metropolis. Safari walks in the park are popular among tourists. The Giraffe Centre (20 km from Nairobi) is also of great interest. Here you can feed these amazing animals from hand, pet, hug, and even kiss them. We recommend you climbing to the heliport, which is located on the roof of the second-highest building in Nairobi (163 m) and the third one in Africa, to take a picture of the city panorama. This is the Old Mutual Tower office complex. An hour's drive from the capital of Kenya is Naivasha, a rather deep freshwater lake that has become home to hundreds of birds and a huge population of hippos. Finally, to feel Kenya in all its manifestations, one cannot ignore the Kibera slum. They are just 5 km from the center of Nairobi, close to clean and cozy homes. They are the largest slums in Africa, home to over 500,000 adults and children.

Mombasa

It is the economic center and the second-largest city in the country. Here is located Fort Jesus, built in 1593, to protect against attacks by Turks and African tribes. It is ranked among the architectural masterpieces of the XVI century and is included in the UNESCO World Heritage List. The old part of Mombasa, consisting of narrow streets and Arab-style houses with open-worked balconies, deserves special attention. There are several dozen mosques in the city. The oldest of them, Mandhry (1570), is of the greatest interest. In ancient times, it was a lighthouse for ships. There is also the largest crocodile farm — Mamba Village Crocodile Farm — in Africa, where 12 thousand crocodiles of different ages live. Don't miss the Tsavo East National Park. However, it is located 200 km from Mombasa but is especially popular with tourists. It is the largest park in the world, where you can see animals of the "great five": an elephant, giraffe, buffalo, rhino, and a leopard.

Kisumu

Kisumu is the third-largest city in Kenya. It has an airport. Agriculture and shipbuilding are developed. Nearby is the Kisumu Reserve, where baboons and hippos live.

Nakuru

This town offers a fascinating Lake Nakuru National Park. Pink flamingos, black and white rhinos live here. Safari in this area is impressive — the lake often gathers over a million flamingos and pelicans. The surface of the water becomes entirely pink from the abundance of these beautiful birds.

Malindi

It is known for being visited by the famous navigator Vasco da Gama in 1498. On this occasion, a coral pole was erected, which can be explored. In addition, tourists are attracted by the buildings of the Old Town.

Narok

The largest national park in Kenya, Maasai Mara National Reserve, is located in the vicinity of this city. It stretches on one and a half thousand square meters, at an altitude of 1650 m above sea level. It is home to over 80 mammal species and four hundred various birds. A great number of lions especially attract the attention of tourists. You can see the beauty of the park only by jeep, accompanied by a guide. You can't go on foot. For those who do not save money on leisure, there is an option to travel by hot-air balloon.

description.en: Anyone who has eaten chocolate at least once in their life can say that they have tasted a delicacy from Côte d'Ivoire. And that's because this West African country is the largest cocoa exporter in the world. But only a couple of centuries ago, the country was a major supplier of elephant tusks. Until 1986, its very name had sounded like the Coast of Ivory. The barbaric extermination of these animals led to a critical decline in their population. Now elephants are protected in national parks and reserves, but there are still very few (less than 800). Another example of contrasts in Côte d'Ivoire is the presence of two quite modern capitals against a background of almost wild nature and other towns more like villages. The country, with four large universities and a significant French heritage, still has indigenous tribes. And the majestic ruins of the ghost town are peacefully nestled next to luxury hotels and lively beaches.

Lesotho is noticeably different from other African countries, primarily because of its mountainous terrain. The landscapes of this kingdom are breathtaking and very similar to the foothills of Tibet. One of the most exciting activities in Lesotho is fishing on the mountain rivers — masters of fishing from around the world come here to hunt trout. Many places will be of interest to fans of African history and culture. Moreover, most small towns of this country have preserved their unusual architecture, traditions, and lifestyles.

Libya is a state in North Africa on the Mediterranean coast. Its history dates back thousands of years, as its unique monuments indicate. For example, the oldest Acacus Mountains hiding in the Sahara desert, which rock paintings date back to 12 thousand years BC, and the ancient cities of Cyrene, Sabratah, Leptis Magna, keeping the memory of former glory. They are on the UNESCO World Heritage List. Picturesque landscapes, warm sea, and interesting sights make Libya attractive for tourism. However, it is among the world's most dangerous countries — armed conflicts have been taking place here for decades. In 2011, there was a revolution and then a civil war. Now the country is divided — people are eager to leave their homeland in search of a safe haven.

The small state of Mauritius is primarily associated with a wild African flavor and impassable jungle. But this island opens up with new colors, where nature remains untouched near modern cities. The unique natural wonder of a waterfall underwater, extinct volcanoes, and mountain peaks make the country an incredibly "rich" popular resort. The attractiveness and diversity of the underwater world attract the avid divers to the deep waters of the ocean, and couples in love aspire to a secluded wedding ceremony on a sandy shore. It seems that there are two worlds: the land world and the underwater world. In such magical places, you can forget about the city fuss and give in to the earthly and unearthly pleasures.

geography.en: The Republic of Mauritius is located in East Africa and is a group of small islands near Madagascar. This small country is washed by the Indian Ocean and is named after its largest island. The volcanic past of Mauritius has smoothed the relief, so now the land is mostly flat and fertile. However, there are several mountain ranges on the island with impressive green peaks. Next to the capital is the Moka mountain range with a peak on Pieter Both (818 m), and the most remarkable peak is called Piton de la Petite Rivière Noire, overtaking the previous one by 10 meters. The coasts are framed by coral reefs, which have made the island one of the main diving centers. In the heart of Mauritius lies the crater lake Ganga Talao (Grand Bassin), known for its sacred sacral status in Hindu culture. In the middle of the purest water, there is an island of God, which is absolutely no place to go. According to legends, one who steps on this sacred land is doomed to death. The largest water reservoir in the country is Mare aux Vacoas, a quiet and cozy harbor with stunning and even surreal views.The Republic of Mauritius is divided into nine administrative districts and the Outer Autonomous Islands (Rodrigues, North, South, and Ile des Deux Cocos).

long_description.en:
In addition to its natural beauties, the island attracts travelers from all over the world with its architectural sights and a wide selection of all kinds of entertainment. 

Port Louis

The island's capital, Port Louis, has preserved colonial-era buildings: the Government House, the Parliament House, the City Theatre, and the National Museum. The most popular place in the city is the colored land of Chamarel, where blue, brown, green, orange, purple, red, and yellow wave patterns have decorated the dunes of the frozen volcanic rock. Next to this magical attraction, surrounded by vibrant jungle, runs a waterfall of the same name. The city is well known to race lovers, as it has the oldest racetrack in the southern hemisphere — the Field of Mars. On a hill, overlooking the harbor is the citadel of Port Louis, a fort that was built in the 1930s to protect the city from the riots during the abolition of slavery. Today, various concerts and art shows are held here, and the stunning panoramic views are a great addition to the festival. Port Louis also can boast of its Sir Seewoosagur Ramgoolam Botanical Garden, where five hundred species of plants on display include nutmeg, magnolia, and even a tea tree from China. One of the most exclusive places to visit is the Blue Penny Museum, located in a beautiful old stone building near the Caudan Waterfront. It features stamps and many other interesting objects that tell the story of the Mauritius postal service. For a few hours a day, the most expensive stamp in the world, Blue Penny, is exhibited here, which every philatelist dreams of getting. The most visited attraction of the city is the huge local market. There you can find French shawls, Arabic carpets, and hot Indian spices. Due to its diversity and the combination of several vibrant cultures, the market attracts thousands of tourists.

Rose-Hill

Beau-Bassin Rose-Hill is the second-largest and most picturesque town in Mauritius. It blends European and Eastern cultures perfectly. The most popular place is the City Hall Plaza, where you can often witness a theatrical or musical performance or a wedding celebration. Rose Hill is also known as a student city, as it is home to the University of Mauritius, where thousands of students from around the country study. 

Mahebourg

In the south of the island, there is a small town of Mahebourg, at the entrance to which Chateau Robillard is located. Now it houses the Museum of National History with ancient engravings, maps, dishes, and pirate swords. In addition to ancient architecture, the city has a confectionery factory and an excellent photo deck to take pictures of the Grand Port mountain range, called Pointe Canon. Concerts are often held here, as well as annual ceremonies to celebrate the abolition of slavery.

Grand Baie

Grand Baie is a unique resort located in the north of the island. It is popular with young couples who come here to spend their honeymoon. It is also a favorite place for a relaxing family holiday. Grand Baie has many cafes and restaurants with exotic cuisine in the center, and the beaches are alluring with golden sand and emerald green water. 

Souillac

Souillac is a small village located on the rocky shores of Savanne district. It's worth going here to admire the beautiful nature of Telfair Garden, see the cliffs of Gris-Gris, with polished and unusual "stucco" of years of erosion, and admire the Rochester Falls. 

Curepipe

The city of Curepipe is situated in the center of the island. There is the largest stadium next to it, making the city's shops and restaurants almost always crowded during celebrations and competitions. People come to Curepipe for the extinct volcano of Trou aux Cerfs, which is nearby. Its crater is 85 m deep and almost 200 m wide.

Le Morne Brabant

The hammer-shaped peninsula of Le Morne Brabant on the west coast of Mauritius requires special attention. In addition to the rocky peaks and dense forests, there is a spectacular natural wonder — an underwater waterfall. This unique phenomenon fascinates with emerald water flowing from the coast deep into the ocean. In fact, this natural optical illusion is created by strong underwater currents. The landscape of the seafloor is formed by coral reefs flowing to the depths, which, along with the sand inundation, seem to be strong streams of a bubbling waterfall.

description.en: Madagascar is a paradise island that lies in the warm waters of the Indian Ocean. A hundred million years ago, the Mozambique Channel cut it off from Africa, leaving humanity a unique natural gift. The landscapes of the island are changing like kaleidoscope images, from wild relict forests in the north to the red desert lands in the south. The flat crowns of baobabs centuries-old nine-story high trees hold the sky, and the sharp spikes of the Tsingy de Bemaraha Strict Nature Reserve stone forest make your blood turn into ice. Sapphires, emeralds, and topazes are washed in muddy waters of the rivers. White-tailed sifakas hide from fossas on the tops of the tropical forest, and the ring-tailed lemurs, the distant relatives of cartoon king Julian, are throwing parties in the thicket of the jungle.

geography.en: Madagascar is divided into six major tourist regions: Antsiranana, Mahajanga, Antananarivo, Toamasina, Fianarantsoa, and Toliara. Each of them has its own unique ecosystem, but where should you start to explore the island?

long_description.en:
Antananarivo

Antananarivo is an unusual and long word, isn't it? The Malagasy people call their capital and main city Tana. The city rests on the high hills inside the island. From dawn to dusk, it is buzzing with dozens of bazaars, where some people try to bring down the price, and others try to sell at a higher price. The ensemble of the palaces of Royal Hill of Ambohimanga, the burial vaults of the Malagasy monarchs, the red walls of the Baroque Andafiavaratra Palace — all of them stand out frighteningly against the mud and poverty of the poor quarters. Lake Anosy is located at the heart of this heady mix. It was designed and artificially created by the English missionary James Cameron in the shape of a heart.

Toliara

Toliara grew among the desert with its thorny bushes in the cozy Bay of Saint-Augustin. It is a major port city in Madagascar. The 250-kilometer reef protects the city's coast from the dangers of the ocean and is also a mecca for diving and snorkeling enthusiasts. More than 200 species of coral, 760 species of fish, dolphins, turtles, tiger sharks, and ancient Latimeria — this underwater world is admirable. And when you see your fingertips wrinkling from a long stay in the water, go to the Reniala Private Reserve, where hundreds of species of birds will cheer you up — literally and figuratively.

Antsiranana

Antsiranana is a region in the north of the country, where hiking enthusiasts go to conquer the shaggy slopes of the mountains and the volcanic mountain range of Tsaratanana. Extreme adventures are waiting for travelers in Mahajanga area as well: narrow paths of the Tsingy de Bemaraha Reserve stone forest with peaks, sharp as a sword's blade, can take your breath away. Relax after active hiking through cool-down volcanoes and mangroves on the sandy beaches of Morondava, in the west of the island. The legendary Avenue of the Baobabs and Kirindy Forest, an ideal spot for observing lemurs, mongooses, and fossas, are all within easy reach.

Nosy Boraha

"Yo-ho-ho, and a bottle of rum!" - this is how pirates sang back in the XVII century, burying looted treasures on the island of Nosy Boraha (better known by its former name Île Sainte-Marie). It is unknown whether it is true or not, but no gold deposits have been found on the island so far. But the fact is that the tourists love Ile Saint-Marie very much for its white beaches, clean ocean, and palm trees that slope low above the shore. The Torre del Homenaje, Ozama fortress, the churches of Saint Nicholas and Saint Francis, Alcazar castle — the island's colonial architecture will surely appeal to curious minds. And the cherry on the cake will be the watching of humpback whales: they twirl a flip over the waters of the strait near the island every year from July to September.

Nosy Be

In the north-west of Madagascar, there is another paradise place, the island of Nosy Be. It has experienced much during its centuries-long history. It was a refuge for pirates and a living embodiment of a treasure chest; a prison and hard labor for French colonizers; a slave trade center; it even had a fleet of Russian General Rozhestvensky. Today Nosy Be smells of coffee and ylang-ylang. In the forests of Lokobe Strict Reserve, black lemurs are jumping from one tree to another. Cold streams of waterfalls lull the cooled volcano. In the town of Djamandjary, they pour the world-famous Dzama rum. The Omura's whale, the rarest species of these mammals, demonstrate their fountains near the coast. Besides, it offers excellent hotels, gorgeous beaches, the best quality of service Madagascar has, and you won't be able to resist the temptation to book your own ticket to Madagascar.

description.en: Mali is a Muslim country in West Africa, one of the poorest in the world. Here you can come across everything that goes with poverty — ignorance, dirt, and diseases. And yet, as nowhere else in this country, it has ancient traditions and everyday life. Sometimes it seems that time has frozen, and it is difficult to understand what century you are in. In small towns, there are huts without water supply and electricity, made of clay bricks (here it is the main building material). People still turn to shamans for advice and help. He cures, gives pieces of advice in matters of love, work, protects from evil spirits, and other troubles. It is an agricultural country where every year (in December), the biggest cattle overlanding festival in Diafarabe takes place. During it, shepherds return to their families after several months in the desert. It is particularly impressive for the country's folk traditions and customs.

Modern Morocco still remains one of the most exotic Arab countries. It looks like a living illustration of the "One Thousand and One Nights" fairy tales. Towers and palaces, narrow streets and colorful houses, serpent-charmers and water carriers, camel caravans wandering in sand dunes, the Atlas Mountains, and of course, the gentle Mediterranean Sea and the spectacular Atlantic Ocean. It is a country that captivates and mesmerizes, promising a real adventure.

geography.en: Morocco is an Islamic state located in the north-west of the African continent. The country is separated from Europe by the Strait of Gibraltar. In the south-east, Morocco borders with Algeria, and the southern borders are dissolved in the sands of the Sahara. A characteristic feature of Morocco is its diversity, including nature. There are two coastlines here — the Mediterranean one, with an abundance of rocks and caves, and the Atlantic, which is an endless beach almost 3000 kilometers long. It is a real paradise for fans of passive beach lounging, sea SPA, and active water recreation — diving, windsurfing, and kitesurfing. The center of Morocco is a group of mountains: the High Atlas and the Middle Atlas.As for the administrative division, the country's territory is divided into 12 regions, which in turn consist of provinces and prefectures.

long_description.en:
Rabat

The Roman port, a corsair base, and an Arab military outpost is modern Morocco's administrative capital, Rabat. It is still cherishing its history to this day. Its old part, Medina, seems to still live in the past. They still hand-weave carpets, knit lace, make clay pots, and produce copper dishes. Rabat pleases the eye of the tourist with unique exhibits of museums of antiquity and art, minarets of Hassan Tower, and the Kasbah of the Udayas with its blue streets. And on Fridays, you can watch the King's departure ceremony for namaz at the Royal Palace. You should also find time to visit the ruins of the ancient city of Salé, founded more than 1000 years ago by the Phoenicians. This city was the capital of the corsairs that kept all Europe in fear in the XVII and XVIII centuries. 

Marrakesh

Marrakesh is one of the oldest cities in the country and its former capital. The town is located at the foot of the Atlas Mountains. At dusk, Marrakesh's main square, Jemaa el-Fna, becomes a hub of fun. You can hear singing, jugglers, and dancers performing everywhere. Serpent and scorpion charmers strike the imagination of tourists. Acrobats and funny monkeys spin with puppets, and aromas coming from numerous fries can arouse the appetite of even the most sophisticated gourmet. Fortune-tellers and mysterious sorcerers add a mystical note to the atmosphere. Mornings in Marrakech begins with the voice of a muezzin standing on the tower of the beautiful Kutubiyya Mosque. You should definitely visit the Menara Gardens, the Bahia Palace, and the Mosque of the Booksellers.

Fes

Fes is the so-called religious capital of Morocco and the center of Islamic culture. It is the oldest city in the country, with an entangled labyrinth of ancient streets and a myriad of mosques. Fes has two medinas — Fes el-Jdid and Fes El Bali, surrounded by medieval walls and included to the UNESCO List of World Heritage Sites. The world's oldest University of al-Qarawiyyin lies in the heart of the city. Fes is also known for its madrasas. These are educational institutions, such as boarding schools, which operated until the middle of the last century. In addition, the so-called Chouara Tannery is very popular with tourists, where the leather is still processed in the same way as it was thousands of years ago. Here you can also buy clothes, souvenirs, and leather goods.

Casablanca

Casablanca stands for a "white house" from Spanish. It is the largest port, business, and industrial center of the country. Corporate offices, bank headquarters, the largest airport, and the giant Hassan II Mosque, where 25,000 believers can simultaneously pray. It is a real paradise for tourists. The town offers numerous beaches, clubs, restaurants, Habous Quarter with its abundance of stalls and boutiques. It seems that its buildings have descended from the pictures of advertising campaigns. However, we should disappoint you a little — the famous film Casablanca was not filmed here! 

Agadir

Agadir is a resort city. They say that it provides the country with half of all tourist income. The sun shines here 300 days a year, and elegant hotels seem to compete for the title of the best. Life always seems to be buzzing on the sandy beaches, with scuba diving, water skiing, yachting, and boat riding. It is also the most European city in Morocco. Women here practically do not wear a hijab. Of course, it's worth visiting the Bird Valley and Zoo and the local market that sells products made by skilled craftsmen. By the way, you have to bargain with them to get the best price.

Chefchaouen

Chefchaouen, by right, has the title of the most beautiful city in Morocco. It is known for the fact that the vast majority of buildings in it are entirely or partially painted blue. For several centuries, it had been forbidden for foreigners to visit Chefshauen on pain of death. Maybe that is why the city has retained its medieval appearance. It is said that even slaves were traded in the local markets until the 30s of the last century. Nowadays, you can easily buy marijuana in these markets. But it would be best if you did not do it, because the mere presence of it will be enough to spend from 3 months to 5 years in prison.

description.en: Namibia is a country in the south-west of Africa that is famous for its unique wildlife, hospitable climate, and excellent tourist services. A trip to Namibia is always an unforgettable adventure. For someone, it is exciting and extreme, and for others, it is mysterious and romantic. The country is often called "Africa for Beginners" because its main trump card is a combination of real continental flavor and European comfort. Here you can spend time in the company of wild animals, ride an SUV or sandboard on sand dunes, enjoy surreal landscapes, and listen to what the desert is silent about. Tourists from all over the world come here for extraordinary entertainment, hot sun, and a hurricane of emotion. Namibia is a land of endless possibilities, where you can expand your horizons and distract from the usual reality for a while.

geography.en: The Republic of Namibia is located in South Africa. It borders Angola and Zambia to the north, Botswana to the east, and South Africa to the south-east and south. The Atlantic Ocean washes the country from the west. Its area is 824.3 thousand km². Most of the country's territory is occupied by plateaus with average heights of 900 — 1500 m. To the east, it descends to the Kalahari Desert, and the west it breaks off to the Namib coastal desert, which is known for the world's highest dunes. Its highest point is Brandberg Mountain (2,606 m). Mountains surround it called the "Twelve Apostles". There are few rivers in Namibia, and most of them are filled only in certain periods. The largest of the rivers are the Orange and the Fish. In the north of the country, there is the largest in Africa saline Etosha pan. Its area is about 5 thousand km². Once every few years (during rainy periods), it is flooded with water, forming a lake up to 1.5 m deep.The Namibian state is divided into 13 regions, which, in turn, form 102 districts.

long_description.en:
Windhoek

Windhoek is the capital and largest city of Namibia, located almost in the heart of the country. Mountains and savannahs surround this fantastic region. There are many parks and private farms where tourists can watch the animals. The city is the starting point of many safari routes, and this is one of the most popular entertainments here. After enjoying the wildlife, you can go to the National Museum of Namibia, visit a meteorite exhibition on Post Street or go to the city market for souvenirs. The best way to relax is to go to the hot springs of Rehoboth or Gross Barmen, which are located half an hour from the city. Nightlife is also quite active here, with almost all the clubs and bars open until dawn. Chez Ntemba, Club Thriller, Tower Bar, and La Dee Da are particularly popular.

Swakopmund

Swakopmund is a popular resort on the coast of the Atlantic Ocean. This place is ideal for active and curious tourists. Here you can conquer the largest water slides in South Africa, make an airplane flight over the sand dunes, see dolphins and seals during a catamaran ride, or take a short trip to the Skeleton Coast. Major attractions include the Kristall Galerie, City Aquarium, Swakopmund Museum, and Woermann Tower, which offers beautiful views of the coast and desert. Fans of lazy holidays can sunbathe on Palm Beach and visit one of the restaurants in its vicinity.

Walvis Bay

Walvis Bay is the only port city in the country located on the west coast where the Namib desert meets the Atlantic Ocean. The city is famous for its vast flamingo habitat, and tourists have the opportunity to watch the birds in the natural environment. The huge flocks of flamingos in shallow water resemble glades of pink flowers, and this spectacle is breathtaking. In the vicinity of the desert, safari tours on jeeps and ATVs are offered for tourists, as well as fishing in the quiet bays of the Atlantic coast. After an active holiday, you can have a snack at one of the cozy cafes overlooking the ocean.

Kolmanskop

Kolmanskop is a ghost town sunk in the Namib desert. In 1908, a diamond deposit was found here, which attracted those who wanted to get rich. But during the First World War, prices for jewelry fell sharply, and diamond reserves gradually exhausted. After that, people started leaving the city, and in 1954 it became completely deserted. Today, tourists come here to visit local museums and organize a photoshoot. This place has become a popular location for directors. Dust Devil and The King Is Alive, as well as the series Life After People, were filmed here.

Etosha

Etosha is a national park located 410 km from Windhoek. It is the main reserve of the country, the name of which is translated as "Great White Place". It is home to about 114 species of rare mammals, 340 species of birds, 16 species of reptiles and amphibians, one species of fish, and many insects. There are two zones in the park for tourists: the eastern zone, where one can travel by car, and the western zone, where only special tourist cars are allowed to enter. The park has camps with shops, restaurants, petrol stations, and observation decks. Here you can easily meet zebras, antelopes, giraffes, and other animals at the watering hole, look into the Fairy Tale Forest, where the "inverted" tree of the moringa grows and take memorable pictures. This is one of the most popular destinations on the tourist route.

description.en: The Republic of Nigeria is located in West Africa. It has access to the Gulf of Guinea in the south and partly to the relict Lake Chad in the north. Tourists come here to relax on the stunning beaches of the Atlantic, travel through the reserves, and learn about the interesting customs and traditions of local residents. The plant world of Nigeria consists of tropical forests, savannahs, and hot semi-deserts, while the main attraction is the Niger River, which divides the country in half. During a safari, you can see much African wildlife — elephants, buffaloes, camels, monkeys, hippos, and crocodiles. Before traveling to Nigeria, you should definitely get the necessary vaccinations. Insects are carrying various diseases typical for Africa.

Unique natural attractions, perfect ecology, a stunning mix of cultures, and good tourist infrastructure make Tanzania very attractive to discover the African continent. A guest of the country can combine here several types of recreation — beaches, safari, sightseeing, sports. But ecotourism is especially popular. And not surprisingly, because the state has twelve large national parks and more than 40 reserves, wildlife preserves, and marine parks.

geography.en: Tanzania is the largest country in East Africa, located below the equator. In addition to the mainland, it includes the largest islands of the neighboring archipelago — Zanzibar and Pemba. They form an autonomous region. The state borders with eight neighbors: Uganda, Rwanda, Congo, Burundi, Zambia, Malawi, Mozambique, and Kenya. The Indian Ocean washes the eastern part of Tanzania. The area of the country is 945.1 thousand m². The territory off the coast is flat, but most of the state is located on the East African Plateau. Small groups of mountains rise in the southwest and northeast of Tanzania. Among the latter is the highest peak of the continent — Mount Kilimanjaro (5895 m).Three of the most important lakes in Africa are partially within or bordering the country. Lake Victoria is to the north (its Ukerewe Island is part of Tanzania). In the south, there is Lake Nyasa. In the west, Lake Tanganyika is the second-largest freshwater lake in the world. The major rivers of the state are the Ruaha, Kagera, Ruvuma, and Rufiji.Tanzania is divided into 26 regions (known as "mkoa" in Tanzanian). Of these, 21 are on the mainland, and five are on the islands of Zanzibar and Pemba. The regions, in turn, are divided into 98 districts (wilaya). These communities are managed through local government — councils. There are currently 114 of them.

long_description.en:
Dodoma

Dodoma has been the legal capital of Tanzania since 1973. The city is home to the Parliament of the country. There is a small airfield for domestic airplanes and a railway station. There are several interesting religious buildings in Dodoma — the Ismaili Mosque, Anglican Church, Catholic Cathedral, and the sacred Sikh temple. They are open to the public, and the latter even offers tea and sweets. The government buildings have beautiful and more modern architecture. But you can't take a picture in front of them; it's forbidden. In the city market, you can buy a lot of interesting knickknacks-souvenirs, spices from Zanzibar, and jewelry with precious stones. The capital of Tanzania is the only center of winemaking in the country. Therefore, the main souvenir from Dodoma is a bottle of wine of the same name made locally. A little to the south of the city is the Kizigo Game Reserve, where from July to mid-November, you can take part in hunting wild animals.

Dar es Salaam

Dar es Salaam is the historic capital, the administrative center, and the largest city in Tanzania. The majority of government institutions are still located here, along with international missions and embassies. In addition, the city, located on the Indian Ocean coast, serves as a major transportation hub. It is home to the largest seaport and international airport. The most popular architectural monument of the city is the ancient palace of Sultan Sayyid Majid (XIX century). There are also several religious buildings of the colonial era (St. Alban Anglican Church, St. Joseph's Cathedral, and the Greek Orthodox Cathedral), and beautiful administrative buildings of that period. On Mosque Street, you can see many mosques. The municipal beaches here are not clean but are suitable as locations for photoshoots. Swimming is better on the beaches of hotels, as well as travel to the suburbs (Mbesi and Kigamboni) or islands nearby (Mbudya and Bongoyo). 

Zanzibar

Zanzibar is the administrative center of the homonymous island and autonomous region. The oldest area of this city under UNESCO protection is Stone Town. It is a chaotic interweaving of narrow streets, a mixture of buildings of different styles and eras. But the region's infrastructure is surprisingly well-developed. Tourists will find souvenir shops, shopping malls, hotels, cafes and restaurants, medical facilities, and information points. There are several fascinating museums in the city, and the suburb is famous for its Mangapwani Slave Cave. A stroll to the port will allow you to admire the beautiful yachts and cruise ships. Tourists who are tired of sightseeing can relax in comfort in one of the wonderful beaches. The beautiful Jozani Chwaka Bay National Park is very close to the city (40 km), with daily excursions.

Mwanza

Mwanza is a city in northwestern Tanzania. Its symbol, Bismarck Rock on the shore of Lake Victoria, is easily recognizable with photos and postcards spread around the world. It is a pile-up of stones that protrude picturesquely from the water, and the uppermost of them — for many years — has been dangerously balancing on weight. The view of the rock is exceptionally beautiful during sunset. There is a lovely park on the shore to admire the sun. Popular attractions among tourists include boat trips and fishing on the lake. If you do not want to fish, you can buy it at the Mwaloni Market. Fruit and vegetables are also sold here. And at the Maasai Market (in the area of the pedestrian bridge), the tribesmen offer their customers traditional jewelry made of beads. A trip to Saanane Island National Park and a safari in Serengeti National Park will leave a lot of unforgettable impressions. 

Kigoma

Kigoma is a small town on the shore of Lake Tanganyika. From here, you can take a ferry to neighboring countries — Zambia, Congo, and Burundi. The natural sights of Kigoma include the Jacobsen or Mwamahunga beach. It is the best place to relax on the lake — with two small cozy bays surrounded by green hills, clear water, and orange sand. The beach looks absolutely idyllic and serves as a perfect background for photography. Next to the town, there are two national parks, Gombe Stream National Park and Mahale Mountains National Park. Tourists visit them to observe the life of chimpanzees, baboons, leopards, wild pigs, blue antelopes, and other animals in reserve.

description.en: Réunion is a picturesque island in the Indian Ocean, belonging to the French overseas territory. Fans of active and beach holidays choose it. These places are perfect for climbing, mountain biking, and hiking. Until 1500, the island had been uninhabited, and the beauty of pristine nature has been preserved here to this day. These are unique beaches with black volcanic sand, the magical beauty of waterfalls among tropical forests, lava fields, and formidable volcanoes. The active volcano of Piton de la Fournaise (2631 m) is considered to be the most important of them. It is located in the south-eastern part of the island and, according to scientists, has already celebrated 500,000 years of active life. Not far from it, the sleeping Piton des Neiges (3070 m) settled down. It is 8 million years old. If we talk about the interesting beaches of Reunion Island, they can be found at the resort of Saint-Gilles-les-Bains. There are many hotels, restaurants, and shops with sales.

São Tomé and Príncipe is an independent state located on islands in the Gulf of Guinea, in the heart of the Atlantic, near Africa. The name of the country (names of saints) was given by Portuguese navigators who discovered these places in the second half of the XV century. The islands are formed by a chain of extinct Cameroonian volcanoes and are an area of fascinating scenery. The peaks of São Tomé (2024 m) and Principe (948 m) are the highest points of the area. Climbing volcanoes, hiking in the rainforests, watching exotic birds and relaxing on deserted, clean beaches are the main features of the program for those who visit these delightful places. In addition to the two islands located approximately 150 km from each other, the state also includes at least six smaller islands.

Swaziland (known as the Kingdom of Eswatini since 2018) is a country in South Africa with picturesque and diverse nature. Here you will meet high mountains, the highest point of which is Emlembe (1862 m), flat plains, and tropical forests. These are very beautiful places of untouched civilization, with rich flora and fauna. The Hlane Royal National Park, where large mammals and rare birds live in natural conditions, as well as the Mlawula Nature Reserve with its many endemic plants and rare animals, is definitely worth visiting. Go to the village of Mantenga, an open-air museum, where you can see representatives of the country's native people, the Swazi. It hosts an event that is considered a landmark and attracts crowds of tourists from August to September. It is called Umhlanga. During the extraordinary three-day festival, tens of thousands of beauties claiming to be one of King Eswatini's new wives dance half-naked.

The Republic of Seychelles is located in the Indian Ocean, just south of the equator. The archipelago comprises a group of 115 islands, and 33 of them are inhabited. The resorts of Seychelles are famous for their beaches and the highest level of service. It is a real paradise for newlyweds as well as lovers of a beautiful life, exotic fruits, diving, and surfing. The magnificent coral atolls inhabited by colorful reef residents — fish, crabs, octopuses, and starfish — deserve special attention. But do not think that life in Seychelles is concentrated only near the ocean. There are nature reserves with colonies of seabirds and a luxurious UNESCO-listed park on Praslin Island. You can have a rest at the resorts of the archipelago in any season — the average temperature is constantly around the mark of +26 °С.

Senegal is a safe country in West Africa. It used to be a French colony. This has left its mark on the architecture, history. It also influenced the local cuisine, which is now considered to be the best on the continent. Tourists are attracted by the diversity that Senegal has to offer. Its small area seems to contain all of Africa. Civilization and ancient traditions coexist peacefully in this country. French enchantment and charm live alongside the African spirit of hidden tribes. And on its wide beaches, the number of hotels with European service is increasing every year.

geography.en: Senegal is in West Africa. It borders on Mauritania to the north, Guinea, and Guinea-Bissau to the south, Mali to the east, and the Atlantic Ocean to the west. The state of the Gambia is located inside Senegal. It stretches almost 300 km inland from the coast. The largest rivers are Senegal (in the name of which the state was named) and Casamance. They freely cross the savannahs and woodlands of the country.

long_description.en:
Dakar

Dakar is the capital and the largest port in Senegal. Although the city is big, it is very poor. Among its main attractions are the African Renaissance Monument (the highest statue in Africa) and the Grand Mosque of Dakar. It will be fascinating for tourists to see the battles of local fighters in the city's squares, before which they perform unusual ritual dances and ablutions. On the outskirts of Dakar, you can visit the pink Lake Retba. It amazes with its unique, saturated color. Another unusual place is Acro Baobab, the only rope park in the world organized on baobabs. Just 10 km from the capital is the resort-town of Les Almadies. Its rocky coastline attracts divers and snorkelers.

Saint Louis

It is the ancient capital of Senegal, located on a narrow island of the river of the same name. Here, Europeans once founded their first settlement. The city was quickly filled with rich Frenchmen, who competed in their wealth, building luxurious mansions. Now the historical center of Saint Louis is on the UNESCO World Heritage List. Just 20 km south of the former colonial capital is the beautiful Langue de Barbarie National Park with its graceful pink flamingos. And 60 km to the north is the world's third-largest ornithological park — the Djoudj National Bird Sanctuary. The old town is not only famous for its historical and natural attractions. Annually, in May, the city hosts a jazz festival — the largest on the continent. Fans of blues come here for their holiday in January and February.

Kaolack

Kaolack is the peanut capital, where monkey nut plantations are spread around the city. One of the sights worth noting is the most beautiful mosque in the country in Moroccan style (entrance is closed to non-Muslims). The Saloum Delta attracts tourists on the outskirts of the city. Everything there is covered with mangroves, and oysters grow in the saltwater, on the roots of trees. It should be noted that Kaolack is one of the dirtiest cities in Africa, so outbreaks of malaria, cholera, yellow fever, and even leprosy are regularly recorded here.

Ziguinchor

Ziguinchor is a city that still has the architecture to tell about its colonial past. And one of the best markets in Senegal and the Aboriginal villages in the surrounding area remind everyone that this is an authentic African city. From Ziguinchor, it is convenient to go on excursions to the southern parts of the country.

Cap Skirring

Cap Skirring is a famous resort in which beaches are considered to be the best in Africa. It is a beautiful place for tourists to go for relaxation on the shore of the ocean with azure water. There are indigenous villages around the town, where you can see their ritual dances and listen to the singing. On the border with Guinea-Bissau, there is the Lower Casamance National Park, where you can see wild African animals in their natural habitat.

Saly Portudal

Tourists have awarded Saly Portudal the well-deserved title of the best resort in Senegal. Its popularity is growing rapidly, and there is every reason for it — high-quality service in hotels, clean wide beaches, blue ocean waters, and postcard-like views around.

description.en: Sierra Leone is a country in West Africa. An uncommon name for these places on the Atlantic coast was given by the navigator Pedro de Sintra, who discovered them in the second half of the XV century. In Portuguese, it means "Lion Mountains." There are luxurious beaches and amazing reserves. The Gola Rainforest National Park is worth a visit. It is the largest in the country. You'll be surprised at the variety of flora and fauna here. Mamunta Mayosso Wildlife Sanctuary is also of interest. It preserves and breeds endangered dwarf crocodiles. Active recreation lovers should take a look at the Loma Mountains, where the highest point of the mountain system and the whole Sierra Leone is situated — Mount Bintumani (1945 m). This is an oasis of wildlife, where there is not a single house. In the capital, Freetown, make sure you visit the National Museum of Sierra Leone. Here you can learn a lot about the country's history and see unique exhibits found during archaeological excavations.

The Togolese Republic, together with neighbouring Ghana and Benin, is home to a mystical voodoo cult. They still practice bloody rituals with sacrifices and injuries, believe in magical amulets, and healing potions. There are large national parks in the country where elephants, monkeys, lions, hippos, and other animals live in their natural environment. In the south of the country, one can stroll along the Atlantic Ocean. And in the center of the state, you can communicate with people who live as their ancestors — without the benefits of civilization.

geography.en: The Togolese Republic is in the west of the African continent. It borders Burkina Faso to the north, Benin to the east, and Ghana to the west. To the south, it is washed by the Gulf of Guinea of the Atlantic Ocean. The relief of the Togolese Republic is quite diverse. It mainly consists of savannahs and plateaus. Diagonally, from the south-west to the north-east, the Togo Mountains run through the center. It reaches both Ghana and Benin. The highest point in the country is Mount Agou (986 m). The main rivers of the state are the Oti and the Mono, with their numerous inflows.The Togolese Republic is divided into five regions (Kara, Maritime, Plateau, Savanna, and Central). The regions, in turn, are divided into 30 prefectures and one commune.

long_description.en:
Lomé

It is the capital and the main port of the Togolese Republic. The main raw materials exported from here are coffee, cocoa, palm kernels, and phosphates. In Lomé, first of all, you should visit the Togo National Museum. There you can trace the history of the country's development and see an exhibition of folk musical instruments. The museum also includes the Botanic Garden and Zoo, where travelers can get acquainted with flora and fauna of the Togolese Republic. There is also a skansen, where a traditional village is located. To the west of the city center is the famous Akodessawa Fetish Market or Marche des Feticheurs, which is dedicated entirely to voodoo culture. Here you can find body parts and organs of animals, various herbs and potions as well as amulets.

Atakpame

This is a small town in the center of the Togolese Republic, where you can see how coffee, cocoa, cotton, millet, and yams are grown and harvested. Atakpame is the country's commercial center. Previously it housed the residences of German colonists.

Togoville

It's a town in the south of the country. This is the main center of the voodoo cult. Here, mystical shrines neighbor the royal palaces. The town offers the house-museum of King Mlapa III, a church with stained-glass windows depicting African saints and their tortures. Togoville also has a whole artisan district, where you can buy handicraft items made in the traditional style.

Sokode

It is the second-largest city in the Togolese Republic. Travelers will particularly appreciate its ancient colonial buildings. This is where the journey to the Fazao Malfakassa National Park begins. It is located in the Malfakassa mountains. You can watch birds and monkeys in the park. And from the top of the mountains, you can see elephants and lions living in the natural environment.

Aneho

The city had been the capital of the state until 1920. Here you can stroll through colonial quarters with ancient buildings. They've already lost their former gloss, but they still look dignified. Aneho lives like a seaside town. Like a few centuries ago, fishers go to the ocean every morning and come back with the surf. At night, the city is filled with the sounds of folk instruments and the screams of street merchants.

description.en: Sapphire-colored sea, velvet sandy beaches, delicious dates, opuntia, charming French boulevards, military forts, ancient medinas — Tunisia is rich in all of this. It is a beautiful, hospitable country with a long coastline, excellent modern hotels, and high-quality service. Here you can visit the Sahara Desert and the place of tourist pilgrimage — Matmata village. Its inhabitants are Troglodytes-Berbers, who live in caves. And it became widely known thanks to the "Star Wars" of George Lucas, which scenes were filmed here. Now, you can stay overnight at the underground hotel Sidi Driss where Luke Skywalker's home was shot and feel like a hero of the popular saga. Besides, Tunisia is known for the renowned ruins of ancient Carthage and unique mosaics of antiquity. Thalassotherapy is the pearl of a vacation in this country. A trip to Tunisia will give you not only the most positive emotions but also a beautiful tan.

geography.en: The Republic of Tunisia is the smallest country in North Africa. It is located on the Mediterranean coast, southwest of the island of Sicily and south of Sardinia. It neighbors with Algeria in the west and with Libya in the southeast. Much of Tunisia is occupied by the eastern spurs of the Atlas Mountains, the rest of the territory is covered with savannahs. Administratively, the country is divided into 24 provinces (Wilaya), which in turn are divided into 264 districts (mutamadiyat), and those consist of municipalities (baladiyats).

long_description.en:
The centuries-old history of Tunisia attracts lovers of not only beach holidays, but also ancient history. The ruins of one of the greatest cities of antiquity — Carthage, will tell you about the Empire of Phoenicia, which competed with the Roman Empire for influence in the Mediterranean Sea. That's where Julius Caesar stepped, the fate of many nations was decided, the world map was changed. Tunisia is a balanced combination of ancient history and excellent beach resorts. 

Tunis

An excellent starting point for exploring the country will be the capital of the state of Tunisia - its main trade, economic, industrial, and cultural center. In Tunis, modern mirrored-glass buildings are in harmony with the refined boulevards built by the French, and medieval Arab Medina, with all its bazaars, mosques, colorful shops, and port buildings. Tunis hides many interesting attractions such as the Tourbet el Bey, the palaces of Dar El Bey, Dar Hussein, with a collection of Islamic art, Dar Ben Abdallah, decorated with colored marble and paintings, the Bardo National Museum, with a collection of Roman mosaics. There are also plenty of charming coffee shops and restaurants in the city where you can eat, enjoy the local color, and drink tea with pine nuts.

Hammamet

Hammamet is a wonderful resort city within an hour's drive from the capital. Its famous white sandy beaches, azure water of the bay of the same name, and a pleasant atmosphere attract tourists. It is buried in greenery, and the most important principle of urban development in Hammamet is that the buildings do not exceed the height of the cypresses growing here. The city is divided into two parts: Yasmine-Hammamet and Hammamet Sud. The medina and the Ribat Fortress, towering along the coast, belong to Hammamet Sud, the old part of the city. Yasmine-Hammamet was built relatively not so long ago when it was decided to develop tourism in Tunisia actively. There are large hotel complexes, bars, nightclubs and discos, a casino, golf club, the largest Tunisian water park "Flipper", and the best thalassotherapy centers. Holidays in Hammamet are great for families with children as well as for lovers of active nightlife.

Sousse

The next most popular resort in Tunis is Sousse. It rises on a hill, on which small white houses are built. The resort has a water park, discos, and bars. Besides active entertainments, Sousse has sights reminding of its ancient history. The round tower-minaret of the XI century, Kasbah of Sousse, and Sousse Museum, where you can get acquainted with the history of the country depicted in mosaics, as well as see the remains of outstanding ancient empires: Phoenician tombs, Roman houses, Byzantine fortifications, and Christian catacombs. 

Monastir

The city of Monastir used to be the ancient religious capital of Tunisia, and today has become a respectable resort with magnificent beaches and azure sea surface. Unlike Hammamet and Sousse, it does not have such an active nightlife, it is a calmer and more measured resort, with modern restaurants and hotels. There is the Skanes resort area 6 km from the center, where you can play golf, take lessons at a horse riding school, or scuba dive in the diving center. The sights of the Monastir are the Fortress Ribat Hartem, the Mausoleum of the first President Habib Bourguiba with its four domes. The Museum of Islamic Art is also of great interest, with a rare collection of glassware from the Fatimid Dynasty, ancient manuscripts, and fabrics.

Mahdia

Mahdia is 45 km from Monastir. It is the southernmost resort in Tunisia (not taking into account the Island of Djerba) and the country's main fishing port. This city is situated on the site of an old Phoenician settlement and has survived various rulers, including Spaniards, Turks, and French. Mahdia is a peaceful resort with a measured rhythm of life, a great place to relax with children. It has everything for an enjoyable stay — cozy street cafes, shops with wonderful fabrics, a large park area, and a diving center.

description.en: South Africa is the type of country that you should visit at least once in your life. A trip here is a real adventure, memories of which will remain in your mind forever. South Africa is unique in a number of ways. Nature is the main treasure of this land. Mountains, deserts, waterfalls, caves, the best beaches on the planet, and primeval forests — everything can be found here. People come here to relax on the world's cleanest beaches, dive with sharks and swim with crocodiles, watch the desert dawn, and watch elephants play. Its depths are full of minerals that have made South Africa the wealthiest country on the continent. People still mine unique diamonds and gold here. It is also unusual in its ethnic composition — no other country has such a diversity of races and nationalities. There are over a dozen official languages, but they never prevent people from understanding each other.

geography.en: South Africa is located in the tropical and subtropical latitudes of the Southern Hemisphere and almost exclusively occupies the entire southern African continent. The Atlantic Ocean washes it in the west and the Indian Ocean in the east and south. The length of the country's coastline is 2,798 kilometers. The closest neighbors of the Republic of South Africa are Mozambique, Zimbabwe, Namibia, Botswana, and Swaziland. The country also has an enclave, the Kingdom of Lesotho. South Africa has different climatic zones, from desert to savannah and subtropics. The territory of the country is crossed by several large rivers — the Orange, Limpopo, Umgeni, and Tugela. Most of South Africa lies above 1000 m above sea level, while in the east, it rises to form the Mountains of Dragons, where the highest point of the country is Mount Njesuthi (3,410 m).South Africa has rich subsurface resources. The things its depth is hiding! — platinum, diamonds, gold, manganese, iron and uranium ores, coal. Thanks to this, South Africa has the most powerful economic potential on its continent.In terms of administrative structure, the country consists of nine provinces nowadays. These, in turn, are divided into districts — there are 52 of them in South Africa (44 rural and eight urban districts).

long_description.en:
Pretoria

Pretoria is the administrative capital of South Africa, combining magnificent architecture and an equally magnificent nature. It is decorated with picturesque residential and administrative buildings. Even the presidential residence here looks more like a fairy-tale palace. It seems that every block of the city has prepared a beautiful gift for the guests of Pretoria. Church Street, the longest street in the world, is waiting for you in the center. It is a landmark in its own right, with a length of 25 kilometers. While walking along Church Street, you should take a closer look at the St. Alban the Martyr Anglican Cathedral, Palace of Justice, Mint, old post office, buildings of several banks — each of these constructions is unique in its own way. There are a lot of beautiful monuments, sculptural groups, and fountains in the city, and you can wander in the squares, parks, and gardens all day long. The Botanical Garden and the Zoo with their unique collections of flora and fauna, respectively, deserve special attention. There are many exciting museums in Pretoria. Fort Klapperkop will tell you about the events of the Anglo-Boer War, the National Museum of Culture of South Africa will introduce you to the cultural heritage, Melrose House will surprise with magnificent paintings, carpets, and porcelain, and the building itself is a beautiful masterpiece of the Victorian era. Pretoria also has one of the largest observatories in the country. And the tour to the real diamond mine, located next to the city, where you can see how diamonds are mined and processed, will surprise and delight even the most sophisticated tourists. By the way, at the beginning of the last century, a huge stone was found here, the size of an adult fist.

Cape Town

Cape Town is the legislative capital and the second-largest city in South Africa, which rightly claims also to be the cultural capital. It is located at the Cape of Good Hope and is one of the most prestigious resorts in the world. A must-see route for any tourist arriving in Cape Town is the ascent to Table Mountain, which has long been a symbol of the city. Kirstenbosch botanic garden, which is situated at the foot of the mountain, will also give a lot of impressions and fabulous pictures. Other rightfully renowned attractions of Cape Town include the Castle of Good Hope ( the oldest building in South Africa), St. George's Cathedral, Houses of Parliament, real Turkish baths, mosques, Victorian buildings, mansions in the Old Dutch style. As for the natural curiosities, it is impossible not to visit the beach with a very "talking" name - "Boulders". In addition to unusual stone groups and sculptures, here you can swim and sunbathe in the company of penguins. In recent years, there is a whole colony of these extraordinary birds, about two thousand individuals. And off the coast of Cape Town is Robben Island, where one of the terrifying prisons in Africa, where Nelson Mandela, a man who defied the apartheid regime, spent almost three decades.

Bloemfontein

Bloemfontein is the judicial capital of South Africa, and this is where the country's Supreme Court is located. In translation, its name stands for the "City of Roses" or "Fountain of Flowers". It is one of the cleanest and most well-groomed cities in the country, and it's the local nature that attracts attention in the first place. Gardens, parks, and squares, nature reserves, and sanctuaries — all of them definitely deserve your attention. The exuberance of smells, flowers, and the total diversity simply can not leave anyone indifferent. The view of all this magnificence can be seen from Naval Hill. You can still find the picture of a giant white horse on its slope, depicted here during the Anglo-Boer War as a signpost for riders. The architectural constructions that deserve your attention include the church with two spires, the first parliament building, the Court of Appeal and the Supreme Court, and the old presidential residence.

Johannesburg

Johannesburg is the largest city in the country. It is often referred to as the financial capital because it is where the main monetary and industrial projects are concentrated. It's also the air gateway to South Africa. Locals simply call their city "Joburg" or "Johansburg", and also "Josie" and "Egoli". At the end of the last century, it deserved the dubious glory of the most criminal metropolis in the country. Still, in recent years, the situation has improved significantly, although, in some areas, tourists should keep away from it. By the way, unlike most cities, the center is the most problematic in this respect, and the district of Soweto has earned the palm of the criminal championship. However, adrenaline enthusiasts often come here on tours. Unfortunately, there are very few impressive historical buildings in Johannesburg, except for the early XX century colonial-style town hall and a few mansions. But it has the tallest skyscraper in Africa, the 50-story "Carlton". Its observation deck is always included in the program of local sightseeing. By the number and richness of collections of local museums, Johannesburg can also outpace many cities. It offers the Transport Museum, Military Museum, African Museum, Apartheid Museum, Art Museum. And there's also a zoo to visit.

Durban

Durban is the third-largest city in South Africa, a fashionable resort with luxurious promenades, luxurious hotels, and almost ideal beaches. Durban's Golden Mile (the one where Vasco da Gama docked) will amaze even the most demanding guest. And the picturesque colonial architecture deserves the attention of tourists. The Town Hall is considered to be the most beautiful building in the city. It is decorated with columns and porticoes, a huge dome, and a couple of smaller ones, intricate balustrades, and original interiors. St. Paul's Church still looks like a portal to old England. And there is also the largest Indian community in Durban, which also gives the city a unique flavor. It has the largest Hindu temple in Africa and the largest mosque in the Southern Hemisphere. You should definitely get out to the picturesque Valley of a Thousand Hills and visit the snake reserve and crocodile farm from Durban.

Port Elizabeth

Port Elizabeth is a city on the Pacific coast that can also fascinate tourists with its magnificent architecture. The whole Donkin Street has been preserved here since the colonial past, with unusual monuments and exciting museums. But first of all, Port Elizabeth is a resort. Its beaches, marked by the "blue flag" for the exceptional purity of the water and coastline, have only one drawback - they are often overcrowded. It is a real paradise for diving and surfing enthusiasts. There is also a unique oceanarium, which includes a snake park. The Addo Elephant National Park is also located not far from the city, where a huge population of elephants (over 500 individuals) lives today. A trip there will be a really unforgettable experience.

Kimberly

Kimberly is the "diamond" capital of the country. In the late XIX century, adventurers and explorers from all over the world rushed here as everyone here had a chance to get rich in an instant with the help of local diamond deposits. The first huts of the miners became the foundation of this city. The so-called "Big Hole", where more than 30 thousand people worked every day, who manually extracted more than 22.5 million tons of soil, was the main place of their work. Their efforts were rewarded with a "diamond" harvest with a total yield of 2,722 tons. In 1914, the "Big Hole" was flooded, and diamond mining stopped here. A memorial to diggers was erected in Kimberley to commemorate the people who died here. However, valuable stones are still being mined in the vicinity of the city, and the locals gladly allow numerous tourists to watch this process. In addition to the sparkle of diamonds, Kimberley is also interesting for its natural attractions. Nearby, you will find the National Park and Flamingo Island, which is home to a population of up to 60 thousand individuals.
